Do not be fooled by the triangles and female nudity on the album cover: San Francisco's Young Prisms have absolutely nothing to do with witch house or whatever. The contents in their cauldron: shadowy
column3: reverb-smothered guitar rock-- something that's never been in short supply
column4: sure
column5: but that doesn't diminish how well-timed the band's debut LP
column6: Friends For Now
column7: feels. In case your issue of Indie Rock Gossip ended up in your neighbor's mailbox last month
column8: the knotty Canadian indie rockers in Women spectacularly dismantled on stage at the tail end of 2010
column9: leaving a potential void for similarly styled up-and-comers to take their place while the band works their shit out.

column1: In a sense
column2: Young Prisms are perfect placeholders; they seem to favor complexity and confusion above all else
column3: and the notable moments of Friends For Now find the band utilizing those elements like able chemists. Not so fast
column4: though: It seems the band forgot that while you're making music
column5: it's a good idea to have some hooks. Instead
column6: the record's leaden; as a straight-through listen
column7: it plays like a monolith-- massive and somewhat uninteresting. Every once in a while
column8: an enjoyable part of the record's whole emerges from the murk-- the menacing Sonic Youth-y guitar line that emerges in the middle of ""Feel Fine""
column9: or the way that the submerged melody of ""In Your Room"" breathes like curtains near an open window. Otherwise
column10: the fact that this 36-minute record plays like it's twice as long means that something went wrong here.

column1: As with a lot of bands of late
column2: their vocalists
column3: Giovanni Betteo and Stefanie Hodapp
column4: are dragging them down. Just the fact that you need a Google search to tell that more than one person sings in Young Prisms is the reddest of red flags. Their personality-bereft voices take on a chameleonic quality in which
column5: when surrounded by the accompanying music
column6: they eventually become nothing at all. It's possible that the lack of inspiring melodies is a reason why there's no passion in their performances-- alternately
column7: as the maxim of ""Sugar"" states
column8: ""I'm still high/ I'm still alive."" With those extremely modest goals checked off the list
column9:
it's unclear if Young Prisms care much about accomplishing much else for the time being.

Lust and Contempt From the 1920s and 1930s|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dust-to-Digital']|2011-02-04 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:40.715218|"

It seems odd to pair the 1920s and 30s together
column3: as they could not be any more different
column4: at least in the public consciousness. The 20s roared decadently
column5: all Prohibition sneakiness
column6: flapper fervor
column7: and urbane jazz music. The 30s nursed the nation's wounds during the Great Depression
column8: producing hobo itinerancy and angry labor songs. Baby How Can It Be?
column9: compiled from the collection of John Heneghan (of Eden & John's East River String Band)
column10: largely ignores history and geography
column11: deriving its personality and power from the broadness of its organizing concepts-- which are really just excuses for making an engaging
column12: exciting mixtape. Heneghan and co-producer Steven Lance Ledbetter uncover the lasciviousness lurking beneath the decades' remembered propriety
column13: which means today the sexual code words in these songs are more unexpected and therefore more shocking than
column14: say
column15: the racial epithets.

column1: And yet
column2: musically Baby How Can It Be is so diverse and wide-ranging that these two decades come across as a period of intense innovation
column3: perhaps the busiest time for popular music in America. To some extent
column4: credit goes to Heneghan and Ledbetter
column5: who see no difference between genres and geography. Instead
column6: they treat rural and urban music
column7: as well as black and white music
column8: equally and let small-town blues pickers rub elbows with big-city jazz sophisticates. Baby How Can It Be plays as a travelogue: lingering in Louisiana to ogle some Creole chicks
column9: assimilating on the reservation to win a chief's daughter
column10: eyeballing the hula girls in Hawaii. Think Jay-Z's ""Girls Girls Girls""
column11: except with banjos and hot horn sections.

column1: The set gives each of the emotions in the subtitle-- Love
column2: Lust
column3: and Contempt-- its own separate disc
column4: which winkingly implies a narrative trajectory beginning with getting it on and arcing toward getting over it. The Love songs typically hint at some impending disaster-- read: marriage-- while the Lust songs display a strong devotion
column5: albeit one based on sex rather than romance. And Contempt is an especially intriguing word here
column6: covering a range of attitudes from Robert Hill's ""You Gonna Look Like a Monkey When You Get Old"" to the Callahan Brothers' high-lonesome ""I Want to Ask the Stars"". Rather than being depressive
column7: however
column8: the compilation crackles with sly wit and lusty energy.

column1: The musicians on Baby How Can It Be are innovators of innuendo
column2: and anyone who thinks the first half of the 20th century was a period of propriety and repression will be blushing beet red even before hearing Harry Roy & His Bat-Club Boys' 1931 romp ""Pussy"". There's an endless parade of double and sometimes single entendres throughout the collection
column3: especially on the Lust disc: a memorable yo-yo
column4: some wienies and buns
column5: a pan of shortnin' bread
column6: and Frankie ""Half-Pint"" Jaxon boasting on ""It's Heated""
column7: ""I can keep your boiler hot 'til the superintendent comes!"" The lovin' sounds freer and funner than anything the 1960s had to offer.

column1: Baby How Can It Be proves just as spirited when the singers are down in the dumps. Laura Smith opens Disc Three with the gleefully depressive ""I'm Gonna Kill Myself""
column2: in which she enumerates the many ways she plans to do it: ""I wanna die die die till I die."" These songs brim with playful humor even in the face of remorse and despair. Even when offering a lascivious wink
column3: they're never being simply lewd
column4: thanks to the producers' careful sequencing and to the artists' happy revelation that pop music can convey all their desires and frustrations. Or
column5: as the unnamed female singer on ""Banjo"" Ikey Robinson and His Bull Fiddle Band's ""My Four Reasons"" so eloquently puts it
column6:
""Everybody get filthy!""

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16143/homepage_large.2369e64c.jpg|Rolling Blackouts|1835.0|The Go! Team|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Memphis Industries']|2011-02-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:41.226698|"

You have to wonder if Ian Parton ever regrets naming his recording project/collective the Go! Team
column2: let alone affixing it with an exclamation point for guaranteed bonus exuberance. Few bands have gone to such great lengths to forge a connection between their name and their sound. Since its inception
column3: the group has reconstructed sounds that are all about inspiring motion-- cheerlander chants
column4: rollerskate jams
column5: breakdance beats
column6: cop-show chase themes
column7: 90s mosh-pit rock-- into a brass-blasted wall of squall. But the side effect of constant movement is fatigue-- in this case
column8: on the band itself
column9: which charged through its 2007 sophomore release Proof of Youth with the same gusto heard on its dazzingly 2004 debut
column10: <i><a href=""http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/3654-thunder-lightning-strike/"" target=""_blank"">Thunder
column11: Lightning
column12: Strike. Compounding the exhaustion on Proof of Youth is Parton's unwavering deference for high-pitch-frequency productions that sound like they're blaring out of an old Zenith
column13: tenuously walking the line between ingratiating and just plain grating.

column1: From the outset
column2: Rolling Blackouts provides little relief: opener ""T.O.R.N.A.D.O"" announces itself with all the subtlety of an air-raid siren
column3: as lead MC Ninja wages a losing battle against a torrential blitzkrieg of horn breaks and scratch effects. The song essentially serves the same function as the opening themes to the 80s action shows Parton was raised on: it's the Go! Team advertising itself
column4: an instant reacquainting device to remind you of what you're tuning into. But thankfully
column5: Parton proves much more willing to change up the script. His cut-and-paste aesthetic is still very much in effect; he just uses it to assemble more varied and satisfying songs.

column1: There's always been a latent appreciation of 60s girl-group pop buried beneath the Go! Team's hyper-funk ballast
column2: and that quality is given more time and space to shine here
column3: whether in the Motown-by-way-of-Tokyo sweep of ""Secretary Song"" or the ""Ready Steady Go!""-worthy ""Ready to Go Steady"". Most successful of all is the band's wonderful collaboration with Best Coast's Bethany Cosatino on the fuzz-pop delight ""Buy Nothing Day"". But even the typical jump-rope exercises (""Apollo Throwdown""
column4: ""The Running Range"") are leavened by acoustic-based sonics and congenially melodic choruses. Meanwhile
column5: Parton's sound world now absorbs everything from endearingly schmaltzy soap-opera soundtracks (""Yosemite Theme"") to Yo La Tengo-style dream-pop reveries (the title track). Of course
column6: ""Back Like 8 Track"" closes the album by returning to the group's familiar schoolyard terrain. Hopefully
column7:
Rolling Blackouts marks the moment in the Go! Team's career where the idea of moving forward becomes less of a literal concept and more an artistic one.

Young the Giant recall any number of fourth-tier alt-rock bands from the early 2000s-- groups like Audiovent
column3: Injected
column4: and Tantric
column5: who served as grout between the latest Linkin Park and White Stripes singles
column6: every bit as functional and anonymous as their names suggested. Young the Giant not only sound like these bands to a certain extent
column7: but their self-titled debut fits this mold philosophically as well. In recent years indie rock has been increasingly appealing to commercial interests
column8: yet it's hardly seemed to be growing out of an assembly line in the machine room of the Big Music Industry. But this is ""corporate indie."" You almost hope Young the Giant acquiesced to some music executives' request to compromise their style
column9: because nothing else sufficiently explains a debut so devoid of personality.

column1: A quintet of Persian
column2: Indian
column3: British
column4: and French Canadian members descent hailing from Newport Beach
column5: Calif.
column6: they're signed to Roadrunner Records
column7: which is presumably still eating off the back catalogs of Slipknot and Nickelback. But their debut LP exists on a singular plane
column8: in that it's pretty much indescribable. I don't mean in the sense that it has no artistic precedent-- think any form of rock that was called ""alternative"" despite being completely uninformed by punk
column9: electronic music
column10: or anything actually ""alternative."" Rather it seems the album's intent is to make no impression whatsoever on the listener: ambient music performed like rock
column11: except nowhere near as interesting as that sounds in theory.

column1: Vagueness pervades the album; politely distorted guitars twist and churn but never turn into riffs. Choruses become placeholders instead of hooks. Sameer Gadhia's vocals
column2: often recalling Chris Martin's trembling midrange
column3: deliver prosaic lyrics that are neither plainspoken enough to reveal simple truths nor evocative enough to scan as poetry-- there are passing references to general bummed-ness (""Apartment"")
column4: addiction (the rank Cold War Kids karaoke of ""My Body"")
column5: and prostitutes (the cutely named ""St. Walker"")
column6: but nothing specific enough to prevent them from also selling deodorant.

column1: This sort of purposefully blank approach means that the few songs boasting any sort of frill stand out by default
column2: whether it's the perfunctory slide guitar of ""St. Walker"" or the sleepwalking harmonies of ""I Got"". But just to hammer home the indistinctness of it all
column3: after its relatively dry start
column4: Young the Giant take a mid-album reverb bath and dial up the distant
column5: delayed guitar leads and tentative tom beats
column6: once again proving that U2 is still the most influential band of all time for those artists who can't think of other ways to conjure atmosphere.

column1: Remember when Candlebox was described by Madonna as ""our grunge band"" after they signed with Maverick? It's easy enough to make fun of Candlebox
column2: but what that line represented was the point where ""grunge"" was something all labels felt they needed to ""have
column3: even with only a vague idea of what that actually was. You get the idea of something similar here
column4:
a clumsy attempt to siphon indie rock's sound and relative commercial momentum with none of its spirit.

Morgan Kibby first came to our attention when Anthony Gonzalez drafted her from MySpace to sing on M83's album Saturdays=Youth
column2: a new-wave revival that might as well have been called Cocteau Twins=John Hughes. The blissful retro-homage carries over on her solo project
column3: White Sea. This Frontier opens (on ""Mountaineer"") with Kibby's layered voice intoning
column4: ""It's a teen dream
column5: over a mountainous synthesizer and a cascade of electronic drum pads. It's familiar territory here in teen-fixated 2011
column6: when
column7: even as 90s mania is in full swing
column8: we just can't shed the 80s. Lighthearted and well-built
column9: the EP captures Kibby in transition
column10: between emerging under the wing of a bulletproof band and defining her own style
column11: which already lurks amid all the glossy nostalgia. It's a roundly enjoyable if embryonic electro-pop debut.

column1: Kibby favors more svelte
column2: less majestic productions than M83
column3: and set free from the anesthetic coo Gonzalez required of her
column4: it turns out that she can seriously sing. Her approachable and earnest delivery can occasionally tip toward cheesiness
column5: though it's mostly winning
column6: and Kibby sculpts it a little differently on each song. Her singing can be floridly enunciated like Imogen Heap
column7: sweetly petulant like Tegan & Sara
column8: or breezily swinging like Metric's Emily Haines. It's matched by a diversity of productions
column9: from the politely sleazy night-disco of ""Ladykiller"" to the frosty pseudo-Italo of ""Cannibal Love"". The dilettantism isn't a problem
column10: but the topicality feels generic
column11: and the bottlenecking reference points don't give us a clear picture of what makes Kibby unique. The best track
column12: ""Overdrawn""
column13: emphasizes her greatest asset-- the mobility and naturalness of her voice-- against a clean
column14: speedy backdrop of bassy synth stabs and buoyant claps. It's more convincing than the Chromatics-style iciness she affects on ""Cannibal Love"" or the Fever Ray-ish abstraction of ""Oljato"".

column1: If This Frontier feels like a dance-pop starter kit
column2: that's essentially what it is. Kibby did have a little help: Jonathan Leahy provided disco bass lines and preppy post-punk guitars
column3: Jonathan Bates did some mixing
column4: and Ray Suen wrote string arrangements. But mostly it's the product of her teaching herself Pro Tools after finishing her big tour with M83. For such a new producer
column5: she has a sharp ear and a direct style. Her classically inclined tracks are a dynamic fit for her voice
column6: and they benefit from her smart
column7: sparing use of cut-up vocal rhythms
column8: splashy drum accents
column9: and cinematic texturing. It suggests that lighter and more concrete formats
column10: rather than darker and more abstract ones
column11: fit Kibby most productively. Now that she's learned to make a solo album that shows us what she likes
column12: she's primed to dig a little deeper next time
column13:
and show us something of who she is.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16159/homepage_large.e061ad6c.jpg|Wuppdeckmischmampflow|23762.0|Robag Wruhme|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kompakt']|2011-02-03 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:42.374510|"

Though the label was initially and famously born around a signature sound
column2: Kompakt has slowly diversified over the past 10 years
column3: more thanks to a creative restlessness shared by its founders than a desire remain commercially viable in the trend-fixated world of techno. Ten years ago it would have been unthinkable for a Kompakt mix to open with something as traditional as the minimal deep house of Guillaume & the Coutu Dumonts' ""Odyssee""
column4: as Robag Wruhme does on Wuppdeckmischmampflow. Its stripped-down
column5: jazz-tinged boogie just wasn't within Kompakt's purview
column6: which favored atmosphere over funk. But if the choice doesn't feel like a total curveball in 2011
column7: it's in part because Kompakt's sound has become so wide-ranging that its output seems more defined by mood than any specific production tricks or any subgenre's identifying marks.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: the label's name will likely always evoke the lush and moody tech-house and fluffier-than-fluffy ambient it made famous between 1998 and 2002. Those spacious
column3: soft-edged sonics and that inimitable late-night vibe certainly persist on Robag Wruhme's new mix CD
column4: which features plenty of muffled melodies lurking behind static-y textures
column5: synths twinkling against dark bass
column6: and intricately layered
column7: gently flowing beats. But as catholic a selector as any DJ ever tasked by Kompakt to make a mix
column8: Wruhme includes classics Villalobos' ""Dexter""
column9: regardless of how ""dated"" they might feel to some
column10: alongside up-to-the-minute dancefloor cuts and left-field electronica moves from artists like Four Tet
column11: choosing records that chase the same atmosphere rather than what a techno DJ ""should"" be playing in 2011.

column1: It's also often plain gorgeous
column2: the kind of richly detailed home-listening techno that Kompakt's mixes have always promised
column3: albeit taking a new form. While many Kompakt mixes have used smooth extended fades to bridge the gaps between disparate-sounding tracks
column4: here Wruhme makes use of virtuoso in-the-moment sampling
column5: hypnotic snippets of voice
column6: or jittery percussion fills to blend his often wildly diverse selections into a unified whole. That patchwork feel
column7: a lot of tiny elements being smoothly edited together
column8: extends to the tracks themselves
column9: many of which feature rhythm tracks far more antic and poly-percussive than the sleekly gliding pulse Euro-techno Kompakt made famous. Some of the stuttering transitions--like chunky syncopation that leads into Moderat's ""Rusty Nails""-- are downright garage-y
column10: not a genre ever associated with the label before. Others recall a thicker
column11: more voluptuous and sensual take on old-school micro-house.

column1: Idiosyncratic in their choices yet never less than artfully constructed
column2: Kompakt's mixes have always felt more like first-rate mixtapes
column3: of the sort made by one friend for another
column4: rather than an advertisement for the season's latest club smashes. If Wuppdeckmischmampflow
column5: with its nearly decade-old inclusions and tracks taken from outside techno's well-patrolled borders
column6: won't please those looking for dance's next-big-things from their mixes
column7: it's never less than evocative and involving
column8:
which are the only two guidelines that count when you take a DJ set out of the club.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16154/homepage_large.b6c9bf3c.jpg|Stars Have Shapes|5080.0|Exploding Star Orchestra|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Delmark']|2011-02-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:43.069599|"

For the last two decades
column2: Chicago's music scene has been one of the most unique in the U.S.
column3: not so much for the music it's produced as for the way the city's various scenes are integrated. In Chicago
column4: the lines between the experimental electronic scene
column5: jazz scene
column6: and rock scene aren't just blurred-- they're practically invisible. The free movement of ideas and musicians between these worlds ideally wouldn't be so rare
column7: but I can't think of another city where jazz and rock musicians have so much currency with each other and play so often in each other's bands and ensembles.

column1: Rob Mazurek has long been one of the key musicians keeping the scene integrated. His projects
column2: including Brokeback
column3: Isotope 217
column4: Tortoise
column5: his own solo albums
column6: and Exploding Star Orchestra
column7: are aggressive about keeping the assumed lines between genres there from solidifying. Exploding Star Orchestra is a six-year-old project led by the trumpeter and cornetist
column8: who now makes his full-time home in São Paulo
column9: Brazil
column10: but is still very much a part of the scene he made his name in. ESO began as a sort of all-star jazz band organized for a concert in Chicago's Millennium Park but eventually became a recording project that made one album of its own and another with the late
column11: great Bill Dixon
column12: to whom this new LP is dedicated. A second dedication is made to the late saxophonist Fred Anderson
column13: who also was an associate of ESO.

column1: Stars Have Shapes is therefore an appropriately contemplative record
column2: and very much a Mazurek project in the way it brings together strains of cool jazz with free jazz
column3: ambient electronics
column4: and musique concrète into a seamless whole. The sounds of insects
column5: rain
column6: and bicycles are used as accent textures
column7: and Mazurek has his way with tone generators and effects pedals as well
column8: setting a surreal backdrop for the group's improvisations. The album is structured as two long tracks
column9: each followed by a short
column10: more traditional one. The sprawling opener
column11: ""Ascension Ghosts Impression No. 2""
column12: is a stitched-together opus in the Bitches Brew tradition
column13: beginning with thick drones and working its way through squawking free jazz
column14: yet at its center is a gorgeous
column15: fleeting passage of slow
column16: swinging cool jazz that gives the piece a human heart. The other sprawler
column17: ""Three Blocks of Light""
column18: expends more energy on textural playing among the horns and has the effect of being alone in a room full of people engaged in conversation-- chatter everywhere
column19: but nothing directed at you. It eventually resolves to a luminous drone.

column1: The two shorter pieces are far more focused and melodic than their titanic counterparts and are overall the most satisfying tracks on the record. Here
column2: the 13-piece band plays more developed compositions with greater rhythmic drive-- Jason Adasiewicz's clouds of vibraphone provide a sort of through-line to the more ambient pieces. Just as importantly
column3: the short pieces help the album feel balanced by pulling the band back from the margins and anchoring it to its roots. ESO is the type of project that could only really come from its city
column4:
and Stars Have Shapes finds the group ably carrying forward the unique modern Chicago jazz aesthetic.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16108/homepage_large.ffa90937.jpg|Tryptych|29335.0|Demdike Stare|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Modern Love']|2011-02-02 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:43.636337|"

Demdike Stare is a collaboration between a techno DJ/producer and a dedicated crate-digger for Finders Keepers
column2: one of those boutiquey Euro labels that issues albums of Czech cult-horror soundtracks and Persian funk under gonzo banners like ""20 vintage slices of Cymraeg Soft Psych and Welsh Kosmic Pop."" The particular digger in question
column3: Sean Canty
column4: was once referred to by Fact magazine as one of Manchester's ""best-known record collectors
column5: which is illustrative of the company we're in: People who not only rate records
column6: but rate their collectors. Canty's partner
column7: Miles Whittaker
column8: has been been an associate of Manchester's Modern Love records for nearly 10 years
column9: primarily  sticking around the kind of eerie
column10: minimal techno that production groups like Basic Channel developed in the 1990s. Basically
column11: Canty and  Whittaker are lifers in communities where darkness and obscurity are  tools
column12: not handicaps.

column1: Demdike Stare is primarily a sample-based project
column2: and ""dark"" is its organizing principle. Their logo is a skull
column3: rose
column4: and triangle; the cover of one of their EPs  is a visual riff on a Ouija board; and they're named after a 17th-century witch-- a quasi-gothic
column5: English variation on the sci-fi and horror imagery that has saturated the American underground over the past couple of years. The tracks on Tryptych are droning and nightmarish: lots of close murmuring and distant wind
column6: lots of groaning earth and quietly  whining steam-powered machines
column7: glassy techno keyboards and the buried  wailing of undefined tribes. But like some drone (and most minimal techno) there's usually a build  or a climax
column8: and one of the most consistently satisfy

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>

ing things about listening to Tryptych is that it takes music you might expect to be purely ambient and shapes it into something with a hump somewhere in the middle-- something with a narrative to it.

Canty and Whittaker also manage to give their atmospheres rhythmic inertia and shape their beats in ways that make them sound like they're emerging from the track's atmosphere. I'm guessing this comes from Whittaker's time in the world of minimal techno
column2: where the sound of static can pass for a backing track when edited and looped just right. Tryptych's collapsing of background and foreground is a holistic approach that makes their unexpected connections-- between the black ambience of Nurse With Wound
column3: Middle Eastern chant
column4: and minimal techno-- sound seamless and logical. The result is a style part-techno
column5: part-drone
column6: part-noise
column7: sometimes European-sounding
column8: sometimes  ambiguously ""ethnic
column9: part-heavenly
column10: part-hellish-- a kind of map to a musical otherworld.

column1: Demdike Stare's influences are well integrated and their commitment to them feels enduring
column2: and after the  deluge of half-kitschy
column3: self-parodying indie-goth bands last year (GL▲SS †33†H  was when I got off the bus)
column4: the commitment is refreshing. Tryptich is sample-based but doesn't just suss out some particular cultural moment and heap static on top of it
column5: it reaches for a moment-- a confluence of sounds-- that never actually happened. In a blog post on what he called ""the new doom
column6: Pitchfork contributor Philip  Sherburne wrote that ""Demdike Stare are even more deserving of the  'witch house' tag [than Salem]
column7: given that they're named for an actual  witch and have a deeper connection to actual house music."" True
column8: but I have no temptation to belittle Demdike Stare with the term.

column1: Tryptych collects the three EPs they released in 2010 and adds 40 minutes of bonus material to them
column2: which ostensibly leaves you with  an album that's about two and a half hours long. Two and a half hours is  a long time. I'd be lying if I said I had the patience to give it my  full attention from start to finish
column3: but the caveat is that I think  it's best enjoyed either in small listens or in a kind of absent-minded  immersion. It's the kind of thing you can keep turned on but tuned-out-- for bad dreams
column4: adventures into chemical hinterlands
column5: night drives
column6: and so on.

column1: Canty and Whittaker are impressively capable in that respect: they know exactly what will and won't belong in their creepy little mood-worlds
column2: and as a result
column3: Tryptych rarely calls attention to itself. I tried playing it while I slept a few times
column4: and  woke up in the middle of the night with a real <i>oh god
column5: what's going on and how can I make it stop feeling
column6: which in this context is an absolute plus. I in fact recommend that you listen to Tryptych at night-- thematically
column7:
it's where the album lives and where it thrives.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16152/homepage_large.18f90adc.jpg|Superlongevity 5|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Perlon']|2011-02-02 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:44.389475|"

The Berlin-based Perlon label is one of the titans of the last decade of electronic music
column2: but if their name doesn't ring out like Kompakt or Warp (or Hyperdub)
column3: it's mostly because they don't want it to. The label has a strictly-for-aficionados air about it
column4: not least because their idea of how to present a big release constitutes ""releasing a CD version"" (the label's wares are often vinyl-only and they mostly stay away from digital). As of this writing
column5: the label's website is still a giant Flash animation alerting you that Perlon.com is ""Opening Imminently."" Breath: bated.

column1: Perlon's Superlongevity series has served as a clearinghouse for the label in the past
column2: often collecting bushels of their 12""-only singles. The middle volumes can stand tall next to Kompakt's Total 3 and Total 4 as essential documents of 2000s techno-- specifically minimal
column3: the hypnotic
column4: spare house offshoot that dominated DJ decks and established Germany as the center of the electronic music world. Perlon's relative obscurity is due partly as well to prolonged silences from some of its bigger artists: Ricardo Villalobos
column5: Melchior Productions
column6: and STL have all quieted down or moved their releases elsewhere. (Shackleton's Three EPs was the label's last release to gain any traction outside dance circles.) So Superlongevity 5 represents a pretty substantial release for the label
column7: not just because it revives a dormant brand name
column8: but because it offers new music from the artists above as well as from standbys like Baby Ford
column9: Kalabrese
column10: and Shackleton.

column1: Keeping to form
column2: Superlongevity 5 is offered as a mix of new or unreleased material spread across two CDs (a limited seven-record vinyl box set was also made available). As a mix
column3: it differs substantially from a stone-skipping DJ set: the tracks are presented in large chunks
column4: usually between five and six minutes
column5: which not only gives each track plenty of room to breathe and develop but also obviates the need to hear ""full"" versions for all but the compulsive. Always the slightly sillier cousin to the starker Kompakt
column6: Perlon has only gotten wilier since their heyday. Superlongevity 5 is bursting with weird mantras (""Just being tape!"" from Matt John's ""The Tapedeckers"")
column7: tropical horns (Kalabrese's ""The 2010 Kitchen Session"")
column8: and rubbery rhythms (everything
column9: really). Dandy Jack's lounge disco ""Show You My Tent"" actually chuckles at itself throughout (or at me?). San Proper's ""Lady Cop"" is a funky noir that features samples of dialogue from ""The Wire""'s beloved Kima Greggs.

column1: Coming for the headliners-- Villalobos
column2: Shackleton
column3: and Melchior arguably have the most cachet here-- is a mistake. Superlongevity 5 is a place where everyone wilds out; at times it feels like a group of goofball college buddies meeting up years later. Matthew Dear takes his Jabberjaw moniker out of mothballs; ""Pop Bottle"" features sampled baby nonsense and someone shouting ""I need help!"" Label co-founder Zip teams with Sammy Dee on their Pantytec project and offer the detuned
column4: jazzy ""Zwölvis"".

column1: Nothing here settles too heavily. Zip mixes an imposing 28 tracks of carbonated oddities into two hours of vibrant techno. When it's through
column2: it's hard not to compare Perlon's stubborn vinyl adherence and low visibility to the colorful
column3: clever music of its artists. But this is the context in which Perlon has always thrived: mixed among friends and peers. It's techno music for techno fans
column4:
but it never makes the mistake of being too serious or exclusive.

column3: one might understandably classify Australia's My Disco as a post-punk band.  Never mind that the first track off their first stateside release (third overall) is titled ""Closer""
column4: and disregard the fact that they've recorded with Steve Albini
column5: or that the group named itself after a Big Black song.  The guitar and drums in ""Closer"" are aggressive and rhythmically focused
column6: recalling the usual cast of post-punk characters: Wire
column7: Gang of Four
column8: the Fall.  The sort of cathartic punch one might also associate with these groups
column9: however
column10: isn't there; it's not something the song is necessarily lacking
column11: but its absence is nonetheless notable.

column1: At first
column2: track two
column3: ""Young""
column4: follows the same tack.  It works up a similar head of steam
column5: but without the sort of tension and release one might expect.  Around the three-minute mark
column6: the more boisterous
column7: guitar-driven song the group seemed to be playing turns out to be a feint.  Instead the rhythm section settles into a calmer version of the track's original beat and rides it out for the next five minutes.  The drummer adds a few rolls and flourishes over this extended outro
column8: but otherwise ""Young"" contentedly sits in this little pocket until the track end. It's those meditative five minutes that exemplify what My Disco offer on Little Joy; not so much post-punk as post-rock (with a krautrock bent).

column1: No doubt My Disco's particular formula-- to settle into a repetitive groove and ride it steadily for the length of the song-- might strike some as simply formulaic. How a song begins is
column2: for the most part
column3: how it ends. ""With Age""-- its sharp staccato guitar strums giving way to brief but powerful splashes of amplifier excess-- helps to add some contrast. That said
column4: there's a hypnotic allure to Little Joy and the way most of its songs content themselves with simply staying the course. Those steady rhythms are definitely soothing
column5: especially when coupled with Liam Andrews' sporadic
column6: minimal mantras.  And when something out of the ordinary appears
column7: like the aforementioned flare-ups in ""With Age"" or the fragmented introduction to ""Sun Bear""
column8: its presence carries much more impact than it would otherwise.  Those out-of-character moments are few and far between
column9:
but listeners willing to roll with the lack of punch Little Joy offers will find that shortcoming easy to live with.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16160/homepage_large.c5e096ed.jpg|Party Store|1194.0|The Dirtbombs|['Rock'
column3: Detroit's Dirtbombs have about everything you could want: a magnetic frontman
column4: a famously frantic live show
column5: a handful of songs catchy enough to show up in TV commercials. But Mick Collins has never been content to run his band as just a garage-punk band. Instead
column6: he follows his batshit conceptual tangents wherever they might lead him. Ten years ago
column7: the band released Ultraglide in Black
column8: a collection of covers of classic soul and funk tracks. And even though it's a ballsy move to translate songs by Curtis Mayfield and Marvin Gaye into simplistic stomp-rock bangers
column9: those songs at least shared some structural similarities with the punk songs that the band had already been playing. On the new Party Store
column10: the band leaps even further into uncharted territory
column11: turning in a full hour of classic Detroit techno covers.

column1: Collins' love of techno runs deep. Detroit
column2: of course
column3: has served as a breeding ground for plenty of disparate genres of music
column4: and garage rock and ancestral techno belong to the city the same way transcendent pop-soul and melanin-challenged battle-rap do. Collins himself has been a techno devotee for a long time
column5: and he even made a few techno tracks himself early on. The song selection on Party Store is the work of a true aficionado; canonical classics like ""Strings of Life"" and ""Bug in the Bass Bin"" share space with some truly early electro examples of the form
column6: like Cybotron's ""Cosmic Cars"". But there's still something jarring in hearing a band known for sweaty
column7: loose workouts take on a genre of music where precision and repetition and icy control are paramount.

column1: That's the point
column2: of course
column3: and the album gets a lot of mileage out of the way techno synth-riffs work just fine as punk rock guitar riffs if you play them with the right scratchy intensity. The Dirtbombs have a strong enough rhythm section that the tracks rarely defeat them
column4: and it's fun hearing Collins pitch his wail down to a robotic monotone delivery. Plenty of these old techno tracks are totally silly fun on some level
column5: and Collins knows it. So he delivers the lyrics straight (""Smoking on his cigarette/ Cruising to his car cassette
column6: ""Laser beams cloud your dreams"")
column7: without any sort of wink.

column1: The whole ridiculous idea reaches its highest state on the band's version of ""Good Life""
column2: an immortal track from Kevin Saunderson's Inner City. (For whatever reason
column3: the band covers the Basement Roots mix rather than the canonical one.) This is a song with actual singing on it
column4: so Collins gets a chance to cut loose vocally
column5: doing a pretty good subdued version of house-diva histrionics. Around him
column6: the band attacks the beat with the same skritchety lunacy that James Chance once applied to James Brown grooves. The end result transcends the silliness of the concept and turns into something that Flipper would've been proud of.

column1: But as fun as the album is
column2: there's a big problem sitting right at its center: a 21-minute take on ""Bug in the Bass Bin""
column3: the evolutionary leftfield track from Carl Craig's Innerzone Orchestra. Craig himself shows up on the Dirtbombs' version
column4: playing some awesomely trashy keyboards
column5: but the song is still an endless marathon of splintered
column6: discordant guitars that takes up more than a third of an album that's a party otherwise. You can hear Collins straining for ""Maggot Brain"" expressionism
column7: but you need a genius guitarist like Funkadelic's Eddie Hazel to pull off ""Maggot Brain""
column8: and Collins isn't it. Still
column9: even if the Dirtbombs' version of ""Bug in the Bass Bin"" isn't anything you need to hear more than twice
column10: it's weirdly heartening that the band actually tried it. Like the album that surrounds it
column11: it's an awesomely doomed attempt at an idea that nobody's ever really tried before. And even if these Dirtbombs covers don't take on their own lives the way the Ultraglide in Black covers did
column12:
you still have to respect their gall.

'Cooperative']|2011-02-02 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:46.244006|"

File this one under ""Dreams Really Can Come True"". Like many of his peers
column3: David Sztanke-- a Parisian musician and leader of the expansive 1970s pop revival outfit Tahiti Boy and the Palmtree Family-- always had a thing for Brazilian Tropicália trailblazers Os Mutantes. After a few happy networking accidents
column4: Sztanke found himself in direct communication with Os Mutantes head honcho Sérgio Dias
column5: who confessed to digging the Palmtree Family's stuff so much
column6: he proposed they get together and make a record. The result is We Are the Lilies
column7: a jubilant
column8: cleanly presented appropriation of both musicians' styles that charms with skill and contagious energy.

column1: Backing Dias and Sztanke is the Palmtree Family (and a few very notable guests)
column2: a band so open and adaptable
column3: their endless incorporation of different instruments and styles seems breezy and effortless. Tracks are jam-packed with horns
column4: sitars
column5: keys
column6: and more percussive elements than you can list
column7: but their ambition never trumps their professionalism. The songs themselves feel very much the property of Sztanke and lean heavily on his eclectic brand of power-pop. It's hard to tell just how much direct influence Dias had on these recordings: In a short album teaser video (which promises a forthcoming companion film)
column8: we see band members working diligently in the studio
column9: intercut with shots of Dias only strumming and advising
column10: looking comfortable in his role as celebrity advisee. In a larger sense
column11: Dias' influence is undeniable
column12: both in the fact that you can hear a great deal of Os Mutantes in Tahiti Boy and the Palmtree Family
column13: and that everyone involved seems so genuinely jazzed to be working with him.

column1: That enthusiasm makes We Are the Lilies a spirited
column2: earnest kind of record
column3: but in a way that simply communicates the joy of collaboration and input. Even when songs come across as a little too eager or excited (they often do-- ""Over My Head"" suggests the Polyphonic Spree dabbling in sitcom theme songs)
column4: the engaging genre variations (60s French pop
column5: Latin-tinged funk
column6: Motown) help pad things a bit. Still
column7: the choicest material here refrains from throwing everything into the mix all at once: ""We're Gonna Live Forever"" is essentially a doo-wop tune centered around Beatles-esque vocal harmonies
column8: ""Sarava"" boasts a rockier edge but oozes pure soul
column9: and the excellent closer ""Oh Bahia"" is the expectedly solid Os Mutantes big-up.

column1: But the two big moments on We Are the Lilies come courtesy of special guests Iggy Pop and Jane Birkin (the actress/ singer most famous for her recordings with ex-husband Serge Gainsbourg)
column2: and both are most unexpected. The Iggy-assisted ""Why?"" is great fun
column3: but almost only because he seems be having most of it (""Why do the French smoke? Why do Americans fight? Why do Brazilians dance?"" he yelps over a spotty appropriation of a little Motor City rumble). Birkin's ""Marie"" fares better with its stripped-down approach
column4: channeling Blue-era Joni Mitchell with a bit of that perfectly flat-but-pretty French affectation.

column1: Tahiti Boy and the Palmtree Family have created a bright environment to play in
column2: and they make the most of it for Dias
column3: who must dig the unbridled enthusiasm of these young musicians sprouting in his honor. In this sense
column4: We Are the Lilies comes off like well-executed dinner party
column5:
where both the guest and host seem to be enjoying themselves in equal measure.

"|15049.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15049-we-are-the-lilies/|6.4|Zach Kelly

There's a reason for this
column2: a giveaway EP featuring remixes of a single song from RJD2's 2010 LP The Colossus
column3: to exist; the reason just isn't very obvious
column4: that's all. It's certainly not because ""The Glow"" was a standout on the record; there were no standouts on that just-making-the-grade effort. Doesn't help
column5: either
column6: that the song is disjointed and fails to find a pocketed groove that'll stick. If anything
column7: RJ's lyrics are what's to focus on here
column8: as they oddly embrace old-fashioned wealth signifiers like white tablecloths
column9: tans
column10: and gold wrists. There's also some talk about not having to vote or pay taxes
column11: but the whole thing is ""political"" the way N.E.R.D.'s ""politicians they soundin' like strippers to me"" line in ""Lapdance"" is.

column1: ""The Glow"" is a song about feeling yourself
column2: and the producer born Ramble John Krohn has had good reason to indulge in recent years. After watching folks' ""Next DJ Shadow"" predictions sadly come true with the release of 2007's utterly horrible
column3: rock-heavy third album The Third Hand
column4: it looked like RJ's fortunes resided alongside Prefuse 73's in the used CD bin. Lucky for him
column5: then
column6: when his instrumental for ""A Beautiful Mine""
column7: from 2006's collaborative Magnificent City LP with rapper Aceyalone
column8: was used as the theme song to ""Mad Men"". Because of this
column9: more people have heard RJD2's music on a regular basis than the number of people who bought Since We Last Spoke; it's also very likely that this slice of synergy has kept RJ well-fed.

column1: So the mood here
column2: it seems
column3: is celebratory
column4: and the remixers tapped to do their stuff here are well aware. For the most part
column5: they lean heavily on that pitchy
column6: lost-from-the-Big-Beat-era vocal hook
column7: recontextualizing it to reflect on some of dance music's more ubiquitous preoccupations at the moment. Chicago's Fool's Gold-affiliated duo Flosstradamus apply disco-edit touches
column8: stretching the tune out by a few minutes with a patient beat that is easy enough to leave on
column9: if slightly unremarkable. Italian composer and fan-chosen remix contest winner Paolo Palazzo takes a more kitchen-sink approach
column10: folding everything into an asthmatic slurp of a rhythm that fits with the sonic aspirations of California's Low End Theory beat scene. It's UK producer Candy Panther
column11: however
column12: who files the most intriguing take here
column13: experimenting with low pitches and shades of dark melody in a way that calls out to the dronier work of his brethren in the Night Slugs crew-- specifically
column14: the grime-flecked Jam City and tunnel-house alchemist Egyptrixx.

column1: So
column2: no one is doing bad work here-- but there's nothing essential either
column3: which might prompt fans to look this particular gift horse in the mouth (unless they're really into the included cars-and-dolls video for ""The Glow""
column4: which is not likely). Was this release really a gift to begin with
column5: though? Celebratory angle aside
column6: RJ has another decent reason to go about raising his profile right now: he's about to release an LP under a new moniker
column7: The Insane Warrior
column8: which is said to take cues from horror and sci-fi soundtracks. The Glow Remixes
column9: then
column10:
becomes less of a generous offering and more of a profile-raising promotional tool.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16139/homepage_large.93fb6344.jpg|Talk About Body|27929.0|MEN|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['IAMSOUND']|2011-02-01 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:48.040176|"

Around 2004
column2: there was a moment where many of the bands from the then-insurgent dancepunk wave signed with bigger labels that didn't quite know what to do with them. So Radio 4 and Hot Hot Heat and
column3: yeah
column4: Le Tigre
column5: aimed to make a dent in the dying alt-rock radio format
column6: burnished off their edges
column7: polished up their guitars
column8: and cranked out records that worked as anonymous
column9: lifeless versions of the fiery
column10: exciting music that'd made them interesting in the first place.

column1: Of all those bands
column2: Le Tigre might've been the saddest story. When they first roared into existence five years earlier
column3: they took the rip-snorting howl that Kathleen Hanna had perfected leading Bikini Kill and used it for something new: rudimentary but guns-blazing dance-pop that kept all the energy of her older band. Hanna had that same withering sneer and dizzy joy in her voice she always had
column4: but now she was using it to make amped-up party jams like ""Deceptacon""
column5: a song that felt like a new world opening up the first time you heard it. But by the time they got to 2004's Universal bow This Island
column6: much of that livewire vitality was gone. Their message was still a righteous beacon of feminist unity
column7: but their choruses just weren't sticking anymore
column8: and the group pretty much blinked out of existence soon after.

column1: JD Samson wasn't in Le Tigre when they released that clarion call of a debut album
column2: but she was on board by the time they dropped the still-pretty-great follow-up
column3: Feminist Sweepstakes. And now that Le Tigre have been on hiatus for the better part of a decade
column4: she's the first of the group's three members to work up an album's worth of material. In MEN
column5: she's crewed up with friends Michael O'Neill and Ginger Brooks Takahashi
column6: but she's the leader and figurehead of the group
column7: the visible member. Visibility is a big concept for Samson. With her strikingly masculine appearance
column8: Samson's mere existence has probably helped more than a few kids develop some confidence of their own. That's the idea
column9: anyway; in a recent L.A. Weekly interview
column10: Samson says that her main goal in Le Tigre was always to reach the queer kids. And that keeps going with MEN; plenty of the songs on their debut album are pitched as anthems: ""We want some options/ There is a way."" And that's great; but unfortunately
column11: those sentiments are still musically stuck in that 2004 moment that destroyed so many promising bands.

column1: To hear Samson tell it
column2: the Le Tigre of This Island had worked hard on their music-making ability
column3: and they could do things that they weren't able to do a few years earlier; that leap toward competence is what drove away so many of the longtime fans who loved their DIY edge. Except she's only got the story half-right; that DIY edge went a long way toward making the band dangerous and unpredictable and willing to devote an entire (great) song to their own conflicted feelings about the filmmaker John Cassavetes. Talk About Body builds itself around outmoded ideas of what moves dance floors; the beats are slick and professional enough that they've got no trace of any punk-rock basement-show roots
column4: but they aren't big or inventive enough that they can carve out dancefloor space next to the Ke$has of the world. And virtually the whole album stays locked in the same midtempo clippety-bloop rut-- processed guitars
column5: dinky keyboard riffs
column6: total lack of dynamics. MEN want to reach as many people as possible
column7: but the way to make a pop-music impression is not to be boringly professional.

column1: Samson's sloganeering could use some work
column2: too. If you're trying to write a song about the challenges of raising kids feminist
column3: you're going to need to come with something more nuanced than ""Radical politics/ Sontag in the crib"". Also
column4: ""multimedia performances"" is the sort of phrase that just isn't meant to be sung. If Samson's voice had the full-blooded verve of her old bandmate Hanna
column5: she might be able to sell this stuff. Instead
column6: she delivers all the album's lyrics in the same flat monotone
column7: and she just sounds bored the whole time. Maybe Talk About Body will be a big help to some kids who really need it; I don't know. But if you don't need the album
column8: you probably won't have much use for it
column9:
either.

Toward the end of Whit Stillman's excellent film The Last Days of Disco
column3: one of the main characters delivers a monologue about how disco will ""never die"" (it's early 1980). Sure
column4: he says
column5: it may be temporarily forgotten or wrongly remembered by the masses as John Travolta and platform shoes
column6: but the music itself is too great to ever truly perish
column7: there will always be keepers of the flame keeping it real. If Ice-T had delivered a similar speech at the end of Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo
column8: you might have the manifesto for Dark Party: Electro will never die. And their debut full-length Light Years provides good reason to cheer the genre's longevity
column9: or at least its modern revival.

column1: Dark Party is the duo of industrious producer Eliot Lipp and the lesser-known Leo 123
column2: whose scant credits so far include a production for L.A. underground rapper Subtitle and some previous appearances alongside Lipp. The latter's debut was released by hip-hop instrumentalist Guillermo Scott Herren of Prefuse 73
column3: and for several albums
column4: Lipp applied his own bright gloss to that style. In 2009
column5: though
column6: Lipp dropped Peace Love Weed 3D
column7: a grinning but uneven album that began taking things in a more distinctively electro direction. Maybe part of what the less prolific Leo 123 brings to Dark Party is a more exacting level of quality control
column8: because the duo's long-gestating debut
column9: Light Years
column10: is an unflagging blast
column11: the sort of non-stop electro party that Peace Love pointed toward but didn't entirely deliver.

column1: Old-school electro isn't exactly an unusual angle these days
column2: but Dark Party kick it with more concision than Dâm-Funk's wandering jams and with deeper sound design than
column3: say
column4: Copy's analog monophonia. ""Down"" has a reedy vocoder hook that evokes Daft Punk circa a couple of helmet upgrades ago. ""Tonight"" features chicken-scratch guitar and luxurious plush bass. ""Tina"" even achieves the feel of a live
column5: if keyboard-equipped
column6: band rocking out
column7: with its acoustic drum sounds and its loose fills and guitar strokes. Multiple tracks add chopped-up vocal samples to the mix
column8: from the diva garble of ""Status"" to ""Feets""
column9: with its chanting command to ""get your feet
column10: get your feet
column11: get your feet up in the air""-- an inversion of the more common hip-hop request (hands) that all but demands headspins and b-boy acrobatics.

column1: Even when they're just having fun with their synthesizers
column2: the results are consistently catchy. The synth glissandos of ""Easy"" slide up and down octaves in the finest g-funk style. A teasing keyboard trill on ""Fifth"" resolves into an archly dramatic little melody. Grounding everything is an unshakable foundation of thick 808 kicks and similarly vintage drum machine claps
column3: snares
column4: and clicks. At 50 minutes long
column5: the album manages not to lag until the very last
column6: with the mellow MPC bumps and synth noodling of ""Cab Weather"" feeling like a nice
column7:
relaxing ride home. At which point you'll want to start the party again.

Pairing R&B chops with scorching
column4: Stooges-worthy bashing
column5: Death's mid-1970s demos-- compiled and released by Drag City as For the Whole World to See-- lived up to every bit of their missing-link and lost-classic billing when they finally arrived
column6: more than three decades late
column7: in 2009. <i>Spiritual
column8: Mental
column9: Physical-- a follow-up collection of grotty practice tapes and studio goofs culled from a set of tape reels recently unearthed in a Detroit basement-- is a bit less awe-inspiring.

column1: To be fair
column2: For the Whole World to See set a high bar. By the time they hit the studio
column3: Bobby
column4: David
column5: and Dannis Hackney-- a trio of Detroit-based
column6: African-American brothers who temporarily set aside their Motown roots for steam-rolling proto-punk after checking out an Alice Cooper concert-- had their chops down pat. During their original
column7: five-year lifespan
column8: Death didn't make many waves. A self-released 7""-single
column9: ""Keep on Knocking"" b/w ""Politicians in My Eyes""
column10: was the group's only official release. It quickly faded into the record collector-ether. But listening now
column11: the music sounds visionary-- a missing link between MC5 and the hardcore punk of the early 1980s. The songs are performed at blistering speed
column12: burbling over with bad attitude. Death were not messing around. In just 27 minutes and seven songs
column13: the trio made a potent argument for its place on punk's Mount Olympus.

column1: But Spiritual
column2: Mental
column3: Physical is the sound of the band figuring out its chops one freewheeling basement jam at a time. The takes are raw-- most of them recorded live to two-track tape in the band's practice space. They're loose and
column4: frequently
column5: unfocused. In a few instances
column6: Death's brilliance is clearly evident. ""Views""

column8: wouldn't have sounded out of place on For the Whole World to See. ""The Masks"" explodes with heavy-metal thrashing
column9: but quickly dials back the fury for a verse lifted directly from the Beatles' ""Got to Get You Into My Life"". The song's main trick-- leap-frogging back and forth between mellow melodies and full-bore grind-- is one that the band would put to more polished use on songs like ""Let the World Turn"" and ""Politicians in My Eyes""
column10: from the For the Whole World to See sessions.

column1: But the record's B-side is padded with less revelatory material-- solo-instrumentals
column2: psychedelic asides
column3: and half-finished song ideas. Aside from ""The Storm Within""
column4: a garage-leveling three-minute freak-out
column5: it's mostly unremarkable. If anything the collection proves that Death were not produced into existence during a handful of studio sessions. Even goofing off in the practice space
column6: their musicianship is clear
column7: even if their vision hadn't totally solidified. The majority of <i>Spiritual
column8: Mental
column9: Physical was recorded in a practice space
column10: with no intention of public release. It's a collection of unguarded
column11: unconsidered moments. On For the Whole World to See
column12: Death were getting down to business. Here
column13:
they're having a good time.

Ever since Ricardo Villalobos forged a 17-minute club anthem out of a looped piano riff and children chanting in Spanish (2007's ""Enfants (Chants)"")
column2: minimal's narrative of rewriting the definition of club music has felt exhausted (more kindly: completed). The astonishingly young Nicolas Jaar has emerged in the shadow of that endpoint
column3: and he has pursued a sound that cuts diagonally across modern house and techno's continuum of revivalist simplicity to outré sound design. This range can be heard from his straightforwardly lush disco edits to the generous use of silence and repetition on his forthcoming solo album
column4: Space Is Only Noise.

column1: It's as if Jaar is simply adding new lines across post-minimal's completed coloring book
column2: straining through sheer craft to change the tone and feel of the pictures. This restlessness gives his work the feel of being transitory
column3: offering no statement of a fully formed aesthetic
column4: only snapshots of resting places between one mode and the next. Somewhat perversely
column5: the most coherent articulation of Jaar's approach is captured on a release not even in his name. Strictly speaking
column6: Inès is a compilation of output on Jaar's experiment-slanted Clown & Sunset label
column7: though as compilations go it's very single-minded: four of the 10 tracks here are from Jaar
column8: and he collaborates with artists Soul Keita and Nikita Quasim on two others
column9: while Keita and Quasim offer two solo tracks each.

column1: Inès is also single-minded in feel in spite of its sonic diversity
column2: each track asking different versions of the same questions: what is the relationship between groove and non-groove
column3: between chaos and order? Does the sun shine more brightly if it suddenly emerges from behind clouds? While stylistic contexts differ
column4: from the softly popping Jan Jelinek downtempo of Quasim's ""Freshman Year"" with its woozy accelerations and decelerations
column5: to the loping blues-disco stomp of Jaar's ""Love You Gotta Lose Again"" to the morose and mysterious instrumental hip-hop of Keita's ""Dusties N 808s""
column6: everything here points to an underlying sensibility of absolute looseness finding itself pressed into the service of the beat.

column1: If that sounds like Downtempo 101
column2: well
column3: it is; Inès' point of distinction is the deliberateness of its constructions. They are simultaneously more fragmentary and more intricate
column4: more tentative and more precise than your standard narcoleptic headnodder
column5: with tracks that are rigid with barely restrained tension. So
column6: the seemingly adrift piano tinkles of Jaar's ""Tribute to My Mother"" become drawn into a cat's-cradle of electronic zaps and buzzing bass surges
column7: while on his ""Dubliners"" papery rustles and scratches gradually coalesce into an eerie percussive house groove
column8: like cells becoming molecules before your eyes. Best of all is the entire collective's ""Her String""
column9: where succulent hand percussion and live bass build to a gorgeously deliquescent flamenco guitar solo.

column1: With its fragile
column2: whispery pools and eddies of sound
column3: Inès recalls the rhythmically attenuated constructions of Villalobos (in particular his Achso EP) but also Henrik Schwarz's naturalist dance music fusions. But unlike these artists
column4: Jaar and company remain determinedly small scale
column5: preferring to offer carefully constructed pinnacles that never outstay their welcome. As such
column6: it's easy to dismiss Inès as a minor work
column7: to conclude that the delicacy of its articulations feel hard-won only because they're staged that way. All of which is true
column8:
but once you're on the album's microscopic level of activity even the slightest developments feel immensely evocative.

column3: right off

column5: producer
column6: and creative director
column7: Andy Butler
column8: remains in place

column6: house as it was understood around 1987

column8: in particular

column1: As the album rolls on
column2: though
column3: Butler fails to recapture the chemistry he had with previous vocalists. Negrot and Wright are not quite anonymous
column4: but lack the dynamic presence of previous contributors. While it's interesting to hear how his style works in a pop-house context

column8: this might be who you are"") is hardly juicy enough to bring the track to life on its own. Nearly every dance track here still has something to recommend

column4: featuring Butler's own voice rather aggressively high in the mix. Butler has talked about wanting to demonstrate his ""ability to write more than a four-to-the-floor dance track."" The thing is

column6: and the other stuff is nowhere near as interesting.

column1: Blue Songs closes with a meandering
column2: beatless six-minute cover of another Jefferson production
column3: Sterling Void's 1987 house single ""It's All Right"". That song was also covered
column4: much more famously (and effectively)

column7:
like the Boys.) Is Butler commenting on the relationship between house and pop music? Is he reclaiming house from some version of the mainstream? Is he just underscoring his own sources? It's hard to tell: So much of the album is straining to be more than just an homage to the club sounds of the late 80s that it ends up being a bit less.

All their mother wanted was to keep them off the streets. The Scroggins sisters came of age in a South Bronx eviscerated by Robert Moses' Cross Bronx Expressway-- a neighborhood carved up by projects and abandoned by government. Their mother bought them instruments in the hope that her girls might devote themselves to music and stay out of trouble. And they did. Her deal with them stipulated they had to give her a performance every week
column4: and the band the teenaged sisters formed (with occasional minor assistance from a few neighborhood guys) became ESG. The ""E"" and ""S"" stand for emerald and sapphire
column5: the birthstones of Valerie and Renee Scroggins. The ""G"" is for gold
column6: which is what they wanted their records to be certified.

column1: The gold records never came
column2: but something even more unexpected did: The band developed a sound unlike any other and quite by accident became a major influence on hip-hop
column3: dance music
column4: and dance-punk
column5: fitting right in with New York City's arty downtown scene and the UK's vibrant post-punk explosion. Their 1981 debut EP
column6: recorded by Martin Hannett after the band was discovered at a talent show by 99 Records founder Ed Bahlman
column7: is among the most sampled records around-- ""UFO"" alone as been reused several dozen times
column8: by Public Enemy
column9: the Beastie Boys
column10: N.W.A.
column11: Big Daddy Kane
column12: EPMD
column13: Liars
column14: DJ Qbert
column15: DJ Shadow
column16: Girl Talk
column17: and Nine Inch Nails.

column1: It's easy to hear why the band's work is so ripe for sampling. It's uniquely spartan music
column2: driven by economical drumming
column3: tersely phrased bass
column4: and minimal
column5: sometimes even surf-y guitar parts. Marie and Renee's vocals and lyrics take a similarly minimal approach-- chanting
column6: repeating phrases
column7: taunting
column8: nearly rapping
column9: nearly singing. On ""Erase You""
column10: Renee takes center stage
column11: delivering a deliciously snotty
column12: assured put-down. It's easy to see why the band was embraced in punk circles-- that song has a nasty guitar tone and tense rhythm that wouldn't sound out of place on a Public Image Ltd. album
column13: and their music was brilliantly concise. The sisters quickly realized where they fit.

column1: The band's debut EP and first album are nearly perfect
column2: and Fire's Dance to the Best of ESG acknowledges that
column3: including all three studio tracks from the first EP and all but two songs from Come Away With ESG on the first of its two discs. None of it has aged: ""UFO"" still sounds intense and weird; ""Moody""
column4: which is heard in its original version and three other variations
column5: is tough and sleek
column6: a clear house antecedent; and ""Chistelle"" is a demented surf-punk romp that seems to be a case of convergent evolution with the Fall. ""My Love For You"" remains fantastically funky
column7: mimicking the ""My love for you
column8: baby
column9: is like a rollercoaster"" opening line in its gonzo rhythm.

column1: The songs aren't sequenced chronologically
column2: but most of disc one is devoted to those releases and the band's self-titled 1991 album
column3: while disc two concentrates on 12""s and later EP tracks. A few songs from the band's 2002 and 2006 albums for Soul Jazz
column4: with Valerie and Renee's daughters in the group
column5: pop up in the running order
column6: too
column7: sounding remarkably of a piece with the older material-- organizing by chronology becomes less important when a band's vision is this consistent. The set ends with three songs from the 1992 EP Sample Credits Don't Pay Our Bills
column8: which is perhaps a subtle way of telling the band's side of the story of their immense influence. Even today
column9: Renee has a company on retainer to track down payment for uncredited samples
column10: and the band's bitterness over others achieving success on the back of their music while they toiled in obscurity and kept day jobs is obvious
column11: in both the music and the liner notes to this set.

column1: The need to have a company constantly searching for uncleared samples of their work is also a measure of the band's impact
column2: of course. They started out as unpretentious amateurs accidentally bridging the gap between dance parties and art scenes
column3: went on to play the opening of the Haçienda and the closing of the Paradise Garage
column4: and can now be satisfied that what they did really meant something. If you've never heard ESG
column5: you could be forgiven for approaching them with some skepticism. A lot of obscure bands are lauded as influential and essential by critics and other musicians
column6: only to disappoint when you actually hear them
column7: but ESG are the real deal. The music isn't just influential and important
column8: it's exciting too
column9:
and very much its own thing. This set is a good place for beginners to get acquainted.

""Southern Decline""
column2: a fuzzy power-pop tune about using booze as a means to escape life's problems (and about learning that trick from our fathers)
column3: kicks off The Year of Magical Drinking
column4: the debut album from Apex Manor
column5: former Broken West frontman Ross Flournoy's first project following the dissolution of that group in 2009. Given the album's tastelessly terrific title (and I say that as a huge Joan Didion fan) and the subject matter of its opening cut
column6: I was all geared up for a full-fledged diary of inebriation. Sadly
column7: the record's handle turns out to be essentially a throwaway joke.

column1: That doesn't mean Flournoy doesn't have plenty of other depressants at his disposal. There's lots of love and sex gone bad on the album
column2: as well as seeming allusions to abused substances that don't come in a bottle. Flournoy largely balances out these bum trips with basically the same brand of melodically driving pop-rock he proffered with the Broken West. Unsurprisingly
column3: he frequently evokes other artists with a rich history of blending buoyant rhythms with deflated or heartsick lyrics-- witness the early-Wilco moves on the insistent rocker ""Under the Gun"" or the R.E.M.-ish bassline on the chimingly wistful ""I Know These Waters Well"". That said
column4: Flournoy's bread-and-butter style can start to feel pretty anonymous after a while
column5: as evidenced by the boilerplate likes of ""The Party Line""
column6: ""Teenage Blood""
column7: and ""Elemental Ways of Speaking""
column8: and it certainly doesn't help that the words to those songs are equally undistinguished
column9: full of vague impressions and empty jargon.

column1: To his credit
column2: Flournoy breaks up the facile pop-rock monotony a few times
column3: with encouraging results. ""My My Mind"" and ""Burn Me Alive"" both exhibit a cool
column4: atmospheric sway that proves to be a good look for Flournoy (the latter even finding him unpacking an admirable falsetto)
column5: while ""Holy Roller"" displays just the right light touch of country and gospel. The closing ""Coming To"" stands out from the pack as well thanks to a little cowbell and guitar ruckus
column6: and also features the album's best line
column7: with Flournoy stringing together the set-up of the song's title with the punchline
column8:
""a bed near you."" The irreverence suits him well; maybe Flournoy should consider a year of magical winking.

Even though it's rooted in stasis
column2: ambient music is always evolving. The German label Kompakt
column3: an authority in the field
column4: has driven both its evolution and the entrenchment of certain habits in the last decade. Label co-founder Wolfgang Voigt's ambient techno with Gas and other projects inspired a generation of frank imitators
column5: even as his label's Pop Ambient compilations have pushed the limits of what ambient can entail. The term has picked up such varied connotations since Brian Eno coined it that it's become hard to define clearly. As usual
column6: this year's Pop Ambient entry is an opportunity to take the temperature of what ambient means right now.

column1: Pop Ambient 2011 does suggest some common properties of modern ambient music. It assumes an air of immutability-- then
column2: it changes. It features cyclical phrases
column3: layered drones
column4: sculptural textures
column5: and flashes of traditional instrumentation. It avoids crisp delineation of sections
column6: obscuring its internal dynamics to create a sense of traveling without moving. It has more in common with abstract visual art than other music-- it calls attention to its materials and features enigmatic subjects
column7: like the scraped and peeled paint fields of Gerhard Richter
column8: the colored light sculptures of Dan Flavin
column9: and especially the monumental land art of Robert Smithson. Ambient insists that music is already latent in the raw terrain of sound.

column1: But Pop Ambient 2011 provides exceptions to every rule. ""Bernsteinzimmer"" by ANBB (that's Alva Noto and Blixa Bargeld) conveys an abstracted but palpable narrative via harmonic development and whispers that suddenly break into an authoritative voice. Against the notion that ambient music is sonic wallpaper
column2: it shockingly commandeers the foreground. Triola's ""Dunkelraum"" also taps into the current vogue for submerged voices
column3: but otherwise is merely an inert bed of tone and texture that represents ambient music at its most pro forma.

column1: Mikkel Metal and Bhutan Tiger Rescue take the ""pop"" part to heart. The former's ""The Other Side Of You"" places dreamy piano and drums amid a radiant synthetic sunburst. The latter's ""Beginner's Waltz"" is built around three lustrous tones that sway endlessly
column2: splashed with sleigh bells and ethereal harmonies. Here
column3: ambient music is something superficial; a haze gathering around repetitive tunes. That's not a ringing endorsement
column4: but it's hard to get mad at pretty songs for conceptual reasons
column5: and the Bhutan Tiger Rescue track has an especially memorable mood. At the other extreme
column6: Crato conceives of ambient as something closer to noise or drone-metal: ""30.6.1881"" is a grayscale dirge midway between Infinite Body and Svarte Greiner
column7: spooky but rote.

column1: But the most fertile influence on this year's comp is classical music. Voigt offers orchestral halos that wax and wane majestically
column2: like an overdubbed Arvo Pärt symphony. Marsen Jules splices Glassian piano minimalism with a coiled
column3: pouncing filter odyssey
column4: and the Orb's Thomas Fehlmann creates a ""cover"" of Mahler's First. Best of all is label co-founder Jürgen Paape's huge
column5: swooping ""Ein Schöner Land"". Like Voigt's offering
column6: it has more false endings than a James Brown song
column7: and a dramatic sense of tension and release. Its shapes are stalwart and high-relief. Nothing feels vague or accidental. These are bona fide compositions
column8: relying on traditional building blocks like tonality
column9: counterpoint
column10: and motivic development instead of the haphazard interaction of shimmering tones-- a style that some of Kompakt's artists seem content with
column11:
even as the founders who enshrined it keep pushing forward.

"|15043.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15043-pop-ambient-2011/|6.8|Brian Howe

column11: it would seem

column3: Hexadecagon feels like little more than a who's-who of important-to-indie-kids instrumental music. That approach-- all glittering midsections

column6: just like every collapse

column13:
not a disco ball. Guess you just had to be there.

Fujiya & Miyagi have always been open about their admiration for Krautrock icons Can
column3: but that influence has as much to do with methodology as mere mimicry. Using a literal interpretation of the concept of ""art rock
column4: Can famously approached recording much like sculptors
column5: chiseling down extended
column6: amorphous jams into more manageable forms
column7: if not quite linear songs. Fujiya & Miyagi simply take this logic one step further
column8: distilling the syncopated grooves and mantric incantations of Can circa Ege Bamyasi or Future Days into accessible dance pop. (Even the band's M.O.-- British guys operating under a Japanese alias to make Teutonic funk-- is redolent of Can's multicultural composition and ethos.)

column1: But there is
column2: of course
column3: a crucial distinction between Fujiya & Miyagi and their forebears-- F&M's preference for steely precision and sleek minimalism means that their music lacks the volatility and mercurial quality that made Can's work so eminently fascinating. And while they've enlisted a somewhat surprising choice of producer for Ventriloquizzing-- Devendra Banhart/Vetiver compatriot Thom Monahan-- the new album does little to upset their pulse-regulated tempos and hushed-voice intimations.

column1: As on the preceding Transparent Things and Lighbulbs
column2: consumption and materialism comprise the thematic grist of Ventriloquizzing. But Fujiya & Miyagi are self-aware enough to acknowledge that their music is essentially just another lifestyle accoutrement-- in the spirit of Kraftwerk's ""Showroom Dummies"" and Air's ""Electronic Performers""
column3: the opening title track sees F&M likening themselves to puppets
column4: emotionally empty and easily manipulated. Ironically
column5: this admission of their own synthetic quality marks one of the few occasions when Ventriloquizzing really catches fire
column6: as the song's ping-pong bass line yields to a powerful burst of analog-synth drones. But for all the premium they place on motion and rhythm
column7: Fujiya & Miyagi songs rarely take you very far away from where they begin; whether employing a live drummer or an 808
column8: the grooves are locked in early
column9: with only minor textural tweaks (e.g.
column10: the invigorating Suicide-style organ fuzz on ""Yoyo"" and ""Tinsel & Glitter""; the haunting choral vocals of ""Universe"") to subtly increase the intensity.

column1: As a result
column2: Ventriloquizzing places undue emphasis on David Best's sing-spiel to move the action along. While he does have a flair for understated satire-- the piano-rolled ""Taiwanese Boots"" cheekily itemizes food choices as a measure of status
column3: while ""Minestrone"" updates an old parable about the devil positing the titular soup as the ultimate temptation-- Best tends to confuse repetition with profundity. It's no secret Fujiya & Miyagi aren't Japanese
column4: but Best's lyrics often sound cribbed from a beginner's guidebook to common English phrases (""you don't know which side your bread is buttered on
column5: ""you go up and go down like a yo-yo"")
column6: and his sinister
column7: admonishing delivery doesn't invest them with any more weight or meaning. Over the ""Yoo Doo Right"" bass pulse of the closing ""Universe""
column8: Best repeats over and over again: ""You love to hear the sound of your own voice."" On an album that takes glee in skewering the chattering classes
column9:
at least Best is self-effacing enough to save the last shot for himself.
