column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16050/homepage_large.2633084d.jpg|White Wilderness|4452.0|John Vanderslice|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2011-01-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:53.546031|"

John Vanderslice is a known and avowed tinkerer. He operates Tiny Telephone Studio
column2: so if he wants to take his time making a record
column3: he certainly can. All of his albums to date have been meticulously assembled things
column4: full of carefully layered sounds
column5: tweaked and prodded into shape over months. I guess everybody needs a change of pace now and then
column6: because White Wilderness was recorded in three days with a live band
column7: outside of Tiny Telephone. The live band in question is something called the Magik*Magik Orchestra
column8: led by Minna Choi. They're not strictly a chamber orchestra in the sense you might expect. Yes
column9: Choi has arranged these songs with strings and woodwinds
column10: but the orchestra members also contribute things like piano
column11: drums
column12: and pedal steel.

column1: So he got out of the studio and stretched his legs a little with a small orchestra. What kind of record does that make? Well
column2: take away the tinkering and you get a record that still fits quite comfortably into Vanderslice's discography-- it's not that different
column3: stylistically
column4: from anything else he's done. The meticulous studio layering missing here is largely covered up by the orchestration. If there's any significant difference
column5: it's in Vanderslice himself. His voice sounds much more vulnerable and fragile in this setting. I think back in particular to 2009's Romanian Names
column6: where he seemed to be growing more comfortable with building himself into a small choir and was really putting his vocals out front; here
column7: he recedes into the band a bit more
column8: occasionally bolstered by a harmony from Choi or a few fluttering ""ah ahs"" from some of the orchestra.

column1: He gets some of those ""ahs"" on ""The Piano Lesson""
column2: a song literally about learning to play piano that Choi uses as an orchestral playground. Vanderslice's wandering vocal melody is anchored by an ominous sax figure
column3: the strings play racing pizzicato patterns
column4: brass and flutes swell queasily
column5: and the overall effect is strikingly dark. There's a subtle tension at play on the album
column6: almost a tug of war between Vanderslice and Choi
column7: and one or the other typically winds up dominating each song
column8: but there are a few where they strike a real balance. Up-tempo standout ""Overcoat"" is one of those songs. Vanderslice isn't so much a verse/chorus songwriter
column9: but he can craft a memorable melody
column10: and this one is great. It keeps the moaning woodwinds and shivering strings at bay until the second half of the song
column11: when the complexity of the arrangement increases
column12: leaving him to carefully pick his way through shards of orchestration.

column1: One thing that working with an orchestra didn't disrupt is Vanderslice's commitment to concision. It must have been tempting to make something sprawling and try to live up to the orchestral scope of the project
column2: but White Wilderness is just over a half hour long
column3: like most of Vanderslice's albums. This has always served him well-- none of his records wear out their welcome. Neither does this one
column4: but I do get the feeling there's a reason he usually spends so much time agonizing over his records-- all that tweaking really brings out the details of his songwriting
column5: which are sometimes lost in the orchestration and less polished vocals here. Still
column6:
these types of projects can help a songwriter refocus and between them Vanderslice and Choi have made a memorable album that successfully adds a new twist to Vanderslice's catalog.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16134/homepage_large.07414893.jpg|The Party Ain't Over|9495.0|Wanda Jackson|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Nonesuch'
column2:
'Third Man']|2011-01-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:54.892151|"

It's easy to see why Jack White wanted to produce rock'n'roll lifer Wanda Jackson after watching just one two-and-a-half minute YouTube video. The performance clip was taped in 1958 for L.A. TV show ""Town Hall Party"" and finds Jackson roaring through an Elvis Presley hit single called ""Hard Headed Woman"". As written
column3: the song doesn't portray  women in the strongest light-- ""a hard-headed woman is the thorn in the  side of a man
column4: goes the 50s-macho hook. But Jackson flips it-- and  gives the thing a good hard jolt
column5: too. When she sings the  chorus
column6: she adds a blustery ""you betcha
column7: yeah!"" While many young women  of her time were content to pine after Elvis
column8: she dated him while in her teens and symbolically kicked his ass with his own song. But the most startling and awesome thing about the ""Hard Headed Woman"" clip may be Jackson's badass introduction: ""We think this is one of the most beautiful love songs that's ever been written."" Kathleen Hanna would most certainly approve.

column1: Jackson's 50s sides would justly earn her the title of ""Queen of Rockabilly
column2: and The Party Ain't Over is a reference to her 1958 hit ""Let's Have a Party"". But
column3: since that  early success
column4: the singer recorded many albums of more traditional  country
column5: blues
column6: and gospel over the last 50 years. And while her voice  was so galvanizing on those early singles-- her signature  growl could match any man's-- it would later prove to be tender
column7: lonesome
column8: and gorgeous without a hint of the toughness that originally  made her famous. Delving into her catalog now
column9: some of her most lasting  music may not be as revolutionary as her gender-busting rockabilly
column10: but it's also less novel; her classy 1964 LP Blues in My Heart in particular is a timeless work
column11: both loose and graceful. But
column12: with The Party Ain't Over
column13: Jack White aims to reconnect the 73-year-old Jackson with her teenage  style by any means necessary. So we get truckloads of overzealous horns  that sound ripped off from his buddy Conan's late-night band
column14: White's  own fuzzed-out guitar
column15: bustling drums
column16: and cartoon-y slide work. The wild excess often ends up shoving Jackson to the sidelines on her own album.

column1: The last time White worked with one of his grandmotherly female idols was on Loretta Lynn's devastatingly personal and loving Van Lear Rose. But there are differences between that project and this one. Van Lear Rose had Lynn writing most of the songs
column2: and White treated them with reverence while maintaining an airy live feel. Jackson didn't write any songs on The Party Ain't Over
column3: which isn't terribly notable in itself considering she hailed from a pre-singer-songwriter  era and wrote few of her own tunes. But the songs on the record--  mostly picked by White-- often come off as forced
column4: unfairly  anachronistic or both. When the too-loud trumpets and juke-joint piano  push Jackson on opener ""Rip It Up""
column5: it feels a little uncomfortable. It's almost the same uneasy vibe you get when watching that fake old guy dancing up a storm in those Six Flags commercials-- something just ain't right there.

column1: Of course
column2: White's intentions are good here
column3: and  chances are many people (including myself) wouldn't even be paying attention if he weren't involved. And if the point was to get folks  to revisit this legendary singer's legacy and grant her much-overdue appreciation
column4: mission accomplished. But White doesn't help Jackson make any new classics on The Party Ain't Over. Annoyingly
column5: the last track suggests it didn't have to be that way. ""Blue Yodel #6"" ditches all the instrumental flotsam as it  finds Jackson singing against only White's twanging acoustic guitar. The  singer's weathered-yet-vibrant voice and personality finally don't  have to battle for the spotlight. It's quite easily the best thing here
column6:
as it hearkens back to her post-rockabilly 60s records and shows this undervalued pioneer doesn't need to party to have a good time.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16131/homepage_large.a041cef5.jpg|Mend|29364.0|Geotic|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2011-01-28 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:55.314539|"

It's becoming common for hazy electro-pop artists to have an ambient side project (see Evan Abeele's work away from Memoryhouse
column2: and the Teen Daze offshoot Two Bicycles)
column3: which makes sense. The music is about vibe and feel
column4: after all
column5: so it has to be tempting to ditch the songs altogether and dive all the way into atmosphere. But while there's a lot of music in this vein being made
column6: much of it seems interchangeable. So it's natural to approach Geotic
column7: a side project of Will Wiesenfeld from Baths
column8: with a certain amount of skepticism. But there's more going on here than just a break from songwriting.

column1: Mend is Wiesenfeld's fifth album as Geotic
column2: a project he's been returning to since 2008. There are a few non-musical elements that might make it seem tossed-off-- its unveiling via an Angelfire page
column3: the fact that it was recorded in four days total
column4: just after this past Christmas. But the record itself is more than just half-formed ephemera. Most of Mend was recorded on electric guitar
column5: an instrument that didn't feature heavily on Baths' breakout debut LP
column6: last year's Cerulean. Wiesenfeld's recent Daytrotter session demonstrated his skill on piano and his ear for deconstructing his own material
column7: and Mend offers further revelations in the form of his guitar playing. Throughout
column8: gently picked patterns skip across webs of static tone
column9: all of which is swathed in amniotic fuzz. There's a bit of sleepiness here and there
column10: particularly on the loping ""Beaming Husband""
column11: but this is otherwise quite physical music for an ambient album. You can hear the bent notes and fingers sliding along the fretboard on opener ""Unwind""
column12: and there is real movement on the lightly galloping highlight ""And Upon Awakening"". Mend ultimately feels organic and human
column13: more about people than machines.

column1: Which makes sense
column2: since the bloops and warped samples of Cerulean were always in service of exploring emotion (the guy titled a song ""♥""). A quick scan through Mend's tracklist (""Find Your Peace""
column3: ""Sleep and We'll Transition""
column4: ""I'll Have Come and Gone With You"") reveals that those preoccupations are still very much present. There are no lofty themes or overwrought sentiments here
column5: though. Instead
column6: Mend's melodies are gently simple
column7: carrying enough heft to stick to your brain without becoming syrupy. For most bedroom artists
column8: that'd be a triumph; for Wiesenfeld
column9: it's something he did over the holidays
column10:
another bend in an increasingly compelling career path.

"|15037.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15037-mend/|7.4|Larry Fitzmaurice

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16140/homepage_large.e2c1baa6.jpg|Clouds Are Mountains|29230.0|Eleven Tigers|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Soul Motive']|2011-01-28 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:55.755225|"

Clouds Are Mountains
column2: the debut album for Lithuanian-born producer Eleven Tigers (and the first full-length release for UK-based Soul Motive records)  is a meditation of sorts on modern electronic music
column3: especially UK bass music. Presented as a ""mix"" rather than a series of tracks-- unlike most electronic artists
column4: Eleven Tigers opts to begin his career with an LP instead of a single-- Clouds Are Mountains nestles intriguing slabs of techno into listless atmospheres.

column1: Eleven Tigers first made noise in the middle of last year with the single ""Stableface""
column2: an insistent and prolonged beat drama on an album filled with vignettes
column3: which excited dubstep fans and received several remixes. It's ironic that an album specifically constructed to be heard as a piece will be defined by its strongest single
column4: one that is ineffectively buried near the end of the album. Clouds Are Mountains doesn't feel like a mix because Eleven Tigers too often mistakes drift for transition. The exciting moments feel like a group of islands amidst an electronic sea. Mixes tend to build toward an emotional or musical release; Clouds Are Mountains ebbs and flows and feels merely like a particularly cohesive album.

column1: In terms of both spirit and execution
column2: Eleven Tigers recalls Burial
column3: but only in part because each plays dubstep: Eleven Tigers relies chiefly on distorted
column4: alien voices and pigeon-footed rhythms for its important moments. It's also unrepentantly moody
column5: like a child prodded too many times about just what is the matter and who keeps answering
column6: ""nothing."" My favorite moments on Clouds Are Mountains almost invariably exist outside those contexts
column7: like the drum'n'bass-indebted middle section of ""Thesis"" and ""Frozen Wheel"". Or when the folk/bass/pop clash during ""Songs for You"" brings to mind the underloved British act Various Production. Moments of ambience and proper reggae are sadly less evocative.

column1: Clouds Are Mountains can't sit still. It sprints between styles and tempos in a way that feels indecisive
column2: especially for a work that stresses its cohesion. Eleven Tigers puts his hands on a lot of styles here
column3: but the only thing he seems to take ownership of is the album's dour demeanor. That kind of monotonous mood can benefit an album of outstanding focus or singular style
column4:
but Eleven Tigers too often feels like he's trying to out-execute his peers.

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Polyvinyl']|2011-01-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:56.143424|"

Deerhoof's drummer Greg Saunier recently noted that ""if there's any pressure on us
column3: it's actually a pressure to not repeat."" That's an admirable goal
column4: and so far they've mostly stuck with it. They've spent most of their career as a fast-and-bulbous hybrid of a super-heavy
column5: experimentation-minded art-rock band and a sweet little pop group
column6: equal parts chirp and pummel. In the six-album-plus run from 2002's Reveille to 2008's Offend Maggie
column7: they perpetually pushed the sound of the band into fresh if occasionally awkward territory.

column1: They're also a totally idiomatic band
column2: one of those groups where you usually only need to hear a few seconds' worth of any song to know it's them
column3: whether or not bassist Satomi Matsuzaki is singing at the time. That puts Deerhoof in a difficult position: Their identity is built around all four members' particular quirks as musicians
column4: but they're struggling not to repeat themselves
column5: so they're hunting for new rooms within the house they have constructed for themselves.

column1: It's been more than two years since Offend Maggie-- an unusually long stretch by their standards-- but Deerhoof vs. Evil is less a leap forward than a transitional record
column2: along the lines of 2005's Green Cosmos EP. They're sticking to their M.O. of repeating a single odd musical or lyrical phrase (""I did crimes for you
column3: they're coming true!"") again and again until it sounds like a hook; beyond that
column4: you can tell that they're trying to wriggle out of what they've been doing in the band's previous phase
column5: but haven't quite figured out what comes next.

column1: In particular
column2: they keep sidling up to the kind of heavy rock that's been their secret weapon in the past
column3: then bolting away from it. Deerhoof have always had a difficult relationship with great big stomps and riffs
column4: but in the past their clever self-sabotage has often let a cracked-but-intact rock song sneak through-- Friend Opportunity's ""+81""
column5: Apple O''s ""Dummy Discards a Heart""
column6: Offend Maggie's ""The Tears and Music of Love"".

column1: There's nothing anywhere near as direct as those songs here. Instead
column2: we get the likes of ""The Merry Barracks"": A handful of rhythmically lopsided loops that eventually synch up with Saunier murmuring ""Hello hello hello/ Atomic bombs are going to explode
column3: then a passage where Matsuzaki's clear-voiced
column4: unemphatic simper alternates with the band going WHAM WHAM WHAM
column5: 15 seconds of the whole group doing their best imitation of '92 shoegaze
column6: a free-noise guitar solo
column7: and so on. It's also the first of two different songs that include the line ""everyone
column8: everyone
column9: sing!"" (The Saunier-sung closer
column10: ""Almost Everyone
column11: Almost Always""
column12: begins with a variation: ""Everyone
column13: everyone
column14: in a bow tie."")

column1: What keeps Deerhoof entertaining even at their most distracted is that they actually mean that ""everyone sing"" bit: they're as open-hearted and goofy as egghead experimentalists get. ""No One Asked to Dance""
column2: one of the prettiest songs they've ever recorded
column3: could be incidental music from a late-60s European art movie; ""Let's Dance the Jet"" actually is a cover of a Mikis Theodorakis piece from a 1967 film
column4: The Day the Fish Came Out-- a drone-plus-freaky-rhythm instrumental that's a welcome reminder that Deerhoof didn't invent this stuff.

column1: Saunier indicated in a recent Popnography interview that all four members of Deerhoof individually write songs
column2: which the other members then alter until everyone's satisfied with them. Sometimes that works out nicely: ""Must Fight Current""
column3: a duet between Matsuzaki and guitarist John Dieterich
column4: adopts the old Sleater-Kinney effect of two different songs that just happen to work when they're superimposed
column5: then dials it down to a prickly
column6: dissonant samba. Often
column7: though
column8:
what's left of these songs is too much or too little. There's a lot to be said for ADD-- it's a pretty good strategy for not being boring-- but Deerhoof are fighting so hard to avoid obviousness and stasis that they're starting to undermine themselves.

"|15039.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/15039-deerhoof-vs-evil/|6.7|Douglas Wolk

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16090/homepage_large.587c192a.jpg|Napa Asylum|19365.0|Sic Alps|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2011-01-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:56.518560|"

Sic Alps' simple garage-rock is both enticing and uncomfortable. They approach classic melody in miniature
column2: chipping nuggets off of Nuggets
column3: and they never go far without an inviting little hook. But they don't let those hooks last long either. Their songs are spare and distant
column4: reveling in negative space and moving with a deliberate
column5: lopsided gait. This sonic personality is best encapsulated in Mike Donovan's singing
column6: which is awkward and endearing. It sounds like he loves hooks but doesn't want to chase them
column7: meditating on melodies rather than working himself up enough to hit the ""right"" notes.

column1: All of which is why
column2: despite the fact that they've ripped out some pretty great singles
column3: Sic Alps make music that's best absorbed on full-length albums. As their odd tics
column4: off notes
column5: and bevy of stops and starts build up
column6: the logic of their approach becomes clearer and more addictive. In that sense Napa Asylum
column7: with 22 songs stretched over 45 minutes
column8: is probably the best Sic Alps full-length so far. Two-chord ditties bump up against noisy distortion
column9: quiet sketches draw out multi-voice harmonies
column10: short lyrics snake through twangy jaunts. And it's all presented in a style that's less lo-fi than old-fi
column11: as if Sic Alps were huddled around a single beat-up mic in a dusty 1950's studio.

column1: The result is creativity doled out in rangy bursts. Take a three-strong stretch about halfway through Napa Asylum-- the slow
column2: distorted
column3: Royal Trux-like ""Trip Train"" slips into the bouncy
column4: Beatles-esque ""Ball of Fame""
column5: then into the sparse ""Ranger""
column6: which mines tons of mood from basically two notes. Because they're all drenched in the trademark Sic Alps atmosphere-- never rushed
column7: over-polished
column8: or abrupt-- these stylistic shifts sound natural and uncontrived.

column1: In fact
column2: Napa Asylum is so rich
column3: its peaks can be easy to miss. One particular highlight deserves isolation-- on ""The First White Man to Touch California Soil""
column4: Donovan portrays California with what could be a celebration of his band's own outlook. ""Now we're in this country living free/ And we got that same mentality/ How the Colorado used to flow/ Now your neighbor's greener grasses grow."" It's the album's biggest
column5: boldest track
column6: buttressed by new member Noel Von Harmonson
column7: bringing his knack for noise over from Comets on Fire. It's easy to imagine the other 21 songs here being that fleshed out
column8: with instruments and textures added and verses and choruses repeated more than a few times. Sic Alps could probably do that version of themselves well
column9: but their essential shaggy-dog personality might get obscured by so much activity. On Napa Asylum they've wisely stuck to their patient
column10:
understated approach-- and pretty much perfected it.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16119/homepage_large.4279d119.jpg|DJ Premier Presents Year Round Records: Get Used to Us|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Year Round']|2011-01-27 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:34:56.893338|"

You could make a strong case for DJ Premier as rap's greatest-ever producer
column2: but his particular strand of greatness is a slippery one to define. The Texas-born Premier perfected and codified a distinctly New York form of beatmaking
column3: a crisp crackle that gained much of its power through tiny ruptures in its own infinite repetition. Premier's preferred tools were and are simple: a tooth-rattle snare
column4: a perfectly-timed needle-slice
column5: an unidentifiable and cannily selected shard of someone else's record. But he blurred all these things together with the grace and precision of a true artist. And like a great film director
column6: he knew just when to disappear
column7: ceding the spotlight to the rappers' voices on his tracks. When Premier's longtime Gang Starr partner Guru died last year
column8: many of the tributes took care to dance around Guru's greatest strength as a rapper: With his unflappable monotone
column9: he made a great foil to Premier's alchemy. It was never the other way around.

column1: But here's the thing about living legends: They continue to live and
column2: in most cases
column3: to work. And in all but a handful of cases
column4: their late-in-life work just serves to remind you how great they were when they were young and hungry and had the world's collective ear. That's absolutely the case with late-period Preemo
column5: who's content to crank out bare-bones headknocks for craggy old N.Y. buddies and asskissy tribute-payers. Superstar former collaborators like Jay-Z aren't exactly knocking down his door for beats anymore
column6: and Preemo's own rudimentary stylistic tics have come to largely overwhelm the indefinable vision he once applied to them. That's what's going on in Get Used to Us
column7: a compilation that exists to highlight the roster of Preemo's new imprint Year Round Records. It's an hour of new DJ Premier beats
column8: a happy occasion even at this late date. But the lack of star-power on that roster just glares. As an instrumental album
column9: this would probably be pretty boring
column10: but it wouldn't be more boring than what we got.

column1: The best moments on Get Used to Us all come from old Premier buddies
column2: grizzled and semi-anonymous hardheads like Blaq Poet and NYGz
column3: whose voices have the sort of lived-in rasp that these tracks demand. On ""Rappin Exercise""
column4: NYGz member Panchi adapts a loping singsong
column5: which makes him the only guy on the whole album to have any fun with his delivery. The worst come from unctuous starstruck open-mic-night herb Nick Javas
column6: whose syntax is truly tortured and who can't stop letting us know how honored he is to be on a Premier track. ""Opportunity Knoccs""
column7: his first showcase
column8: is a skit blown out to song length
column9: and it actually derives its beat from Javas knocking on Premier's studio door to beg for an audition. (The second Javas track
column10: ""Not a Game""
column11: is made up entirely of clumsy sports metaphors
column12: since every song obviously has to have some halfassed unifying concept.) Another relative newcomer is Young Maylay
column13: best known as the voice of lead character CJ in Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas. He's an OK rapper
column14: but once you hear the CJ in his voice
column15: you can't unhear it; it causes an immediate sense-memory flashback to all those times you accidentally drove into the fucking ocean again.

column1: The biggest names on the album are guys like KRS-One and MC Eiht
column2: people who peaked 15 or 20 years ago and who have audibly deteriorated in the years since. Eiht is a particular disappointment. The Compton's Most Wanted veteran is supposedly working on a full-length with Premier
column3: an exciting idea until you hear the tracks that actually come out of it. Eiht thrives over slow-crawling cinematic beats
column4: and you'd think Premier would put a dip in his usual boom-bap to accommodate the man. But he doesn't
column5: and Eiht sounds lost. As recently as the last decade
column6: Premier was capable of smooth left-turns like Devin the Dude's ""Doobie Ashtray"" or Cee-Lo's ""Evening News"". But Get Used to Us shows a brilliant mind trapped in his own wheelhouse
column7:
unwilling or unable to do anything but crank out lesser versions of the sound that built his legend.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16096/homepage_large.d1de0c67.jpg|Grown Unknown|26469.0|Lia Ices|['Rock'

'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2011-01-27 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:34:57.468942|"

It's been more than two years since Brooklyn singer-songwriter Lia Ices let her debut record
column5: the frail Necima
column6: slip quietly into the world. She's stepped up a notch or two since
column7: inking a deal with indie-rock behemoths Jagjaguwar and recruiting Justin Vernon to provide a guest vocal turn on this album's second track
column8: ""Daphne"". There's also a more pliable approach this time around
column9: with Ices subtly contorting her core sound
column10: taciturn balladry
column11: to fold in meatier bursts of guitar and percussion. The key asset on Grown Unknown is her impressively supple voice
column12: which can spiral up into a giddy falsetto and fall crashing to the floor in dolorous rumination within a heartbeat-- although it's occasionally hampered by the uneven backing that Ices latches onto her vocal hankering.

column1: The salient difference between this album and the last is bound up in that vocal zigzagging
column2: which sounds less stiff and more relaxed than before
column3: with Ices mostly eschewing the Tori Amos/Joanna Newsom territory of her earlier recordings for a distinct tone of her own. The instrumentation ticks over at a funeral-paced cadence throughout
column4: but Grown Unknown never settles into a distinct pattern otherwise
column5: often making great stylistic leaps within single songs.

column1: When Ices indulges her avant leanings
column2: the material provides a more suitable foil for her voice. A mixture of finger snaps
column3: glinting piano
column4: and subdued organ provides a suitably artful backbone over which she hangs a touchingly forlorn vocal turn on ""Little Marriage""
column5: and there's a deft marrying of chamber music sadness and welts of distorted guitar on ""Bag of Wind"". But it's the standout title track that provides the most successful conduit for Ices' eclectic whims
column6: with a militaristic handclap and acoustic picking alongside feather-light string parts. Here Ices sounds relaxed
column7: locating a natural meeting point for her disparate sounds and easing into a vocal that effortlessly intertwines with the arrangement.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: the album continues in its asymmetrical way

Since early 2009
column2: the Baltimore-based cabaret-punk trio Celebration have been posting tracks from their new record
column3: Hello Paradise
column4: as free mp3s on their website. Donations are encouraged
column5: but not required. There is no record label advance funding the project. A friendly-looking smiley-faced ying-yang symbol sits to the side of the screen
column6: surrounded by the words
column7: ""Be cool. You make it worth our while."" It's one thing to throw fortune to the digital winds if you're a well-established arena-rocking band like
column8: say
column9: Radiohead. For Celebration-- who have a much more modest following-- financial and business incentives are less obvious. But listening to the completed Hello Paradise
column10: the creative payoff is clear.

column1: They tried it the traditional way first. Celebration released two albums-- 2005's Celebration and 2007's The Modern Tribe-- on major-indie 4AD. But four years of grinding tours
column2: press cycles
column3: and sales expectations withered Celebration's zeal. ""They offered a contract re-negotiation and we declined
column4: frontwoman Katrina Ford told the website Rockin' the Stove last December
column5: explaining the band's decision to leave label's roster. ""For us
column6: in the end
column7: the benefits did not outweigh the cost. The whole business bummed me out."" Stepping off of the music biz treadmill-- and giving up the exposure it  promises-- gave Celebration the space to become a better band
column8: distribute their music on their own
column9: and to take their time doing it.

column1: Unsurprisingly
column2: Hello Paradise is Celebration's most laid-back work to date. Songs unfurl at a measured pace
column3: riding head-bobbing rhythms and bluesy riffs through a low psychedelic haze. Their last record
column4: <i>The Modern Tribe
column5: was soaked in trippy textures. Producer Dave Sitek (TV on the Radio)-- brought forth headshop vibes by the bucketful. In every empty nook and cranny
column6: a set of wind chimes tinkled. As a result Celebration-- a herky-jerky and energetic live band-- came off flat and one-dimensional.

column1: Largely recorded and produced by the band itself
column2: Hello Paradise dials in the sonic soup at the right time
column3: rather than all the time. ""Battles"" uses a sparse intro to springboard into explosive
column4: Zeppelin-worthy
column5: Eastern-tinged riffage. ""Shelter"" builds from a stripped-down ballad into a wave of cheapo-synth-string romance. The anxious pummeling of the group's self-titled debut is long gone. Organist/guitarist Sean Antanaitis and drummer David Bergander play looser but more methodically
column6: throwing themselves fully into the record's reverb-drenched crescendos.

column1: But Ford makes the greatest breakthrough on Hello Paradise. Ten years ago
column2: fronting Love Life-- her former band with Antanaitis-- she was a brutish stage presence
column3: dressed in giant black boots
column4: grunting like a linebacker with a zeal for Nick Cave. On Hello Paradise Ford is
column5: undeniably
column6: a singer-- pushing the music forward
column7: using melodic embellishments to amp up the drama. On ""Junky"" she howls and warps words into strange shapes. But she's also gained confidence at conveying tender
column8: guarded emotions. Ford can be forceful and delicate
column9: frequently within the space of the same song.

column1: And it doesn't hurt that she sounds more defiant. ""I won't lay down and I won't play this harp anymore/ Odds are stacked/ Some love can bring you back/ If you choose
column2: sings Ford on ""I Will Not Fall"". With little hope of prolonging their career through traditional means
column3: Celebration had nobody but themselves to please with Hello Paradise. And
column4: somehow
column5:
that seems to have set the bar higher.

Here's a phrase I haven't heard too often: ""What the fuck was Kweli thinking?"" I know that as far as conscious-skewing MCs go
column3: Talib Kweli's had his share of detractors-- mostly people who consider him too reliant on pop-culture metaphors or just plain don't like his voice-- but he's never managed to stumble his way into alienating the audience he already has. And while he hasn't always been quite as breathlessly venerated as peers like Common or Mos Def
column4: he's also never dropped a Universal Mind Control or a True Magic
column5: a fanbase-disillusioning pratfall that lacks everything the faithful like about him. (At least
column6: not too prominently-- his one big detour
column7: the electro-damaged pastel-stripe-rap side project Idle Warship
column8: got one of those quietly promoted free-download releases in 2009
column9: the equivalent of a big-budget action movie released in mid-January.) If that means Talib Kweli has spent his solo career playing it safe
column10: it also means he's as close as there is to a sure bet in indie rap: He's even less likely to disappoint fans than he is to shake up their preconceptions.

column1: His latest release
column2: Gutter Rainbows
column3: is one of those artistically self-sufficient
column4: post-Internet records that's been created
column5: assembled
column6: and channeled through means completely independent of the mainstream record industry
column7: and yet it doesn't demonstrate a drastic change in Kweli's style at all. That probably says more about the relative freedom Kweli's had throughout his career than anything; when a solitary (and actually pretty good) will.i.am beat on Eardrum is the closest he's ever come to quote-unquote selling out
column8: creative control has never really seemed like an issue. And while there's an album in the works that Kweli has claimed will be a major departure from his usual lyrical persona-- the tellingly titled Prisoner of Consciousness-- Gutter Rainbows doesn't sound like a jaded effort from an artist who's dissatisfied with his normal routine.

column1: In short
column2: it's familiar without feeling rote. Kweli still takes criminal entrepreneurs and gun-clap talk to task with flippant punchline dismissals on the where-I'm-from title track
column3: still holds fast to his roots with a humble gratitude on ""Friends & Family""
column4: and still consistently makes being scholarly sound like a good way to throw your weight around. His learned
column5: nice-guy approach can switch over into good-natured ego-tripping when he wants to
column6: but it doesn't eclipse the sentimentality at his core. Sure
column7: Kweli brags about racking up frequent-flyer miles in Virgin Atlantic first class (""Mr. International"")
column8: but it's only so he can go overseas to connect with fans across the world. And even when he big-ups himself for his cocksmanship (""Ain't Waiting"")
column9: he can't help but put it in fairy-tale romantic terms that invoke Peter Pan and The Princess Bride. Yeah
column10: I know-- at least it's not in hashtag form.

column1: And besides
column2: everyone who hasn't been put off by Kweli's brushes with cue-the-rimshot corniness by now should recognize that he's had one of the more impressive lyrical-rapper flows going. If his metaphor/simile lyrics can be a mixed bag
column3: the way he unfolds them against the backing tracks-- throwing his bars off-kilter
column4: switching from casually conversational to elaborately virtuosic
column5: and tweaking his emphases mid-line-- is worth hearing just for the way he plays both with and against the rhythm
column6: a soloist where other voices are content to just riff.

column1: The beats on Gutter Rainbows are tight-enough neo-soul by committee-- 13 producers handle 14 tracks -- and most of it sounds like faintly modernized versions of Rawkus-circa-2002 boom-bap
column2: with the occasional outlier in the form of a post-""Hello Brooklyn"" old-school banger (Khrysis' ""I'm on One"") or atmospheric synthesizer dirge (Blaq Toven's ""How You Love Me""). But isolating the beats from the rapper seems futile; this is Kweli's most comfortable turf
column3:
and he clicks with it as an MC who works like an ensemble cast member. When it hits on all cylinders-- the Ski Beatz-produced gospel-soul piano avalanche of ""Cold Rain"" being the best of several highlights-- it's hard to blame him for sticking to what he knows.

column3: ""What to do for pleasure?"" on Gang of Four's epochal 1979 debut
column4: Entertainment!
column5: little did he realize that
column6: 32 years later
column7: he'd be answering his own question with: buy an Xbox 360 Kinect! But rather than undermine Gang of Four's ideological integrity
column8: the recent use of the song quoted above (""Natural's Not in It"") in a Microsoft gaming-console commercial marked a logical extension of it. Despite their Maoist fascinations and anger-is-an-energy fervor
column9: Gang of Four were always less interested in smashing storefronts than in exploring the anxiety of consumerism-- how a culture obsessed with status and acquisition reduces personal interaction to a transactional experience. And they did so not out of scorn for those who fuel the capitalist machine
column10: but to acknowledge their own complicity in it.

column1: So the seeming contradiction of Gang of Four hocking video games in 2011 is actually the perfect preamble to the unease and self-doubt expressed throughout Content
column2: the very title of which alludes to the process by which creativity is depersonalized into commodity. Content is the group's first album of new material since the Entertainment!-era band reunited in 2004 at the height of the post-millennial post-punk uprising
column3: and used the occasion to re-record their classic songs (on 2005 release Return the Gift) as a strategy of diverting royalties away from their former label EMI. But even with founding bassist Dave Allen and drummer Hugo Burnham stepping aside in recent years (replaced by Thomas McNeice and Mark Heaney
column4: respectively)
column5: Gang of Four have ironically remained more active than many of the post-punk progeny (the Rapture
column6: Radio 4
column7: Bloc Party) who brought them back into vogue.

column1: If Gang of Four's 2005 reformation proved they could more than hold their own against the upstarts
column2: then Content shows that their chief concerns-- the financial and psychological toll of keeping up with the Joneses-- resonate all the more loudly in an Internet-accelerated era where even those on the vanguard can feel behind the times
column3: and where the lawless
column4: anonymous nature of online exchange threatens to overwhelm our identities. It's thus fitting that the album's most exuberant moment-- the muscular Motown stomp ""Who Am I?""-- is used to soundtrack a modern-day anarchist's existential crisis: ""You can't steal when everything is free.""

column1: After spending the past few years performing only songs from the band's original 1979-82 catalog
column2: it's no surprise the new iteration of Gang of Four comes much closer to capturing that scabrous spirit-- mostly thanks to Andy Gill's still-potent guitar spasms-- than any other Go4 effort without Allen or Burnham (1983's Hard
column3: 1991's Mall
column4: 1995's Shrinkwrapped). ""You Don't Have to Be Mad"" is essentially an aged update of ""Natural's Not in It""
column5: complete with a similar desperately-seeking-leisure theme and a mid-song breakdown where the rhythm section drops out and King and Gill engage in call-and-response warfare; ""I Party All the Time"" strips ""I Love a Man in Uniform"" of its 80s production gloss but keeps the female back-up singers and sardonic humor.

column1: But the band that brought the funk to punk isn't in much of a dancing mood here. Where the early Gang of Four were defined by the oppositional tension between Gill's messy bent-string squiggles and the air-tight
column2: authoritative rhythm section
column3: McNeice and Heaney play a mostly subservient role to Gill
column4: matching the guitarist's Morse-code communiqués with clipped
column5: off-kilter accents. As such
column6: there's a pervading feel of restraint to the album-- especially compared to the ferocity on display during those 2005-2006 tours. It's as if the defeatism running through King's lyric sheet has infected the performances
column7: while the vocoderized spoken-word set piece ""It Was Never Gonna Turn Out Too Good"" threatens to completely kill the momentum on album that only sporadically accrues it. King and Gill's spirited interplay and their obvious commitment to the Gang of Four cause keep Content from becoming the assembly-line product its title signifies
column8: but for all its jagged edges
column9:
Content too rarely goes for the jugular.

column3: overwrought emotional extremes. ""Skip the Charades"" confidently runs with a metaphor so face-palmingly silly

Jim Thirlwell was always on the outside

column1: Early Foetus records

column10: pallid piano bar balladeering set against the Carl Stalling zaniness of Hide's more operatic vocal work.

column1: Listening to Hide

can be just another route to delirium.

column3: Sam Beam reinvented Iron & Wine
column4: building out the whisper-quiet acoustic songs he'd made his name on into a strange and mysterious soundworld
column5: using a full band and mastering the art of multitracking his own voice. It's tempting to think that the hard work was done there-- Beam established a new approach and made a great album in the process-- but Kiss Each Other Clean
column6: the full-band follow-up
column7: is in some ways even more ambitious than its predecessor. He's reaching in a few new directions here
column8: pushing himself hard as a singer
column9: and taking risks
column10: some of which pan out and a few of which don't.

column1: Broadly
column2: Beam at this point is writing by far the most assertive melodies of his career. Not the best
column3: necessarily
column4: but the boldest and most forcefully phrased. Even the song that most clearly ties back to The Shepherd's Dog
column5: album centerpiece ""Rabbit Will Run""
column6: has a melody that's quite different from anything he's done before. ""Rabbit Will Run"" is an easy highlight-- the arrangement is fantastically detailed
column7: driven by a heavily layered rhythm track that bubbles with hypnotic thumb piano
column8: and balanced by sections where the rhythm drops out

It's a weirdly intoxicating mix that exemplifies the imagination Beam brings to bear on his fuller sound-- he's not just putting some drums and bass behind his guitar and voice.

column1: Some of his bolder decisions carry mixed results. Beam brings in a horn section on ""Big Burned Hand"" and ""Your Fake Name Is Good Enough For Me""
column2: and it works well on the latter
column3: the album's seven-minute closer. The horns are arranged loosely
column4: responding a bit to the Tinariwen-ish guitar phrase that opens the song and pulling it into territory somewhere near Charles Mingus' ""Haitian Fight Song"". The horn scrum is nicely offset by Beam's layered
column5: tight self-harmonies on the chorus
column6: and it's also complemented by the ragged lead guitar part. On ""Big Burned Hand""
column7: though
column8: the honking sax is used as a device to try and make the song funky
column9: and it's not a look Beam's really figured out yet-- it lumbers along for four minutes and is the one song where Beam's risks yield no reward.

column1: The more elemental and important change
column2: though
column3: is how Beam sings these songs. On ""Glad Man Singing""
column4: his voice is still a soft instrument
column5: but he's really projecting
column6: both on the lead and the backing harmonies he layers in behind himself. On ""Me and Lazarus""
column7: he reverts to the unique whisper-plus-falsetto layering technique he perfected on The Shepherd's Dog and ""Woman King""
column8: and as signature sounds go
column9: it's a good one that sounds even more distinct when he contrasts it with the other approaches. There are places on the album where the mix of rhythm and electric piano reminds me of Still Crazy After All These Years-era Paul Simon
column10: a writer whose scope is reminiscent of what Beam is now trying to bring to his work.

column1: Kiss Each Other Clean isn't quite on the level of The Shepherd's Dog in terms of overall unity of vision. Oddly
column2: even with Beam's generally bolder singing
column3: it's also not quite as immediately striking. These songs are generally not the type to grab you right away
column4: but there's enough mystery and melody there to call you back. It's an album that takes its time seeping in

and it's ultimately worth putting in the close listening that reveals its many details and delights.

column3: Dylan Baldi-- the young
column4: bespectacled face and brains behind  Cleveland power-pop outfit Cloud Nothings-- was gearing up for two  simultaneous releases: a delicious new 7"" single and a  wide-release compilation that wrangled together nearly every other hook  he had burned to cassette
column5: vinyl
column6: or CD-R in the year before. While both  shared remarkably strong songwriting
column7: said single was recorded  without much of the fuzz and distortion that enveloped his work up  until that point. The difference was huge. Baldi's home-recorded hooks  had never been hard to hear
column8: but out in the open
column9: free of that lo-fi  asterisk
column10: they thrived. Breaks were crisp
column11: turnarounds hit like  boomerangs
column12: and every sweet
column13: tightly coiled melody could be savored in  full. In the lead-up to this
column14: his first full-length in wide-release
column15: Baldi hinted that he'd continue to clarify his recordings. He stuck to his guns.

column1: The result is another fantastic step forward
column2: though  not without some growing pains. In the transition from basement to studio
column3: one  component has yet to come into full focus: Baldi's voice. The gap  between those sounds coming from his hands and those from his mouth is  noticeable. The opening five-song blast
column4: as exhilarating an assemblage  of tracks as he's ever strung together
column5: provides a useful chart of his  comfort level now that his voice is completely uncovered. Within the  insanely hummable
column6: sometimes gummy verses of opener ""Understand At All""
column7: you can hear Baldi's voice originate just at his throat
column8: where the screams of ""Not  Important"" hail. And while the latter motions toward the  skittering Midwestern pop-punk of the Promise Ring and recently reunited  Get Up Kids as much as Buzzcocks
column9: its final gasp echoes (as though  in tribute) that of Wavves' Nathan Williams
column10: another former lo-fi kid  who's made impressive use of the studio. ""Should Have""  opts however for the suburbs instead of the beach and the unabashed  melodicism of Gin Blossoms over Nirvana
column11: Baldi's voice moving even  lower. Once ""Forget You All the Time"" arrives
column12: he sounds as strong and confident behind the mic as he does unspooling all those gorgeous strands of guitar.

column1: That quick trip downward from mouth to core doesn't speak directly to the quality of each song
column2: but it does their overall delivery. When  ""Nothing's Wrong"" and its torrent of sugars and stutters begins just  seconds after
column3: the shift in pitch and pace can be jarring. That feeling  isn't unusual throughout. Cloud Nothings' pop has become deceptively  dense-- there is literally (and paradoxically) so much hook to be found  here from corner to corner that
column4: unlike similarly
column5: ostensibly simple  records
column6: multiple listens are required to appreciate the taste of all  its herks and jerks. In the late sear of ""Been Through""
column7: Baldi hits a  lasting sweet spot. It's a song that moves swiftly and forcefully
column8: the  calm vocal at its center not just its equal
column9:
but also the sort you hear when you first wake up any number of mornings thereafter.

Anyone looking for common threads that bind together the work of Phil Manley
column2: whether it be in his 20-year stint in Trans Am
column3: occasional appearances with Oneida
column4: or his engineering duties with stargazers like Arp
column5: Moon Duo
column6: and Wooden Shjips
column7: would most likely settle on a mixture of ever-repeating krautrock grooves and the eternal space mapped out by electronic pioneers bracketed under the kosmische musik banner. So it's appropriate that his debut solo record serves as a sort of tribute to Conny Plank
column8: the legendary German producer who had a hand in refining both the combustible grooves of Neu! and Can and more free-floating approach of Cluster and early Kraftwerk.

column1: Those influences are keenly felt within the first 30 seconds of Life Coach's opening track
column2: ""FT2 Theme""
column3: which knots a spidery Michael Rother-inspired guitar line to a plodding electro groove and vast sheets of vintage synth sounds. It's similar to the kind of retro-futurist feel that Trans Am have mastered over their expansive career. The difference is that the joints are a little more exposed here
column4: with Manley delving into outright homage instead of using his influences as a touchstone from which he can spin off onto his own unique path. As such
column5: aficionados of Life Coach's most obvious inspirations will likely get a kick out of playing a game of spot the influence
column6: whether it's drawn from the cyclical bliss of Manuel Göttsching's E2-E4 (on ""Night Visions"")
column7: or the nuanced ambient passages that unfurl on Harmonia's 1976 opus Tracks & Traces (on ""Forest Opening Theme"").

column1: So
column2: there isn't a great degree of originality at work here
column3: and Manley is certainly backward-looking in his approach. But it's a testament to his abilities that he is able to eke out compelling riffs and affecting spells of creativity from music that is perilously close to being over saturated as source material. The listless acoustic riff that coils throughout ""Lawrence
column4: KS"" is one such moment
column5: where Manley shifts his attention forward a few decades and hits on the kind of unshakable ennui David Pajo bled into Papa M's Live From a Shark Cage. Similarly
column6: ""Work It Out"" is built around a towering expanse of guitar noise that veers close to Neil Young's Arc experiments
column7: where form and function acquiesce to a kind of primitive
column8: guttural euphoria.

column1: The only vocal turn here is on ""Gay Bathers""
column2: a brief freak-folk-inspired cut that works as a prelude to the ceaseless loops of ""Night Visions""
column3: which in turn gives way to a closing title track that neatly bookends the album by returning to a similar well of inspiration (a bubbling synth spine layered with treated guitars) as its opening song. Life Coach is likely to be a small footnote in Manley's career
column4: albeit one that allowed him to exorcise a few krautrock demons. It's to his credit that he never seems too in awe of his most obvious antecedents
column5: instead simply choosing to flex his own capabilities within the tight constraints that musicians like Rother
column6: Hans-Joachim Roedelius
column7: and Dieter Moebius have operated within for decades. Still
column8:
it's a shame Manley didn't choose to filter more of his own ideas into the myriad eulogies on offer here.

Zs are better suited to remixing than a lot of avant-rock bands because their compositions feel less like songs that need to be carefully picked apart and reassembled than raw chunks of sound ready to be manhandled in new ways. And I mean often literally raw chunks of sound. Unlike many of their once ultra-skronky underground peers who've since smartened up their sound
column2: Zs music has grown expansive while retaining its harder-than-the-rest harshness.

column1: Zs' play no wave with most of the remaining rock dynamited away
column2: avant-classical delivered with noise-punk's fuck-you-all force
column3: drone with a rusty eardrum-slicing edge. Even the calm moments of Zs' albums are more eye-of-the-storm than actual respites. So what's surprising about these remixes
column4: jumping off from 2010's New Slaves
column5: the band's most varied album yet
column6: is how many of them reshape Zs' gales of blare into music that might appeal to those who look for more music in their music.

column1: Not to say it's all suddenly accessible. Weasel Walter's typically skin-peeling screech and blat sounds like he's once again unleashed the free jazz hounds of hell. Thee Majesty's take on ""Concert Black"" is like an old computer on its last legs
column2: motor whining on and off as it hacks up pitiful little data-farts. Of course that's what you'd expect from a Zs' remix album
column3: which doesn't make it any less enjoyable. If you're buying New Slaves Part II
column4: you're probably wanting a little horribleness in your day. But more than one of these remixers take a more beautiful (like Ecstatic Sunshine's slow-burning
column5: almost Tortoise-ish post-rock guitar treatment) or beat-centric approach
column6: sometimes straying into outright dance music.

column1: Ragged rhythms occasionally surface in Zs' music
column2: like the claustrophobic scrapyard gamelan on the original ""Acres of Skin"" from New Slaves
column3: but their music wouldn't fit even the broadest definition of ""house."" The comforting
column4: body-friendly pulse of pop is always under attack in Zs' world
column5: always ready to shatter into arrhythmia. Yet here's Gabe Andruzzi fashioning the textural elements (always a Zs' strong suit) of ""Acres"" into a humid techno track more Tresor club hit than No New York. These total overhauls won't give newbies much of a sense of what Zs' are all about
column6: but then are remix comps ever really for newbies? For those who've found joy in the pain of Zs' forbidding industrial sprawl
column7: consider the more radical rewrites on New Slaves Part II a little peek into what a more traditionally pleasure-centric
column8:
alternate-universe version of the band might be like.

By the band's own explanation

column4: Return of the Century plays less like a biographical concept album and more like a series of tough-minded break-up songs that paint their vocalists as emotionally and sexually candid
column5: if not occasionally even callous. ""If life was lonely then I'd be blessed
column6: sings Jeanine O'Toole on ""Lay a Ghost""
column7: ""if that was all I missed."" These aren't life-changing relationships they're singing about. In fact
column8: they're barely worth the time

column1: In that regard
column2: the 1900s recall another musician who many say has been missing for years: Liz Phair
column3: whose Exile in Guyville was full of similar postcoital postmortems set in Chicago. She was
column4: of course
column5: much more explicit than the 1900s
column6: whose lyrics are veiled and often playfully obscure

column8: he smartly leaves these songs coyly open-ended

Standout ""Tucson"" recalls a road trip through the Southwest and its fallout: ""I'm not so sorry that I took you along

column6: Cold & Kind (whose title still applies)

column8: alternately underscoring and undercutting O'Toole's pleas
column9: and on ""Bmore"" they all click into a tight showtune groove anchored by Charlie Ransford's bass. ""Overreactin'"" opens with heavy breathing and chintzy boudoir beats

column12: catchy
column13:
and deceptively cheery pop.

'Dead Oceans']|2011-01-24 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:35:06.376381|"

Every era has a sound. When considering this
column3: it can be easy to forget that the sound developed as a way to express something. Music heard as kitsch years later was once put forth with complete sincerity. I mention this in connection with Kaputt
column4: the new record from Dan Bejar's Destroyer
column5: because the first thing that strikes you about the album is its unusual sound
column6: one for which we've all developed a cluster of associations. The production and arrangements evoke a narrow window of time-- sometime between
column7: say
column9: or between Chuck Mangione's ""Feels So Good"" and Sade's Diamond Life with stops along the way for Roxy Music's Avalon and Steely Dan's Gaucho. It slides between soft rock
column10: smooth jazz
column11: and new romantic pop. The bass is fretless; the synths have the blocky contrast of a Nagel painting; there are heavily reverbed trumpets and saxophones that almost serve as a Greek chorus
column12: trilling away at the end of every line to enforce the beautiful plasticity of these songs. For Destroyer
column13: this sound is new
column14: and it's there for a reason.

column1: The sound casts Bejar's songs in a very particular light
column2: and reinforces the feeling of the singer as persona. Bejar has always come across this way to varying degrees
column3: sure
column4: and his albums all have their own unique feel-- the rootsy art-pop of Destroyer's Rubies
column5: the MIDI experiments of Your Blues
column6: and so on. But here the persona seems even more sharply defined. Singing these songs
column7: Bejar comes over as the wizened ex-playboy; he's indulged every vice
column8: come through the other side
column9: and now looks on amused. The cover of Leonard Cohen's Death of a Ladies' Man
column10: a record that seems to serve as a spiritual (though not sonic) father to this one
column11: shows this figure in its quintessential form. On that sleeve
column12: we see a man in sharp but slightly disheveled dress
column13: a cigarette dangling from a couple of fingers; beautiful people are seated at the nightclub table
column14: ready for another night of glamor and pleasure.

column1: Leonard Cohen in that image has a sense of swagger
column2: and you want to pull up a chair
column3: have a drink
column4: and hear him hold forth on the topic of his choice. The figure inside the songs of Kaputt understands the allure of this life while understanding equally its futility. On early listens
column5: a couple of lines from the title track jump out and seem to serve as a thesis for the record as a whole. ""Wasting your days chasing some girls
column6: alright/ Chasing cocaine through the backrooms of the world all night
column7: Bejar sings
column8: as horns twist around in a bath of reverb. He sounds bemused
column9: but not necessarily judgmental
column10: holding two feelings in mind at once: our reflex to indulge ourselves
column11: and the knowledge that it's killing us.

column1: But this happens on just one level
column2: which is what makes Kaputt so fantastic. It goes as deep as you want to go. People can miss that Dan Bejar is funny as hell-- he seeds his music with lyrical and musical in-jokes
column3: and everyone has their own favorite lines to pluck out of his songs and admire for their concise wit. He likes surprises-- few lyric sheets have as many exclamation points. But the essential quality of all his records is complexity. They are doing a lot of things at once. Kaputt feels rich.

column1: For one
column2: there is the surface beauty of the sound. Some less inclined to the pleasures of the music from the aforementioned era might have an initial reaction to its essential corniness
column3: but once you've tuned in
column4: it sounds beautiful. The songs seem delicate and glassy and shimmering
column5: and Bejar has toned down his quirky voice and sounds relaxed and focused. So it's easy to enjoy bumping the wet
column6: jazzy pop of ""Chinatown""
column7: which suggests the rainy streets of an old city and new dramas unfolding around every corner. Or wallow in the simple and elegant hook of ""Blue Eyes""
column8: the way Bejar voice works next to Vancouver singer Sibel Thrasher
column9: a regular vocal presence on Kaputt who sort of serves as the Nicolette Larson to Bejar's Neil Young. But ""Blue Eyes"" also has sly lyrical references (""your first love's new order
column10: ""Mother Nature's Son"") and funny put-downs (""I sent a message in a bottle to the press/ It said
column11: 'Don't be ashamed or disgusted with yourselves'""). More than any other Destroyer record
column12: you can just throw this on and it sounds good
column13: and plenty will do well stopping there. But for those so inclined
column14: there's more to explore.

column1: So the lite-jazz style can seem a little funny
column2: but it can also be sad and sexy and joyous. And the writing is dense with references-- to other songs on the album
column3: songs by other bands
column4: to the music business
column5: art outside the sphere of music. ""Suicide Demo for Kara Walker"" is the most striking example. It's a collaboration with the artist Kara Walker
column6: whose work
column7: among other things
column8: probes the racial history of America. Bejar adapted the words she provided for him on cue cards
column9: and the result is fragmented and dream-like
column10: taking the Destroyer project to a new place. ""Wise
column11: old
column12: black and dead in the snow: My Southern sister..."" isn't the sort of thing we've heard from him before. An early demo of the song reminded Bejar of the band Suicide
column13: hence the title. That's how things work in his world. Laughs are mixed with grim insights.

column1: Two tracks stick out a bit here. The astonishing ""Bay of Pigs""
column2: released as a single in 2009
column3: concludes the CD version of this album
column4: and it's the one song that feels out of place. It's longer
column5: proggy
column6: uses different textures
column7: and ultimately seems to be here because it's an amazing song and as many people as possible need to hear it. Fair enough. And the vinyl version of Kaputt also has a side-long
column8: 20-minute ambient track with just a bit of voice called ""The Laziest River""
column9: which is enjoyable and immersive but not essential. Both indulgences are easily forgivable.

column1: Bands can be brands or concepts that can be summed up in a line or two-- which is the power of brands. It's a good thing in proper doses. But Bejar's essential complexity ultimately feels human. It seems absurd to look for genuine wisdom in music in 2011
column2: when we're constantly gorging ourselves on the all-you-can-eat buffet of post-modern web culture. But Kaputt feels wise. Like a mirror that actually points back at something better. Something you can jam and let wash over you
column3: but also something you can use. It feels funny
column4: tragic
column5: artful
column6:
and ultimately true.

Perhaps no band has gone further to disassociate itself from emo than the Get Up Kids
column3: which shouldn't be a huge surprise: Their brand of pining pop-punk
column4: which became the predominant sound of early-2000s alternative rock
column5: was probably more despised by punk and indie kids than any other chart-toppers at the time-- post-Disney pop
column6: nu-metal
column7: big beat electronica. No one got it worse than the Get Up Kids
column8: attacked with the vigor of a scene that finally got to pick on someone its own size. Existing somewhere between the Promise Ring and Jimmy Eat World-- but lacking the former's jittery roots and the latter's obvious pop ambitions-- they once worked with Bob Weston (Mission of Burma
column9: Shellac) and chose not to leave Vagrant
column10: and yet somehow an air of dishonesty was projected on them. Considering they were just some guys from Kansas City who wanted to write songs called ""Anne Arbour"" and cover Mötley Crüe
column11: I'm not sure the churlish punishment fits the crime.

column1: There Are Rules isn't a return to form sonically-- neither to the limp
column2: acoustic bowouts of On a Wire or Guilt Show nor to the eager-to-please effervescence of Something to Write Home About-- but a return to results
column3: a just-all-right record from a band that always felt a step behind even in their own genre. The announcement that Weston was brought back in certainly perked some ears
column4: but anyone expecting his gnarly edge to improve much on their material is destined to be disappointed. ""Tithe"" and ""Birmingham"" are the most obvious beneficiaries of Weston's imprimatur
column5: and they snarl more than anything the Get Up Kids have done in the past. But these dudes just can't do menace
column6: in large part because Matthew Pryor's vocals are the literal embodiment of ""snotty
column7: emanating almost completely from his nostrils.

column1: What they can do is momentarily remold themselves in the form of borderline-emo go-getters Hot Hot Heat on spasmodic word puzzles ""Automatic"" and ""Pararelevant""
column2: or regain some of their caffeinated buzz on ""Regent's Court"". And though they have dabbled in synth-pop before
column3: ""Shatter Your Lungs"" is a legitimate surprise-- Pryor's vocals soften and let the tumbling melody come to him rather than force it
column4: hinting at the sort of maturity There Are Rules should have aimed for.

column1: The title of the album's closer
column2: ""Rememorable""
column3: proves to be pretty ironic
column4: considering they completely forget what made them popular in the first place: the hooks. There Are Rules drags toward its middle
column5: relying more on repetition than snappy melodies for growth: ""Rally 'Round the Fool"" feigns importance with the sort of vague paranoia and electro dabbling that characterized alt-rock's post-OK Computer obsession
column6: followed by a run of three songs that do little else but allow Rob Pope's grinding bass riffs to drill fruitlessly for paydirt.

column1: Gone are the band's geographic puns and tales of the romantic rigors of college freshman
column2: but they're replaced by a professional anonymity that kinda sums up the problem with There Are Rules: When you spent the prime of your career trying to document the contours of post-teen torment
column3: what happens when you no longer have a first-hand view? Get Up Kids likely don't have an answer because none of their peers did either: Jimmy Eat World soldiered on with drastically diminishing returns
column4: Saves the Day alienated almost their entire fanbase with the surprisingly sophisticated pop of In Reverie
column5: the Promise Ring broke up
column6: Hey Mercedes were dead on arrival post-Braid
column7: and Dashboard Confessional just sort of became something beyond judgment. For those of us who spent the tumult of our teen years with their records
column8:
we can hear the Get Up Kids and just think of them kindly.

Before I listened to Not Yet
column2: Monotonix's third album for Drag City
column3: I thought I might actually be able to review it without mentioning the Israeli trio's circus-style live act. After all
column4: their previous two records were surprisingly good for a band known more for spectacle than their music

column1: You can tell by now how that worked out. It turns out that Not Yet is an apt title for this collection of unambitious grunge-punk tunes. Monotonix remain beholden to the kind of churning
column2: muscular groove carved out by the Stooges and Mudhoney. There's no doubt they're good disciples-- Singer Ami Shalev's howl rises and falls with guitarist Yonatan Gat's thick riffs and drummer Haggai Fershtman's punching beats. Every song is pretty enjoyable
column3: but none is all that memorable. The grinding riff of ""Before I Pass Away""
column4: the Mudhoney swing of ""Fun Fun Fun""
column5: and the dramatic echoes of ""Late Night"" sound good when they're happening. But I'm more likely to remember the time I saw Shalev jump off a balcony than to hum any of these tunes from memory.

column1: Which points out an odd paradox with Monotonix: If they're so into chaos when performing
column2: why do their records sound so rote? Live
column3: Shalev never lets anything get in the way of whatever crazy physical move leaps into his head. Yet he and his bandmates allow each song to stick to its opening riff and beat
column4: playing so by-the-numbers that surprises are basically non-existent. Monotonix could stand to let go sonically-- take some left turns
column5: mash up conflicting beats
column6: devolve into noise
column7: play something ""wrong."" They certainly have the energy to go a little crazy musically; no one can say Monotonix lack physical effort on Not Yet. But to get people to care as much about listening to them as witnessing their live shows
column8:
it's time to work on the muscles of their imagination.

column5: however

Ashley Beedle's ""Afrikanz on Marz"" remix of ""Coulibaly"" captures the spirit of the original more than Akon's take
column6: essentially retrofitting it as modern disco

column3:

for better or for worse.

In May 2010
column2: when homemade indie pop of every stripe was deep in the throes of its baffling obsession with the beach
column3: a new band was taking the music to the next logical place: the open sea. Tennis
column4: we learned
column5: were a married boy-girl duo from Denver
column6: and their earliest circulated mp3s came with an odd story. After finishing college in Colorado
column7: the couple sold their possessions
column8: bought a sailboat
column9: and embarked on an extended trip along the Eastern Seaboard. After returning to land
column10: they began to write and record songs based on their experiences. Their music
column11: as heard here on their full-length debut
column12: touches on tide patterns and shifting winds and sandbars scraping beneath hulls; it also emphasizes the essential romance of the whole adventure-- that they went through it all together. Above all
column13: Tennis strive to evoke an unnamed but certainly more innocent past.

column1: Everything about the project comes to us through a thick
column2: triple-folded blanket of nostalgia. From the band's name (a sport that had its peak popularity in the 1970s and 80s) to the overall sound (girl-group pop is the basic template) to the record's cover to the choice of font
column3: it all seems to yearn for one bygone day or another-- the 60s
column4: the 80s
column5: those seven months they spent on the water. The musical structures are straightforward
column6: led by simple guitar lines and rhythms that are either waltz-time invitations to slow dance or more upbeat numbers with the familiar 1-2-pause-3 beat (think the Shirelles' ""Will You Love Me Tomorrow""
column7: the Chiffons' ""One Fine Day""
column8: etc.) so evocative of when Brill Building songwriters ruled the airwaves. The muffled recording
column9: on the other hand
column10: might be an attempt to capture the feel of a cheap AM radio spilling out of a bungalow
column11: but it mostly serves to make the music sound distant and indistinct.

column1: Tennis have a good ear for a tune and a solid understanding of how pop songs in this style fit together. The finger-snap-and-voice opening of ""Marathon"" has an appealingly peppy hook
column2: the guitar twang in ""Long Boat Pass"" is of the proper vintage
column3: and the melody on ""South Carolina"" has a nice build to the chorus break. Alaina Moore sings lead and has a likable voice
column4: though her way of stretching vowels
column5: when combined with the dull recording
column6: sometimes makes the words hard to follow. Still
column7: in single-song doses
column8: the music on Cape Dory is pleasant
column9: if not particularly memorable or expressive of anything in particular.

column1: The problem comes when the music is taken at album length. Even though these 10 songs clock in at less than 30 minutes
column2: their cumulative effect is weirdly numbing. Part of it is up to the central conceit: An extended getaway on a sloop is nice enough image
column3: but is the allure of this one fantasy enough to sustain a record? Not when there is so little personality emanating from the songs themselves. Say what you will about Jimmy Buffett
column4: an artist most people I know consider to be among the most loathsome of the modern popular era
column5: but his tales of island hopping and boat drinks have a sense of humor and an identifiable point of view. Tennis
column6: conversely
column7: seem content to hit their marks
column8: replicate an established style
column9: and let the associations that come with a familiar sound do the emotional work. Bizarrely
column10: considering the detailed and unique backstory
column11: which describes something these two went through and which most of us will never experience even if we wanted to
column12: Cape Dory comes over as a depersonalized exercise. It seems too concerned about transmitting a very specific sound and getting all the nautical details right. So while the record is pretty and intermittently enjoyable
column13:
it feels one-note and ultimately flat.

The liner notes to the Jayhawks' career-making 1992 album
column2: Hollywood Town Hall

column6: but presumably what the music was about: wayward drifters with sad histories who disappeared
column7: hitting the road in search of better times. The Jayhawks were never so down on their luck as their characters

column10: they stayed on the road almost constantly
column11: paying their dues and gradually playing to larger and larger audiences. They were alt-country merely by coincidence
column12: gestating in isolation and predating the movement by several years. The band incorporated a wide range of styles and influences into their stately Americana
column13: not just country and certainly not punk

column15: folk

column1: What the Jayhawks never drifted toward was success-- at least not the kind that they and their fans felt the music warranted. Even so
column2: a full 25 years after forming
column3: the Jayhawks don't come across as also-rans

column6: long-awaited reissues sound like the logical conclusions of a legacy-shaping campaign that began with 2009's career retrospective

column10: devising new ways to combine roots and rock without skimping on either.

column1: Hollywood Town Hall is

column7: more experimental tack. The band tinkers with some new sounds and ideas-- some of which are revelatory

column2: this Tomorrow reissue sprawls with a second disc of bonus tracks
column3: comprised of what have become known among fans as the Mystery Demos. A collection of acoustic run-throughs whose origins were until recently unknown
column4: they feature Louris and Olson tackling a career's worth of songs on acoustic guitar

column13:
an alt-universe greatest hits that sums up the group's appeal as persuasively as any of their proper albums. It's kind of funny that this London band used to be called Fear of Flying
column3: inasmuch as it's possible to find anything funny about White Lies. Fuck merely flying-- these guys want to soar
column4: to be godlike observers proudly watching their music soundtrack the biggest moments of your life. One of the tracks here is called ""The Power and the Glory""
column5: and it sounds exactly like you think it does
column6: i.e.
column7: more needlessly grandiose than both Kanye songs combined. Problem is
column8: for the second straight album

column1: I will say that lead singer Harry McVeigh might be just someone incapable of feeling shame rather than someone who has no idea what his own lyrics even mean. Cringe-inducing lines like
column2: ""You were crying on the shoulders of the men in the shadows/ Whoever taught you to sell your sex like that?"" pop up with alarming regularity
column3: but what makes this most confusing of all is its context in the sort of empathy-rock that's supposed to cue Pavlovian handholding and liplocking amongst concertgoers. Which is why I should tip my cap to Ritual highlight ""Streetlights"" which at least is such an obvious rip of ""Cars"" that you feel thankful they sound like someone other than White Lies for a few minutes.

column1: Otherwise
column2: you've lived through Glasvegas and such
column3: so you should know the drill by now: guitars whoosh and whir to sound exactly like synthesizers while the actual synthesizer goo provides the empty calories required for nearly every track on Ritual to reach its completely arbitrary five-minute length. The constant hi-hats and thrumming bass are meant to imply some sense of urgent momentum
column4: and the inevitable half-time chorus lets McVeigh over-sing even more. Take all these ingredients
column5: mix them together
column6: and voila-- instant UK buzzband. Hey
column7: I don't make the rules.

column1: I mean really
column2: why White Lies? What vacuum did nature abhor that much? Maybe it's the one where the relatively smaller dimensions of the UK make it possible to believe that typical rock bands can become arena-filling gods from their first single. But in the past two decades
column3: the search for the new Radiohead begat the search for the new Coldplay begat the search for the new Libertines begat the search for the new Franz Ferdinand
column4:
and now here we are hoping that someone can perhaps fill the gaping void that would occur if Editors decide to pack it up tomorrow.

There's a great story and an even better idea behind In the Cool of the Day. Not too long ago
column2: Kentucky-born singer-songwriter Daniel Martin Moore rolled through WXVU Radio in Cincinnati to play a studio session and give an interview. Totally routine. But when Moore sat down at the old Steinway piano they kept in-house

column5: for whatever reason
column6: brought it all home.

column1: Moore did something smart here: Rather than record straight covers of these songs
column2: he tried to arrange and play them impressionistically
column3: as he remembered them and as shaped by his feelings on spirituality now. In addition
column4: he contributed four similarly inspired gospels songs of his own. The result is a very warm
column5: very welcoming entry point for anyone interested in the gospel tradition. Though this album doesn't remain entirely faithful to the original source material's every layer

column4: mystical

column6: and though the feel is loose
