column1: Shuffles like ""In the Garden"" or Moore's take on Jean Ritchie's ""In the Cool of the Day"" are fully reclined and although they've got a great energy
column2: those songs with a bit more shadow stand out the most. And with the exception of the mandolin-and banjo-laced ""Up Above My Head""
column3: the majority of those songs were authored by Moore. One minute opener ""All Ye Tenderhearted"" is a brief acoustic inhale whose beauty is matched again
column4: but only by the piano and hush of Moore's ""O My Soul"". Lyrically he stitches everything up quietly by referencing the titles and themes of other songs found here
column5: the latter's chorus a nod to the same Jean Ritchie track noted above.

column1: In that vein
column2: the arrangements here are also uniformly gorgeous. But the conceptual framework is a much harder sell considering the Christian backdrop. Personally
column3: I didn't grow up in a house where faith or religion played much of a role
column4: save for a reason for Mom and Dad to argue at dinner (she's Catholic
column5: he's Methodist). But religious music was never a hot button issue
column6: and at no point does this
column7: Moore's latest
column8: feel like anything other than an honest expression of love. And
column9: to close like a nerd as much as anything else: this isn't a headphones listen. It's music with which to fill a room or
column10: even better
column11:
a home.

column3: a part often leaps out as shorthand for the whole-- the singer's voice

column5: or a melodic phrase. As other parts come into definition over time

column7: a track that we reviewed last February
column8: is a scarcer breed. From the first listen
column9: you can take it in entirely. There's just a patiently elongated voice
column10: a few shifting lyrics
column11: and a C Major scale arcing up over and over. The scale begins at middle C
column12: the eye of the keyboard
column13: but a couple of slowly revolving chords in a lower octave create external pressure. The lyrics address the storm outside as if it were a house
column14: ""so unbearably quiet."" The song's title
column15: instrumentation
column16: and words are all stabilized on a single conceptual base
column17: but stability is undermined by the uneven tempo.

column1: Appropriately for someone named after a poem
column2: Lady Lazarus is all about the essential
column3: a category that has not included a record label
column4: a notable scene
column5: or much of a public presence. I found out about her when her brother emailed me a brief ""RIYL Beach House"" message. I could hear some Beach House in her MySpace demos
column6: though they reminded me more of early Cat Power or a folksier Grouper. I learned that her name was Melissa Ann Sweat; she lived in San Jose (though has since moved to Georgia) and was working on a proper album. The demos were mostly loose refrains played with a lot of feeling
column7: wreathed in reverb and tape hiss. There was something very natural yet cloistered about the music.

column1: I really liked the songs as they were
column2: and worried that the hazy
column3: magical feeling would be lost in ""better"" recordings. Melissa Ann Sweat had the same concern. She started to polish up Mantic
column4: her debut LP
column5: in a San Jose studio but found the results more ""cold and clinical"" than the home recordings
column6: and she went back to her Fostex four-track. It was the right choice. She plays the atmosphere as much as the song
column7: mostly with a reverb-drenched Yamaha electric keyboard on the grand-piano setting. On songs like ""Took in My Diamond Heart""
column8: overtones gather and beat in elusive patterns around several alternating notes
column9: and every part of the music feels responsive to the moment.

column1: Had Sweat gone with a studio version of Mantic

column3: rather than textural accumulation. The same can't be said of ""Immortal Youth""
column4: which seems mostly an excuse to try out the thumb-piano. But it makes sense in this context

column6: ""Twilight on a Steinway"" in her employer's living room. People
column7: though

column10: it doesn't feel like an idle question. Mantic thrives on the sense of being alone with the last voice in the world. Lots of people use music to try and escape their living rooms

but Lady Lazarus seems more interested in inviting us into hers.

There are dreams
column2: there are nightmares
column3: and then there are those night visions that don't quite qualify as either

column5: forgotten details every time you pick at them. That's the kind of stuff we need to be talking about if we're going to call Braids ""dream-pop"" as so many others have. The quartet's bracing debut Native Speaker is almost Inception-like in its warping of reality
column6: equally tactile and dissolute
column7: cerebral and surreal and ultimately haunting for its refusal to answer questions the same way twice.

column1: The Montreal group is constructed like your typical indie rock outfit-- keyboards
column2: guitar
column3: bass
column4: drums
column5: all parties contributing vocals-- but each element is employed in a way that embodies the best ideals of post-rock
column6: where each member coaxes sound like they're trying to learn something new about their instruments at each turn. The same exploratory nature applies to structure-- Native Speaker's seven roomy compositions (ranging from four to over eight minutes) rely heavily on loops and drones
column7: pinwheels of guitar
column8: and clusters of bell tones. There's constant motion
column9: each layer pushing and prodding until they prop each other into something like stasis
column10: its minimalist bent never drawing too much attention to how it's working really hard.

column1: The loop that drives ""Lemonade"" reads like an EKG
column2: dipping and rising steadfastly as the rhythm section builds a limber
column3: athletic pace and introduces Raphaelle Standell-Preston's intriguing and idiosyncratic vocals. She's not without precedent: tonally there's some Régine Chassage in her higher register
column4: and her knack for knocking the listener off course with well-placed vulgarity recalls prime-era Jenny Lewis. But the loopy
column5: playful interaction of her and the strange
column6: gripping placidity of Native Speaker feels like something all its own. She's demure as ""Lemonade"" begins but gets more and more unhinged as Braids hurtle forward. Despite the bizarre imagery she sets forth
column7: the song is ultimately an impressionistic commentary on suburban romantic prospects-- ""what I've found is that we're all just sleeping around.""

column1: As Native Speaker truly starts to take shape toward its midsection

column3: while amidst the catharsis the vocals do the heavy lifting. ""Glass Deers"" plays it as straight as it gets on Native Speaker: the closest they come to typical strumming and clean guitar lines
column4: while Standell-Preston recalls fellow deconstructionist Sue Tompkins (Life Without Buildings)
column5: repeating ""I'm fucked up"" for as much of a percussive effect as an emotional one. Coasting on volume swells and whirring sound effects
column6: the title track finds a point where Braids capture a woozy warmth not far removed from a more tactile take on Animal Collective circa Feels. But within what could scan like post-coital calm
column7: the lyrics drop their often coy logic puzzles for about as straightforward of a cry for sexual need and desire as you'll hear in indie rock.

column1: Immediately thereafter
column2: ""Lammicken"" deeply upsets the mood and throws Native Speaker into a stark relief. ""I can't stop it
column3: Standell-Preston repeats as she navigates a hall of funhouse mirrors with only that line to comfort her

something that can begin as soon as it ends.

Every genre has its icons and its iconoclasts. Rock'n'roll will likely always have both bands that sound like Led Zeppelin and bands that absorbed Led Zeppelin but marched proudly in an unforeseen direction. Country music has chicken grease-and-cheap beer adherents in addition to pop crossover darlings
column2: while rap brims with boom-bap purists and backpacking sonic explorers. These divisions are rarely as evident or amusing as they are in the world of guitar instrumentalists
column3: a realm where either John Fahey is some sanctified combination of Zeus
column4: Athena
column5: and Poseidon or the brilliant dude who has become annoying because he's the only touchstone most people have. You either fully embrace Fahey-- like
column6: say
column7: the late Jack Rose-- or you run the other way
column8: like Ben Chasny with his work as Six Organs of Admittance. A middle ground exists
column9: certainly
column10: but it's rarely been claimed with the grace and elocution of Behold the Spirit
column11: the debut from young Nashville guitarist William Tyler. Arguably the most vital
column12: energized album by an American solo guitarist in a decade or more
column13: it accepts Fahey's legacy while escaping its shadow. Moreover
column14: it's simply a joy to hear.

column1: You might recognize Tyler's name from his long stint as a multi-instrumentalist in Lambchop
column2: or from album credits alongside Charlie Louvin
column3: Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy
column4: Silver Jews
column5: and Wooden Wand. Lambchop's oeuvre should give you some hint as to what makes Tyler special. Just as Lambchop's pan-American indie incorporates soul
column6: rock
column7: country and outsider music into one weirdly warped mold
column8: Tyler integrates a dozen different approaches. He's as comfortable with an electric as an acoustic
column9: as accomplished conducting a long
column10: coruscated drone as he is gliding through fingerpicked hymns. The English folk of Pentangle and the American hum of Tom Carter are clear references
column11: as are Indian ragas and Appalachian ballads. Unlike the work of fellow polyglot Sir Richard Bishop
column12: though
column13: Tyler engages all of those muses at once
column14: consistently folding them into surprising revelations.

column1: Behold the Spirit is a sterling mixture of bravado and dexterity. Tyler could be an ace in any rock band
column2: so crafted are his chops and developed is his taste. During the elegant climber ""Missionary Ridge""
column3: Tyler winds through a complex circuit of melodies and variations with perfect clarity
column4: the low notes resonating and the high ones shimmering resplendently. ""The Green Pastures"" feels like some sort of tantric test of his skill
column5: as Tyler picks the notes from a handful of chords while an ace country band-- pedal steel
column6: then drums
column7: then piano-- threads melodies and tones through the lines of his acoustic. His guitar always prevails. But if technique were enough to recommend an instrumentalist
column8: we could all save a lot of money on records by applying for a job at Guitar Center. Tyler tempers his skills with patience and ease
column9: delivering these winding passages with unimpeachable composure. ""Tears and Saints"" for instance
column10: is a rugged waltz for electric guitar that depends as much on the rests as it does on the notes. Tyler takes his time with the tune
column11: giving each phrase time to radiate.

column1: The nine numbers collected here never
column2: however
column3: feel like expressions of Tyler's skill. Rather
column4: each feels like its own compositional springboard
column5: where Tyler's guitar simply happens to take the lead. Each of these pieces seems to suggest a story
column6: too
column7: whether through the arc of its music or the sound of its instruments. Opener ""Terrace of the Leper King"" admittedly keys on flurries of acoustic guitar notes
column8: but the song peaks when a chorus of horns and fiddle wail between guitar breaks. It sounds like quiet conquest. In ""Oashpe""
column9: a 12-string guitar breaks through the still of field recordings only to create the same atmosphere with a listless but meticulous drift of chords. Tyler takes advantage of that torpor
column10: though
column11: eventually racing ahead
column12: pulling fleet strings of melody from a cloud of overtones. As with the roaring electric drone that follows or the workmanlike acoustic hymn that closes the album
column13: or really like all of Behold the Spirit
column14: both the sounds and the stories they imply are mesmerizing.

column1: Back to the question of icons and iconoclasts among guitar instrumentalists
column2: it's no secret that neither lot courts a very big audience. John Fahey died a legend
column3: sure
column4: but he didn't die a superstar. Behold the Spirit doesn't feel marginal
column5: though; rather
column6: it feels like the sort of album that can achieve crossover success without alienating that core who can hum ""Imaginational Anthem"" from memory. These spry melodies and generous arrangements are the stuff of pop fantasy
column7: while the reach of Tyler's music offers calling cards for fans of folk and more textural avant garde pieces. Behold the Spirit works as well on a lethargic Sunday afternoon as it does after dark
column8: on headphones in a still space. It's the sort of achievement that acknowledges and challenges the expectations of its form-- and smiles knowingly the whole time. It's iconoclastic
column9: then
column10:
just classically so.

2010 was arguably the most successful year of comedian Louis C.K.'s career. His autobiographically based program on the FX network
column2: ""Louie""
column3: quickly became a critical and cult hit. The show was renewed for a second season barely a month after its premiere
column4: an especially triumphant verdict for C.K. considering his first starring vehicle
column5: ""Lucky Louie""
column6: was cancelled by HBO in 2006 following its freshman campaign. The show's acclaim coincided with increased recognition of C.K.'s stature as a stand-up comedian
column7: the trade he's been plying for over 25 years
column8: culminating in his latest special
column9: Hilarious
column10: becoming the first stand-up comedy film ever accepted into the Sundance Film Festival.

column1: Louis C.K.'s work both onstage and on the small screen is marked by traits common to most great cultural criticism-- an unflinching honesty and an unwillingness to accept society's conventions at face value. On ""Louie"" the show
column2: that fearless deconstructive spirit manifests itself both in the topics C.K. addresses-- homophobia
column3: religious indoctrination
column4: and male violence were just a few issues broached in the first season-- and the structure of the show itself
column5: which eschews traditional sitcom tropes in favor of frequent detours
column6: ruminations
column7: and extended passages that don't even aim for laughs. Hilarious
column8: by contrast
column9: may simply capture C.K. and his microphone
column10: but that doesn't mean his love of needling the status quo has been squelched.

column1: Spotlighting absurdity in the seemingly mundane is a wellspring for comedians
column2: but C.K.'s observations dig deeper than most. Silly asides about the satisfying heft of English pound coins and the varying inflective properties of the word ""Jew"" are goofy fun
column3: but the real meat of Hilarious finds C.K. upbraiding himself and everyone else in America for all of the selfish
column4: deceitful
column5: moronic shit we do every day. C.K. spends a lot of time here excoriating our spoiled
column6: dumbed-down nation-- for its impatience with technology
column7: lazy child-rearing practices
column8: even its overreliance on exaggerated adjectives. These lengthy rants pinpoint some really baffling societal hypocrisies (for instance
column9: that it's considered heinous to hit dogs but not children)
column10: yet such generalized grousing doesn't really represent C.K. at his absolute best. His truly brilliant material is always his most deeply personal
column11: the stuff that finds C.K. meticulously exposing his own flaws and failings as a father
column12: husband
column13: and human being
column14: enumerating the world's idiocies and insecurities through a painfully honest account of his own faults.

column1: C.K.'s 2008 stand-up document
column2: Chewed Up
column3: was a masterpiece of wall-to-wall self-deprecation
column4: and Hilarious suffers slightly in comparison only because it's not as relentless with its squirming confessions. Still
column5: there's plenty of hysterical awkwardness here too-- in C.K.'s struggles to meet women now that he's divorced
column6: in his merciless appraisal of his own meager sex appeal
column7: and especially in his affectionately misanthropic attitudes toward his children
column8: culminating on Hilarious in a horrifyingly outrageous scatological scene.

column1: To claim a comedian or other cultural commentator ""says what we're all thinking"" is by now a cliché
column2: yet C.K.'s refusal to shy away from the most awful and destructive thoughts that rattle around in the minds even of decent-hearted people is his greatest strength. What's more
column3: he does it largely without sliding into the bitter smugness that's frequently befallen the likes of Denis Leary
column4: Lewis Black
column5: and David Cross
column6: not to mention he altogether eschews leaning on hip signifiers or knowing pop culture references to help forge an easier connection with his audience
column7: à la Patton Oswalt or Aziz Ansari. C.K. may gripe constantly about his own physical uncomfortableness
column8:
but the crown of America's Best Comic fits him perfectly.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16114/homepage_large.f64a90df.jpg|Light of a Vaster Dark|1621.0|Faun Fables|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Drag City']|2011-01-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:18.294088|"

Previous albums by Oakland folk benders Faun Fables often put the compelling lyrical ideas of founder and architect Dawn McCarthy in frames too baroque for the songs' good. The Transit Rider
column2: the band's 2006 record
column3: explored the woes and wonders that modern technology holds for our social existence. With subways
column4: computers
column5: and the Internet
column6: our relationships might become more casual
column7: McCarthy posited
column8: and our encounters less meaningful. But willfully obtuse arrangements and overly intricate tangents often distracted from the themes
column9: however engaging. And really
column10: that's not surprising for a band that shares its multi-instrumentalist Nils Frykdahl (and his stentorian baritone) with mind-trippers Sleepytime Gorilla Museum.

column1: Faun Fables' fifth album
column2: Light of a Vaster Dark
column3: keys on the American prairie tales of writers likes Willa Cather and Laura Ingalls Wilder to explore the role of women in the early American Midwest. That might seem like an unlikely prompt for a band to reinvent itself
column4: but
column5: for Faun Fables
column6: it's just that: Light of a Vaster Dark is as provocative musically as it is thematically
column7: with rhythms and choruses that swell and arrangements that are smart because they stay out of the way. It's a pop reinvention
column8: if you will
column9: for a band whose intentions have often been subsumed by their own ambitions.

column1: Light of a Vaster Dark focuses specifically on the annals of women who powered families and generations with their quiet
column2: steadfast labor. ""Keeper of the keys with hidden worth
column3: McCarthy sings on the strangely intoxicating ""Housekeeper"". ""A tidy home will inherit the earth."" McCarthy even writes her own old-fashioned work song
column4: ""Hear the Grinder Creak""
column5: a tune that turns the humdrum toil of flour-milling into a sort of survivalist mantra. Listen closely
column6: though
column7: and note the countering undercurrents: Heavily syncopated with handclaps and big drums
column8: the song feels sexually suggestive. But ghastly harmonies and the moaning violin of Meredith Yayanos add a surfeit of foreboding
column9: as though the labor wears on the singer with each cycle of the song.

column1: Indeed
column2: McCarthy's examinations are more intricate than an issue of Good Housekeeping
column3: as she plays on both the passions and perils that such hardscrabble times held for those that lived them. ""Violet"" muses on the seductive powers of Lena Lingard
column4: one of the most intriguing characters in Cather's My Ántonia
column5: with her deeply colored eyes and her ""laughter
column6: lazy and kind."" The title track
column7: on the other hand
column8: depicts the universe as an eerie
column9: consuming place
column10: where body and soul are eventually surrendered.

column1: During the album's introduction
column2: McCarthy sings a poem she wrote during winter 1998. She treats the invading winter like a new religion
column3: something that changes the fabric of how life is lived. ""It began with the cold/ How it crept up our sleeves
column4: she intones
column5: treating each word like drips of water that are nearly too cold to drop. ""Covering the floor/ Making our blankets freeze."" McCarthy uses that same text for ""Hibernation Tales""
column6: the album's closer. In the intro
column7: it's more of a recitative
column8: where the words are sung simply and directly. But during ""Hibernation Tales""
column9: a choir passes each lyric back and forth
column10: repeatedly volleying their wintry realizations. The technique both humanizes and modernizes the esoteric work of Faun Fables. Suddenly
column11: old American tales are pulled into the present.

column1: These long-lost ways of life-- the flour miller
column2: the woman sweeping her dirt floor
column3: the pioneers of open plains-- seem somehow germane. As with The Transit Rider
column4: McCarthy is making a point about our daily life now-- the constant struggle against the elements
column5: our nature
column6: and each other. This time
column7: though
column8: the band at her back gives that point hooks
column9: rhythms
column10: and textures instead
column11: not just tangents. It's a welcome
column12: if obvious
column13:
deviation for a band that's finally more than interesting.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16107/homepage_large.9f4c93ff.jpg|Dungeon Dots|28213.0|Air Waves|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Underwater Peoples']|2011-01-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:18.815987|"

""I'm alive
column2: sings Nicole Schneit of Air Waves on the jangly
column3: major-chord shuffle of Dungeon Dots opener ""Knock Out""
column4: ""I'm on fire
column5: for the first time in my life."" When that line is lifted out of its context
column6: it reflects where the Brooklyn-based songwriter is in her career. After spending the entirety of 2010 (and even a sizeable chunk of 2009) building buzz
column7: playing alongside Real Estate
column8: and serving as Dan Deacon's favorite band
column9: the release of Air Waves' debut serves as a boost to Schneit and her band's already-quick sprint out of the gate.

column1: In context
column2: the lyrics of ""Knock Out"" paint the portrait of love as a boxing match
column3: surveying the opponent (""Can you put all your teeth out/ So we know just how you fight?"") over the vintage bounce of a sock-hop floor-filler. The darker ""Radio"" carves a vignette of the demise of a relationship out of an economy of lyrics
column4: clanging
column5: strummed guitar
column6: and a resilient bassline. Schneit has a weather-beaten alto reminiscent of folk songstresses Jana Hunter
column7: Bosque Brown
column8: and Scout Niblett
column9: and her thin but charming voice often strains to hit high notes that are just a hair out of reach.

column1: While ""Humdrum"" takes minimal musical elements and blends them together to create something surprisingly full sounding
column2: ""Sweetness"" succeeds wildly with just two chords. Throughout
column3: Dungeon Dots displays slapdash pop charm; it sometimes feels as though the running times of the songs are the exact length of time it took her to write them
column4: but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. The rudimentary song structures can get plodding on ""Fort Tilden""
column5: but even then
column6: Schneit manages to add a simplistic-but-infectious element-- in this case
column7: the ""ooh-oohs"" during the chorus-- that carries it over.

column1: There is a sense of melancholy that courses through the fiber of the record
column2: and this is no more apparent than on the two songs that bookend Dungeon Dots. ""Waters"" is a waltz that serves as the highlight of the record
column3: featuring glittery guitar work
column4: sweet spot-hitting harmonies from Sharon Van Etten
column5: and some of the album's best lyrics (""Wear your purple shirt
column6: boy/ But blue hangs on your sleeve""). Picking both the saddest and most climactic way to end the record
column7: closer ""Bisous"" starts as a minor-key ballad and turns quickly into a driving climax
column8: evoking a lonely night drive with fog hanging low on the street
column9: while Schneit dejectedly sings
column10: ""We wait for a change
column11: but that change never came."" There is a rawness
column12: both musical and emotional
column13: in the best moments of Dungeon Dots
column14:
proving that the simplest ways to communicate feelings are sometimes the most effective.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16101/homepage_large.4e17e9eb.jpg|Dye It Blonde|28000.0|Smith Westerns|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Fat Possum']|2011-01-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:35:19.417865|"

Smith Westerns have cleaned up nicely. Just over a year ago
column2: the Chicago foursome were of the strictly ""lo-fi"" persuasion
column3: stirring up hot
column4: filthy garage-rock candy out of Marc Bolan and Beatles signifiers. It was youthful music in feeling and sound-- their noisy full-length  debut was recorded while they were still in high school-- but the remarkable hooks buried therein were clear enough to land them on the increasingly stacked Fat Possum roster. And suddenly
column5: they had a studio budget the likes of which they definitely hadn't enjoyed before. Though the leap is audibly huge
column6: Dye It Blonde's many successes aren't wholly the result of its gilded production values and ambition. This band was able to furnish first-class melodies from the beginning. Now they've grown along with their resources.

column1: You can hear the progress right away in ""Imagine
column3: a song originally released as part of a split 7"" in April 2010. Sped up here just a touch
column4: it's also been re-outfitted with a far creamier set of synths and guitars. The way the latter seem to clasp hands during the coda is particularly breathtaking
column5: frontman Cullen Omori and guitarist Max Kakacek letting their individual lines mate rather than duel. While the melodic foundation was already sturdy throughout
column6: here
column7: what once sounded ragged in stretches is now plush-upholstered from start to finish. Every single piece of Dye It Blonde is similarly decadent
column8: whether it's the sweet whine of semi-titular closer ""Dye the World"" or the twilight jangle of ""End of the Night"".

column1: In an interview not long after the album's completion
column2: Omori noted that this otherwise new set of songs was influenced by 90s Britpop luminaries like Oasis
column3: Teenage Fanclub
column4: and Suede. All are present sonically and spiritually
column5: be it in brash tones
column6: melodic IQ or the sheer scope of these recordings. Where a Smith Westerns hook may have once sounded like another fuzzy member of the Nuggets family/genus
column7: it now unfolds like crane-shot
column8: mainstage festival fare. ""Still New"" for example floats some phasered guitar interplay before Kakacek rips a hole across the chest of the song with a woozy line so big it essentially serves as a chorus. Like ""Weekend""
column9: whose central
column10: hair-flipping lick also hugs all its parts together perfectly
column11: the song just sounds so drunk-- drunk on love
column12: drunk on heavy petting
column13: drunk on drink
column14: or maybe just drunk on a some combination of the above. In song
column15: it all depends on the lean of Omori's voice and the whip of his chord changes
column16: the curves of his brother Cameron's bass lines.

column1: That moony/beery-eyed feel bleeds through every corridor of this album and in turn forms a crystalline expression of what moves this band. Their use of the studio in augmenting that never goes overboard
column2: though: this music still retains the innately psychedelic
column3: lamplit
column4: tongue-kissed sense of atmosphere that set it apart. There's perhaps no better instance of all that than ""All Die Young""
column5: the album's centerpiece. It's a ballad turned hymn whose grand
column6: tumbling scale and ""Oh Yoko""-indebted outro celebration are peaks on an album rich in them. In its closing moments
column7: Omori sings what sounds like
column8: ""Love is lovely when you are young."" They were convincing before
column9:
but now they seem like experts.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16093/homepage_large.74e6e449.jpg|Emerald Fantasy Tracks|29381.0|Lone|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Magic Wire Recordings']|2011-01-18 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:19.958749|"

In 2009
column2: UK bedroom producer Matt Cutler
column3: who makes music as Lone
column4: put out a record called Ecstasy & Friends that now sounds oddly prescient. Released on Actress' Werk Discs
column5: the record contained a wide range of in-vogue sonic elements: humid Dilla-stepped beats
column6: filmic vocal samples
column7: and the beatific tape-warp wooziness of Boards of Canada. Cutler's creation was a stylistic cousin to Bibio
column8: another BoC acolyte with an ear for Dilla. But it was also rough around the edges and disjointed. Ecstasy was a forward-thinking record
column9: but also one that wasn't fully realized
column10: so it's not too surprising that it didn't really catch on.

column1: Cutler's follow-up
column2: Emerald Fantasy Tracks
column3: doesn't suffer from the same underdeveloped tendencies. Issued on his own Magic Wire Recordings imprint
column4: the record represents a clean break from his past. Were it not for the name on the album cover
column5: you'd be forgiven for thinking it was made by an entirely different artist. The sticky tropical atmosphere and knack for sentimental melodies are still there
column6: but gone are the loping
column7: static-riddled boom-bap beats. Instead
column8: Culter offers jackknifing tempos and clattering 808s that recall 1990s breakbeat techno at its giddiest (think Underground Resistance's ""Jupiter Jazz"")
column9: all of which adds up to an album that is dense but immediately engaging.

column1: You get the feeling that Cutler has inhaled 15 years' worth of dance music in the year since his last full-length. This is no history lesson
column2: though-- the music has too much of an emotional pull for that
column3: as Cutler puts his ear for BoC's pitch-drunk melodies to good use. He has a weird knack for arranging clusters of sound to make them feel slow
column4: unstable
column5: and psychedelic. So the perceived speed of neck-whipped cuts like ""Aquamarine"" and the album's prismatic highlight
column6: ""Petrcane Beach Track""
column7: feel oddly off
column8: even while the BPMs stay firmly in place. It's a trick that he puts to use carefully
column9: and its application is disorienting in the most blissful sense.

column1: It's that care and attention to detail that makes Emerald Fantasy Tracks more of an album and less of a grouping of similar cuts. The pacing is sharp
column2: from the album's percolating
column3: Eastern-influenced midsection to the downtempo
column4: affecting closer ""The Birds Don't Fly This High"". Tech-y enough for beatheads but with a direct melodic sense that will appeal to even the most casual of electronic music observers
column5: Emerald Fantasy Tracks is just as thrilling and sensual as the album title suggests
column6:
transcending nostalgia and instead drawing a drum-programmed path straight to the human heart.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16083/homepage_large.29ab6086.jpg|Guider|28092.0|Disappears|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2011-01-18 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:35:20.552257|"

On their second full-length
column2: Chicago's Disappears have gotten more Zen. Where their mix of Velvet Underground chug and krautrock groove on 2010 debut Lux was pretty melodic
column3: on Guider they're more interested in being hypnotic. They've embraced repetition
column4: using it as an end of its own rather than a way to find hooks. They do offer lots to latch onto-- memorable riffs abound
column5: and revving tempos propel the tunes like a car stuck in 5th gear. But they sound more into straight lines than catchy arcs
column6: more into the moment than what came before.

column1: The recording details confirm that immediacy. According to Kranky's press release
column2: all but one track is a first take. In fact
column3: Disappears literally erased the past
column4: recording over tapes originally used for the Lux sessions. Still
column5: for an album so in-the-moment and so short-- it lasts only 30 minutes
column6: and half is taken up by closer ""Revisiting""-- Guider doesn't fly by. All the repetition distorts the sense of time
column7: as if each groove had begun before tape rolled and continued to churn past the end.

column1: That aligns Disappears with another band that can turn one riff into an eternal swing
column2: San Francisco's Wooden Shjips. Both also draw openly on classic influences-- Disappears' twitter bio is ""Music for Record Collectors""-- and this time around the common denominator is Spacemen 3. That group's rumbling bass
column3: reflective guitar
column4: and flattened vocals spring up in the quiet/loud drama of ""Not Romantic""
column5: the stair-climbing ""Superstition""
column6: and the shivering riffs of ""Halo"". But Spacemen 3 weren't unique-- they borrowed as much from Suicide and the MC5 as Disappears borrow from them-- and their influence on Guider produces something that can't simply be called a copy.

column1: A more valid criticism would be that heavy influence makes Guider less able to transcend genre than the more openly catchy Lux. For me
column2: the band makes up for that deficit in sheer magnetic energy
column3:
which isn't easy to wrangle from such a well-worn style. That energy is plentiful enough that Disappears may yet make a record that captures both true believers and recent converts equally.

For all the pre-release hype-- one of southern rap's more idiosyncratic auteurs spitting hard-eyed realism over beats from one of the key flame-keepers for golden age boom-bap-- Death of a Pop Star turned out to be a strange
column4: slight
column5: largely disappointing record. It should have been the album to reverse David Banner's creative slide. But instead of hellfire righteousness over back-to-basics bangers
column6: we got 10 tracks heavy on drippy love raps
column7: dumbly repetitive hooks
column8: and beats suspiciously lacking in thump-value.

column1: Banner made a splash with 2003's Mississippi: The Album
column2: a fascinating mix of amoral thugging and mournful moralizing. After that he mostly ditched the interesting side of his persona-- erudite everyman torn between Southern pride and sorrow over the down-and-out realities of Southern life-- in search of BEP-level hits. This quixotic quest reached an ugly apotheosis with 2008's The Greatest Story Ever Told
column3: where the few moments of politicized rage were smothered and made facile by the icky
column4: half-assed attempts to keep up with the Auto-Tuned Joneses.

column1: In that light
column2: even the title
column3: Death of a Pop Star
column4: seemed promising
column5: a chance for Banner to disavow his attempts to create top-selling ringtones and get back to the fury that once made him one of the quasi-mainstream's most interesting figures. The duo maybe even went into the studio intending to make their Illmatic: a dose of classicist rap intensity
column6: one MC going hard over no-filler beats. What they turned out instead is
column7: like all of Banner's albums since Mississippi
column8: a muddled hybrid of styles that clash more often than they mesh. Many tracks have an awkwardly smooth R&B vibe that diffuses Banner's decidedly non-smooth energy. And Banner's version of ""soul rap
column9: his emotionally naked bluesy drawl
column10: was already a hundred times more interesting than the antiseptic pop-soul stabs on Death
column11: tracks like ""Slow Down"" which have as much grit as the Ace of Base tunes the song's hook recalls.

column1: The album as a whole is as overloaded with guest stars as the way longer Greatest Story Ever Told. True
column2: Death of a Pop Star displays better taste in collaborations than Banner's last few albums. But what's the point of snagging Erykah Badu instead of Chris Brown if you're going to task her with a chorus as inane as ""and I get real silly?"" Throughout Death decent singers and rappers keep showing up to drop dashed-off hooks in what feels like a rather desperate attempt to turn these slickly produced loops into honest-to-god songs. And speaking of loops: Though 9th Wonder cements his well-earned rep for spotting the perfect fluttery soul samples to color a track
column3: the actual beats on Death are mostly slight
column4: skittery things
column5: lacking the low-end force that made folks like Pete Rock and Dilla heroes to folks other than crate-diggers.

column1: Lyrically
column2: the album's a mess. Banner's obviously a smart guy
column3: but as soon as he starts kicking game his IQ seems to drop about 40 points. Entry-level come-ons like ""Stutter""-- ""look at your hips
column4: look at your physique
column5: you're so fine from behind girl
column6: I be scared to speak""-- mark him as one of rap's least convincing lotharios. The saddest thing is that ""Stutter"" is Banner's flow at his best on Death
column7: nimble in a way makes you wish he had something meatier to sink his skills into. And the few moments of overt social comment on Death feel like a pastiche of Banner's older
column8: more committed songs. ""They call it the trap because most hoods is just that"" is the kind of water-weak insight you could expect from the most apolitical gangsta
column9: but worse
column10: Banner just doesn't sound as pained
column11: engaged
column12: or enraged as he once did on songs like ""Mississippi"" or ""Fire Falling"".

column1: There are moments throughout Death of a Pop Star that suggest the better album that might have resulted with a little more focus and intensity. You still hope Banner gets there again eventually; he's too odd and talented
column2: too much his own man
column3:
to wind up an also-ran in hip-hop history.

The most refreshing part about Anika's eponymous debut album is just how unambitious it is. You'd be right to be skeptical of Portishead's Geoff Barrow linking up with another European singer with a deadpan
column4: dramatic voice
column5: but Anika isn't an attempt to capitalize on past glories. Instead
column6: it's a further delving into Barrow's record-nerd fantasies after 2009's krautrock-isms with his band
column7: Beak>. Recorded quickly
column8: and live
column9: Anika preens like high art but eventually reveals itself as a loving and minor pet project.

column1: Barrow and the rest of Beak> back Anika
column2: a Berlin/Bristol-based journalist who stumbles and fusses with a Nico-like charm. She doesn't have a fantastic voice
column3: but she's patient and plays a very specific role-- the emotionally detached European chanteuse-- without ego. That's key too
column4: because this type of muse-pop is usually conducted in the interest of star-making (see: Nico
column5: Brigitte Bardot). Anika and Beak> instead focus on teasing the emotional intricacies out of old songs and styles by pairing them with rougher
column6: niche sonics. The majority of the tracks on Anika are covers
column7: leaning heavily on 1960s pop and folk.

column1: Beak> augment Anika's droll talk/sing with a dubby
column2: beat-driven noir that borrows from minimal wave's chunky rhythms and post-punk's spindly verve. ""Terry"" and ""End of the World"" transform teenage naïveté into lingering fear
column3: though the group is better when the strangeness of the material-- Yoko Ono's ""Yang Yang""-- is on par with the music's obscure referents. (An exception: an airy
column4: organ-led rendition of Ray Davies' ""I Go to Sleep"" closes the album on its most tender note.) The group's two original productions-- the paranoid ""No One's There"" and the punky ""Officer Officer""-- are lyrically tenser than their counterparts and not as rewarding
column5: but they allow Beak> to build some noisy
column6: industrial momentum. The group's biggest and most prevalent misstep is a seven-minute cover of Bob Dylan's ""Masters of War"" (never Dylan's most tuneful or clever song)
column7: one they repeat with a dub version (this begs the question: do dub-leaning bands really need dub edits?). Beak> turn it into a call-and-response bass epic but can't escape its ham-fisted politics
column8: however fitting they must seem.

column1: It's tempting to accuse Barrow of formalism-- Anika sounds just that familiar-- but he's earned the right
column2: and moreover
column3: the treatments here are clever and well executed. Beak>'s productions will jar and quiver in a good pair of headphones

column3: identifiable concept-- in this case

column7: Neil Young

column11: his voice loose and easy

column7: exactly)
column8: but there's an interesting tension between the inherent unpretentiousness of country music-- it's rural
column9: it's populist

column11: Meloy bleats in ""Calamity Song"") and at least one Infinite Jest joke
column12: there are also loads of simple
column13: rousing choruses. In the past
column14: Meloy's ability to write a sweet
column15: memorable melody has occasionally gotten lost
column16: but on King
column17: his songwriting shines.

column2: while ""All Arise!"" seems to repurpose bits of ""Honky Tonk Women"")

but the Decemberists just can't quite relinquish control.

No Joy was a band founded on the concept of distance. Starting out as a collaboration spanning almost the entire length of North America (co-principal Jasmine White-Glutz briefly took up residence in Los Angeles

column5: White-Glutz moved back home

column7: ""the best band ever"")
column8: expanded to a quartet

column2: to the point where their voices resemble conversation from a foggy
column3: half-remembered dream. The guitars
column4: loud enough to obliterate everything within 50 yards

column8: the band displays a very uncommon sense of originality. ""You Girls Smoke Cigarettes?"" is a bass-driven tune with an addictive slurry chant during the verses and a chorus that explodes with harmony
column9: followed by a destructive climax
column10: breakdown
column11: and bridge
column12: all in just a little over two minutes. ""Still"" is an 80 MPH push featuring ethereal vocals not even trying to rise above the careening
column13: bleating guitars that ping-pong all over the track. ""Indigo Child"" and ""Pacific Pride"" temper the righteous noise of the aforementioned songs. The former is a glacial stride into sadder territory offset by the low rumbling of noise that eventually reaches a crescendo by the end of the track
column14: and the latter tests the band's sense of dynamics and succeeds wildly.

column1: ""Distance"" can be a pejorative term

the kind in which you soon find yourself fully immersed.

For most of their first decade
column2: the Black Heart Procession followed one of the most satisfying creative curves imaginable: Every album brought something new to the band's sound and was better than the one before it. A fan can't really ask for much more than that. What started as a Three Mile Pilot side project focused on doleful
column3: monochromatic dirges blossomed into something more substantial
column4: peaking with an excellent pair of albums that expanded the band's approach and conceptual framework: 2002's Amore Del Tropico and 2006's The Spell. There's a degree to which the only thing the band could do after that was consolidate its gains

column1: Blood Bunny / Black Rabbit doesn't do anything to reclaim the band's momentum. It's a textbook placeholder EP: three new songs and a clutch of five remixes that range from inconsequential to annoying. The thing that makes it worth a visit for fans is the fact that two of those new songs are truly excellent. The propulsive
column2: mostly instrumental ""Blank Page"" is a curious inclusion here. With its succession of distinct melodic themes and instrumental textures
column3: it feels like the overture to a conceptual work along the lines of Amore Del Tropico. The band could probably build a good album off of it

column6: slippery bass groove

column5: respectively
column6: add little to the song. One merely makes it a longer
column7: dronier instrumental
column8: while the other adds a beat. They're fine as remixes go but not essential listening. Much more puzzling is the Lee ""Scratch"" Perry psych-dub freakout that follows ""Devotion"". It has its moments of shivering psych appeal
column9: but the opening
column10: in which Perry meows like a cat and mumbles
column11: is irritating
column12: and I say that as someone who likes a lot of Lee Perry's music. Mr. Tube basically just makes ""Heaven Below"" less interesting
column13: while ""Silence"" (also a Mr. Tube joint) comes off like an attempt to recast BHP as Einsturzende Neubauten Jr. Mr. Tube is actually an interesting project (in which Pall Jenkins of BHP sings and produces)

column1: I generally don't expect a stopgap EP to have any consistency of vision or direction

column6:
if not one you'll need to hear all the way through more than once.

It's always impressive when artists make radical shifts without losing any of the intangible qualities that make their approach recognizable. What's more remarkable about Bill Orcutt's stylistic transformation is that it comes after a decade of dormancy. His inimitable electric guitar sound-- a brittle howl akin to knives breaking glass-- was silenced by the late-1990s demise of his notorious noise trio
column3: Harry Pussy. But in 2009
column4: after starting a family and a career
column5: he picked up an old acoustic he's owned since college and channeled his muse into raw improvisations equally indebted to blues legends like Lightnin' Hopkins and abstract experimenters like Derek Bailey.

column1: Those might not be the first names that come to mind when you hear the word ""noise."" But on two self-released 2009 records-- a two-song 7"" and a six-song LP
column2: both packaged here by Editions Mego with four unreleased tracks-- Orcutt uses such inspirations to create acoustic cacophony that retains all the trademark rattles and blasts of his electric playing. That's partially due to his instrument
column3: a vintage acoustic so fragile that its four strings have to be wound loose or the neck will break. This gives the guitar a brittle
column4: steely quality that Orcutt mines for all kinds of racket.

column1: But there's also noise inherent in his methods-- his way of attacking and diving into his ideas-- which has been there since he first started playing. As he told me in a recent ""Out Door"" interview
column2: ""Once I actually have a guitar in my hands
column3: I think I disappear into the same black hole that I was disappearing into when I was 15."" On A New Way to Pay Old Debts
column4: he rips out sharp plucks
column5: strums in blurry bursts
column6: and strangles his strings as if they were a threat. His playing is so urgent and exhaustive
column7: you get the sense that he could coax blare from a feather.

column1: Not that everything here is noise. Orcutt mixes in minimalist repetitions and quieter passages
column2: owing as much to pianists Glenn Gould and Cecil Taylor as to his guitar forefathers. He also adds atmospheric textures (you can hear a phone ring on opener ""Lip Rich"") and wordless singing
column3: similar to Loren Connors' hums and moans on his early acoustic records. When Orcutt barks in time to his buzzing chops on ""My Reckless Parts"" or melds his shriek into ""High Waisted""
column4: he sounds roughly like Connors sped up and set on fire.

column1: Which means this album is a challenging listen
column2: even when it's not noisy. If you're not inclined toward acoustic improvisation or unstructured abstraction
column3: Orcutt won't change your mind. But anyone can admire the raw soul of his playing and the way he shoots out ideas in real-time
column4: reacting so quickly it's as if he's creating a new language as he speaks it. Either way
column5:
it's impossible to listen to A New Way to Pay Old Debts without being affected by it.

In Jewish folklore
column2: a golem is a human-like creature made of mud and animated by the word of a holy man. It's a pale imitation of God's creation of Adam-- close but not quite
column3: because a golem has no free will and can only obey commands. In the most popular version of the myth
column4: a rabbi in Prague creates a golem to protect the city's Jews from persecution
column5: but the monster grows violent and out of control. This golem is a forefather of Frankenstein's monster

column7: or really
column8: of any creative endeavor. The things you birth can get away from you; they can take on lives of their own.

column1: The Golem: How He Came Into the World is a 1920 silent film version of the popular story (traditionally
column2: golems also can't speak
column3: which makes them an ideal subject for the pre-talkie era). Lately
column4: film festivals and musicians have made a nice sideline of presenting live scores to such movies
column5: and in 2008
column6: prolific Pixes frontman Black Francis composed a soundtrack to The Golem for the San Francisco International Film Festival. That score was released in a limited run of 500 as a 5xCD set comprising the live performance
column7: studio recordings

column1: And it is a rock album

column3: spaced-out surf guitar strum of ""Miriam and Florian Theme (Version 2)"" but quickly descends into more raucous territory. This golem doesn't lumber and skulk so much as swagger and be-bop and damn near line-dance. Sure
column4: there are vestigial strings and harpsichord and even a waltz
column5: but they're secondary to guitars that range from acoustic strum to western twang to fried bluesy leads-- and to a saxophone that blows through some songs with Morphine-grade melancholy and rips up others with sputtering free-jazz bleat and squeal.

column1: Then there's Francis' multivalent yet unmistakable voice. On ""Miriam and Florian""
column2: it's that old seductive whine
column3: always just holding back a growl
column4: hiding its teeth. In the final seconds of ""Astaroth""
column5: he lets it loose
column6: grumbling guttural gibberish and capping the song with three quick
column7: strangulated yips. On ""The Maharal""
column8: it's pleasantly weathered and hoarse
column9: and elsewhere
column10: it's a low
column11: emotive croon
column12: richer for its years.

column1: The album's lyrics reference the absent film in ways both obvious and obscure. ""Meet Me at the Ghetto Gates"" is the song that feels most like it was meant for a musical or a rock opera
column2: with its waltz time and its simple
column3: potentially plot-advancing lyrical refrain
column4: although you can just as easily imagine the climactic scene when ""The Conjuring"" hits its shrieking crescendo (""give! to me! the! word!""). But The Golem's best songs transcend the source material or draw from it themes that weren't originally there. At the album's heart is ""The Obedient Servant""
column5: a twangy
column6: melancholic ballad that recasts the master-and-servant relationship between the golem and his creator as that of a hopelessly devoted romantic love with Bonnie-and-Clyde overtones: ""Hurt he who hurts you/ I will be fervent/ Don't cry
column7: it's they who die.""

column1: One wonders if Francis sees something of the golem in his much revered creation
column2: the Pixies
column3: or at least in the legions of fans who can't help but judge his solo work against that band's godlike standard: a monster he brought to life but can't quite kill or control. (The Prague golem is said to be de-activated and stored in a synagogue there; the Pixies occasionally come back to life for a reunion tour.) Well
column4: to add to that mindless lumbering: no
column5: The Golem is not a Pixies album
column6:
but it is a Black Francis record that walks and talks surprisingly well even without the master text of its film.

column3: and Slumberland-style indie pop. This mélange makes Minks somewhat of an anomaly on their label; while other Captured Tracks artists tend to have a style and stick to it-- Beach Fossils' distanced nostalgia
column4: Wild Nothing's Smiths devotionals
column5: the Jameses' brutal weirdness-- Minks seem more content to play the field. It works to their advantage on By the Hedge. The band's one constant is their lyrics
column6: which deal with familiar pop song tropes-- ""girls with broken hearts
column7: sunlight and summertime
column8:
teenage doubt. But there's always a place for a skillful young band that draws from its record collection and sings about the problems between boys and girls.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16085/homepage_large.fae4c74c.jpg|Imaginary Softwoods|29378.0|Imaginary Softwoods|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Digitalis']|2011-01-14 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:27.726228|"

Each member in the Cleveland trio Emeralds has a distinct persona onstage
column2: or at least they did when I saw them perform at Krakow's Unsound Festival last fall. Steve Hauschildt
column3: standing stock-straight behind a tidy array of electronic gear
column4: looked like an understudy for Kraftwerk
column5: right down to the red shirt. Guitarist Mark McGuire played an emotive rocker
column6: his hair dangling in his face like Thurston Moore
column7: a hint of Jimi Hendrix in his body language. John Elliott was the headbanger: With his back to the audience and his frame bent over a rack of synthesizers
column8: he paced and flipped his mane
column9: pumping his fist in the air to rhythms that often seemed audible only to him.

column1: So it's ironic that Elliott is also responsible for one of the mellowest
column2: gentlest offerings to come from the musicians' extended catalog. It's not hard to connect this self-titled album from his Imaginary Softwoods alias to Emeralds or any of Elliott's other projects
column3: like Mist (with Sam Goldberg) and Outer Space. All 12 tracks are based on synthesizers
column4: sequencers
column5: and sound-sculpting effects
column6: and they nod to a vast realm of ambient electronic music
column7: from Krautrock's ""kosmische"" contingent to Kevin Drumm and Tim Hecker. But they also sound little like the frenetic burble of Elliott's other work; it's the most measured and contemplative music that I've heard from him.

column1: That outlier status has helped bring the album to the fore in a catalog that's strewn with cassette and CD-R releases
column2: enough to overwhelm all but the most obsessive fan. It was originally released as a triple cassette on Cleveland's Wagon label in 2008; in 2009
column3: Wagon re-issued it in a CD-R edition of 100 and Digitalis snuck out 150 copies on double vinyl. Finally
column4: late last year
column5: Digitalis brought out a more plentiful vinyl edition
column6: remastered by James Plotkin (who also mastered Emeralds' and Oneohtrix Point Never's recent albums for Editions Mego) and cut at Berlin's Dubplates and Mastering Studios.

column1: Two ideas set out the frame of the album: long
column2: shimmering drones that rotate like threaded icicles
column3: and stately melodic pieces almost Baroque in their sensibility. Across 12 tracks
column4: all of them between four-and-a-half and five minutes long
column5: Elliott slides between those two poles almost as though he were moving the crossfader on a mixer. The record opens with a faraway drone that sounds like a wave machine in a wind tunnel; the next track is similar
column6: with a clearer sense of tone and notes that are almost distinguishable as discrete events
column7: but still drowning in the sound of airplanes far overhead. Then
column8: with the third track
column9: we're thrown to the far extreme with a slow
column10: tentative fugue. Instead of the bubbling
column11: chugging maximalism of Emeralds or Outer Space
column12: it makes do with the barest clusters of notes
column13: just one or two at a time
column14: lingering on the woolly nub of colliding overtones.

column1: It's unusually luminous music
column2: with glowing chords and delicate harmonic movement more intuited than heard; in places
column3: it sounds not unlike Kevin Drumm's majestic Imperial Horizon
column4: but with the modulations sped up tenfold
column5: like a filament emitting tiny
column6: uneven pulses of light at a thousand beats per minute. Many of the tracks are versions of one another
column7: sharing sounds and recurring motifs. Tracks five and six are slight variants on the same clusters of chords
column8: with the first filtered to emphasize a basso grumble and the second stripped shiveringly bare; they feel like still-life paintings of a single object whose difference lies mainly in the lighting.

column1: Perhaps most impressive is how subtly Elliott moves from one idea to another. Track eight
column2: the album's center of gravity
column3: begins with a low
column4: hurdy-gurdy drone and blossoms into an all-encompassing shimmer before a regal synthesizer melody slowly rises and escorts us into silence. (It feels almost mythical
column5: like some musical allegory of form assembling itself from chaos.) Drop the needle several times at random
column6: and you might imagine you were hearing bits of three or four different tracks; let it play out from start to finish and it becomes a kind of teleportation machine
column7: dissolving you into a steady
column8: imperceptible ripple of atoms and planting you gently back on the ground
column9: all in under five minutes. It's a hell of a conjuring trick
column10: like a wormhole at the heart of a hall of mirrors.

column1: Whether you listen to it actively or simply as background music
column2: the album has a way of messing with your head
column3: full of sounds you can't decipher and structured in a way that seems to fold back upon itself. As it proceeds
column4: it snakes its way through a succession of spaces that become increasingly difficult to tell apart-- until a new track comes on and you're thrown into an unfamiliar room once again
column5: with dimensions you can't quite make out
column6:
but furnished with objects familiar from previous chambers. It's a richly disorienting exercise in déjà vu. It's easy to get lost in these woods-- and tempting to remain there indefinitely.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16052/homepage_large.d902110a.jpg|Is Growing Faith|28957.0|White Fence|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Woodsist']|2011-01-14 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:35:28.190539|"

Tim Presley comes from a growing faction of hard-working throwback rock'n'roll artists who share both a love of vaguely garage and punk music but also display a pertinacious work ethic. Seemingly dissatisfied with the ""one album every 18 months"" approach of some of his peers
column2: Presley serves as frontman for neo-psych group Darker My Love
column3: guitarist for garage-poppers the Strange Boys
column4: and still found time to release the self-titled debut of his solo project
column5: White Fence
column6: late last year.

column1: All in all
column2: White Fence played like many solo bows: It was a solid-but-sometimes-unfocused tour through the artist's mental Rolodex of influences and flights of fancy. In Presley's case that happens to be the sort of 1960s and 70s folk-rock that emits a vapor trail of psychedelia behind it. Is Growing Faith
column3: the second White Fence album in under a year
column4: finds Presley trimming the fat and applying stringent focus on improving as a songwriter without discarding his dealer's phone number.

column1: While songs like lead single ""Lillian (Won't You Play Drums)""
column2: ""Sticky Fruitman Has Faith""
column3: and ""And By Always"" continue Presley's attachment to bright guitar lines and delightfully meandering guitar solos
column4: Is Growing Faith also finds him in a more exploratory mood. ""Stranger Things Have Happened (To You)"" sneaks a little country twang into the template
column5: while the laconic
column6: bouncy ""Your Last Friend Alive"" leads into a jangly riff that quickly turns into the lead on cacophonous surf-rock tune ""Enthusiasm"". Tracks such as those help this record feel like a more thought-out work rather than a cobbled-together collection.

column1: The most drastic left-turn is ""The Mexican Twins/Life is... Too $hort""
column2: on which Presley trades his psych influence for hip-hop. The first half of the song is a bizarre
column3: keyboard-driven spoken word track
column4: complete with Presley's voice being pitch-shifted to sound eerily similar to Madlib alter-ego Quasimoto; the latter-- named for the classic Bay Area rap album-- mercifully pulls in the reins musically. Presley's greatest successes come from putting away the drums
column5: sitting an acoustic guitar on his lap
column6: and showcasing his gratifyingly woozy voice. ""Tumble
column7: Lies & Honesty"" finds him double-tracking his vocals and harmonizing with himself while a wobbly keyboard line sends the humble optimism of the song's lyrics to near-soaring heights.

column1: With all the psychedelic instrumental flourishes on Is Growing Faith
column2: closer ""When There is No Crowd"" follows the advice of its title and is presented completely unadorned. Featuring just Presley's voice and a guitar
column3: the song features some of the strongest songwriting on the album
column4: with an earworm of a melody and lyrics that combine laid-back nostalgia
column5: uncomplicated romance
column6: stream-of-consciousness imagery
column7: and even a little advice: ""You might go to college
column8: and you might go to school/ And you may find religion
column9: but don't be nobody's fool."" Ultimately
column10: ""When There Is No Crowd"" is the most appropriate way to end the record
column11: with the image of Presley seated alone and hunched over a tape recorder
column12: sounding more truly comfortable for the first time in his career. Even with all of the bands he punches the time card for
column13: it's starting to become very clear that
column14: with Is Growing Faith
column15:
his solo efforts are the ones that reap the most rewards.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16049/homepage_large.4c1ebaf7.jpg|Red Barked Tree|4611.0|Wire|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Pinkflag']|2011-01-13 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:28.700177|"

Wire always seem to be ahead of their time
column2: no matter what time they choose to exist in. Their legendary three-album evolutionary run from 1977 to 1979 predicted punk's gradual mutation into synth-pop; their second incarnation (circa 1985-1990)
column3: as a textural electro-rock outfit
column4: anticipated the late-80s vogue for industrialized funk and dream-pop. And even their most recent reunion in 2000 was an uncannily prophetic move-- after seeing their currency rise throughout the Britpopped 90s
column5: Wire resurfaced just as indie rock was about to be revitalized by a post-punk craze that eventually also lured first-wave peers like Gang of Four and Public Image Ltd out of retirement.

column1: But if a second Wire reunion was inevitable
column2: its outcome has been refreshingly less predictable: Not only has the band avoided the easy nostalgia trend of playing its classic albums live in their entirety
column3: Wire Mk III have proven to be more prolific and long-lasting than the band's two storied previous phases put together. Sure
column4: founding guitarist Bruce Gilbert checked out of the current campaign back in 2004
column5: but the band's momentum has continued apace. And there's no reason to suggest this won't continue: The new Red Barked Tree shows the band's vigor
column6: melodic prowess
column7: and capacity to surprise remain undiminished.

column1: That album title is the first brow-raiser: Amid a discography filled with cryptic names (154
column2: A Bell Is a Cup... Until It Is Struck
column3: Object 47)
column4: Red Barked Tree presents a disarmingly simple image that's reflected in the album's surprisingly relaxed
column5: pastoral turns (acoustic guitars! on three songs!) and a lyrical framework addressing the emotional and environmental costs of modernity run amok. Red Barked Tree is a shrewdly sequenced album
column6: and it has to be
column7: given that its impulsive stylistic shifts-- from mechanized thrash to psychedelic folk to nervy power-pop-- mirror the ""age of fragmentation"" that Colin Newman is railing against. But its 11 songs are more or less positioned along a logical arc
column8: where a sense of ominous unease gives way to violent release before simmering into a peaceful comedown.

column1: With their 2002 Read & Burn EP series
column2: Wire already proved that a band of fiftysomethings could handily out-thrash all of Williamsburg
column3: and on Red Barked Tree
column4: that hot-blooded energy is still in bountiful
column5: if more rationed
column6: supply. But the most remarkable thing about Red Barked Tree is how
column7: 34 years into their career
column8: Wire are still eager to redefine their essence
column9: whether in the form of shimmering
column10: shoegazed sea shanties (""Adapt"") or a campy suave-rocker that sounds like it sauntered in off the first Roxy Music album (Graham Lewis' ""Bad Worn Thing"").

column1: Even when Wire directly invoke their past work
column2: it's subject to savvy recontextualtion: ""Clay"" puts the bouncing synth-bass frequencies of ""I Am the Fly"" to less caustic use
column3: while ""Two Minutes"" applies the full-torque velocity of ""Too Late"" to a disaffected spoken-word commentary about modern necessities and addictions. By the time we reach the slow-burning title-track closer-- a quiet plea for eco-sanity propelled by tense
column4: tightly coiled acoustic strums-- Wire have successfully reinvented themselves once again
column5:
this time as wise elder statesmen cautioning against a world where over-reliance on GPS systems has replaced the basic survivalist skill of knowing your map references.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16067/homepage_large.b2e46b8e.jpg|Modeselektor Presents Modeselektion Vol. 01|2978.0|Modeselektor|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Monkeytown']|2011-01-13 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:29.170683|"

A big part of Modeselektor's appeal
column2: and what's set them apart from their Berlin techno and international bass music peers over the years
column3: has been their sense of humor and play. Their records have come stamped with a frazzled cartoon monkey logo or bearing a fugly Photoshop of the duo as Madonna and child. Videos for tracks like ""Black Block"" and ""Art & Cash"" run on a kind of frantic goofiness (plus: more monkeys). They collaborate with jokey rap crews TTC and Puppetmastaz (actual rapping puppets)
column4: and they spike their DJ mixes with Busta Rhymes' ebullience and Henry Rollins' ranting (""I don't know which came first
column5: shitty rave music or the drugs"").

column1: That playfulness extends beyond the gags
column2: into their eclectic
column3: enthusiastic taste as selectors and producers
column4: but it's tempered by a serious-minded approach to sound design and even the occasional moment of emotional weight. It's been an animated balancing act on their two full-length studio albums and DJ mixes
column5: but it's one they don't quite maintain on Modeselektion Vol 01.

column1: The compilation
column2: curated for Modeselektor's own Monkeytown Records
column3: is meant to be a calling card for the duo's recently expanding role as event organizers
column4: and it comes across as coolly businesslike-- despite the rainbow monkey face. The duo told Resident Advisor that ""the main concern in all of this was the idea of defying genres and the usual beef between different camps
column5: i.e.
column6: to create without borders and be completely freestyle."" But Modeselektion is probably the most narrowly focused thing they've released this side of the melancholic Apparat collaboration Moderat
column7: sticking to the territory between German techno and UK bass with little in the way of diversion. But at 18 tracks and nearly 80 minutes
column8: it's also a decent survey of those scenes
column9: presenting unreleased tracks from important and rising artists
column10: and displaying Modeselektor's consistently keen ear for quality
column11: low-end-friendly sounds.

column1: 2562's ""The Wind Up"" is pleasantly off-kilter
column2: its heavily filtered chords and echoing woodblock floating over a beat that lunges and lurches around its half-step pivot. Cosmin TRG's ""Space Station Love Affair"" is an appropriately weightless interlocking of clean
column3: clacking beats
column4: a slippery filter sweep
column5: and ping-ponging sonar blips. Ikonika and Optimum's ""Hum"" hides a sneaking
column6: hollowed-out bassline amid percussive melodies and string synths. Ramadanman's ""Pitter"" puts gently sqealing synth glissandos over stuttering hi-hats and loping hand-drums.

column1: And it's not like there aren't glimmers of goofiness here in the odd wonky melody or gassy bassline. Longtime Modeselektor favorite Siriusmo starts things off with a line of tipsy synth on the grin-inducing ""Das Geheimnis""
column2: and continues with the wobbly bass and flute-like lead of SBTRKT's ""The Unspoken"". Michigan/Berlin collaborators Tadd Mulinix and Daniel Mateo turn in ""The Good Star""
column3: whose dubby bassline walks like a jolly
column4: fat drunk
column5: bobbing and swaying just slightly too slowly. Robag Wruhme's ""Der Bierholer"" has some Aphex-y fun
column6: slicing
column7: shushing
column8: and slurring a vocal cut-up about the over-proliferation of microphones. Modeselektor's own ""VW Jetta"" bounces between thick kick drum and rubber-banded bass synth with a kind of madcap intensity. Rephlex Records veteran Cylob's ""Pepper Spray (Capsicum Edit)"" closes the album with a characteristic dose of gleefully weird
column9: acid-squirted electro-pop
column10: its vocals pitched up and down all over the place-- girlish one minute
column11: growling the next.

column1: Some of the shorter or less varied tracks here wind up feeling more like Modeselektor DJ tools than stand-alone songs
column2:
and in fact a mixed version of Modeselektion could've made for at least a welcome bonus disc. They could have even leavened the mood with a Tipper Gore drop or the Chris Rock bit from ""Blame Game"" or whatever.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16092/homepage_large.807222fe.jpg|The Soft Moon|28699.0|The Soft Moon|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2011-01-13 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:29.675139|"

From the Bauhaus-influenced record cover
column2: to the dead thuds that pound every corner of The Soft Moon
column3: there is something imposing and stark about Luis Vasquez's debut record. It casts a bleak shadow
column4: like a graying tower block. The record heavily recalls the industrial and goth 1980s
column5: eras of music bathed in blackness
column6: yet beneath the squall and the otherwise monolithic sound poke out some impressive moments of clarity.

column1: The record announces itself on ""Breathe the Fire"" with a Joy Division-like beat and creeping synths
column2: Vasquez's vocal-- as on much of the record-- never rising out of a whisper. When it finally does on the tense single ""Circles""
column3: it's wordless and yelping
column4: sounding more like a pagan chant. That tense song eventually builds to a visceral
column5: satisfying release of noise; it's a trick repeated a few times on the album
column6: but Vasquez's timing and restraint make it just as gratifying each time.

column1: These fleeting moments of release lend some grounding to a record that-- with its slightly phasing bass lines and watery guitar-- is often hard to pin down
column2: a perception only enhanced by the obscured vocals. The icy exterior of The Soft Moon might make it a little inaccessible
column3: but it's never willfully obtuse
column4: and the sequencing neatly frames one of the albums high points
column5: ""When It's Over""-- a moment of beauty peering through the darkness that surrounds it. It's a natural centerpiece for the record
column6: and Vasquez here allows space to surround the drums for the first time
column7: while a fragile guitar and bass underpin glacial shifts. There's also a rare moment of transparency for the vocals as Vasquez's post-apocalyptic narrative is articulated and given a heart.

column1: That ""When It's Over"" is the sole escape from the claustrophobic drums and frosty static elsewhere makes it seem even bleaker. It's as though the only respite comes for Vasquez when the world is over. While goth was always melodramatic
column2: something about the wordless
column3: faceless dread invoked on The Soft Moon seems distinctly of its time and place
column4: a world in which we're often reminded of our doomed course via out-of-reach financial barons and rogue
column5:
nation-less aggressors. That The Soft Moon carries the look so well here does the same trick as many of Goth's best moments-- it makes oblivion seem like an enticing prospect.
