column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16082/homepage_large.ba790fbc.jpg|Kitsuné Maison 10: The Fireworks Issue|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kitsuné']|2011-01-13 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:30.229320|"

It seems like Kitsuné Maison 10 should demarcate an anniversary or milestone for the fashion-conscious French imprint
column2: but it doesn't.  The label has been releasing these things willy-nilly since about 2006
column3: and if you're still listening at this point
column4: you probably work in an affiliated retail store or are related to one of the artists featured. Instead Kitsuné Maison 10 is just another Kitsuné Music compilation-- a long one-- that happens to sport a flossier serial number than most.

column1: It's hard to forget that these Kitsuné comps are all but destined to fail: They are long-form encapsulations of a style (dance-pop
column2: approximately
column3: but electro-house/blog house if you're nasty) that's usually best heard in a singles format and whose tastemaking impulses are unhidden.  In other words
column4: Kitsuné would gladly subject you to 250 Yelle tracks if it meant finding one more Crystal Castles (it's basically their business model
column5: actually).  Recent Kitsuné compilations seemed to be cheating in this respect
column6: grabbing tracks from Washed Out and the Drums well after they'd been hyped elsewhere.

column1: Kitsuné Maison 10 does away with the obvious heatseeking and returns to a collection of relative unknowns augmented with Kitsuné stand-bys. Standard fare from Yelle
column2: Two Door Cinema Club
column3: Digitalism
column4: and Black Strobe ensures the Kitsuné DNA remains intact. A collaboration between Hot Chip's Alexis Taylor and Kompakt mainstay Justus Köhncke provides some of the only recognizeable names to American indie rock audiences.

column1: The collection boasts little in the way of proper house or disco
column2: but mutated strains recalling former Kitsuné mainstays Bloc Party (Clock Opera's ""Once and For All"")
column3: Cut Copy (Strange Talk's ""Climbing Walls"")
column4: and Phoenix (Is Tropical's ""South Pacific"") are in abundance.  BeatauCue's ""Disque Oh!"" adds some bombast to Gold Panda
column5: and the Aikiu's deliriously dramatic ""The Red Kiss"" is a tart delight. Everything here sounds ""now"" enough to feature in an iTunes commercial or a Sofia Coppola film soundtrack; anyone with knee-jerk reactions to such simple pleasures likely knows to stay well enough away from Kitsuné at this point.

column1: If there's anything surprising about Kitsuné Maison 10
column2: it's how eminently even the collection is.  There's plenty of terrain between Teeth's glossy electro-hop and the Orange Juice-isms of the Heartbreaks
column3: and Kitsuné deserves credit for cultivating an extra-musical aesthetic where beat-driven pop sits unperturbed next to shouty punk and goth-y melodrama
column4: so long as it's all carried out with a certain youthful sparkle.  This aesthetic
column5: unfortunately
column6: doesn't add replay value to the too-long Kitsuné Maison 10
column7:
and more importantly it doesn't turn Strange Talk into Cut Copy.

"|14987.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14987-kitsune-maison-10-the-fireworks-issue/|5.5|Andrew Gaerig

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16088/homepage_large.9f9da279.jpg|Bardo Pond|293.0|Bardo Pond|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fire']|2011-01-13 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:30.750823|"

""Don't know about you
column2: Bardo Pond's Isobel Sollenberger snarls a few minutes into her band's latest LP
column3: ""but I'm willing to wait."" That remains the eternal dilemma at the heart of the Philly mainstays' sludgy
column4: slow-burning
column5: obstinately retrograde stoner rock: Can you stick around to watch this thing unfurl
column6: or do you have someplace else you've gotta be? It's the thing that keeps Bardo Pond fans split between the obsessive and the nonexistent; you can bide an awful lot of time waiting for a Bardo Pond track-- hell
column7: sometimes a whole album-- to get to the good part
column8: and not everybody's got that kind of time. Can you spare a minute? How's about 70?

column1: Bardo's latest
column2: their eighth LP
column3: is a self-titled affair
column4: and the choice to go eponymous couples well with the band's stated desire to offer up a sort of distillation of its many strengths. Naturally
column5: this particular bunch of pharma-enthusiasts have a somewhat looser notion of concision and clarity than most
column6: and with its extraterrestrial expanses
column7: floaty flute-drift
column8: gnarled molasses guitars
column9: and average song length landing on the long side of 10 minutes
column10: Bardo Pond never feels particularly reeled in. Yet
column11: for Bardo Pond
column12: throwing everything at the wall makes for a kind of coherence; from their small-run experimental discs to their semi-formal proper LPs
column13: their slowpoke psychonaut scuzz has floated into all sorts of strange places
column14: with a low to match every high. Bardo Pond holds a mirror up to all of that
column15: proving just as casually transcendent-- and frustratingly sputter-prone-- as the band itself.

column1: Take opener ""Just Once""
column2: which starts with kind of a happenstance guitar strum and an equally tentative-seeming Sollenberger vocal. A few more instruments glide into the mix
column3: and Sollenberger's singing starts clinging to a loose structure
column4: but it's quite easy to get three minutes into it before you realize it's kinda kicking your ass. What sounded at first like a half-forgotten Lucinda Williams demo has cracked the sky open with a streak of widescreen post-rock. Gently nudging a half-assed folk song into the clouds like this would be quite a back-breaker for most young bands
column5: but Bardo Pond is just warming up. Sollenberger shrugs off the second coming in the seedy
column6: Sabbath-like ""Don't Know About You""; in just four and a half minutes
column7: it gets in
column8: flips the blacklight on
column9: then bids a hasty retreat. ""The Stars Behind"" might scrape the 13-minute mark
column10: but its dense fog of shoegaze guitars and Sollenberger's pleading
column11: near-wordless vocal feel like they could (and maybe oughta) go on forever. And the extra-sludgy
column12: more traditionally metal ""Cracker Wrist"" finds the  Brothers Gibbons duking it out on a couple of especially irate-sounding  guitars
column13: then allowing the rhythm section chop through the scene with a  machete. Rickety but never rambling
column14: constantly in motion however slow
column15: these four far-flung tunes are the playing up of strengths promised by the LP title.

column1: Then there's the other three. All 37 minutes' worth of them. One can hardly fault a song called ""Sleeping"" for drowsiness-- particularly from this lot-- but boy
column2: is it ever driftless. The monstrous 21-minute ""Undone"" that follows at least has some heft
column3: but it feels lost in its own labyrinth until they shove the track into wall-of-sound mode just about halfway through. It's not that the song's payoff is especially inspired
column4: it's just so well choreographed from the song's first seconds
column5: you wonder why they'd waste so much time dancing around the eventuality. And closer ""Waynes Tune""
column6: an Earth-y mescalized foot-shuffler
column7: limps along. At the end of most any other Bardo Pond LP
column8: it'd prove the fittingly nonchalant capper; here
column9: though
column10: dwarfed as it is by the maelstrom of ""The Stars Behind""
column11: that it just kind of peters out feels like more of a waste than usual. But I suppose it wouldn't be a Bardo Pond album without a few extraneous seconds-- er
column12: minutes-- and some stuff that'd sound better if only that guy from that one party would call you back. So if the sprawling

column2:
Vols. 1-4|5633.0|Atlas Sound|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2011-01-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:31.351821|"

Back before we could follow an artist's every move on Twitter
column3: Bradford Cox was life-streaming on his band's blog
column4: generously offering demos
column5: mixtapes
column6: rants
column7: and a look inside his creative process. That mostly came to an end after the Microcastle leak turned ugly
column8: when the previously fun back-and-forth between Cox and fans became
column9: for him
column10: a burden or cause of personal anxiety. Can't blame the guy: If you've ever been caught up in Internet drama
column11: you know how shitty it feels. But Cox is still an incredibly prolific musician
column12: and every now and again he logs onto the old site and dumps a whole heap of unreleased tracks for fans to enjoy.

column1: This is one of the great things about Internet-era listening: Instead of waiting around for months for your favorite band to drop another label album
column2: one morning you wake up and you've got two and a half hours' worth of brand-new material to sort through. It can also be overwhelming
column3: of course
column4: because when the new-music faucet never shuts off
column5: you're constantly playing catch-up. This volume of songs from Cox's Atlas Sound guise pretty much typifies that feeling of music overload-- some of it's great
column6: some of it isn't
column7: and you have to show a good amount of patience to sift through it all in order to find the gems.

column1: Recorded over 2010 at Cox's home and in his band's Notown studio in Atlanta
column2: Bedroom Databank is four albums' worth of tossed-off ditties and more fully fleshed-out demos. Sonically
column3: the collection runs from straightforward folk-pop to electronic instrumentals and songs that fall somewhere in between. The folk element is one of the first things that stands out: Generally
column4: we think of Cox as a boundary pusher (and he is)
column5: but the more music we hear from him
column6: the more he also comes across like a traditional singer-songwriter who really loves Bob Dylan and Neil Young. About half of this set consists of simple
column7: waltz-time ballads recorded with a harmonica and acoustic guitar.

column1: The cool thing about these country-tinged numbers is that they put Cox's lyrical content right out in the open. He's obscured words in noise and reverb plenty in the past
column2: but he's a better songwriter than he often gets credit for
column3: and here we get a clearer look at that part of his work. Favoring cryptic turns of phrase over straightforward storytelling
column4: he sings about mundane stuff like getting older and more jaded in a way that makes it feel emotionally rich and sometimes very sad. The track ""New Romantic"" is an example: ""Please don't forget your hometown/ You used to see your friends/ You used to have good friends."" Or ""How to Pass the Time""
column5: which has a similar loss-of-innocence theme: ""Your laughter used to ring out so loud/ Why can't you remember that now?""

column1: The rest of the music on Bedroom Databank focuses on Cox's production skill
column2: which is as sharp as ever when he wants it to be. There are Budd/Eno ambient instrumentals and some of the glitchier haze-pop from the previous Atlas Sound LPs. I'm always impressed at how he injects emotion into these things-- a song like ""Heatwave"" is just an airy wisp at first glance
column3: but with atonal touches and looped-over guitars he makes it feel like more
column4: something like the last seconds of a flickering daydream. As for the mixed-genre stuff
column5: he does it better than most any bedroom producer futzing around with post-Panda Bear textures. Something like ""Wild Love""
column6: which was probably recorded in about 15 minutes
column7: makes all the hypnagogic pop in the world sound pretty uninspired by comparison.

column1: But I'm mostly talking highlights here
column2: and there are plenty of songs that are less worthy of your time. It's not one disc or the other
column3: since there's good material scattered throughout
column4: but generally I'd say Volumes 2 and 3 are the least essential. This is where Cox is the least focused
column5: laying down woozy song sketches and flimsy instrumentals that seem designed more for his pleasure than his fans'. Tracks like ""Pilot Light"" and ""Crossriver"" you can hear once and comfortably not revisit. But that's the nature of this collection: It's very much a grab bag. The reason it's ultimately worth doing the digging
column6: though
column7:
is Cox-- one of indie's most fascinating characters and a guy that just has music pouring out of him.

Chances are Rick Ross and Barry White never met. But in a lot of ways
column2: the two are kindred spirits. As two big dudes with booming voices and theatrical appetites
column3: Ross and White have both taken what should've been limited styles and managed to transcend anyway
column4: just by pushing those styles way beyond excess. White could make arenas ooze just by bellowing the word ""love"" over and over; Ross can emulsify car speakers just by roaring about all the drugs he's almost certainly never sold. And on ""Even Deeper""
column5: a track from his new Ashes to Ashes mixtape
column6: Ross sounds almost as comfortable on the smooth orchestral funk ripples of ""I'm Gonna Love You Just a Little More Baby"" as White once did
column7: with White's disembodied voice showing up to egg him on.

column1: Ashes to Ashes comes on the heels of last year's Teflon Don album
column2: the moment when Ross pushed his own zero-subtlety bark to insane levels of charismatic absurdity. Beyond the singles
column3: Ross albums used to be grim trudges
column4: but Teflon Don just about burst with indulgent decadence
column5: Ross sharing million-dollar tracks with A-list guests and slurping up every minute of it. And it also had the identity-bending anthem ""B.M.F. (Blowin' Money Fast)""
column6: rap's song of the summer. Ashes to Ashes is a free mixtape dashed off on Christmas Eve
column7: in anticipation of yet another new album that's supposedly lurking just around the corner
column8: and it's no surprise that nothing on it reaches the facepunch immediacy of ""B.M.F."" or the chiffon luxury of ""Maybach Music III"". But for a dashed-off mixtape
column9: the scope remains pretty epic.

column1: Ashes to Ashes has famous guests (T.I.
column2: Ludacris) and big producers (Boi-1da
column3: Lex Luger)
column4: and its sonic depth and serious mastering job are enough to push it way beyond most mixtapes. But the mixtape's best moments come directly from Ross himself. Here
column5: he continues to conjure hilariously larger-than-life ways to let you know he's spending more money than you are: ""I'm still ballin' like I'm Bo Diddley! I park the Caddy in the living room!"" On ""Retrosuperfuture""
column6: he claims to be ""skateboarding aboard the Pan American
column7: and the image of Ross skateboarding anywhere
column8: for any reason
column9: is pretty amazing. Even Ross' dumbest moments are fun. On ""John Doe""
column10: he says he's ""jumping niggas like a chess piece
column11: and unless he's talking about the knight
column12: I'm pretty sure he's thinking of checkers. And on the chorus of the very first song
column13: he rhymes ""cell phone"" with ""iPhone""; he's almost certainly the only big rapper currently working who could get away with that.

column1: The tape moves from bangers to slick
column2: more meditative tracks before returning to bangers
column3: and it might work better if it were all bangers
column4: all the time. Ross knows he's onto something with ""B.M.F.""
column5: and he sounds more urgent and alive over churning minor-key trunk-slams than over just about everything else. But other than one godawful chorus from the Chester French chump
column6: the whole thing comes off slick and professional-- more than enough to tide the world over in the brief period between Ross albums. And it ends on a deliriously high note: ""Another One""
column7: an early glimpse of Ross' new Bugatti Boyz duo with Diddy
column8: one of the only guys alive who can match Ross in sheer
column9: infectious money-zest. These two sound just awesome together
column10:
Diddy inhabiting Ross' flow and Ross relishing his violent punchlines just a little bit more. This guy is just having fun with us now.

Vol. 1: A Chicago Footwork Compilation|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-01-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:33.391710|"

Let's be clear: footwork
column3: or footwurk
column4: or footwerk is not blowing up. Not like dubstep or electroclash or hyphy blew up. Footwork is really more of a lit fuse at this point
column5: and one of those painfully slow
column6: Wile E. Coyote-style fuses at that. Roughly
column7: footwork pits sharp
column8: repetitive samples of soul
column9: hip-hop
column10: and reggae against limping
column11: junkyard-dog 808s. It is music composed
column12: at least theoretically
column13: to encourage a specific kind of dancing
column14: but the strangeness of the tracks suggests the producers have ulterior motives. (The dancing looks a bit like breakdancing
column15: but using your arms is discouraged.) <i>Bangs & Works
column16: Vol. 1 is the first widely available compilation of footwork music
column17: released by London-based Planet Mu
column18: whose founder
column19: Mike Paradinas
column20: is relentless in his quest for new sounds.

column1: There is little question why footwork evolved in Chicago: House music birthed the raunchier
column2: uptempo ghetto house (or ""juke"")
column3: which in turn led to the stripped-for-parts footwork sound. Like ghetto house
column4: tracks usually settle in around 160 bpm; at 140 you've found yourself a ballad. There are hip-hop roots too: the sound's genesis is rooted in RP Boo's ""Baby Come On""
column5: a track that prominently features an Ol' Dirty Bastard sample (sadly not included here). Other tracks owe a debt to hip-hop's vulgar confidence. Kanye West is said to have been influenced by the scene's early progenitors.

column1: Chicago-based journalist and DJ Dave Quam called footwork ""more or less the gum under the shoe of mainstream electronic music
column2: which is a fantastic visual that also speaks to the tuff pliability of the sound. Footwork is not expansive. Unlike
column3: say
column4: house music
column5: which has been refracted into a million directions
column6: Bangs & Works will sound homogenous and alien on first listen (remember back to your first listen to Run the Road or Favela Booty Beats; shit's going to start off a little annoying). Repeated listens will parcel the tracks into three or so basic categories: short
column7: styled dance numbers; novelty tracks; and slyly artful tracks.

column1: Regarding that third category: it's probably fair to say that ghetto house never spawned tracks that sought as obviously to transcend their club context as DJ Elmoe's ""Whea Yo Ghost At
column2: Whea Yo Dead Man"" or DJ Trouble's ""Bangs & Works"". Tracks like DJ Roc's ""One Blood"" and DJ Nate's ""Ima Dog"" remind me of anyone's first experience with a sampler: They invariably mash a single pad
column3: rhythmically restarting the sample again and again.

column1: The core element of footwork appears to be contrast: between the sharp drums and the melodic samples
column2: between art and novelty. ""Ima Dog"" pits its ripping
column3: staccato title sample against what sounds like a new age elegy. RP Boo's ""Eraser"" feigns Armageddon
column4: but its ascendant soul diva exposes it as something more optimistic. DJ Nate's ""He Ain't Bout It"" mixes banal trash talk with soothing chants. ""Jungle Juke"" goofily steals from ""The Lion Sleeps Tonight""
column5: and ""Freddy vs. Jason"" is a horror-movie mashup.

column1: Footwork seems like it should be a young man's game
column2: but it's not
column3: really. It's been fermenting in Chicago for at least a decade
column4: if not longer
column5: and many of its principals-- RP Boo
column6: DJ Rashad
column7: DJ Roc
column8: DJ Spinn-- are hardly fresh faces. Footwork reminds me spiritually of the blues that artists like Junior Kimbrough used to play: raunchy
column9: fun music that knowingly sacrificed complexity for rhythm (the ramshackle clubs this music was played in: juke joints). And like some strains of blues
column10: footwork appears to be catching on overseas before it finds larger audiences stateside. Bristol-based dubstep producer Addison Groove's ""Footcrab""
column11: one of the year's dance music smashes
column12: is an obvious homage and would be even if its mantra-like
column13: goofball refrain didn't sound like a G-rated version of DJ Roc's ""Fuck Dat"".

column1: At this point
column2: it's not worth speculating about the future prospects of the footwork scene. If dubstep and house long ago left the club in search of other musical terrains
column3: footwork is only just peeking out the door. The real promise of Bangs & Works isn't an international footwork movement per se
column4: but a generation of resourceful and creative producers-- heretofore ignored-- redefining dance music for themselves. Here's hoping the size of their audience matches their appetites for the goofy
column5: the melancholy
column6:
and the left-field.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16041/homepage_large.cfb746d1.jpg|A Young Person's Guide to Kyle Bobby Dunn|28249.0|Kyle Bobby Dunn|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Low Point']|2011-01-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:33.904595|"

To picture the effect of the music on A Young Person's Guide to Kyle Bobby Dunn
column2: close your eyes and imagine that you're driving across Antarctica. You begin on a flat
column3: white plain
column4: and you watch the landscape go by. It's so unchanging
column5: it's hypnotizing
column6: and you notice changes only when you look away for a second and then refocus. The ground gets rougher
column7: maybe slopes. Something appears on the horizon
column8: mountains in the distance. The angle of the sun changes
column9: and with it the quality of the light. It's actually that last bit that is closest to the experience Dunn provides on his best extended works. If you were to watch the same spot on the ground all day
column10: its appearance would vary greatly over time
column11: but not in such a way that you'd register the changes as distinct moments when something was suddenly different.

column1: It may seem as though I'm comparing listening to his music to watching paint dry (and to some people
column2: that's probably what the glacially shifting 17-minute drone ""Butel"" will seem like)
column3: but it really is interesting
column4: involving music for fans of ambient drone. The sound sources for this music are brass
column5: strings
column6: and guitar
column7: plus piano on a couple of short tracks
column8: but it's hard to distinguish which source you're hearing at any given time because Dunn uses a computer to thoroughly distend
column9: reshape
column10: and smear these sounds until they result in new timbres of his own creation.

column1: Four of the 12 pieces on Young Person's Guide originally appeared on the download-only album Fervency (the ""young person's guide"" title of this release seems like a self-conscious joke about our instant-archive culture
column2: and may also be a King Crimson reference)
column3: and they're here inserted into a massive
column4: two-hour
column5: 12-song cycle of drones and textures. The eight extra tracks are from the same sessions that produced Fervency
column6: and they are far from padding. I think this actually works better than that album precisely because of its much longer running time
column7: and the shorter
column8: more active pieces on the entirely new second disc help balance the longest
column9: stillest tracks. There is a certain element to this supremely patient music that requires immersion for the listener to really draw maximum satisfaction from it
column10: and positioning these four familiar tracks as a much more expansive work accomplishes that. Think Stars of the Lid's sprawling double-disc albums for a point of comparison.

column1: I don't think Dunn's work here will do much to pull in listeners who haven't enjoyed drone music in the past-- it's too committed to the form and takes stasis too seriously for that-- but for drone fans this stuff is catnip. On the second disc especially
column2: the injection of muted broadcast samples and rougher textures offers a welcome evolution of Dunn's style
column3: one that he's also tentatively explored on the Rural Route No. 2 EP. As an expansion of Fervency
column4: Young Person's Guide fills in what in hindsight was a very incomplete picture of where Dunn was as an artist during the recording
column5:
and in the process becomes his definitive statement so far.

The liner notes for the reissue of the Dismemberment Plan's Emergency & I come as an oral history: interviews with the band
column2: label types
column3: and D.C. scene staples
column4: touching on everything from the death of singer Travis Morrison's father shortly before the album's conception to the band's oft-repeated
column5: ill-conceived goal to cross-pollinate Radiohead and De La Soul. Among the best bits is Morrison's story of sketching the album's now-famous cover on his computer
column6: then showing it off to skeptical friends. ""People would just stare at me
column7: he remembers. ""It's a weird image. I've seen people with tattoos of it in the last few years.""

column1: To a certain segment of indie kids
column2: many now indie adults
column3: branding ourselves permanently with that weird sunset scene seems no stranger than an older dude's Black Flag bars or a youngster's Funeral laptop wallpaper. To many
column4: Emergency & I
column5: first released in 1999
column6: is that record; breakup balm
column7: to be sure
column8: but also the voice in your head
column9: the thing that seems to say as much about us as we know about ourselves. Though its influence on music at large has been difficult to chart
column10: if we're to gauge a work's import by what it's meant to the people that come across it
column11: Emergency & I is one of indie's key LPs. Its songs-- nervy
column12: cacophonous
column13: uncomfortably real-- actually mean something to people
column14: whether they came to the record recently or have been letting it run through their lives for the last decade and change.

column1: The history of Emergency & I isn't contained in the particulars of Eric Axelson's bass tone
column2: or the band's brush-up with Interscope
column3: or how much they liked Brainiac
column4: or what was or wasn't going on in D.C. in the late 1990s. That stuff is just the prelude. Fact is
column5: the history of Emergency & I lies with the people; people who hear too much of themselves in ""The Jitters""
column6: who've vented spleen to the tune of ""What Do You Want Me to Say?""
column7: who've cast off all shackles to the strains of ""Back and Forth"". Morrison claims not to grasp the significance of the album's title
column8: but it's always seemed fairly obvious to me: There's the encroaching chaos of modern life-- the emergency-- and then there's you
column9: standing outside it
column10: yet inextricably linked. Emergency & I is a record about learning how to live with both.

column1: Better than anyone
column2: Morrison captures that awful
column3: driftless
column4: locked-up feeling you back yourself into sometimes; bored at work
column5: unlucky in love
column6: low on friends
column7: lower on prospects. You're unsure where to move
column8: be it another city or into another room
column9: or whether either is worth the effort; that feeling
column10: so perfectly articulated in ""The City""
column11: that ""something seems to happen somewhere else
column12: yet for reasons financial and social and geographical alike
column13: you're powerless to do anything about it. Call it self-insult to existential injury: You're so down
column14: you start counting yourself out. That's ""Spider in the Snow""
column15: in which a change of scenery still means the ""same VCR
column16: the same cats""; the same rut. That's ""Memory Machine""
column17: in which eternal life seems little more than an excuse to chain-smoke. That
column18: especially
column19: is ""The Jitters""
column20: in which our sick and sad protagonist can't bring himself to do much more than 10

column1: But allowing himself to wallow or pointing fingers at everyone but himself
column2: Morrison assesses the situation
column3: turns over the problems in his head
column4: sorts out what's in his control and what's out of it
column5: and moves along. He sometimes invents elaborate metaphysical devices-- the all-access pass of ""You Are Invited""
column6: the memory machine of ""Memory Machine""-- to explain away what a more rational observation couldn't
column7: but he's a strikingly realistic
column8: austere lyricist
column9: detailing just how dull feeling like crap can be
column10: encouraging action even when he's not so certain he can manage it himself. He's not striving for perfection
column11: just normalcy. That's struggle enough.

column1: All this
column2: Morrison delivers deftly
column3: elastically
column4: switching up cadence to match the mood. In 2011
column5: an indie rock frontman copping to liking rap doesn't merit mention
column6: but Morrison's MC-inspired delivery was and is rather novel; his voice alone is just a few notches above merely okay
column7: yet he's never less than a commanding presence on the mic
column8: able to pull off sharp tone-switches and jutting asides with the unusual clarity of a guy who's picked up just as much from Rakim as Ian MacKaye. Drummer Joe Easley's gifts are immediately apparent
column9: his beefy
column10: hyperkinetic style owing as much to dusty rock royalty as the then-contemporary drum'n'bass the band were clearly keen on. Axelson's basswork is unparalleled in both speed and tone. Jason Caddell's guitar weaves in and out of the tunes; they're a rock band
column11: but not a guitar band per se
column12: and Caddell's reserve is a big reason why they rarely get lumped in with the glut of D.C.'s spazzy post-hardcore contemporaries. And that woozy synth
column13: a frequent presence throughout Emergency
column14: beautifully echoes the weary resolve of Morrison's lyrics. Nearly as much as his voice and their explosive rhythm section
column15: that keyboard smear is the sound of Emergency & I.

column1: The Plan's melodic sense was unusual
column2: borderline dissonant
column3: and their arrangements curiously spare and well-considered. It's a busy record but never cluttered; weird but not altogether alien; lush and constantly transmogrifying. It is a perfectly realized sound-- difficult if not impossible to imitate. Not even the band itself ever quite sounded like this anywhere else. As the liners explain
column4: at some point during the sessions
column5: all assembled parties came to the realization that what they were working on was really something special. The reissue comes with a smattering of enjoyable singles
column6: but even the best of those-- the barnstorming ""B.O.B."" rewrite ""The Dismemberment Plan Gets Rich""-- feels thin and frenzied next to the vibrant
column7: remarkably self-assured Emergency & I material.

column1: That tension between musical perfection and lyrical uncertainty is the heart of Emergency & I; here you have these incredibly exacting musicians playing this gorgeous
column2: frantic
column3: hyperstylized pop who then let some neurotic chart his insecurities over top. And yet the two disparate sides form an electrifying symbiosis. The music seems to alchemize around Morrison's lyrics
column4: throbbing and melting to match the mood: ""The Jitters"" is the most downtrodden in tone and tempo alike
column5: steady closer ""Back and Forth"" echoes a kind of acceptance with the state of things
column6: frantic Brainiac hat-tip ""Girl O'Clock"" feels like the murderous sexual frustration it depicts. ""8 1/2 Minutes"" is positively apocalyptic
column7: its whirring keyboards and Axelson's humongous bass runs akin to sonic blitzkrieg
column8: and while the world ends around him
column9: all Morrison can talk about is how beautiful it is. It's a survival strategy
column10: the self-obsessive's way of navigating the world
column11: a way to keep the emergency at bay. That's what Morrison seems to be positing throughout Emergency & I
column12: urged along by its crazy rhythms: Retreat is as good as defeat. Bad as it gets
column13: you've gotta keep moving.

column1: I was a teenager when I first heard Emergency & I
column2: still months from college
column3: in a relationship I sensed then was shaky and know now was doomed. Back then
column4: it was a constant. It deepened further for a couple years afterward
column5: after I'd discovered all sorts of instincts I couldn't trust
column6: after I'd found that I too can put myself on pause the way Morrison does in ""The Jitters"". I set it aside for a while in my mid-twenties
column7: convinced I'd juiced the thing of all its meaning; then I lost a job and a best friend in quick succession
column8: and I buried myself in it again
column9: uncovering untold solace in the same old lines. Talking about these songs with others over the past few weeks
column10: arguing over their slippery meanings
column11: there's precious little in the way of consensus; we've all used it for breakups
column12: for family emergencies
column13: for nights when we're feeling low and can't quite settle on the source. But there's so much in these songs
column14: so many situations to which they seem to hold up a mirror
column15: what we take from them seems forever in flux. Their history
column16: like ours
column17: is constantly changing. One thing keeps coming up
column18:
though: Everyone I've talked to mentions that they can't imagine getting through their twenties without it. I certainly couldn't have. Bet those guys who made it feel the same way.

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16079/homepage_large.9f03d21e.jpg|The Best of N.E.R.D.|3021.0|N.E.R.D.|['Rock'
column4: a greatest hits album from a group without a single honest-to-god hit to their name
column5: and one that only includes half of that group's still-short career. N.E.R.D. have released only four albums
column6: and after their second one
column7: they switched labels from Virgin to Interscope. So maybe that's why all of this so-called best-of album only includes stuff from those first two albums and completely ignores their post-2004 existence. So that's pretty weird. But even weirder is the very idea of a N.E.R.D. best-of in the first place. As the Neptunes
column8: Pharrell Williams and Chad Hugo have had one of the all-time great runs of any pop production team
column9: cranking out dozens of hits for tons of artists across the stylistic spectrum-- usually finding room for their own austere future-funk sensibility in the process. But N.E.R.D. is their vanity project
column10: the one that allows them to push that sensibility toward riskier
column11: proggier areas and removes them
column12: at least in theory
column13: from the pressures of the marketplace. Theoretically then
column14: this is a group that should not have a greatest hits album.

column1: Of course
column2: N.E.R.D. is a way messier project than that suggests
column3: and if these guys didn't care about making hits on their own
column4: they wouldn't have made an awkward car commercial during last year's VMAs. The tracks on Best Of are pop songs that failed in interesting ways
column5: by pushing the Neptunes' Triton click-thuds into punk-rock clatter and spotlighting Pharrell Williams' truly goofy sloganeering. As N.E.R.D.
column6: the Neptunes couldn't just make a great strip-club song; they had to force in all these fake-profound lines about how the real strippers are politicians and society. But at its best
column7: this stuff worked anyway because they knew they were being absurd and because they couldn't help but make great pop songs. That strip-club song
column8: ""Lapdance""
column9: is their first single
column10: Pharrell flexing a slithery Curtis Mayfield falsetto over cowbell-heavy strut-funk while never-seen-again white rapper Lee Harvey drops an endearingly ridiculous guest verse that I still quote when I get drunk enough: ""Burnin' a flag
column11: all in the name of white trash!""

column1: When N.E.R.D. worked
column2: that sort of messy collision between good and bad ideas was what made them work. They recorded their debut album
column3: 2002's In Search Of...
column4: twice: once on their own
column5: once with funk-metal crew Spymob backing them up. Alas the Spymob version was the one that eventually saw American release. The Neptunes
column6: totally on fire at the time
column7: seemed smart enough to know that they didn't need a rock band cluttering up their arrangements; they should've been above that sort of Warped Tour pandering. But listening back to those tracks now
column8: it's pretty remarkable how they made their spare sci-fi pop work even though all that fuzz-pedal abuse.

column1: All the best moments on Best Of come from In Search Of... ""Provider"" is the rare drug-trade chronicle that admits to uncertainty and desperation
column2: and its slick
column3: bluesy swagger only adds to its depth. ""Rock Star"" gives us the irresistible spectacle of Pharrell pretending to be a Hot Topic cashier and railing against ""posers""
column4: and its classic Neptunes slink makes even the overcompressed Static-X fuzz assault sound cool enough for Jay-Z to freestyle over it on the great S. Carter Collection mixtape. ""Truth or Dare"" is oozing
column5: sinister dance-funk with just a hint of My Life With the Thrill Kill Kult decadence working for it. In Search Of... is a sloppy and uneven piece of work
column6: but it's a lot of fun hearing these highlights again.

column1: In all
column2: Best Of includes eight of In Search Of...'s 12 tracks
column3: jumbled up and sprinkled with songs from the way-less-inspired follow-up Fly or Die. If you already have In Search Of... in your iTunes
column4: there's no reason to seek out Best Of. If you don't
column5: there's no reason to start with this one instead. The rare tracks here
column6: like the Justice remix of the Fly or Die single ""She Wants to Move""
column7: don't warrant more than a listen or two
column8: and the compilers missed a golden opportunity when they opted not to include the slept-on Native Tongues remix of ""She Wants to Move""
column9: which recruited rap's late-80s art-kid geniuses to rap about butts over Adam Ant-esque burundi drums and somehow made the whole thing work. And on top of that
column10: there's just no way to compile an hour-plus N.E.R.D. comp without tossing in a few clangers
column11: whether or not you include anything from the last two albums. So what we have hear is a fun and sometimes frustrating listen
column12:
and one that has absolutely no reason to exist.

Reissues usually connote a repackaging and reappraisal of a classic or the re-introduction of something buried or overlooked. Asthmatic Kitty's campaign last year to re-release producer Roberto Carlos Lange's work as Epstein appeared less like a revelation than a gentle reminder of something unintentionally misplaced in the decade's deluge of music. The Brooklyn-by-way-of-Florida beatmaker and sound artist isn't exactly an unknown. He's released albums as Helado Negro
column2: participated in Guillermo Scott Herren's Savath y Savalas project
column3: produced Bear in Heaven's latest album
column4: and collaborated with Juliana Barwick
column5: among other projects. But the spliced-together sections of Epstein compositions on this remix disc make a case for revisiting that particular part of his back catalog
column6: an eclectic one filled with dusty
column7: laid-back beats and the occasional lyricism of jazz
column8: like the trumpet on ""Y Entonces"".

column1: Herren teamed up with Jason ""Jaytram"" Trammell
column2: Yeasayer's drummer as well as a past collaborator on Epstein records
column3: to re-appropriate and reshape Epstein's sound collages. While his band is known for kinetic and multilayered production
column4: Jaytram's contributions often feel suspended
column5: viscous melodies with samples stretched like taffy. ""You Know They Out"" gingerly steps forward
column6: woozy and lightheaded
column7: while ""Haunted Hotel Beat"" starts with a bulbous sample from ""Needed"" before lurching forward with half-speed swagger. The slightly tense ""Joy Me""-- propelled in part by the chopped-up bassline from ""Sin Pueblo""
column8: off 2005's Gente Sin Pueblo-- is topped off with the gorgeous vocals of ""A Lost Animal"" provided by Alejandra and Claudia Deheza from the School of Seven Bells.

column1: Herren and Lange's shared history in Savath y Savalas isn't as evident on the Prefuse 73 remixes. Herren leans toward his short-attention-span style rather than his more Iberian
column2: folktronica work
column3: and tracks like the brief ""Mar del Enfermo Abrazos"" seem to corkscrew in on themselves. Granted
column4: Herren could graft together any number of shape-shifting compositions from a handful of random albums
column5: but it's a credit to Lange's range that Herren doesn't seem bored or limited by the source material.

column1: None of the remixes on Prefuse 73/Jaytram/Epstein come off as revelatory
column2: and actually they may make a better case overall for the originals than themselves
column3: especially Jaytram's
column4: which breathe enough to provide clearer glimpses of Epstein's work. It's always telling to see yourself through your friend's eyes
column5: and while the raw material isn't immediately recognizable
column6:
it will definitely make some curious.

The uptick in bedroom musicians slotting cassette tapes into dusty four-tracks and coating their music with thick layers of distortion reached its apogee in the past year. It's difficult to sift through any music content online without stumbling across reams of opaque artists blurring out the world
column2: many of whom were tied together under the ""hypnagogic pop"" banner. Real Estate guitarist Matthew Mondanile is one such musician
column3: principally for his work as Ducktails. Fortunately
column4: and perhaps wisely
column5: considering the glut of soupy material out there
column6: Arcade Dynamics is a step away from the nebulous constructs of Ducktails' last full-length record Landscapes. Instead
column7: it edges closer to the conventional song structures of Mondanile's work in his other band.

column1: Unlike Landscapes
column2: there's a great shaft of light cleaved through this album
column3: a loosening up of the murk that beautifully corroded Mondanile's prior work. Similarly
column4: the harkening back to 1980s video game soundtracks and half-remembered VHS ephemera has been condensed down to a few songs (""The Razor's Edge""
column5: ""Arcade Shift""). Perhaps Mondanile was wary of the current genre clog
column6: or maybe the chance to stretch into bigger venues via the upwardly curved Real Estate touring schedule inspired him to saturate his music with more space. Either way
column7: this is a subtle refraction of the Ducktails aesthetic
column8: where the brittle abstraction and detours down lo-fi cul-de-sacs are siphoned into songs that are breezier
column9: less inward looking
column10: more in thrall to the possibilities of pop.

column1: Album opener ""In the Swing"" signifies the general thrust
column2: with a Tropicália-inflected guitar thrum shoved to the fore
column3: and the filmy tape damage less obtrusive than before. Not that this is a vast leap in production values; the drums on ""Hamilton Road"" sound like someone thwacking away on a cardboard box
column4: and ""Sprinter"" is set to a thin slurry of drum machine noise. But the difference in vocal delivery is pronounced
column5: with Mondanile widening his scope
column6: from the deep Elvis Costello drawl of ""Hamilton Road"" to the wistful hankering of ""Sunset Liner"". Similarly
column7: the guitar tones offer a broader range
column8: including country-fied plucking
column9: squelched-out wah-wah dynamics
column10: and the crystal clean jazz-pop inclinations the Sea and Cake veer toward.

column1: Arcade Dynamics peaks over two tracks. ""Killin the Vibe"" is driven by Mondanile's milky Hawaiian guitar lilt and a pensive summertime-at-dusk chorus flooded with stacked-up vocal harmonies. Panda Bear appears on an alternate take of this track
column2: further elevating it with bursts of peppy vocalizing
column3: although his contribution simply serves as a saccharine bolster to its perfectly understated pop goodness. The sweetly melancholy ""Art Vandelay"" is the twin highlight here
column4: where the sound is scooped into an irresistibly catchy verse/chorus/verse structure that further blurs the lines between Ducktails and Real Estate
column5: especially as the latter has performed this song. If further proof were needed of Ducktails' malleability
column6: Arcade Dynamics ends with another bend in the road
column7: the 10-minute improv amble through ""Porch Projector""
column8:
which severs open another possible world in which Mondanile could reconfigure this ever-evolving project.

On ""Chunk of Coal""
column2: the second song on Blurry Blue Mountain
column3: Howe Gelb sings: ""I was lonesome and the wind blew bold/ I was lucky she had the eye to find the diamond in this chunk of coal."" It seems to be about Gelb's romantic life

column1: Gelb's followers largely know what to expect by this point

column3: there are a few things to know. First is that
column4: more than a lot of other music that could reasonably be called rootsy

column6: you can hear his command of songwriting and melodic vocabulary in the writing
column7: but in the delivery

column10: too: ""Monk's Mountain"" captures the chill of the night in seven and a half minutes of ink-black
column11: tense rock

column13: which is as sunny as anything Gelb's ever done. The band breaks out a little to rock harder on ""Brand New Swamp Thing"" and ""Thin Line Man""

column4: after a while
column5: fill them in. It's something his fans are used to. It's an adjustment (and for some
column6: too much of an adjustment) for everyone else. If you're willing to make the time
column7: though
column8:
Blurry Blue Mountain will repay your attention.

column3: the unknown Minnesota quartet self-released its self-produced

column3: around the time Salem were causing such an online ruckus by marrying exploitation movie aesthetics to plodding beats

column5: dank electronic music. He cast a wide net
column6: from the krautrock-ish Emeralds to the haunted sound of post-Burial dubstep. But he also noted that
column7: whatever the subgenre

column1: Perhaps no new act exemplifies this aesthetic as much as sometime Salem associates Gatekeeper. From its cover art (an Atari cartridge meets the Portable Grindhouse aesthetic?) to its sound
column2: Giza is a slab of carefully reconstituted 80s synths. Gatekeeper combine elements of mid-period Cabaret Voltaire (the eerie

column6: over-amped electronic music made for teenage metalheads playing coin-op games in grotty strip mall arcades. And despite Gatekeeper's audible love for Z-grade horror flicks
column7: this isn't really bleak stuff. Gatekeeper realize that there's also lot of kitschy joy to be had with such superficially spooky materials

and at its best Giza offers the same kind of brute adrenaline rush this stuff gave good-natured darkness junkies the first time around.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16062/homepage_large.08e8639b.jpg|Undressed EP|28423.0|Future Islands|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Thrill Jockey']|2011-01-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:38.802441|"

Last September
column2: Future Islands took four of their songs apart. The Baltimore trio was preparing to play unplugged for the first time at a local gallery
column3: and to supplement their live set-up
column4: they enlisted a cellist
column5: drummer
column6: and guitarist. The recordings of these sessions were laid down for broadcast on WYPR's ""The Signal""
column7: then set to vinyl for Undressed
column8: a limited 12"" release. It's a quick but promising listen
column9: the clear
column10: fundamental beauty of every song's construction on full display.

column1: Future Islands' sound is built largely around electronic textures both dense and lush
column2: as well as the stubbled vocals of Samuel Herring. Stripping the former away has made more breathing room for the latter
column3: and the result is compelling. Herring's vocals typically bring to mind Tom Waits
column4: but here
column5: they're all over the map and
column6: thankfully
column7: still over the top. Opener ""In The Fall"" makes good use of every instrument available before Herring makes his entrance
column8: his voice transitioning from reptilian hiss to growl to Antony-like flutter. And all that extra space in a song allows for Herring's grandiosely phrased stories to take even clearer shape.

column1: While none of the arrangements here do any disservice to their counterparts
column2: a couple find a way to channel what made them good starting points.  ""Little Dreamer""
column3: one of Future Islands' finest and a song that's already been remixed along with the added vocals of fellow Baltimore-native Victoria Legrand of Beach House
column4: is the best example. Originally a cavernous
column5: drum machine-based dirge
column6: here it becomes a snaggle-toothed lullaby. The moaning synth is gone
column7: as is the echo
column8: and what's left is a great deal of beauty
column9:
both lyrically and musically. Undressed would suggest Future Islands have plenty more in store.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16053/homepage_large.6b905d2d.jpg|Stay Home|29365.0|The Beets|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2011-01-10 00:00:00|2011|2016-06-11 17:35:40.136477|"

At a time when bands place a premium on lo-fi production values
column3: the Beets deserve credit for taking it way too far. 2009's Spit in the Face of People Who Don't Want to Be Cool had a recording quality that was shoddy to the point of self-sabotage
column4: forgoing noisy static for a sound that suggested the band had wrapped their microphones in damp towels before pressing the ""record"" button on a thrift-store answering machine. Their debut was a blend of 1960s rock swagger
column5: infectious melodies
column6: and wry humor
column7: becoming a minor cult hit among the DIY set and receiving both an enthusiastic rave by John Darnielle and an opening slot for his Mountain Goats on tour in 2010. Stay Home finds the band using the attention they've received as inspiration to clean up their act... a little.

column1: While Spit in the Face-- described by the band as ""a collection of 12 songs about being cool""-- executed the ""cool"" concept right down to its outrageously limited run of 200 physical copies and hand-drawn
column2: Crayola-core cover art
column3: Stay Home is (spoiler alert) ""a collection of 13 new songs about staying home."" ""This ain't paranoia
column4: no it's not
column5: sing guitarist Juan Wauters and bassist Jose Garcia in unison on ""Hens & Roosters""
column6: debunking any notion that the album was created by a group of Chicken Littles crouched in fear of the sky crumbling around them. But the record is very much about staying home
column7: whether parking your behind in front of the boob tube (the raucous and charmingly amateurish ""Watching TV"")
column8: hanging out with your old man (""Pops N Me"")
column9: or doing the same with the person you love (""Your Name Is on My Bones"").

column1: With delivery split between singing and barking
column2: the relative clarity of Garcia and Wauters' voices benefit their songs greatly-- as opposed to the last album
column3: you can almost make out the lyrics. Still
column4: they're buried far enough in the mix that the vocals are just another instrument
column5: equal with all other components of the songs. The near-sneer in songs like ""Dead"" and ""Knock on Wood"" nestle in perfectly with the arcane chord changes
column6: while ""Pops N Me"" features call-and-response vocals that accurately replicate the comedic
column7: exaggerated singing of 60s musicals and sitcoms. Though there have always been plenty of bands mining the same era
column8: with reverbed vocals and drummers that don't sit down
column9:
Stay Home captures attitude and devil-may-care confidence better than most of today's bands worth their weight in Nuggets compilations.

"|14954.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14954-stay-home/|7.6|Martin Douglas

column2:
'Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2011-01-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:40.667789|"

M.I.A. is coming off of a pretty brutal year
column3: what with a string of PR disasters and /\/\/\Y/\
column4: her abrasive
column5: disheartening clang of an album. As a self-consciously confrontational experiment in all-out agitprop and industrial sonic overload
column6: that record had snarl and ambition but little of the sassy snap and sidelong force of her first two classics
column7: Arular and Kala. For all her bombs-exploding imagery and global-warchild empathy
column8: M.I.A. always came off like a smart
column9: arty
column10: round-the-way girl who
column11: it happened
column12: had seen some shit; she was concerned about the fate of her homeland and about the text messages on her man's phone
column13: and those concerns coexisted in nervous harmony. /\/\/\Y/\ replaced that persona with a near-humorless conspiracy theorist who really seemed to think the government controlled Facebook.

column1: But with her new Vicki Leekx mixtape
column2: M.I.A. buries her 2010 with a single
column3: chaotic
column4: 36-minute track. Released to the Internet on New Year's Eve
column5: Vicki Leekx madly crams around 20 tracks into its runtime and channels /\/\/\Y/\'s furious tumult into something that sometimes slips into sheer dizzy joy. Vicki Leekx is also an experiment in steamrolling sonic overdrive. This is a busy piece of work
column6: with noisy interruptions and song excerpts that end as soon as they begin. But it's delivered with heart and vigor and humor
column7: and it reintroduces an M.I.A. who actually sounds like M.I.A. once again.

column1: Vicki Leekx is M.I.A.'s first mixtape since she and then-boyfriend Diplo released Piracy Funds Terrorism
column2: Vol. 1 more than six years ago
column3: introducing her to the world in a blur of then-current global-pop genre-fusion. Piracy Funds Terrorism chased its moment
column4: and M.I.A. existed beautifully alongside Missy Elliott and baile funk and LL Cool J's ""Headsprung"". Without Diplo playing party controller (though he does contribute some production)
column5: Vicki Leekx only rarely sounds specific to an instance in time. Musically
column6: it falls right into M.I.A.'s wheelhouse: fast
column7: cheap
column8: and out of control dance music that pulls a ton from Baltimore club and old-school rave but never settles into anything you could nail down as an actual genre.

column1: A couple of /\/\/\Y/\ tracks show up here in stridently altered form
column2: pushed toward party-anthem status. The tape's itchy beats dissolve into each other with head-whirl speed
column3: and its momentum flags only at the end
column4: when a series of slower tracks force things into the wrong gear. And periodically
column5: a digitized female voice-- the record's title character-- floats in to add Internet-age sloganeering
column6: like an insurrectionist version of the robotic tour guide from A Tribe Called Quest's Midnight Marauders.

column1: But despite its title
column2: Vicki Leekx isn't a blast of political turmoil. Instead
column3: it's M.I.A. tuning back into everyday life and micro-level personal relationships. One song
column4: without any detectable irony
column5: is titled ""Let Me Hump You""
column6: and it's pretty much exactly what you'd expect. Another
column7: ""Super Tight""
column8: finds M.I.A. using sex as a weapon: ""You better be big boy kryptonite because I got my shit down super tight."" ""Gen-N-E-Y"" seems to target old frienemy Diplo. And the harshest blast of bile
column9: ""Marsha/Britney""
column10: is a scathing attack on ""bitches who are fame hoes
column11: or
column12: more specifically
column13: a girl who ""wanna be a model for American Apparel"" and ""always claim she's part native Navajo."" Even in a brilliantly petty snarl like this
column14: though
column15: M.I.A. uses politics just to give her taunts a little extra bite: ""Your shoes could feed a village; you should think about that.""

column1: In its brief onslaught of sneery fun
column2: Vicki Leekx only occasionally reaches the dizzy pop heights of Arular and Kala. But it does give us an M.I.A. who
column3: once again
column4:
seems to be having a blast doing what she's doing. And it's great to learn this M.I.A. still exists. I'd sigh with relief if the thing hadn't left me breathless.

"|14970.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14970-vicki-leekx/|7.8|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16059/homepage_large.ad84255a.jpg|Love Letter|2385.0|R. Kelly|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jive']|2011-01-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:41.242540|"

A perfectionist when he wants to be
column2: a traditionalist steeped in 40 years of R&B craftsmanship
column3: a commercially canny pop star with a knack for right-place-right-time collaborations
column4: R. Kelly can knock out exquisitely slick
column5: universally appealing hits in his sleep. But there's also no denying that Kelly's a real-deal eccentric
column6: in his art as in his life. If Kelly's seemed to court a geek-show level of appreciation lately
column7: it's sad but understandable. Because embracing those eccentricities
column8: cranking up the outlandishness-- often at the expense of everything else-- has resulted in some really bad records over the past few years.

column1: For some Kelly fans
column2: his excesses of personality are the crux of his appeal. For others
column3: they're something you have to listen past (or suffer through) to enjoy the more everyday pleasures like
column4: oh
column5: killer hooks
column6: effortless funk
column7: some of the best singing in R&B. Love Letter is different in almost every way than the Kelly we've gotten to know over the last decade
column8: good news for those who prefer solid soul records to train wrecks.

column1: All of the forehead-slapping elements of Kelly's more recent work-- the sex metaphors
column2: the seemingly free-associated multi-character narratives
column3: the ego-tripping over the idea that everyone is inherently fascinated with the workings of R. Kelly's weird-ass brain regardless of the quality of the tunes-- have been dialed back considerably. No one will be backhandedly praising Love Letter for its camp. The music itself
column4: a gorgeously rendered tribute to a certain swathe of R&B history
column5: is praiseworthy enough
column6: as is Kelly's frequently ignored voice.

column1: Not to say that Kelly could ever keep from indulging himself a little. By the third track he's already comparing the object of his affection (positively) not only to Avatar but Coming to America. Dumb-assed double-entendres and ""okay
column2: really?"" moments are still strewn throughout Love Letter. But their infrequency makes them feel charmingly silly again
column3: and nowhere does Kelly drop a groaner on the level of ""sexasaurus.""

column1: Perhaps realizing he was alienating his grown-folks base
column2: and how silly he'd sound hopping on one of will.i.am's jumped-up ringtones
column3: Kelly claims here that he wants to ""bring the love songs back to the radio."" And
column4: for Kelly
column5: growing up also means looking back. Once he moved away from the lung-bursting swingbeat come-ons that made his name
column6: his albums have been sometimes ungainly (and often over-long) agglomerations of styles. On Love Letter he sticks tightly to the stuff that shaped the now 43-year-old singer/songwriter/producer as an adolescent and early twentysomething.

column1: I think people have been mislead by the cover art
column2: and Kelly's own pre-release hype
column3: because Love Letter is no way a strict recreation of 60s soul. The time frame that's referenced here is much broader
column4: taking in the classic Motown era (""Radio Message"") but also drawing as much from the smoother-than-smooth pop-soul of the 70s (""Just Like That"") and the pre-new jack swing of the 80s (""Number One Hit""). A few outright and faithful homages to the Marvin/Smokey era aside
column5: Kelly smears these period references-- tremulous Hi Records guitars
column6: popping SOS Band bass
column7: the percussion of Michael Jackson's disco years-- into unexpected combinations. The songs don't feel like 2010
column8: but they're harder to pin to any one decade than Kelly's press might have you believing. While it's easier to excite people who might be indifferent (or antagonistic) to Kelly's music by invoking the Four Tops rather than LaVert
column9: Love Letter is much more gliding
column10: quiet-storm retro than ""American Bandstand"" retro.

column1: <div>There are some inexplicably cheap production choices that are obviously intentional
column2: moments when Kelly's bad taste still gets the better of him. The synthesized faux-opulence of ""When a Woman Loves"" grates hard
column3: especially given Kelly's Apollo-leveling vocal
column4: the grittiest performance on Love Letter. But from the pillow-soft ""Just Like That"" to the sparely deployed orchestral ornament that swells between the warm empty spaces of ""Music Must Be a Lady""
column5: Love Letter is mostly poised
column6: polished
column7: and lush beyond belief. And despite being the preeminent R&B thug
column8: there's zilch in the way of hip-hop hardness. That goes double for Kelly's singing
column9: which is a marvel throughout. His vocals are at their best when he's more insinuating than showy
column10: when he remembers the sly
column11: bouncy
column12: conversational come-on works best. On Love Letter
column13: he's as often whispering in your ear as filling the room.

column1: Even with that amount of craft and care involved
column2: it might be easy to hear Love Letter as a slight project
column3: a work of loving
column4: comfortable pastiche rather than someone pushing himself. It certainly lacks the batshit breadth of his less successful recent work. But given the often ignoble results
column5: maybe R. Kelly has pushed himself enough over the last 10 years. Perhaps this back-to-basics move will remind him of where his true talents lie
column6: that his ""easy"" stuff
column7: the slow jams and the steppers
column8: will endure longer than the half-deranged performance art of ""Trapped in the Closet"" or ""Real Talk"". And even if it's a sugary
column9: one-off trifle
column10:
it's a compulsively listenable one all the same.

"|14967.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14967-love-letter/|8.2|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16058/homepage_large.375562d0.jpg|Scientist Launches Dubstep Into Outer Space|5970.0|Scientist|['Global']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tectonic']|2011-01-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:41.889145|"

Asking a veteran of dub reggae's golden age to remix a bunch of dubstep tracks seems like a room-of-mirrors effort in self-acknowledgement
column2: a concept that echoes off itself as deeply as a reverbed snare hit. With most of dubstep's appeal already fully present in the bass-heavy sonics of its more traditional practitioners
column3: where else is there to go with a dub remix? For dubstep producers
column4: the most memorable remixes are exercises in rhythmic tweaking or deeply altered melodic interplay-- drawing on the lineage of 2-step
column5: hardcore
column6: jungle
column7: and UK funky to fundamentally reconstruct a track's beat. But the great dub producers of the 1970s and 80s worked more closely with the rhythms they already had
column8: opting to further draw out low-end dynamics through engineering tricks and manipulating the space between the beats. When a track already uses those dynamics to start with
column9: how much deeper is there to go?

column1: The spirit of a somewhat redundant ""meta-dub"" is the big Catch-22 with Scientist Launches Dubstep Into Outer Space
column2: and it's a problem that's at least somewhat sidestepped. If you're familiar enough with the likes of Scientist Encounters Pac-Man or Scientist Rids the World of the Evil Curse of the Vampires
column3: it's not hard to imagine the dub producer's aesthetic-- mile-deep bass
column4: cavernous drums
column5: notes split apart and phased across space and time-- applied to the artists on the Tectonic roster. Of course
column6: that's also a prime aesthetic of the Tectonic roster itself
column7: so what Scientist adds to the songs on this collection
column8: if anything
column9: is a subtler alteration. When he gets into the innards of a track
column10: he can use a few well-placed shifts in emphasis to create entirely new moods: Kode9 & Spaceape's ""Abeng"" is twisted inside out into a more tense buildup
column11: and after stripping all the elastic bounce out of Jack Sparrow's ""Red Sand""
column12: he makes it hiss and bristle turbulently. When he sticks to the surface-- well
column13: I'm still trying to find the differences between Guido's ""Korg Back"" and Scientist's dub
column14: aside from a bit more echo somewhere in the middle.

column1: That said
column2: this compilation's character is a bit deceptive. Despite the noble
column3: if sporadically executed
column4: attempt to connect dubstep to its roots
column5: the real draw of this collection is the new and unreleased recordings from artists on the Tectonic label. And no complaints on that front-- unearthed tracks from the likes of Shackleton
column6: King Midas Sound
column7: and Roly Vex'd are always welcome. Those three artists alone should give you an idea of the scope Scientist had to work with: The spacious percussive austerity of ""Hackney Marshes""
column8: the lovers-rock shudder of ""U""
column9: and the assaultive wobble of ""The Long Way"" are evidence enough of dubstep's ability to redefine its own parameters. Factor in the aforementioned Guido track's glimmering futurism
column10: the borderline-gothic trip-hop nod of Pinch & Emika's ""2012""
column11: and the muffled
column12:
low-slung intensity of long-lost Mala cut ""City Cycle""-- previously available only as a radio rip-- and you've got as wide an outlook of the genre as you can ask for. That a crucial forefather was given the opportunity to tinker with it all? That's a pretty choice bonus.

"|14963.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14963-scientist-launches-dubstep-into-outer-space/|7.7|Nate Patrin

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2011-01-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:42.421400|"

Greg Cartwright doesn't duet enough. With Oblivians and especially Reigning Sound
column3: he has documented love's fallout from an inescapably male perspective
column4: painting women as both the perpetrators and victims of emotional violence. Men suffer and inflict just as much pain
column5: which means the genders are pretty well matched in his songs. Yet
column6: aside from a brief dalliance with the Detroit Cobras
column7: we rarely hear from the other parties in his songs or get any other side to his sad stories. The Parting Gifts
column8: however
column9: provide a Loretta to his Conway
column10: a Nancy to his Lee-- namely
column11: Coco from the Ettes.

column1: The band itself is a pick-up group featuring
column2: among others
column3: Cartwright
column4: members of the Ettes and the Greenhornes/Dead Weather
column5: and (at least on record) Dan Auerbach of the Black Keys. But Cartwright (who produced the Ettes' most recent album
column6: Do You Want Power) and Coco are the two mainstays
column7: writing and singing almost everything on the band's debut
column8: Strychnine Dandelion. Coco may not possess the same eloquent despair Cartwright conveys so effortlessly
column9: but she does have a youthful sass and smartass phrasing that contrasts eloquently with his more mature hound-dog burr. On ""Bound to Let Me Down""
column10: they trade verses like jaded lovers
column11: exchanging blame and recrimination with wine-tinged kisses: ""How do you stand so straight when your mind is so crooked?"" they ask each other
column12: before concluding with a mutual kiss-off: ""Walk your crooked mile and think of me.""

column1: That's actually the only song from Strychnine Dandelion to feature vocals from both of them
column2: but it's enough to flesh out all the you's in their songs and to create a he said/she said vibe throughout the album. Cartwright gets more songwriting credits than Coco does
column3: but ultimately it sounds pretty well balanced
column4: with each airing their romantic grievances and subtly pushing the other out of his or her comfort zone. Sounding like a young Tammy Wynette working with a pre-crazy Phil Spector
column5: Coco anchors ""My Mind's Made Up"" and ""Born to Be Blue"" in specific predicaments-- a love triangle
column6: an abrupt departure-- and makes them sound like supercharged Ettes tracks.

column1: Cartwright opens the album with ""Keep Walkin'""
column2: a strident
column3: catchy number that sounds like a refugee from Reigning Sound's last album
column4: but he stretches out as the album progresses
column5: enlivening ""My Baby Tonight"" with an Elvis lip curl and instilling ""Shine"" with the sweet excitement of a secret crush. The Gifts themselves are surprisingly versatile
column6: especially for a pick-up band. They kick out ""Staring"" with the jittery rumble of early Love
column7: then instill the cover of the Stones' ""(Walking Through the) Sleepy City"" with a DIY wall of sound. Stylistically
column8: Strychnine Dandelion is all over the place
column9: but that pan-60s diversity may be one of its most winning traits
column10: as the Gifts make everything sound lively and modern. It's unclear whether the band will end up being a one-off
column11: but even if there's no follow-up
column12:
Strychnine Dandelion has already fulfilled its mission by making Cartwright and Coco sound rejuvenated and ready for another round of heartbreaks.

"|14969.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14969-strychnine-dandelion/|7.5|Stephen M. Deusner

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16054/homepage_large.2567a842.jpg|Soft Landing|29207.0|Soft Landing|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ba Da Bing!']|2011-01-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:42.877606|"

Though they hail from Brooklyn
column2: Soft Landing can sound a bit like a band without a country. The spry indie-poppers-- headed by Beirut associate Paul Collins
column3: with that band's Perrin Cloutier on drums here-- cut their ebullient tunes with snatches of Tropicália
column4: mariachi
column5: samba
column6: and Balearic beat. You name it
column7: they dabble in it
column8: but unlike their sometime-boss Zach Condon-- who delves into his disparate source material head on-- Soft Landing let their ex-pat dalliances color the tunes rather than drive them. They move confidently through these bouncy mutlicultural flourishes
column9: liberally draping brassy keyboard fanfares and shimmering dancefloor textures onto their sprightly songs. But their breezy melodies are both outshined and outweighed by their arrangements; the sound's there
column10: but the songs underneath could stand a little more fleshing out.

column1: Collins' voice is warm and sweet
column2: if not the most expressive; he's got much of Condon's sustain but little of his vibrato
column3: and he sings the tunes with a sort of pleasant
column4: everyman ease. A few clever turns aside
column5: his lyrics are similarly serviceable
column6: almost cute; ""Ibiza"" is about a dancefloor
column7: ""Papaya"" a gentleman's surname. In ""Mic Check""
column8: ""this love"" is real
column9: but ""this world"" isn't
column10: and that's just about all you'll learn. The songs-- largely strummy
column11: mid-tempo acoustic things-- flit by amicably enough
column12: but stripped of their window dressing
column13: they're fairly straightforward
column14: unsurprising in their construction. The lightness in tone
column15: the crisp recording
column16: and especially all the judiciously applied instrumental touches give Soft Landing its character; without them
column17: as on the comparatively unadorned ""Pendleton Woolen""
column18: the album slips into competent anonymity.

column1: Still
column2: those arrangements really are something; despite its goofy lyric
column3: ad execs ought be on high alert for the immediately appealing chunky Spanish guitar rave-up of ""Mic Check""
column4: and the recent glut of Balearic-influenced dance tracks doesn't make the faux-naif ""Ibiza"" knock any less. Keyboard gurgles and percussive explosions pop up around nearly all of Collins' melodies; they're not meant to be the focal point
column5: but when the songs themselves don't have much to offer
column6: there's always something else going on. But fun's fun
column7: and while at this point Soft Landing's buoyant
column8: uncomplicated tunes aren't much more
column9:
they're also rarely anything less.

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16057/homepage_large.bbe9c7c4.jpg|The Fall|1767.0|Gorillaz|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['EMI']|2011-01-06 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:43.476844|"

""It can be anything you want it to be. This is the nearest we have got to seeing what I would call a universal machine."" That's British artist David Hockney talking about the iPad. Hockney does sketches on his
column3: using an app called Brushes
column4: and several of his works are already hanging this month in an exhibition at the Pierre Bergé-Yves Saint Laurent Foundation in Paris. Hockney is presumably drawn to the novelty as much as to the functionality of Apple's curious device
column5: which is like a big iPhone that won't make calls
column6: or like a small laptop without a keyboard. Rather than render it redundant or limited
column7: those disabilities have made it as universal as Hockney attests
column8: attracting hundreds of thousands of users ranging from my mom to Damon Albarn
column9: who recorded the new Gorillaz album on his iPad.

column1: The Fall
column2: released for free on Christmas
column3: is a nice marketing gimmick and the product of Albarn's restlessness on tour. While Hockney's sketches clearly look like they were done on some kind of computer
column4: nothing about Albarn's songs reveals their origins. Instead
column5: The Fall possesses the crisply eccentric production value of a typical Gorillaz album
column6: which may be a testament to the iPad's ability to manipulate and combine sound files with little loss of fidelity or complexity.

column1: On the other hand
column2: it doesn't appear to handle hip-hop very well. The Fall contains opens stretches of loping
column3: belching beats that are painstakingly crafted yet often sound like they've been created as backdrops for MC cameos. But there's only one guest
column4: a barely recognizable Bobby Womack on ""Bobby in Phoenix""; otherwise
column5: it's Albarn singing and creating songs
column6: which gives The Fall the feel of a solo album. At times it needs other voices to liven up some of these long stretches. Even so
column7: it's fitting that Albarn has released it under the Gorillaz moniker. For one thing
column8: that band has always had a strong visual component that makes the cartoon/hologram characters seem like they were meant to be up- and downloaded
column9: so it's not hard to imagine them trapped in an iPad like General Zod at the end of Superman II.

column1: Songs like ""Revolving Doors"" and ""Detroit"" have the same hazily martial beats that have marked the Gorillaz' output since ""Clint Eastwood""

column5: homemade Democrazy set.) Albarn's mode may be somber and road-weary
column6: but there's not a whole lot of heft here

column8: it's a tour album
column9: leaving behind the Pacific Ocean trash island of Plastic Beach for the highways of America
column10: evoked in songs named after Phoenix
column11: Aspen
column12: Dallas
column13: Detroit
column14: Seattle
column15: and Amarillo. With its rangey beats and garbled transmission noises

column1: Despite the emphasis on atmosphere that pervades the album and that seems like a necessary byproduct of its creative technology

column3: therefore
column4: the most banal. At his best

column7: he's always passing through
column8: never stopping for a visit
column9: and as a result
column10: The Fall is a blur. Whether as an album or as a touring document
column11: it doesn't add up to much of a statement
column12:
which means the particulars of its creation will probably always overshadow whatever life this album may find.
