Tensnake's ""Coma Cat"" was a track everyone in the increasingly balkanized world of dance seemed to agree on. By neatly riding the tightrope connecting deep house restraint to more straightforward and populist impulses
column3: the Hamburg-based producer hit a winning formula. The track became a hit in a diverse range of clubs and was re-released on the Defected label after its initial run on the more niche-oriented Permanent Vacation. It was even accompanied by a risqué video complete with dancing nymphets. Tensnake's follow-up
column4: this 2xCD mix
column5: ties together several strains of underground house that have achieved considerable currency in the past five years. It serves as a solid summation of the weird place dance music finds itself in 2011 and celebrates the genre's strengths while stubbornly sticking to its weaknesses. So as strong as the selections are
column6: it feels more like Tensnake is in a holding pattern and falls short of suggesting a new direction.

column1: While mainstream dance conquers the pop charts for the first time since the Jock Jams era (the Black Eyed Peas
column2: David Guetta
column3: etc.)
column4: the post-dubstep diaspora is challenging underground dance music's hold on its audience from the other direction. In the middle
column5: the international polyglot of dance producers and DJs continues to build upon the trends of the past few years
column6: reviving disco
column7: 1980s boogie
column8: Italo
column9: Balearic beats
column10: Detroit techno
column11: and deep and acid house-- a constellation of sounds laid out in weekly Beats in Space podcasts. Of late
column12: this scene seemed further disconnected from any sense of zeitgeist
column13: which is why ""Coma Cat""'s popular appeal was such a significant victory. It offered this scene a hero who not only played by the rules but also worked like an alchemist to transform varying influences into pop-house anthem gold.

column1: On In the House
column2: Tensnake largely succeeds at outlining an aesthetic that reflects this careful balance between hip references and hedonistic populism. He's a producer with a diverse range of trendy influences
column3: but more importantly
column4: he loves hooks
column5: romantic emotionalism
column6: and the kind of notes that easily pluck heartstrings on a dancefloor. The bulk of the first disc traces through these unabashed pop moves
column7: with a heavy focus on disco. Tensnake's own ""Need Your Lovin'"" is a love-letter to 80s post-disco R&B that appears on the first disc; thankfully
column8: he uses its ""dub mix"" here
column9: as the original version veers close to Chromeo-style pastiche. An easy highlight of the first disc is Prins Thomas' remix of Al Usher's ""Lullaby for Robert""
column10: a gorgeous instrumental that masterfully builds euphoric intensity through repetition. Tensnake also makes a clever connection with Michael Mayer's ""Amanda"" from 2000's Kompakt Total 2
column11: a house edit of 80s Italo track ""Precious Little Diamond"" by Fox the Fox. Mayer's version appears prescient when considering the edits craze that took hold in the latter half of the decade.

column1: The second disc shifts into more muscular territory
column2: relying on the kind of sexualized grooves and trance-inducing repetition that characterized the classic Chicago house sound. Again
column3: disco-infused classics
column4: like Heaven & Earth's ""Prescription Every Night"" and DJ Sneak's filter house reconstruction of Chaka Khan's ""Clouds"" (""In Da Clouds"") make their way into the mix
column5: but this time
column6: it's done in the service of a more aggressive
column7: mechanized dancefloor sound. After the disc's ""Coma Cat"" apex
column8: Tensnake increases the energy by building to an edit of legendary Chicago producer Armando's spiraling acid track ""Don't Take It"" before resolving to the traditional gospel-house of Phase II's ""Reachin"".  The second disc
column9: while not a brave new world for house heads
column10: does capture some novelty in contrasting different approaches to physicality.

column1: Ultimately
column2: though
column3: Tensnake's mix suffers because it epitomizes a style that seems calcified
column4: as the trends of the last few years overstay their welcome. Tiger & Woods ""Dr. Burner"" is a solid disco edit
column5: with an emotionally moving core
column6: and it's hard to fault a rarity like Carol Williams ""Can't Get Away (From Your Love)"" or the untouchable Shirley Lites instrumental. Yes
column7: the music is timeless-- ""Heat You Up (Melt You Down)"" is a staple for Chicago house DJs for as long as I can remember-- but those DJs are working in a long-running tradition
column8: rather than mapping out a contemporary scene. In the House
column9: as great as its selection is
column10: feels more like a state-of-the-union celebration a few days into the decline. One possible ""out"" for producers to consider is the one that Classixx
column11: who work in a similar vein of populist underground dance
column12: have moved toward in the past few years-- to engage in a dialog with contemporary pop music. Or consider 2010 dance successes like Deadboy's re-edit of Drake's ""Fireworks""
column13: or Soul Clap's remix of R. Kelly. These data points don't quite feel like a movement at this point
column14:
but they do offer a potential direction for house producers focused on the history books.

column9: filming his story on location and without special effects. ""It's a land which God
column10: if he exists
column11: has created in anger

column13: but something is missing; you can't hear the place itself. In more ways than one
column14:
The River EP seems like a transitional effort.

Can it really have been nine years since Jürgen Paape's ""So Weit Wie Noch Nie"" lept out of Kompakt's Total 3 compilation? The intervening decade of dance music seems shorter than that
column2: though maybe it shouldn't

column1: In its pert synth-pop and soothing dreaminess (by way of its female schlager vocal)
column2: the track feels like Kompakt's quintessential moment: Much of the label's greatness
column3: and certainly most of its distinctiveness in contemporary German techno
column4: can be traced to its privileging of concepts alongside-- and at times above-- sonics. The novelty and inventiveness of many of its greatest records resides more in their articulation of the relationship between pop music and dance music than in pure production values.

column1: By extension you could make a case for the reclusive and decidedly unprolific Paape's being one of Kompakt's most defining producers. Alongside fellow label co-owner Michael Mayer
column2: Paape captures glints of nearly all of Kompakt's pop-minded adventurers: The wistful melancholia of Superpitcher
column3: the utopian dazzle of Rex the Dog
column4: the childlike openness of Justus Köhncke. Where Paape differs from Mayer is that
column5: while the latter retains the dancefloor as the site where groove and nostalgia intersect

column7: but that fact is almost incidental to their powerful charm.

column1: For all that
column2: ""So Weit Wie Noch Nie"" could be Paape's curse
column3: a tune so brilliant that he is doomed never to surpass it. The difficulty of Paape's task-- proving that he is more than just one inspired moment-- hangs over this otherwise fine retrospective of his past work for the label like a small question mark. Which is a shame
column4: because Kompilation
column5: if it was released as an artist's first album
column6: would rightly be hailed as one of Kompakt's finest
column7: an excellent balance of dancefloor functionalism and pop daring that the label has tried many times but usually failed to capture successfully.

column1: Paape's intermittent use of schlager vocals makes it tempting to suggest that his expansive notion of pop-techno is his greatest skill; the evidence against this is the gimmicky oompah-schaffel of ""Ofterschwang""
column2: which has little use except as a taster for an imaginary techno rendition of Peter and the Wolf. Paape's real fundamental skill
column3: the one that inheres in almost all of the productions collected here
column4: is his facility for the architecture of grooves
column5: his simple
column6: pared back and grid-like tech-house arrangements effortlessly attaining a sense of build and sweep that feels inevitable
column7: like a slow rush of blood to your head.

column1: It's for this reason that Paape is particularly well-suited to the straight compilation format: Even the collection's most anonymous moments
column2: such as the brooding electro-house of ""Nord""
column3: deserve to be heard in full. This skill also infects the producer's finest dancefloor cuts with a sense of perpetually building excitement and energy that might surprise the casual fan-- the melancholy
column4: ominous ""Fruity Loops #2"" and the menacing
column5: bleepy ""Take That"" are
column6: if you'll forgive the phrase
column7: dancefloor bombs.

column1: Yet for all this
column2: ""So Weit Wie Noch Nie"" and its two likeminded companions
column3: unofficial sequel ""Mit Dir"" and the stirring
column4: dramatic ""Come Into My Life""
column5: stand out like beacons. These are the times when Paape's diverging talents for pop vision and groove precision snap into accord
column6: their largesse and grandeur so undeniable that Paape's attempts at any other style can start to feel like finely wrought distractions. If Kompilation inspires Paape to take stock at all
column7: hopefully he'll resolve to bite the bullet: Even if lightning doesn't strike twice
column8:
his noble failures would be hard to resist.

Floored By Four is Mike Watt (Minutemen

column5: bass

It is also helpful to know that many musicians from the underground rock scene of the 1980s and 90s have created a second home for themselves in the world of avant-garde improvisation
column9: much of which flourishes in downtown New York City. Floored By Four is such a project.

column1: The album is divided into four tracks
column2: each one named after a single member of the band. One and two are titled ""Nels"" and ""Miss Yuka""
column3: respectively
column4: and each is around 10 minutes long; three is titled ""Watt""
column5: and is about four minutes long-- a pop song by comparison; the last track

column1: To call these sessions ""works"" is a stretch-- they sound less like the show and more like the soundcheck. Listening to the album
column2: it's difficult to spot any element of inventiveness. While each track has its own identity-- swampy blues on ""Miss Yuka""
column3: Booker T. & the MG's-style swinging on ""Watt""-- the sound itself is relatively anonymous
column4: and the album has no arc or coherence. If you played Floored By Four without knowing who comprised the band
column5: you wouldn't be able to hear any of these musicians' signature styles. This album doesn't sound like inspired jamming

column1: Since all four of these players have exhibited such distinct approaches to their respective instruments in the past
column2: one wonders what their contributions are here. Because as it stands
column3: one thing that is noticeably lacking from Floored By Four is personality. It could be viewed as a neat curio
column4: or a slight peek into a group's beginnings
column5:
but little more.

The duo Eternal Summers hail from Roanoke
column2: Virginia-- decidedly off indie rock's beaten path. The group's members
column3: Nicole Yun and Daniel Cundiff
column4: are both integral players in an artistic collective known as the Magic Twig Community. The last word in that appellation is key
column5: as it speaks to the close-knit
column6: self-sustaining quality of a small unit of people who probably draw more inspiration from each other than they do from outside trends and fads. The term ""scene"" doesn't even begin to apply.

column1: That physical and mental separation from hipper spheres is a very likely factor in the pleasing incongruity of Eternal Summers' sound. On the duo's debut full-length
column2: Silver
column3: Yun and Cundiff display a pretty firm grasp of two quite disparate musical styles-- jangly post-punk and dream-pop-- and only occasionally allow those styles to interact. Were they based in an indie rock hothouse
column4: it's easy to imagine Eternal Summers feeling somewhat pressured to streamline or smooth out their sound in a way that would be more easily describable and digestible. Instead
column5: the duo happily flits back and forth between nervy
column6: combustible raves and languorously pretty head nods without a care for thematic cohesion. The former mode is typified by the arch
column7: driving opener ""Disciplinarian""
column8: the trashily fun ""Pogo""
column9: and the yelping ""Running High""
column10: while the swooning ""Eternal"" and sleepy ""Bully in Disguise"" (utilizing a similar dramatic chug as Coldplay's ""Yellow""
column11: of all things) exemplify the duo's slow-burning preferences.

column1: One thing that does unite the group's polarized tempos and attitudes is a resolute minimalism. The only instruments on Silver are guitar and drums
column2: and Eternal Summers take no pains to mask that fact. A paramount pleasure of listening both to the album's quick sprints and its slow dances is enjoying the clarity of Yun's simple but glittering guitar lines (particularly on the beautifully spacious ""Safe at Home"") and Cundiff's spartan drums (though he does plenty on ""Salty"").

column1: No one's suggesting Yun and Cundiff are doing anything necessarily groundbreaking here. Past tourmates Best Coast and the Dum Dum Girls both wed lo-fi leanings to girl-group laments
column2: while the duo's giddier stuff owes debts to late-70s punks like the Raincoats. Still
column3:
it's nice to hear a burgeoning group pursuing a couple of different strands of music simultaneously rather than locking itself into one single niche.

column5: ""Back Like That""
column6: the ""Back Like That"" remix
column7: bummed out interviews
column8: and hiring Diddy's production team for Big Doe Rehab-- all pretty clear actions of someone who takes his poor commercial fortunes very personally and isn't trying to be anyone's idea of a cult act. Of course
column9: none of it worked in the slightest
column10: so even if it was a giant fuck-you to his hardcore contingent
column11: Ghostdini was at least understandable as the culmination of years worth of frustration from someone who felt like he ran out of crossover options. Or
column12: as Ghostface said in Only Built 4 Cuban Linx
column13: ""I'm hanging this shit up if this shit don't work.""

column1: On its face
column2: Apollo Kids is a weirdly deflated concession from both parties: Twelve spartanly named tracks
column3: barely over 40 minutes of music
column4: a ton of guests hailing from Ghost's inner circle
column5: a rehashed album title
column6: and a near total lack of promotion: If Ghostface didn't have a Twitter account
column7: there's a good chance we wouldn't be aware of this thing's existence. But isn't that what we were all clamoring for after the desperate shilling of Ghostdini? At the outset
column8: it would sure seem so. Apollo Kids plays out something like a lower-stakes version of The Pretty Toney Album
column9: no RZA but plenty of that record's time-honored breakbeats
column10: blaxploitatied guitars
column11: and swallowed-whole soul samples.

column1: It's the kind of stuff that his harried intensity always sounds viscerally powerful over
column2: even if the rhymes aren't prime material. He doesn't throw his darts sideways anymore
column3: but without sort of bullshit clutter
column4: he's still an incredibly ostentatious lyricist
column5: just one that's easier to parse. The record's opening trio is evidence enough of that: on ""Purified Thoughts""
column6: Killah Priest and GZA add their typical ballast-heavy musings on metaphysics and crack sales to Ghost's boasting of feeding children in Benin and ""Africans chantin' me on like Coachella."" When matched up with a more comparable style
column7: Busta Rhymes helps turn ""Superstar"" into an Olympic-level track meet of fast-rap
column8: while Ghost and Cappadonna appropriately spaz out for ""Black Tequila"". And while ""Handcuffin' Them Hoes [ft. Jim Jones]"" is possibly the least promising run of words ever to grace a Ghostface tracklist
column9: there's still an illicit glee in how lines like
column10: ""And I ain't even gotta be dipped/ I pull out my pocket two sloppy joe mitts this thick!"" counter the problem that some of his most locked-in performances as of late come at the expense of tactful gender relations.

column1: While the music and the personnel are all comfort food for Ghostface
column2: Apollo Kids still leaves something of a strange aftertaste. The basically arbitrary sequencing never allows too much momentum to build
column3: and the lack of any sort of organizational principle makes it come off seeming more slapped-together by Def Jam interns than an Event release befitting Ghost's rep. But the larger issue is that Apollo Kids feels like a record that's good because it never dares to be great. Even on Ghostface's more uneven LPs
column4: there are always reasons to think of Ghostface as a victim of his own prolificacy rather than someone who can no longer make a legit claim as one of the greatest rappers ever-- ""Alex (Stolen Script)""
column5: ""Maxine""
column6: ""White Linen Affair""
column7: to name a few. That ""2getha Baby"" and ""How You Like Me Baby"" didn't spark much buzz in advance shouldn't be a surprise
column8: as they feature the kind of clock-punching rhymes (""She look like she get it from her mama/ That's right Michelle I'm Obama"") that Ghostface is supposed to be an alternative to. Those are two of the three songs on Apollo Kids that are solo joints (the other being ""Starkology""
column9: which is so minimal it's barely there)
column10: and the most troubling aspect is that Apollo Kids makes a strong claim as Ghost's best LP since Fishscale
column11: and he's hardly on it.

column1: You'll never have to question whether foot soldiers like Shawn Wiggs
column2: Trife Da God
column3: and Sheek Louch are going to try and bring whatever constitutes their A-games
column4: but Ghostface should never get outshined by the likes of Joell Ortiz when it comes to criminology. ""In Tha Park"" also is somewhat underwhelming for a song that features two of the best voices in hip-hop on the same track for the first time; yet whereas Black Thought's invocation of fights at the Spectrum and out-of-town ice skaters feels steeped in personal history
column5: Ghost's hip-hop origin story comes off like he's told it dozens of times.

column1: It's hard not to feel conflicted about Apollo Kids. Unlike Ghostface records that presumably get unfairly judged by the standards of his best work
column2: it's tempting to overrate it due a general relief that he didn't try to make Ghostdini again. And even if the initial buzz of simply getting a new LP wears off pretty quickly here
column3: it's not to the point where ""no Ghostface"" is better than ""new Ghostface."" But as with the aforementioned Weezer
column4: Ghostface's weakest output is coming at a point when he's releasing more than ever
column5: and differentiating correlation and causation just gets harder and harder: I realize the days of spiced-out Calvin Coolers are long gone
column6:
but it's also been enough time since the relatively earthbound Fishscale that I'm not certain the remedy is just slowing the fuck down.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16034/homepage_large.34a7d736.jpg|Fabric 55|8811.0|Shackleton|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fabric']|2011-01-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:54.687756|"

Sam Shackleton approaches dance music cautiously. He does this both personally (shuttering his dubstep-affiliated Skull Disco label
column2: moving to Berlin) and artistically (his intricate
column3: pattering rhythms can take months to program). Fabric 55 is one step further into the dance world
column4: expanding on the stolid gray sonics of 2009's Three EP's for a nightclub/label at the center of the techno community. But Fabric 55-- a studio-reproduced mix of Shackleton's set at the club featuring plenty of new material-- doesn't see Shackleton cast his hat into the ring of prominent DJs so much as affirm his status as an inspired squatter of whatever scene he inhabits.

column1: In his review of the first Skull Disco compilation
column2: Tim Finney said ""Shackleton's production can seem like statues... waiting for someone to enliven and animate them."" On Fabric 55
column3: Shackleton plays the animator himself
column4: carefully stitching together his own already careful work.  Like Fabric DJs Omar S and Ricardo Villalobos before him
column5: Shackleton mixes exclusively his own material.  He doesn't necessarily shed new light on his work
column6: but the shorter
column7: more transitory nature of the tracks here releases them-- Shackelton himself enlivens and animates his own productions.

column1: Shackleton all but abandons his Skull Disco tracks
column2: cutting his already tenuous ties to dubstep.  Instead he focuses on bizarro earworms (""Negative Thoughts"") and still more Middle Eastern vocal samples.  Strung together they reveal an alien noir
column3: one whose sound-world is complete enough to divorce you from the feeling of listening to techno.  In a home-listening context
column4: it's often easier to file him alongside Coil and your Edward Gorey prints as Michael Mayer or Skream.  If Shackleton's rhythms previously served primarily to hollow your mind in order to better contemplate Deep Dark Thoughts (see: ""Death Is Not Final""
column5: ""I Am Animal""
column6: etc.)
column7: they now highlight his idiosyncrasies
column8: the tilted drum timbres and haunting vocal melodies he seems completely subservient to.

column1: Shackleton's craftsmanship lends his work a resilient delicacy. His idea of a big build-and-release DJ moment appears to be to ratchet the tension up one half-notch and then sneakily ratchet it back down
column2: before anyone gets too excited.  The two-part ""Man on a String"" suite features furious
column3: jazzy hand drums and a tip-toeing synth line in what amounts to an explosion of activity.  Shackleton has always been kin to minimal techno producers
column4: but Fabric 55 isn't spare so much as careful and modest.

column1: Fabric 55 is world music in the most literal sense: It is a Londoner living in Berlin composing dance music with African rhythms
column2: reggae melodies
column3: and Far Eastern vocals.  Shackleton does this using a computer
column4: and he does it not to educate or out of deep respect for these cultures and traditions; he does it because these are some sounds he's heard and he likes them better than other sounds. I think this augurs well for Shackleton's future
column5: even if Fabric 55 sounds like a weird purgatory between the vitality of his early singles and his next true breakthrough or change-up. This mix lingers and waits; it stirs and then settles again. Rather than a career retrospective or a greatest hits package
column6:
Fabric 55 is a thoughtful moment in a singular producer's trajectory.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16035/homepage_large.0eaabe7f.jpg|Utopia EP|1613.0|Jason Forrest|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Deathbomb Arc']|2011-01-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:55.179455|"

Full disclosure: I have been licked by Jason Forrest. However
column2: I'm probably not alone
column3: as Forrest presumably tongue-bathed many a supporter in the mid-aughts while touring on the back of his two wonderfully spastic full-lengths
column4: The Unrelenting Songs of the 1979 Post-Disco Crash and Shamelessly Exciting. At the time
column5: laptop artists warranted notice for out-performing a statue on stage
column6: but Forrest's sugar-rush antics raised the bar for point-and-clickers everywhere
column7: showing that it was possible to create a party atmosphere around a guy playing air guitar to his laptop.

column1: Of course
column2: in the four years since Forrest last released music under his own name
column3: laptop dance parties have become a common sight
column4: with Girl Talk the scene's reigning superstar. Forrest meanwhile hid behind his cheeky breakcore/remixer pseudonym DJ Donna Summer
column5: concentrated on curating his labels
column6: Cock Rock Disco and Nightshifters
column7: and invented an iPhone sampler app. But with the quiet Soundcloud release of this EP and big plans for 2011
column8: Forrest seems poised to reclaim his rightful place in the world of sample abuse.

column1: Put mash-up artists on alert-- where Girl Talk and compadres are content to punch the nostalgia button dead center
column2: Forrest prefers to nibble around the edges with his copyright infringement. Consider ""My 36 Favorite Punk Songs"" from Shamelessly Exciting
column3: which is exactly what it says
column4: but dices each sample down to almost-subliminal length
column5: weaving out of those microfibers new material that is simultaneously punk and punk's mortal enemy
column6: prog. The final product is better than fair use; it's novel use.

column1: But the DJ Donna Summer experiments may have siphoned off some of Forrest's party-rock playfulness
column2: as Utopia suggests his frenetic style has been infected with something resembling maturity. Recognizable samples and skittering drumbeats-- two hallmarks of Forrest's usual style-- are scarce
column3: and the tone of the record's brief 13 minutes is less a danceable prank than a cinematic short. Opener ""Ciccone Youth"" (named for Sonic Youth's classic piece of lawyer chum) is even downright doomy
column4: slowly fading in on anxious backwards strings and ominous buzzings before dropping in martial drumming
column5: simulated heavy breathing
column6: and modem bleeps.

column1: The title track contains Forrest's most familiar rhythmic stutter-step
column2: if sparser than usual
column3: but it's over in less than a minute
column4: bleeding back into another chilling soundscape: ""Infinite Organ""
column5: haunted by guitar drones and horror-flick piano. Only the closing ""Goldbluff"" satisfies one's classic Jason Forrest craving
column6: combining classic rock carpet swatches-- a bit of Garth Hudson organ here
column7: some Chicago Transit Authority horn stabs there-- and crafting a piece of violet
column8: head-bobbing psychedelia that survives a late-term disintegration into bit-core.

column1: But just like that
column2: the enticing glimpse of Forrest's old tricks is over
column3: decaying to field recordings of slot machines. EPs are funny things; some are previews
column4: some are diversions. If Utopia is a teaser of Jason Forrest's post-metamorphosis state
column5: he's leaving behind the face-licking
column6: yielding the floor to the mash-up mashers
column7: and moving into more ponderous territory. But given Forrest's prankster past
column8:
I wouldn't bet on it.

"|14948.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14948-utopia-ep/|6.5|Rob Mitchum

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16037/homepage_large.4938449b.jpg|Worry|28375.0|Big Troubles|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Olde English Spelling Bee']|2011-01-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:56.468783|"

Upon releasing their debut album a short time ago
column2: New Jersey's Big Troubles released a statement announcing their break up. This later transpired to be a joke started by band member Sam Franklin-- also of Ridgewood's Fluffy Lumbers and Ducktails.  The statement poked fun at the increasingly common dramas of so-serious touring bands
column3: and although November was a little late for an April Fools gag
column4: Big Troubles do things on their own time.

column1: The band initially comes across as a retro act. They open their debut album
column2: Worry
column3: with ""Video Rock""
column4: pitching them right back into the early 1990s with the VHS name drop and the four-track recorded guitars on maximum gain. The blown-speakers lo-fi sound gives them an attention-grabbing aesthetic and pulls them close to their forebears
column5: lending the guitars an intensity and warmth that recalls shoegaze's noisiest moments. The most obvious nod to the original dream poppers comes with the drum stutter that ushers in ""Video Rock""
column6: tipping its hat to the first few seconds of Loveless.

column1: Despite this
column2: Big Troubles shouldn't be slotted into the same bracket as the numerous My Bloody Valentine imitators. For one
column3: they seem more intent on sculpting would-be anthems than soundscapes-- most of the songs run under three minutes
column4: and outer-space closer ""Astrology Screen Savers"" seems epic at almost four. Debut single ""Freudian Slips"" covers itself in glory
column5: with a churning beat and huge guitar riff and vocals that slip just beneath its rough surface. While the ragged sound is more crumpled bubblegum wrapper than pop
column6: it doesn't disguise the promise at work. ""Bite Yr Tongue"" is similarly irresistible
column7: with a crooning vocal carried along by fuzzy guitars that add a layer of static that threatens to detune the entire picture.

column1: At first
column2: it's exciting to chase the melodies through all the noisy wormholes
column3: but this ultimately becomes an exhausting pursuit. The brash production tends to keep the album sounding one-dimensional
column4: and what makes the record so alluring at first becomes a honey trap. In less gritty surroundings
column5: the songwriting might shine even brighter
column6: and this nagging frustration isn't helped by frontloaded sequencing that builds a heady momentum only for the record to fall beneath its own weight as it drags in the second half.

column1: The front cover of Worry shows an assortment of dilapidated furniture and electronics
column2: and Big Troubles take care to give off the same detached vibes
column3:
from the fake band break-ups to the beyond-the-red guitars. But in the middle of the clutter are some potent guitar-pop songs. And the strength of this core suggests that next time Big Troubles don't need to lean so hard on the stylistic trappings that limit the scope of Worry.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16036/homepage_large.369d0495.jpg|She Was Coloured In|29362.0|Solar Bears|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2011-01-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:57.089470|"

Ireland's Solar Bears are clearly into sci-fi. Their name is a nod to Russian filmmaker Andrei Tarkovsky's classic 1972 film
column2: Solaris
column3: about a psychologist who is haunted by what he perceives to be his dead wife aboard a space station. And while it's easy to call up images of oceanic planets while listening to the duo's debut LP
column4: She Was Coloured In
column5: conjuring the emotionally complex and ruminative themes at work in a film like Solaris is much more difficult. Solar Bears instead seem to take their inspiration from less sophisticated fare
column6: as much of She Was Coloured In feels like the soundtrack to a cheesy
column7: choose-your-own-ending sci-fi novel you might pick up at a yard sale. But this is no slight
column8: despite a proclivity for epic synth lines and rhythm-driven tracks built for B-movie chase sequences. Solar Bears are able to cleverly balance their nerdier impulses by taking cues from Air's most amorous leanings and shading their music with the dark electronics that mark contemporaries like Matthew Dear and CFCF.

column1: On one end of the spectrum are songs like ""Head Supernova"" and ""The Quiet Planet""
column2: which sound like what people in the 1950s must have assumed the music of 2011 would be like
column3: while ""Solarization"" could have easily stood in as an early ""Nova"" theme song. These cosmically fanciful tracks sometimes threaten to overwhelm the more restrained moments
column4: especially considering the record's clumsy sequencing. But as producers continue to warm to the idea of integrating unhip
column5: dated 80s motifs into their music
column6: it seems frivolous to scold Solar Bears for pushing it a little.

column1: Having a strongly defined sound doesn't mean you aren't allowed to play around
column2: and Solar Bears make the most of these excursions. ""Cub"" features a chilly acoustic guitar at its center
column3: overlapped by a soft
column4: woodwind-like swell. ""Primary Colours at the Back of My Mind"" mirrors Air's ""Playground Love"" so closely it almost borders on plagiarism
column5: all hazed-out on 70s FM slow-burn sexy. But the finishing touches-- melting orchestral flourishes
column6: wah-wah'd porno guitar
column7: some perfectly plain drums-- all showcase Solar Bears' ability to get the details right.

column1: So the very best stuff on She Was Coloured In manages to touch all the bases
column2: using the low-key moments for atmosphere and juicing them up with stylish genre tweaks. ""She Was Coloured In"" pulses with a progged-out
column3: psychedelic energy
column4: while ""Crystalline (Be Again)"" is a delicate club jam that oozes late-era New Order. Highlight ""Dolls"" ambitiously drags bleary
column5: wistful keys and strings through an epically aggressive trip-hop suite
column6: followed by an anthemic final act. In these moments
column7:
She Was Coloured really pops; the mysteries of the universe as imagined in a pulp novel seem to come into focus.

"|14944.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14944-she-was-coloured-in/|6.9|Zach Kelly

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16031/homepage_large.e464aa5b.jpg|Tron: Legacy OST|990.0|Daft Punk|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Walt Disney']|2010-12-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:57.662343|"

This is not the new Daft Punk album. It's a score for a Disney franchise film that cost an estimated $200 million to make. As such
column2: there are  lots of classical-inspired strings and horns played by an 85-strong  orchestra. Most of the soundtrack's 22 pieces don't last more than three  minutes; only a few could be considered actual songs. And while we knew  this was going to be a score since it was first reported nearly two  years ago
column3: it's tough to shake the gloom of blown expectations while  listening to the same ominous theme as it repeats in slightly  mutated forms across the hour-long soundtrack. The French duo's current  move is almost undeniably disappointing
column4: but it's also not a surprise.

column1: Daft Punk aren't the same two guys who made Homework and Discovery. Over the course of the last decade
column2: Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo and Thomas Bangalter have increasingly relied on images to complement-- and sometimes justify-- their music. Since their last proper LP
column3: 2005's Human After All
column4: the pair staged the greatest dance music tour of all time-- one that  blasted its audience with enough visual stimuli to leave them blinking  stars for hours. The pyramid
column5: the gleaming helmets
column6: and the lite-bright  leather jackets brought Daft Punk's greatest hits to a holy
column7: undiscovered realm. Their 2006 art-house indulgence Electroma went even further as it was directed by the twosome yet featured no new music. Daft Punk haven't even attempted a can't-miss song in at least five years
column8: and the Tron: Legacy soundtrack keeps that unfortunate streak alive.

column1: The score keeps another trend going
column2: too. Bangalter and de Homem-Christo have flexed their robot obsession for years
column3: but its nature has changed. On Discovery tracks like ""Digital Love""
column4: ""Something About Us""
column5: and ""Harder
column6: Better
column7: Faster
column8: Stronger""
column9: they employed robotic voice effects to bring out the childlike naïveté of artificial intelligence. And Discovery's accompanying animated movie
column10: Interstella 5555
column11: was a bright and fun technicolor cartoon. But their mechanized fantasies have gotten continually darker since then-- consider the much more sinister robo effects on Human After All's ""The Brainwasher"" and ""Television Rules the Nation"". Electroma's two metal-machine leads commit harrowing self-destruct suicides. Most of the robot doomsaying can't compare with their ebullient side; their apocalyptic visions are hardly Philip K. Dick-worthy
column12: and they're oftentimes a huge bummer to boot.

column1: Tron: Legacy is rated PG and aimed at igniting the imaginations of 10-year-old boys. When I watched it in IMAX 3D it was easy to revert back to my younger self and just gawk at the exquisite whiz-bang of it all. That said
column2: it's pretty fucking dark. Most of the movie takes place in a virtual world that doesn't know sunlight-- it's like a futuristic version of Tolkien's Mordor. Almost all of the post-Han Solo humor that buoyed the original Tron is replaced by a thunderous seriousness (and blue-black color scheme) more akin to The Dark Knight. And the music follows suit with endless crescendos of pounding timpani drums and monolithic strings. Naturally
column3: the music synchs a hell of a lot better when you're watching the stunning images it was made to accompany. Daft Punk's score plays a vital role in making this poorly scripted mega movie seem bigger and more important than it actually is.

column1: Even so
column2: it hems frustratingly close to the sweeping classical film music style pioneered by John Williams (Star Wars) and picked up by Howard Shore (The Lord of the Rings) and Hans Zimmer (The Dark Knight). The Tron: Legacy score's supposed innovation is combining an orchestra style with electronics
column3: but the meshing of the two styles is rare and rudimentary.  More often than not
column4: each piece is either mostly synth-based (including filter-house also-rans ""Derezzed"" and ""Tron Legacy (End Titles)"") or symphonic (""Nocturne""
column5: ""Outlands""). When they pull off the combo-- as on the blistering ""The Game Has Changed""-- it's thrilling even without an IMAX  screen hijacking your senses. And while the classical arrangements mark  a new style for Daft Punk
column6: it's hardly revelatory in the sphere of movie scores at large.

column1: Watching the movie
column2: I couldn't help but  think that this was Daft Punk's attempt at topping their legendary  pyramid tour. Theoretically
column3: by teaming up with Disney and the most  high-tech cameras and surround-sound systems and recording facilities  known to man
column4: the two could could dive bomb into the minds of millions of people in one immense opening weekend and stay consistent with their man vs. machine ideology-- all without leaving the comfort of their own homes. But the tour was phenomenal because they were the central characters-- not just a side act-- and because it was delusionally fun. Tron: Legacy has flashes of that sort of brilliance
column5: but it's downright puny compared  to the sheer joy that is ""One More Time"" or ""Around the World"". Daft  Punk used to be a couple of guys hellbent on making genius dance music who  happened to wear goofy robot helmets. Along the way
column6: though
column7:
their priorities seem to have changed.

"|14938.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14938-tron-legacy-ost/|5.5|Ryan Dombal

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16030/homepage_large.9bf7b481.jpg|Golden Haze EP|28353.0|Wild Nothing|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2010-12-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:58.105145|"

Whether digging through the crates at a used CD store
column2: or plumbing the depths of Amazon
column3: one of the great thrills of being a music fan is discovering a certain style that appeals to you
column4: and seeing just how deeply you can immerse yourself in it before coming up for air. Gemini felt like Jack Tatum was sharing that feeling with all of us-- that first experience with a Smiths or Cocteau Twins album when you wonder
column5: ""Where has this been all of my life?"" That he made his album stand out amidst a formidable number of similar acts was a testament to how well he could extract one recognizable cell from the past and spawn it into something wholly his own
column6: reverential but hardly derivative.

column1: Golden Haze initially appears to be the culmination of Wild Nothing's big year
column2: collecting the previously available Evertide EP
column3: a Gemini B-side
column4: and two new tracks. But as a State of Wild Nothing Report
column5: it shows that Tatum is nowhere near done messing with his favorite musical ingredients. While still enamored with 1980s UK indie
column6: like so much of Gemini
column7: the maneuvering here sneaks up on you. The sunny jungle of ""Summer Holiday"" is almost completely forgone for something sleeker and darker
column8: more along the lines of Gemini standouts ""Chinatown"" or ""Bored Games"".

column1: It's a good look for him
column2: considering Tatum's knack for succinct romantic pleas (""beautiful one
column3: I want to go where you are"") and weaving chains of floral guitar notes
column4: both of which propel the gorgeous title track. It's one of Wild Nothing's strongest singles
column5: but it's also where he starts to tweak the arrangements
column6: particularly with drums. The textural mesh of its severely-gated snare and sleigh bells recalls the Cure's ""Just Like Heaven""
column7: and Tatum's portentous and maudlin vocal range invites further comparisons to Robert Smith.

column1: Oddly enough
column2: the one selection from Golden Haze EP that would've been the most jarring inclusion on Gemini is actually a B-side from ""Summer Holiday""-- ""Vultures Like Lovers"" is pure
column3: ecstatic texture
column4: a heavily processed guitar ping-ponging with delay
column5: and Tatum's tremolo'd vocals building a cyclone from the ground up. It's the sort of experiment that ends up as a B-side for a reason
column6:
but its inclusion is evidence of what I find most charming about Wild Nothing: The combination of decades-old influence with the ability to see a modern prolific talent progress almost in real time.

"|14937.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14937-golden-haze-ep/|7.7|Ian Cohen

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16016/homepage_large.4cc95908.jpg|No Mercy|4400.0|T.I.|['Rap'
column3: No Mercy was going to be called King Uncaged. Its cover was going to feature T.I.
column4: in front of a stark white background
column5: sunk deep into a wicker throne
column6: a lion standing by his side. King Uncaged
column7: an album we'll now presumably never hear
column8: was to be Tip's first after he completed almost a year in prison
column9: finishing up a gun sentence that could've sent him away for a whole lot longer. This was supposed to be the final triumphant chapter in Tip's redemption story
column10: and everybody loves shit like that. Instead
column11: life intervened. A Los Angeles traffic stop led to a drug arrest and a parole violation
column12: and now T.I. is headed right back to prison for another 11 months. So No Mercy is a confused muddle
column13: some of the material presumably recorded before the arrest and some of it after. It's called No Mercy presumably because King Recaged wasn't catchy enough
column14: and the album cover seems to be T.I. either wiping away a tear or punching himself in the face. Given how the album turned out
column15: the face-punch is exactly the right gesture.

column1: T.I. sounds best when he's in dominant form
column2: tossing punchlines at inferior rappers from a great height. His best tracks come with a sense of inevitability; you know
column3: from the first moment you hear them
column4: that they're going to boom out of passing cars for months to come. ""What You Know"" worked like that. ""Rubber Band Man"" worked like that. Even ""Whatever You Like"" worked like that. Absolutely nothing on No Mercy works like that. Simply put
column5: introspection does not work for T.I. At this point
column6: he has nothing thought-provoking left to say about his gun arrest or its aftermath
column7: and it's no fun whatsoever to hear him say ""I'm only human"" or ""Apologies to the fans"" for the millionth time. But No Mercy is his third straight album of halfassed introspection. The things that were boring or simplistic about his forced humility have only gotten worse. On No Mercy
column8: he sounds absolutely sapped of energy. And that's rough; nobody plays the ferocious livewire better.

column1: The last time Tip made an album like this
column2: he was just about to head off to prison
column3: and he scored the biggest hit of his career with the maudlin but catchy ""Live Your Life"". Here
column4: he tries to repeat that success
column5: roping in a wide and dazzling cast of collaborators to chase a commercial hit that he sounds too depleted to actually score. No Mercy
column6: I'm almost positive
column7: is the first album to feature contributions from both Swedish pop mastermind Max Martin and Houston rap O.G. Scarface. The assembled list of guests and contributors is just nuts: Kanye West
column8: Eminem
column9: Drake
column10: Christina Aguilera
column11: Dr. Luke
column12: the Neptunes. But too often
column13: this amazing assemblage of talents seems to want to make introspective Flo Rida tracks-- and
column14: worse
column15: they fail at it. ""Big Picture"" has an emaciated synth-rap track so tinny that I can barely believe DJ Toomp produced it. The-Dream has never sounded more like Chester Bennington than he does on the ill-advised crunch-rock title track. And album closer ""Castle Walls"" is downright insulting-- Tip wallowing in his rich-guy sorrows as a wave of gloopy Europop keyboard washes over him. ""Everyone thinks I have it all
column16: but it's so empty living behind these castle walls
column17: Christina Aguilera sings on the hook. Yeah
column18: that must be really tough. My sympathies
column19: rich people.

column1: Throughout No Mercy
column2: Tip remains an absolutely impeccable rapper
column3: delivering even his lamest pieces of self-help nothingness in masterful clumps of singsong cadence and slurry double-time bounce. I get the impression that he could still absolutely rip a track to shreds if he could only get himself excited about the prospect. And every so often
column4: No Mercy crackles to life
column5: and we hear flashes of the rap hero Tip could still be. ""Amazing""
column6: for instance
column7: finds the Neptunes taking it back to 2002
column8: delivering the sort of chilly minimalist computer-funk that they never make anymore
column9: and Tip just dives into those chasms of empty space with the assurance of an old pro (Pharrell gets the best punchline
column10: though: ""That dark blue shit? Y'all niggas been had/ My diamonds rainbowed like they registered for GLAAD.""). And ""I Can't Help It"" is a blaring
column11: menacing gangsta-rap crawl that gives Tip a chance to just attack in a way he rarely lets himself anymore. But a quick guest appearance on ""Strip"" highlights everything that's wrong with even the album's best moments. T.I.'s exuberant protege Young Dro careens onto the track with the sort of joyous virtuosity that T.I. used to display. Maybe he'll show it again. Not for at least another 11 months
column12:
though.

"|14923.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14923-no-mercy/|5.5|Tom Breihan

column2:
Volume 1|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Night Slugs']|2010-12-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:59.208610|"

The title here has to be just a little tongue-in-cheek: The Night Slugs label has only been around for about a year
column3: and this compilation covers literally every artist who has recorded original material for it. One way to read it is that they're all stars-- corny
column4: I know
column5: but the label's releases have been noticeably consistent (or at least consistently interesting) since they started coming out in January
column6: demonstrating a cross-section of UK dance music whose influences are all over the map: southern U.S. rap
column7: London grime
column8: a little bit of dubstep
column9: Detroit techno
column10: Dâm-Funk-style electro-funk
column11: etc. Throwing proper nouns at this music is fun for genre wonks
column12: but the reality is that the comp works well because it makes all that variety explicit.

column1: Still
column2: the marks that unify Night Slugs are as obvious to my ears as the ones that vary it. Most of the label's productions are colorful and brash
column3: working not only through layers of sound but head-on collisions of them. If the music were generally less imaginative than it is
column4: I'd say that the urgency and pride with which it all foregrounds its glitz borders on tasteless
column5: but Night Slugs know to whom they're appealing
column6: and it's not the folks thoughtfully nodding their heads in the corner. Some of the synths here are noxious enough to peel paint from the walls
column7: and though the futurist crunk of Girl Unit's ""Wut"" is the only song to feature an actual airhorn
column8: airhorns are implied throughout. There is exactly one track that could probably be described as ""laid-back"" here-- Jacques Greene's ""(Baby I Don't Know) What You Want""-- and its runner-up is called ""Booty Slammer"".

column1: Night Slugs' record covers-- all designed by co-founder and label contributor Bok Bok-- are always combinations of black and one or two other colors
column2: presented in various shades. Usually
column3: the image is geometric and semi-architectural (a suspension bridge and car; glowing pistons spelling out words)
column4: but presented ag

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
ainst a completely black background in a way that makes them look iconic
column2: like they're without space or landscape. I mention them because they're a strong analogue for the label's musical style: Not only do the bright colors sing in the darkness
column3: but they're given a proper spectrum. In the same way the tracks remind me that there's a lot of range to be extracted from the seemingly monotonous blast of a rave synth
column4: the covers remind me that hot pink can get as close to purple as it can to white-- range in places you might expect to be limited. Listen to this comp more than a few times and you'll probably start to hear chasms between stuff like Bok Bok & Cubic Zirconia's ""Reclash (Dub)"" and Girl Unit's ever-luxurious ""Wut"". The palettes are similar
column5: but the ends to which they're used-- and the moods they evoke-- are different.

column1: People who've followed the label since its inception-- and before that
column2: when it was just a club night-- will diddle around with arguments about what should or shouldn't've made it onto this comp. Those arguments can be fun
column3: like: Two tracks from Lil Silva seems more generous toward Lil Silva than to us as listeners; ""She Wore Velour"" is a more obvious choice for Velour than ""Booty Slammer""; and ""Bust Broke"" as a choice for Kingdom feels willfully evasive when we have ""Fogs""
column4: but they're both good. On the other hand
column5: Bok Bok gives Girl Unit's ""IRL"" a remix
column6: and Jam City's ""Arpjam""-- one of the comp's new tracks-- indicates that regardless of whether Night Slugs are ready to put out Volume 2 by 2012
column7:
they're not slowing down just yet.

"|14927.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14927-night-slugs-allstars-volume-1/|8.1|Mike Powell

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/16018/homepage_large.d45b2ef5.jpg|Autre Ne Veut|29170.0|Autre Ne Veut|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Olde English Spelling Bee']|2010-12-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:35:59.870420|"

One of the lessons of this past year is that there's surprisingly fertile ground to be tilled between D'Angelo and Avey Tare. Between them
column2: stripped-down R&B and arty
column3: slurry
column4: ritualistic avant-pop privilege a similar kind of guilelessness. Both modes do impressionism well
column5: and both have no problem letting vocals veer into the moans and murmurs one might hear at a séance. Differences abound
column6: of course
column7: but so do signs of fruitful communion-- among them Autre Ne Veut. A one-man act from New York (he prefers to keep his identity secret)
column8: Autre Ne Veut shares qualities and a scene with acts like How to Dress Well
column9: Games
column10: and
column11: less directly
column12: soul-aspiring indie bands from Bon Iver to Yeasayer. But Autre Ne Veut has something special. For one thing
column13: every song on his self-titled debut is a marvel
column14: each in its own way. For another
column15: the way he steers his voice toward the eccentricities and extremes of R&B sounds disarmingly logical
column16: natural
column17: and heartfelt.

column1: To speak of R&B in this context might just be another way of saying
column2: ""He really sings-- like
column3: he really leans into it."" But it's less his voice than his way with hooks and trills and melody that signals Autre Ne Veut as someone who could transcend the arty underground (if he wanted to
column4: which he may well not). Wherever they find a context
column5: the songs on Autre Ne Veut are packed
column6: concise
column7: abstract pop dynamos. The disarming album opener ""Tell Me"" spins like a pop song in a centrifuge
column8: with Autre Ne Veut singing against himself in overdubbed layers over a backing track that manages to cast harsh
column9: disorienting electronic smears in a comely melodic role. It's seriously out-there stuff
column10: but also
column11: oddly
column12: possessed of a directness and clarity that could work just as well on a lost album by someone like Billy Ocean.

column1: There's also a sort of bravery at play in some of Autre Ne Veut's more unflinching moves. In ""O.M.G.""
column2: he lays down his guard with lyrcs directed to a prospective paramour-- ""Oh my god
column3: I can feel it in my body
column4: and
column5: ""Everyone says it's the perfect night""-- that are sung as if by someone half-remembering an older cousin's tales of what 1980s pop radio sounded like. But then the song snakes around and finds Autre Ne Veut hesitant to do the deed-- filled with neuroses and empathy for someone he'd rather not hurt
column6: even if by chance. ""I don't want to be your heartbreak
column7: he sings. ""I don't want to be the one to make you want to have to work.""

column1: ""Wake Up"" is comparatively spare
column2: with Autre Ne Veut urging himself to get out of a relationship in a severe falsetto. Parts of his vocals peal into a sort of demonic mode (like Avey Tare when he pushes past his range)
column3: and the subtle
column4: spacious track behind him is rendered by cheap digital gear. But again
column5: there's no overstating how also sturdy and strong it is as a certifiable ""pop"" song in the end. The same goes even more for songs that totally go for it
column6: too. Over a hooky strobe effect and some chintzy
column7: chancy chimes that give everything a sense of grandeur
column8: ""Drama Cum Drama"" lays out a store of great melodic vocal ideas that Autre Ne Veut files through with seemingly very little effort or deliberation. He does the same on other highlights like ""Two Days of Rain""
column9: ""New Depth""
column10:
and ""Soldier"". The way really gifted guitarists or keyboardists might attach little arpeggios or counterpoint lines to a melody while just fiddling around? Autre Ne Veut does that with his voice. He jams.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/16014/homepage_large.dc62af22.jpg|First Four EPs|29131.0|OFF!|['Rock'
column2:
'Metal']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Vice']|2010-12-09 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:00.577812|"

The very last scene in the 2006 documentary American Hardcore finds Zander Schloss of the Circle Jerks delivering a eulogy. ""It was over a long time ago! It's over
column3: okay? Go home! Your cage is clean."" The screen goes black just as Black Flag's ""Nervous Breakdown"" starts up; the vocal is by Keith Morris
column4: Black Flag co-founder and Schloss' longtime boss in the Circle Jerks. It's a funny juxtaposition
column5: considering the recent history of the Circle Jerks; though Morris attempted to keep the Jerks' engine running after yet another failed go
column6: he and Burning Brides frontman Dimitri Coats teamed up
column7: called a couple of buddies
column8: ground out 16 songs. The results would stop in their tracks anybody who'd dare declare punk rock dead. Morris was around for the birth of hardcore
column9: and from the sound of his new band OFF!
column10: they're going to have to drag him away from the stuff
column11: screaming.

column1: For OFF!
column2: Morris and Coats rang up bassist Steven McDonald of the perennially underrated Redd Kross
column3: and Rocket From the Crypt/Earthless drummer Mario ""Ruby Mars"" Rubalcaba. Coats may be OFF!'s least known quantity
column4: but here
column5: as with the stoner rock of his Brides
column6: he's got an adaptable style and ear for detail that are perfect for this recapturing job. McDonald holds down the low end with an uncharacteristic simplicity that suits these airtight tracks to a T. And Ruby Mars couldn't have been a tough call
column7: hell of a drummer that he is; you'd have to be to hold these songs together. These guys might be punks
column8: but after years in the game
column9: they're total pros. And all that backstory melts away in three seconds on this bruiser of a record
column10: one that reignites the hardcore spirit and turn-on-a-dime intensity of Morris' work with Black Flag and early Circle Jerks years without ever coming off like a history lesson.

column1: OFF! is Morris' show
column2: and for all their help getting him back to his roots
column3: the band keeps out of his way
column4: firing off blistering
column5: not-a-second-too-long rumbles that feel shot out of a cannon. But having some new blood in the room lights a raging fire under Morris
column6: and he pounces on these tracks. As ever
column7: he speak-shouts with an unusual clarity
column8: even when he's spraying out a ton of words at once. But it's the adaptability of his voice that's most stunning
column9: the way he'll start out spitting and then swoop down into a scream. Lyrically
column10: the OFF! songs seem to play on Morris' role as an angry young man all grown up; a line like ""you wonder why I'm always screaming?"" would sound fine coming from some 17-year-old with a glue-stuck mohawk
column11: but given Morris' elder statespunk position
column12: the question deepens
column13: the emphasis falls on the ""always."" The young dude declaring ""I've Had It"" three decades back still shouts ""Fuck People"" with equal fervor.

column1: First Four EPs crams 16 tracks into just over 17 minutes; the thing's packed so tightly
column2: an extra second here or there could feel like one too many. This is lean
column3: propulsive hardcore
column4: played just as it would've been in L.A. circa 1981. The live-in-a-room recording lets you all but hear the sweat drip on the mic
column5: Morris' hair slapping into Coats' amp. The breathless intensity of Morris' vocals is matched by the one-and-done feel of the musicianship; as Coats told Pitchfork last month
column6: ""the demo is the record
column7: and no decision's been overthought. Morris spent a decade and a half trying to get the Circle Jerks together enough to make another album
column8: and this thing sounds like it was made in two days
column9: almost for the hell of it
column10: and those lowered stakes result in a ramped-up fervor.

column1: Even with the short runtime
column2: First Four EPs really takes it out of you; each EP takes you through highs and lows in quick succession
column3: so hearing all four straight through is like being put through a tenderizer. For all their ripchord intensity
column4: I wish they'd made just a little more room for McDonald
column5: whose work with Redd Kross proved him more adept at sneaking intricate bass lines under hardcore rhythms than he's allowed here. But these are
column6: after all
column7: the first four EPs
column8: which assumes there's more to come. You could argue that there's a nasty conservative streak running through these four EPs
column9: that Morris already made better versions of this record with his previous bands. But OFF! feels less like a regression than a regrouping
column10: a shoring up of old strengths with the hopes of recapturing an old feeling. And that much they nail.

column1: In an indie rock landscape that typically values complex arrangements
column2: subtlety
column3: and good taste
column4: OFF! are not just refreshing
column5: but  totally necessary. It's an economic shithole out there right now-- the  same conditions that led to hardcore in the first place. This music is built  for a climate of frustration and powerlessness
column6:
and its bare-knuckled punch-in-the-face is a long-needed wake-up call to nostalgic escapism. Get mad instead.

"|14919.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14919-first-four-eps/|8.5|Paul Thompson

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16026/homepage_large.93256b0c.jpg|Land and Fixed|27782.0|Blank Dogs|['Rock'
column2:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Captured Tracks']|2010-12-09 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:01.153189|"

Never let it be said that Mike Sniper doesn't put his money where his mouth is. The roster for his Captured Tracks label is a veritable who's-who of any up-and-coming lo-fi indie bands
column3: and his own hyper-prolific recording project
column4: Blank Dogs
column5: is no exception.  While some lo-fi groups have been accused of hiding their musical shortcomings with generous helpings of static
column6: those claims can't be made against Sniper.  His self-avowed ""blown-out Factory Records demos"" are intentionally undercut by Sniper's distorted vocals.  The end result is a friction between vocals and music
column7: akin to This Heat taking on the Joy Division catalog
column8: and it raises Blank Dogs above most of their like-minded peers.

column1: It might come as a shock to long-time fans
column2: then
column3: that Land and Fixed doesn't immediately sound like a Blank Dogs record. The most obvious difference is the recording quality. The success of both Captured Tracks and Sniper's own music allowed him to purchase better recording equipment
column4: and that's clearly evident from the first few seconds of ""Goes By"". Blank Dogs have always had synthesizers as part of their mix
column5: but they've never been as prominent
column6: or sounded as good as they do here.  It's a bold step forward
column7: but it doesn't come at the expense of the group's innate wanderlust.  If anything
column8: it's helped clarify its eclectic sound.  On previous records
column9: the distended futuristic funk moves of ""Insides"" might have sounded oddly similar to the twee-pop of ""Northern Islands"" or the instrumental space-age voyage taken by ""Elevens"". Here
column10: the quality of the recording lets these various flavors better distinguish themselves from each other
column11: which goes a long way toward making the album an enjoyable listen.

column1: However
column2: the upgrade in fidelity doesn't come without a cost. While the music on Land and Fixed revels in this newfound clarity
column3: the vocals are still processed and manipulated.  Where that juxtaposition worked on earlier recordings (when the two sides were still on the same playing field)
column4: it doesn't coalesce nearly as well here. Tunes like ""Blurred Tonight"" and ""Languages"" could benefit from a more straightforward turn at the mic; they're instead subjected to the same obfuscated singing as other Blank Dogs songs.  Ironically
column5: now that Blank Dogs have seemingly moved beyond the need for low-grade sonics
column6: the band is leaning on that particular crutch more than ever.  Befitting the group's skittishness
column7: the next Blank Dogs record is slated to be a set of instrumentals reminiscent of ""Elevens""
column8: which will remove contending with this issue.  However
column9: the next time Blank Dogs book some studio time to record their next set of vocals
column10:
here's hoping they show the same courage there that they've shown musically on Land and Fixed.

"|14933.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14933-land-and-fixed/|7.3|David Raposa

column2:

Koen Holtkamp is one-half of the post-kosmische duo Mountains. He and his Mountains partner-in-chime Brendon Anderegg gradually and intermittently layer different instruments-- mostly guitars
column3: but also rattles
column4: melodicas
column5: and wood blocks-- using an array of pedals
column6: eventually retreading into their laptops to wield the resulting chaos into a breathless
column7: engulfing whorl. As a solo artist
column8: Holtkamp crafted the most elaborate and varied record in the Mountains discography
column9: 2008's Field Rituals
column10: which found him obfuscating field recordings though erosion and effects
column11: then playing symphonic and folksy guitar and keyboard parts over them. Gravity/Bees is no less expansive in sound
column12: but it's a smaller and more specific record.

column1: The album
column2: as its title suggests
column3: is binary: Its two tracks
column4: ""In the Absence of Gravity Please Note the Position of the Sun"" and ""Loosely Based on Bees""
column5: scrape the 15-minute mark. Each is an alteration of a performance: The first morphs a live show in Brighton; the second
column6: bees working in a hive. Unlike many of the selections on Field Rituals
column7: which pulsated and liquefied
column8: the two works here are horizontal and gaseous. The misty tones and harmonicas that open ""In the Absence of Gravity"" are punctured by the tapping stabs of acoustic guitar strings
column9: imparting a spatial interference that is jarring at first but pleasant with more listens.

column1: ""Loosely Based on Bees"" has a more perverse trick up its sleeve: The opening murmur of bees is not the violent buzzing we might expect-- they're soothing and soft. But as instruments are added on
column2: the music becomes more confrontational
column3: as do the buzzing sounds. The implication is that things we find most frightening can often be peaceful
column4: while things we find comforting can also end up frightening.

column1: Like Field Rituals
column2: Gravity/Bees is pleasant in sound but not dull enough to sink into the wallpaper. But unlike Field Rituals
column3: its simultaneous expansion of space and reduction of texture makes it a little less confrontational. It doesn't make it less contemplative
column4: but it's the kind of music that drifts
column5:
occasionally distracting yet otherwise hypnotically distant.

"|14910.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14910-gravitybees/|7.7|Tal Rosenberg

'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['V2']|2010-12-09 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:02.247640|"

Blood Red Shoes have been hiding in plain sight. Since 2005
column3: the Brighton-based duo of drummer Steve Ansell and guitarist Laura-Mary Carter have released a handful of singles and one album
column4: 2008's Box of Secrets
column5: on major label V2. They've toured extensively at home
column6: throughout the EU
column7: and been billed at festivals from ATP to Pukkelpop.

column1: They mostly forgot about the United States
column2: though. While their post-punk peers and countrymen-- Foals
column3: Arctic Monkeys-- have made frequent sojourns to American shores
column4: Ansell and Carter have
column5: for whatever reason
column6: kept primarily in Europe. The band's first wide stateside exposure has come only recently
column7: via the soundtrack to the Michael Cera flick Scott Pilgrim vs. the World
column8: which includes their song ""It's Getting Boring By the Sea"". It's too bad it took so long. Blood Red Shoes are an excellent riffs-and-rhythm rock band-- they make classic bash-and-scrape music with a debt to 1990s-era heroes Fugazi
column9: Drive Like Jehu
column10: and Nirvana.

column1: Now word is starting to get around a little more. This fall Blood Red Shoes completed one blink-and-you'll-miss-it U.S. tour
column2: and the band's sophomore effort
column3: Fire Like This
column4: has gotten a worldwide release
column5: though it's iTunes-only in North America. It's as good an introduction to the band as any-- Blood Red Shoes haven't altered their sound too much over the years. But Ansell and Carter are clever enough shuffle the familiar elements around. Album opener ""Don't Ask"" hands over the chorus immediately
column6: then falls back to a stop-start verse. They use the same trick on ""Keeping It Close""-- seizing attention with the hookiest
column7: highest volume riff.

column1: Ansell and Carter are relatively young-- 24 and 22 respectively-- but they've been around long enough to know how to avoid clichés. Ansell in particular is an old hand. He was a founding member of post-punk outfit Projections and emotional noisemakers Cat on Form
column2: who released a few records on Southern. Both sing here
column3: but Ansell gets most of the good lines. He has a bratty but melodic delivery that keeps the stripped-down verses chugging. Carter isn't bad
column4: either
column5: but she's too often stuck on ballad duty. The best moments come when they play off of one another-- trading off lines and alternating back-up duties
column6: like the interplay on ""One More Empty Chair"".

column1: On Box of Secrets
column2: the pair limited their arrangements to herky-jerky blasts of distortion and drums. On Fire Like This
column3: Blood Red Shoes favor slow builds-- stretching out repetitions for big
column4: noisy crescendos. Those hands-in-the-air moments are not always within their grasp
column5: however. Carter's ""When We Wake"" gets tedious during the three-minute climb toward its inevitable fuzz-box stomp. But ""Colours Fade"" unfolds into head-banging abandon. In its best moments
column6: Fire Like This strikes a balance between heartfelt and heavy. Blood Red Shoes may be squat-hall sized
column7:
but they are arena-equipped.

"|14932.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14932-fire-like-this/|7.4|Aaron Leitko

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16021/homepage_large.bb979070.jpg|Dead Head|3670.0|Residual Echoes|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Teenage Teardrops']|2010-12-09 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:02.697092|"

Dead Head is far from Adam Payne's first spin around the block. As the frontman of Residual Echoes
column2: he's crafted folk-rock drenched in acid and hung out to drip-dry in the California sun for almost seven years. But there's something about Dead Head that-- despite being Payne's ninth official release-- feels like a debut record.

column1: It could be that this is the first solidified lineup of the band's history (drummer Allen Bleyle and bassist Greg Arnold make up the rhythm section); it could be that this record sounds far more polished than the rough
column2: almost demo-like quality of past albums; but it's mostly because Dead Head has a greater sense of purpose than anything previously bearing the Residual Echoes name. After folky intro ""Warts""
column3: the album goes into warp speed for the rest of its 38-minute run
column4: with incinerating guitar solos shooting sparks all over the place.

column1: More than two-thirds of ""Chopper"" is filled with this blistering six-string work
column2: taking exploratory detours and tossing in a couple of seconds of stark silence before the blistering climax
column3: recalling the nimble (and outrageously loud) fretwork of J Mascis. In fact
column4: about six of the album's nine tracks adhere to this same template: fast tempo
column5: exploratory guitar solo
column6: hell
column7: they're almost all written in the same key. The solos are always interesting
column8: even bordering on remarkable
column9: but the songs suffer from a lack of more diverse songwriting. The album's highlight
column10: ""Fugks""
column11: slows down the tempo and builds around a gorgeously laidback quasi-surf riff before settling into Neil Young-inspired songwriting. Sadly
column12: it's one of the album's rare diversions into stylistic variety.

column1: Essentially
column2: Dead Head actually does play like Residual Echoes' debut release; everything is urgent and high-stakes
column3: but it sounds more like the work of a young band settling into a sound
column4:
rather than a seasoned band knowing what works and using it as a springboard to see what else they can do.
