column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16023/homepage_large.e9de24a8.jpg|Bonus Tracks 2008-2009|3916.0|Spoon|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2010-12-08 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:04.291615|"

Over the course of the past decade
column2: Spoon have earned a reputation as one of  the most meticulous and stylized studio perfectionists in rock. Their aesthetic is unmistakable-- the percussion is crisp and  in-the-pocket
column3: the instrumentation is bone dry
column4: and tight performances  get juxtaposed with moments of off-the-cuff improvisation. Their style  is so distinct that when Britt Daniel and Jim Eno have exported it to  various artists they've produced such as White Rabbits
column5: Anya Marina
column6: and  Sally Crewe
column7: they all end up sounding more than a little bit like Spoon.

column1: Given all of this deliberate studio craftsmanship
column2: it's a little bit  surprising that they've made a practice of releasing a steady stream of  demo recordings on their official website. After all
column3: most artists this  particular about their sound tend to shy away from putting out anything  that isn't flawlessly executed. Clearly
column4: Spoon are not hung up about that sort of thing: The 10 demos and alternate versions on Bonus Tracks 2008-2009 present the band at their most sloppy and casual
column5: offering hardcore fans an intriguing glimpse into the group's creative process without entirely demystifying what they do.

column1: Aside from having been initially given away as free mp3s on the Spoon website between 2008 and 2009
column2: there isn't any particular rhyme or reason to  the selection of recordings in this set. Aside from the non-album tune ""In the Right Place the Right Time""
column3: all the songs are from Kill the Moonlight
column4: Gimme Fiction
column5: or Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga. In come cases
column6: like ""Rhythm & Soul"" and ""Don't Let It Get You Down""
column7: the  arrangements and performances aren't much different from what ended up  on album
column8: though the recording is a lot more raw and lo-fi. These cuts  aren't particularly interesting or useful. It's more fun to hear them  put a country rock spin on a familiar song like ""You Got Yr. Cherry  Bomb""
column9: or attempt a version of ""Was It You?"" that integrates elements from electro and Afrobeat.

column1: Only a couple of tracks offer any sort of clear window on the band's songwriting process. The version of ""My Mathematical Mind"" here is especially rough and bare bones
column2: sounding almost as though Daniel is  still writing the song as he plays it while ad libbing silly provisional  lyrics like ""I'm gonna try chicken-fried snake."" He's similarly playful  and loose on the ""writing exercise"" version of ""Eddie's Raga""
column3: which is about half the length of what appears on Ga Ga Ga Ga Ga though more or less fully formed.

column1: The most frustrating thing about Bonus Tracks is that for a compilation of this nature
column2: it's not nearly complete enough to be satisfying. It's over  and out in less than a half hour
column3: and while that may be perfectly  reasonable in terms of listenability
column4: this small arbitrary collection of demos only scratches the surface of what ought to be the band's answer to the Beatles' Anthology or Guided By Voices' Suitcase series. While it's nice that the band apparently values concision even when it comes to vault-clearing stocking-stuffer releases
column5: it seems to miss the point of putting this stuff out there in  the first place. If we want to listen to an album
column6: we'll put on one of  the studio records. However
column7: if we're feeling nerdy enough to check out a  band's unfinished demos
column8: it's better to pore over dozens at a time  while attempting to glean some insight into their methods. Maybe that  would be giving too much away
column9: but honestly
column10: if Spoon are going to go  this far with things
column11:
they may as well go all the way.

"|14930.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14930-bonus-tracks-2008-2009/|6.3|Matthew Perpetua

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16009/homepage_large.115105bf.jpg|I Drink the Air Before Me|6442.0|Nico Muhly|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Decca']|2010-12-08 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:04.761385|"

The 29-year-old composer Nico Muhly crossed over into the indie world in part because of his many collaborations with indie artists. He's written arrangements and orchestrations for Bonnie ""Prince"" Billy
column2: Sam Amidon
column3: Grizzly Bear
column4: and Antony & the Johnsons
column5: among others. It also helps that he worked as an editor
column6: conductor
column7: and keyboardist with Philip Glass
column8: whose eloquent minimalism is already a touchstone for many indie and electronic music fans. But the crucial thing is simply Muhly's compositional voice. His minimal
column9: Neo-Romantic style has a balance of graceful form and emotional generosity that resonates with listeners who are more interested in personal statements than musicology. And his freehanded use of electronics
column10: drones
column11: and fluttering pulses blurs his classicism into accessible shades of post-rock.

column1: Muhly embodies the corroding boundary between classical and popular music
column2: but the two worlds remain distinct in some ways. Classical fans often favor the concert hall
column3: with recorded music as a secondary concern; the reverse is often true in indie and pop. Muhly has proven particularly adept at splitting the difference. He's written lots of music for performance that doesn't appear on any recording. He's also cherry-picked this repertoire to piece together two albums with the kind of modular structure that non-classical music fans are accustomed to
column4: 2007's Speaks Volumes and 2008's Mothertongue. Both of the new albums Muhly released this year are beholden to external forces
column5: so neither is necessarily the pop-friendly artifact you might be waiting for. I Drink the Air Before Me
column6: the score for a dance by choreographer Stephen Petronio
column7: is more esoteric than Mothertongue. A Good Understanding
column8: a choral work written for the Los Angeles Master Chorale
column9: might be ""too classical"" for casual fans. But both have a lot to offer
column10: and taken together
column11: they comprise a fascinating study in adaptability. Appropriately
column12: Drink is as physical as Good is ethereal
column13: though in each case
column14: Muhly's brash
column15: lyrical sensibility shines through.

column1: Working with an ensemble of flute
column2: viola
column3: bassoon
column4: trombone
column5: upright bass
column6: piano
column7: and electronics
column8: Muhly and Petronio made a set of rules for Drink: ""Start small
column9: get big""; begin and end with a children's choir; evoke weather with lots of ""irregular
column10: spiral-shaped music."" The influence of John Adams is palpable in the craggy piano parts. You can hear it on ""Music Under Pressure 2 - Piano""
column11: and on ""Salty Dog""
column12: where corkscrews of sharps and flats trouble an otherwise jaunty woodwind line. ""Music Under Pressure 1 - Flute""
column13: on the other hand
column14: has a Glassian depth and fluidity
column15: with its light flute melody and heavy undercarriage. The overall feeling is neurotic and twitchy
column16: with even the most elegant moments frequently wandering into murkier territory. Throughout
column17: Muhly realizes some magical effects
column18: like transforming string drones into a wilting melody on ""Varied Carols"". At times
column19: though
column20: the thematic content becomes so disjointed it threatens to break down
column21: and also occasionally errs in the other direction. ""Jagged Pulses"" is tight and satisfying
column22: though Muhly making a track called ""Jagged Pulses"" is like Sonic Youth naming one ""Arty Guitar Feedback""-- no surprise.

column1: If Drink sometimes feels a mite incomplete away from its intended use as a dance score
column2: A Good Understanding is remarkably whole. Its mostly-religious songs draw upon traditional Anglican choral music
column3: as well as Muhly's recollections of being a boy chorister. As opposed to the pushy and ostentatious Drink
column4: it's calm and centered. Muhly inscribes his personality onto the antique holiness of the texts and structures with uncommon humility and reverence. His personal stamps-- high contrast timbres
column5: deep bass
column6: hummingbird motifs-- are intact
column7: but subordinated to the crystalline vocals of the Los Angeles Master Chorale. Muhly's keyboard is mixed low
column8: merely glinting through the first part of ""Bright Mass with Canons""
column9: and rippling through the second with Terry Riley-like insistence
column10: coloring the tiered vocal harmonies. The chant-like invocation of the word ""Senex"" at the beginning of ""Senex Puerum Portabat"" retroactively highlights the traditional choral influences lurking behind the high-modern façade of the first part of Mothertongue. The infrequent instrumental flourishes Muhly allows himself hit harder than on Drink
column11: which can seem nothing but flourishes at times. For listeners who only get down with the most overt crossover attempts in classical music
column12: it might feel uncomfortably like going to Sunday services. For others
column13:
it will show a reticent side of Muhly that adds an intriguing dimension to his character.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/16024/homepage_large.f119d037.jpg|Volume On|28255.0|Tanlines|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Family Edition']|2010-12-08 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:05.176515|"

Even though Jesse Cohen and Eric Emm of Tanlines do plenty to honor the spirit of their name (and yes
column2: that is a MiniDisc on the cover)
column3: don't be so quick to lump them in with every other nostalgia junkie cluttering Brooklyn. It's actually fitting that the 2xCD Volume On is a European-only release
column4: since Tanlines' blindingly bright synth-pop has more in common with jetsetters like Tough Alliance
column5: Delorean
column6: and Studio-- acts that are influenced by the sounds of the tropics rather than just the idea of them.

column1: You won't get much of an idea of what Tanlines actually sounds like from Cohen and Emm's backgrounds (Professor Murder and Don Caballero
column2: respectively). But what has been carried forward from earlier projects is a lab-rat work ethic that makes Volume On more than a bunch of obvious signifiers. Sure
column3: the kick drum insistently hits on every beat and the percussion tempts Miami Sound Machine jokes
column4: but the songs here are always playful and never pushy. It's dance music if you want it to be
column5: maintaining a Balearic vibe without being wholly tied to it.

column1: It's hard to say if Tanlines' real strength is production or songwriting
column2: but Volume On has its share of highlights where they do both. ""Real Life""
column3: the song that has become Tanlines' signature track
column4: is a regular presence here. In addition to its original version
column5: there three remixes of the song on the second disc
column6: including a smeared-lens rendering by Memory Tapes. The song endures even in the dead of winter in large part because it's the best showcase of Emm's odd melodic charm as a vocalist
column7: and ""You might think I'm still that way... It was a past-life thing"" stands up as a strangely affecting mea culpa.

column1: More prominent here than on this year's Settings EP
column2: Emm's vocals are a strange
column3: sonorous thing that occasionally morph into something Sting-like but also have the go-for-it spirit of the Rapture's Luke Jenner (who appears here on new song ""O Seizing The Day O""). By the same token
column4: his voice doesn't work particularly well in isolation. Like on the acoustic version of ""Real Life""
column5: which is startling any way you slice it. It's a complete sonic anomaly within the confines of Volume On
column6: but Emm's vocal delivery isn't altered one bit and turns out to be entirely at odds with the arrangement.

column1: Volume On isn't officially Tanlines' first album
column2: but it doesn't sound like a hastily cobbled-together bid for year-end lists either. In fact
column3: it holds together almost too well. They work within a pretty narrow range of BPM's and the textural sleekness can have a dazing cumulative effect over the span of Volume On's hour-plus runtime. Nonetheless
column4: the promise is there. Tanlines obviously know how to properly book an island getaway
column5:
but it could really be something special if they can learn to diversify the itinerary.

'Someone Good']|2010-12-08 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:05.820867|"

Australia's Lawrence and Rebecca English have spent the past few years proving that the everyday can be avant-garde. The husband-and-wife pair run Someone Good
column4: while Lawrence curates sister imprint Room40
column5: a preeminent experimental label that has recently put out records by the ambient-inclined Grouper and Tim Hecker. Someone Good takes a more modest
column6: domestic view of gorgeous textural abstraction
column7: releasing music often by Japan-based artists: avant-twee couple Lullatone
column8: piano minimalist Akira Kosemura
column9: Tenniscoats offshoot Nikasaya. This is simple yet elegant stuff.

column1: As Miko
column2: Tokyo-based Rie Mitsutake assembles vividly mic'd piano
column3: acoustic guitar
column4: and off-kilter percussion-- along with field recordings and her own hushed vocals-- into languidly immersive sound worlds that make the familiar wonderfully strange. Her 2008 debut
column5: Parade
column6: successfully introduced the basic elements of Miko's developing aesthetic
column7: but that effort placed a greater emphasis on glimmering electronics and at times used near-shoegaze levels of ear-splitting distortion. Sophomore album Chandelier
column8: like Kosemura's excellent Polaroid Piano from last year
column9: takes a turn toward the organic. The result shapes restrained
column10: homespun instrumentation into something at once quaint and futuristic.

column1: Someone Good is billing Miko's latest as a ""new kind of folk music
column2: and that's apt. Bird-like squawks and delicate vocals transcend their potential cutesiness to attain a sort of ascetic grace (""Sea House""); Talk Talk-inclined drums gently splash behind indie pop plinks and plonks (""Kikoeru""); saxophones drift past thrumming acoustic guitar (""New Town""). When Miko sings the word ""America""
column3: on the hypnotic track of the same name
column4: she conjures up a faraway place vastly different from the one I know. Compared with traditional folk song
column5: there's certainly more attention paid to what words and sounds sugges

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
t rather than their literal meanings.
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
(Apparently Miko chose the title Chandeliers as much for its spoken sound as for its associations with light and warmth). But there's also a sense of intimacy
column2: of basic human connection
column3:
on which the old avant-garde might look with disdain. That would be missing the point.

Montreal producer/singer/composer D'eon started making synthesizer music when he was four years old
column3: continuing through years of formal music training before dropping his studies entirely as a teenager. He developed acute forms of anxiety and agoraphobia
column4: which he worked out
column5: then went to the Himalayas to study Tibetan music
column6: living in a monastery and not speaking for months. Since then
column7: he's integrated himself within the burgeoning underground experimental scene; Daniel Lopatin
column8: aka synth-drone alchemist Oneohtrix Point Never
column9: even brought him and his music to of-the-moment label Hippos in Tanks.

column1: D'eon's personal history and line of study are relatively fascinating; I wish that personal experience would've informed the music on his debut LP
column2: Palinopsia
column3: just a bit more. There's some ephemeral flourishes of Eastern music figures here and there
column4: but the record feels more like a collection of well-executed genre exercises than anything else. ""Well-executed"" is the key adjective
column5: though; untangle the hypnotic knot of synths underneath ""2040"" and you'll find the backing track for a lost 1980s electro-pop cut. ""What We Want to Be"" is a straightforward slice of euphoric piano house
column6: while ""Keep the Faith"" falls in line with the latest fashion of embracing mainstream R&B signifiers. However
column7: the most noteworthy contemporaries in that line of sound (How to Dress Well
column8: Autre Ne Veut) have applied their own skewed vision to that particular genre; here
column9: D'eon basically plays it straight. He does a good job across the board here
column10: but you might be left a little wanting for something more chewy to sink your teeth into.

column1: The other main issue with Palinopsia is D'eon's voice: Not specifically how he sings
column2: which ranges from a meditative croon to a histrionic whine without much room for accessibility in between
column3: but what he's saying. There's a vaguely socio-political vibe to D'eon's music
column4: and its somewhat message-muddled application doesn't always ad

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
d up. The electronic epilepsy of ""Kill a Man With a Joystick in Your Hand"" does well to convey heat-stroked modern combat in foreign lands
column2: but it's not easy to scan his intent when he sings
column3: ""Everybody want to fuck with the Taliban/ All the way from Kabul to Pakistan"". Conversations in college common rooms are unintentionally evoked in ""Keep the Faith"" (""Why don't you stay with me a little while/ And talk about the things we do to survive"")
column4: while the record's ideological nadir
column5: ""Recession Proof ($40 Paycheque)"" goes from complaining about (you guessed it) a $40 paycheck to
column6: uh
column7: this: ""The ocean is a sewer/ The city is a whore/ Money in the toilet/ Oil on the shore."" The imagery is serviceable but clichéd; like the most well-tread parts of Palinopsia
column8:
it could use a fresh twist.

column2:
'Metal']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Profound Lore']|2010-12-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:06.903035|"

Whether you self-identify as a metal-attuned hipster or a hipster-hating metalhead
column3: and whether you scan Pitchfork's reviews or prowl the message boards of the American Nihilist Underground Society
column4: you've likely considered the shifting sound of black metal during the last decade. In recent years
column5: the bands that have earned the most attention and acclaim have generally used what began as Scandinavian misfit rock to springboard into something epic. Wolves in the Throne Room's atmospheric bombast
column6: then
column7: aligns with Alcest's haunted dreamscapes. Deathspell Omega's mean psychedelic crunch links with the scorched expanses of Horseback and Locrian. Sure
column8: plenty of recalcitrant bands-- Watain
column9: Akitsa
column10: the intractable Immortal-- adhere to decades-old
column11: fast-blasting strictures. But from the keys and strings Emperor used to the sense of grandiosity Mayhem promulgated
column12: orchestral elements and widescreen scope have consistently been part of knotty ol' black metal. On their fourth album
column13: Portland
column14: Ore.
column15: quartet Agalloch peerlessly unify both camps. As atmospheric as it is aggressive
column16: as reliant upon old-school bona fides as on imaginative flourishes
column17: Marrow of the Spirit confirms Agalloch's place at the frontier of American metal.

column1: Marrow of the Spirit begins
column2: as have each of Agalloch's three previous LPs
column3: with a reflective instrumental. A forlorn cello moans over field recordings of a brisk stream and chattering birds
column4: mixed so that each element feeds into the others. Together
column5: they offer an image of melancholy
column6: energy
column7: and beauty that serves as a prelude in the most proper sense. Agalloch deals in light and dark here
column8: moving beyond simple damnation and apocalypse to consider escape and renewal
column9: too. Through a series of sketches and scenes
column10: frontman John Haughm offers desolation and collapse-- ""I slumber in clouds of ice/ These are my hands... so it is done
column11: he groans during the opener. The next hour is a tug of war between retreat and rebirth. ""There are gods in the wake of the very flame
column12: he sings at the album's other end
column13: placing his hope in a hopeless void.

column1: The music here mirrors that message
column2: a trait that requires dynamic
column3: diverse
column4: and compelling arrangements. Introduction excepted
column5: Marrow of the Spirit's five tracks range from 10 to 18 minutes in length
column6: and
column7: more often than not
column8: one marathon simply segues into another. Though the album breaks well past the hour mark
column9: Agalloch couple economy and pacing with imagination and ideas in a way that should make most black metal bands green with envy. The 12-minute ""Into the Painted Grey""
column10: for instance
column11: maneuvers with enough agility that its runtime feels appropriate. It transitions from ascendant guitar solos to relentless
column12: howling stampedes
column13: twisting the two again and again into blissful terror. A barely audible 12-string acoustic guitar laces much of the track
column14: adding ballast to the blast. That guitar serves as the bridge into ""The Watcher's Monolith""
column15: itself a perfect distillation of the breadth that's made Agalloch matter for the last decade. Spider-webbing from folk-rock smolder to mid-tempo thrash
column16: from hair-metal guitar workouts to dirge-like chants
column17: ""The Watcher's Monolith"" plays like an unpredictable
column18: seamless mixtape of Agalloch's strengths.

column1: And that's the key: Many of Agalloch's peers in bending black metal manipulate it one way or another
column2: then simply revisit
column3: retread
column4: and retrench. For Agalloch
column5: though
column6: black metal is just the thread that ties together dozens of different looks
column7: be it the industrial roar and mid-tempo climb that characterize ""Black Lake Niðstång"" or the saturating sustains that spread from one end of closer ""To Drown"" to the other. ""Ghosts of the Midwinter Fires"" sprints and twists like a lost take from Maserati or Mogwai
column8: its chiseled guitar line leading the way through sharp turns. But just as Alcest did on this year's excellent Écailles de Lune
column9: Agalloch almost always retain a stylistic placeholder
column10: be it rolling blast beats or Haughm's lacerated exhortations. Black metal
column11: then
column12: becomes a compositional catalyst
column13: not a stylistic restraint.

column1: Agalloch don't tour much
column2: picking and choosing their tour dates and bill-mates based on what they find interesting. In March
column3: they flew to Romania to play two shows with Alcest for free
column4: though they've barely played within their own country at all. The band seldom offers interviews
column5: either. ""We believe in having a spectacular experience rather than touring constantly and making a lot of money
column6: Haughm told a Brooklyn Vegan writer who made that trip to Romania

column8: or all this rock-star bullshit. We're fine if we're at an underground cult base forever."" Similar ideas have cultivated audiences for the formerly hermetic songwriter Jandek and veteran masked emcee DOOM. But black metal itself has started to seep closer to mainstream culture
column9: both through its influence on other artists and in acknowledgment from big media outlets. Agalloch's cult status might not be so safe

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/16015/homepage_large.76868d4b.jpg|Quest for the Sonic Bounty|14227.0|Horsepower Productions|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tempa']|2010-12-07 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:08.103649|"

Artists commonly object to genre labels. We get it: limiting
column2: it boxes you in.  Dylan wasn't just folk
column3: Pearl Jam weren't merely grunge
column4: and nobody-- nobody-- will cop to being chillwave. So have a little respect for Horsepower Productions
column5: the decade-old UK production team who don't seem to be in any hurry to discard the dubstep label.  If anyone has a rightful claim to it
column6: it's ringleader Benny Ill and his cohorts
column7: whose dub-heavy early B-sides were
column8: by many accounts
column9: the inspiration for the term.

column1: After a six-year hiatus
column2: Quest for the Sonic Bounty is the second proper Horsepower Productions LP (following 2004's To the Rescue; their landmark debut
column3: In Fine Style
column4: was partly a compilation)
column5: arriving at a time when dubstep enjoys fringe mainstream appeal. Quest thankfully isn't a transparent attempt to capitalize on reputation
column6: but neither does it sound like a labor of love.  Instead it sounds like plain ol' labor
column7: as if someone spent a lot of time worrying about this music. The album's title is probably a joke
column8: but with a nod to that threadbare line about jokes containing elements of truth.

column1: Benny Ill
column2: the last remaining member of the original HP team
column3: now works with another producer
column4: Jay King
column5: and it sounds as if the duo have internalized dubstep's touchstones. They began as true dance producers
column6: making garage and 2-step; they play with dubplates and have collaborated with Lee Perry; their albums feature obscure movie quotes recalling mid-1990s American hip-hop (Wu-Tang are an obvious touchstone).  The album opens with nearly a minute of rain and deeply echoing keyboard chords before a skittering beat kicks in; one minute later
column7: the signature bass wobble and some vaguely rave-y sirens sound. And there you have it: dubstep. If the genre's other leading names want to be pop stars
column8: bards
column9: or shut-ins
column10: then HP are content to focus on the music.

column1: Quest isn't the type of wretched
column2: bigger/louder/wobblier dubstep that now plagues a lot of clubs and DJ sets.  The album sounds best on a great system where its bass can dominate
column3: but its largess supports the album's general tone and cinematic scope.  The dialogue samples almost seem to suggest a narrative; survival and water are themes.  On the group's remix of Lee ""Scratch"" Perry's ""Exercising"" (on CD for the first time here)
column4: it's clear that Benny Ill could more often use a shaman/muse whose natural strangeness augments the HP's concussed worldview.  Still: ""Water"" absolutely explodes; ""Damn It"" is bright
column5: sampledelic reggae. ""Poison Wine"" takes its Middle Eastern vocal samples and turns them into schizoid house divas.

column1: A search for one of the album's movie quotes-- from 1983's Stryker-- led me to a page dedicated to movies that ripped off Mad Max. This is an unkind-- but funny-- metaphor for a genre whose dregs have made a living Xeroxing sonic oblivion. When I listen to Quest
column2: I miss the relatively weightless stir of In Fine Style; it seems clear that the last decade of UK body music has gotten to Benny Ill. A new Horsepower Productions album offers the opportunity to reflect on dubstep's past
column3: and Quest
column4: for better and worse
column5: sounds a lot like its blueprint
column6:
even if plans have changed drastically in the interim.

Kokning
column2: the title of Bjørn Torske's fourth full-length LP
column3: is a Nordic word that sounds ineffably lewd to American ears. It has no English equivalent
column4: unless there's an obscure English word that means ""putting potatoes on to boil
column5: going fishing
column6: and then preparing the fish with the potatoes."" The uniquely Scandinavian concept suits the uniquely Scandinavian music. Torske's blend of playful austerity and wistful wonderment can also be found in his Smalltown Supersound compatriots
column7: from diskJokke to Lindstrøm to Kim Hiorthøy. The title also evokes the relaxed
column8: patiently simmering quality of the album
column9: which boils down Torske's long-running fixations upon dub
column10: cosmic disco
column11: house
column12: and Balearic sounds into a highly refined personal style. Sophisticatedly minimal
column13: Kokning improves upon 2007's excellent Feil Knapp by retaining yet streamlining Torske's idiosyncrasies.

column1: To create the album
column2: Torske recorded instrumental parts in various places and then edited them together with rhythm tracks. His sensitivity as a producer makes the album
column3: for all the styles it lightly flits through
column4: an organic room-tone odyssey at heart: alive with inventive sounds and warm with feeling. It opens with three wonderful
column5: ultra-mellow cuts that slide you into Torske's sound-world with zero friction. On the title track
column6: liquidly hypnotic phrases for clean electric guitar weave through shining ambiance
column7: with just a couple of alternating plucks coolly marking time. ""Bryggesjau"" is a clip-clopping set piece for acid-bright guitar riffs in taut counterpoint
column8: and ""Gullfjellet"" features rich nylon strings and watery synths
column9: rooted by the calm thump of a kick drum. Besides their appealing sound palettes
column10: the great thing about these tracks is how deliberately they take on definition. By the time the dancier middle run of songs come around
column11: you're deeply immersed.

column1: This middle run is marked by lots of intricate hand percussion
column2: funk progressions
column3: and proggy keyboard swirls
column4: though it retains the light

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
touch and hint of critical distance that characterize the opening tracks. ""Slitte Sko"" is the sort of casual
column2: chiming beat workout that Arthur Russell liked to cook up
column3: and ""Bergensere"" calls Prins Thomas to mind with its arch yet passionate funk. As the album progresses
column4: Torske gets more unleashed
column5: slathering ""Nitten Nitti"" with a goofy-fun vocal synth arpeggio and framing stylized dub reggae with monster-party samples on ""Versjon Wolfenstein"". After the more focused songs preceding it
column6: the 12-minute closing epic ""Furu"" is a bit long-winded for my tastes
column7: but at least it feels earned. It also makes me feel Torske is naturally inclined to stretching out-- even his short pieces here have a sense of endless range-- which makes his restraint elsewhere all the more admirable. His shorter tracks have a diorama-like sense of compact but vivid detail
column8: and the merest gestures make big impacts. Unflashy and muted
column9: Torske gets less props than some of his peers. With any justice
column10:
Kokning will correct this slight.

It's not normally a good sign when you put on an album and the first thought that comes to mind is a dude in acid washed jeans noodling for hours on a guitar in the middle of a music store. The opening bars of Public Service Announcement by Purling Hiss bring to mind such an image
column3: but the album turns out to be a little more complicated than that.

column1: If underground rock music has spent the past couple of years skewing rough and lo-fi
column2: toying with ideas that lean away from actual structure or fully completed pieces
column3: then Purling Hiss (aka Mike Polizze
column4: who also plays in Birds of Maya
column5: a band that kicks around Philadelphia with Kurt Vile) takes the idea to its logical conclusion. Songs bend under warped tape while guitars jam up into upper-register treble. Listen to Public Service Announcement on mediocre headphones
column6: and it can sound like watery background static. But a situation involving staring at a wall and focusing on the record while accepting its controlled mania can be rewarding.

column1: Tracks like ""Porch Dude/Slight Return"" begin with a perfectly normal riff. But then the tape wobbles and the music sounds like an accident that's been reigned in and controlled. The jams are given shape and then ripped apart by recording technique. And these days
column2: when an album sounds this imperfect
column3: you have to assume there's a reason. It's 2010
column4: and recording pristine songs takes little more than a good mic and some pirated editing software. It's up to artists to recreate primitive
column5: raw recordings artificially
column6: and Purling Hiss uses this rawness as a dominant instrument. Without these smudges
column7: Public Service Announcement could play out as an off-kilter
column8: potentially flat version of recycled AM radio gold. With these imperfections
column9: though
column10: it sits comfortably beside other sonic innovators with a vital pop music heart: Ariel Pink
column11: John Maus
column12: and even at times a stony version of Phil Elverum's warm
column13: all encompassing ambient hiss.

column1: But if Public Service Announcement finds its comfort in rambling experimentation
column2: then its main fault is how drawn out it is. It's the risk that comes when you stuff the music with a million ideas that are about halfway there. Nothing sticks around too long-- except
column3: unfortunately
column4: on ""Malice in Wonderland""
column5: when the guitar grind sounds like a propeller plane taking off for about five solid minutes. Beyond that
column6: it's a challenging record in the best way
column7:
splitting the difference between easy nostalgia and a windswept take on pop experimentation.

That's frontwoman Nona Marie Invie naked on the cover of Dark Dark Dark's second full-length
column2: Wild Go

column4: she seems to rebuke you for seeing her in this state of undress
column5: hips and tattoos exposed. We get other band members' asses
column6: too
column7: but Invie's is front and center
column8: which is only appropriate: The band's songs are cleverly arranged and expressively performed
column9: but Invie's vocals remain the focal point. While it's tempting to suggest she lays herself similarly bare in her lyrics
column10: in truth she is slightly more guarded
column11: writing songs whose meanings must be puzzled out and singing them in a voice that sounds refracted
column12: as if we're hearing her through a mirror.

column1: Invie's an intriguing presence on Wild Go
column2: which traffics in pristine
column3: moody chamber pop that's light on hooks but heavy on stark atmosphere. Working with producer Tom Herbers (Low) in Minneapolis and Duluth
column4: the band itself proves agile and inventive
column5: opening ""In Your Dreams"" at an abrupt gallop
column6: rushing us into the album in medias res as the members provide backing vocals that sound like a Balkan choir practicing next door. There are hints of Beirut in ""Celebrate""
column7: of an artier Hem in ""Daydreaming""
column8: of a less wild Wild Colonials in ""Say the Word""
column9: of chanson on the title track
column10: and perhaps Dark Dark Dark's true accomplishment here is how they mix sounds and influences so effortlessly. They comprise a tight
column11: intuitive unit
column12: especially when the instruments swirl together into an otherworldly eddy of sound. They even know enough to back off the spectral ""Robert""
column13: which is mostly Invie at her piano.

column1: ""What do words mean to me now?"" she asks on ""Say the Word""
column2: possibly explaining the cumbersome band name and awkward album title. She never lets on which words she's talking about or what they might have meant in the past; as with the album cover
column3: she knows that the glimpse of a part is more engrossing than a gawk at the whole. Occasionally
column4: the songs threaten to blur together and lose their distinctiveness
column5: yet she makes Wild Go sound tough-minded and questioning. That makes it only more egregious when banjo and clarinet player Marshall LaCount takes over vocals from her on ""Right Path"" and ""Heavy Heart"". He has a thin
column6: slightly reedy voice and a tendency toward overenunciation; it's not unpleasant
column7: but relatively pedestrian. Moreover
column8: in the context of the album it's disruptive
column9: breaking the careful spell of the music. The band works via accumulation
column10: gradually building up to moments of muted drama
column11:
yet LaCount's leads wreck that momentum.

To gain entrance to Jónsi Birgisson's first private solo performance last March
column2: attendees were required to dress as animals. The show was a final dress rehearsal at 3 Mills Studios in London
column3: a few weeks before the Sigur Rós frontman's proper debut LP
column4: Go
column5: was released and his theatrical
column6: projection-bolstered live setup would hit the road for much of 2010. There were women donning feathered headdresses
column7: kids with furry earmuffs
column8: and grown men in bear outfits nursing beers. Also amongst the crowd was a camera crew on hand to capture the event
column9: footage of which has been spliced together with backstage scenes and interviews to comprise the visual half of Go Live
column10: a DVD/CD available exclusively on Jónsi's website (and
column11: apparently
column12: in some Japanese shops). While the live audio recordings here were culled from a later show in Brussels
column13: the relationship between the two halves is close. That scene in London mirrors what's been happening on every stage he took this year
column14: the often playful
column15: always kinetic spirit of Go come to life in more than one way.

column1: Because Jónsi's only got the one record of his own material
column2: he bulked up his setlist with tracks that are seeing release together for the first time here. Songs like the stately
column3: fingerpicked opener ""Stars in Still Water""
column4: forgettable ""New Piano Song""
column5: or his contribution to the How to Train Your Dragon OST
column6: ""Sticks & Stones""
column7: add an extra layer of muscle to his sparse catalogue.

column1: One of the major challenges Jónsi faced when bringing Go to the stage was in figuring out how to translate the indelible studio contributions of composer Nico Muhly and percussionist Samuli Kosminen. Each track here has been reworked terrifically
column2: Muhly's lively flourishes sometimes left behind for ambience's sake
column3: but never far at all. Instead
column4: like in the nearly three-minute intro to ""Tornado""
column5: a similar magic and color is conjured by bells
column6: piano flurries
column7: and xylophonic tapestry. In that vein
column8: ""Boy Lilikoi"" feels warmer and more spritely. Jónsi's band has been able to generate extraordinary levels of texture
column9: the crisp sound of live percussion alone enough to give already strong arrangements new breath.

column1: As compelling as the many visual elements (see the Never Never Land sartorial decisions
column2: atavistic animations
column3: interview snippets
column4: HD everything) on the DVD can be
column5: the Fifty Nine Productions-helmed film is more a document of their concepts than the actual Jónsi live experience. That's why the album itself seems all the more necessary. The sonics are appropriately huge
column6: and there at its center is an instrument that's better recorded than it could ever be filmed: Jónsi's voice. It arches
column7: it splays
column8: it cloys
column9: it still coats everything here with expansive
column10: far-reaching qualities that befit the cinematic nature of his songwriting.

column1: What's particularly special about Go Live is the fact that Jonsi's vocalizing loses the safety netting and sheen it enjoys in a studio. There are moments
column2: like in the early quiet of closer ""Grow Till Tall""
column3: when he goes unimaginably high
column4: his cords unable to hold up as long as he'd like. You can hear him inhale and you can hear his voice give out ever so briefly. Part of the appeal in seeing Jónsi (or Sigur Rós for that matter) in a live setting for the first/any time is being able to attach faces to often-faceless music. When Jónsi's voice cracks
column5:
what was alien on record now sounds positively human.

The Soft Boys' 1980 masterpiece
column2: Underwater Moonlight
column3: is probably best known for inspiring a laundry list of 80s-90s alternative greats
column4: including R.E.M.
column5: the Flaming Lips
column6: and the Replacements. This lineage speaks broadly to the record's sound-- if you guessed that Underwater Moonlight is ""jangly"" and ""melodic"" but ""off-kilter
column7: you wouldn't be wrong. But the Soft Boys did not simply provide a rough template to be polished and perfected by their better-known successors. These reissues make a great case for the Soft Boys' recorded output on its own terms
column8: forgoing liner note-heavy fanfare and supplementing the band's two proper full-lengths with a wealth of illuminating demos
column9: live tracks
column10: and EP cuts.

column1: While Underwater Moonlight received a reissue from Matador nine years ago
column2: this marks the first time in recent memory that the Soft Boys' debut album
column3: A Can of Bees
column4: is widely available. Far blunter than Underwater Moonlight
column5: A Can of Bees positions the Soft Boys as a coal-stained industrial British counterpoint to Devo's futuristic automatons. The guitar figures are repetitive as jackhammers
column6: the drums simple and utilitarian
column7: and Robyn Hitchcock's voice oozes sarcasm and bitterness. Occasional forays into delicate guitar pop (see ""Human Music"") serve primarily as a foil to Hitchcock's snarl but only hint at the singular infectiousness the band would later achieve. A Can of Bees is a good record
column8: but it is also a low-stakes one
column9: never moving beyond a set of well-honed stylistic gestures.

column1: Underwater Moonlight wastes no time blowing away its predecessor with one of the smartest headfakes ever to lead off a rock album. The anthemic opening chord of ""I Wanna Destroy You"" settles unexpectedly into a different key via a walking bass line and a tremendous blast of harmonized vocals
column2: one of many head-turning moments on a disarmingly clever and well-paced record. The way a catchy chorus slinks out from under the spartan verses of ""I Got the Hots""
column3: the shifting rhythm of ""Old Pervert""-- the elegance of these should-be incongruous moments speaks to the album's versatile and far-reaching musical language.

column1: While the cynicism of A Can of Bees borders on relentless
column2: Underwater Moonlight offers a uniquely tinted play of darkness and light that befits its title. Lechery and romance are in frequent tension
column3: to the point where you sometimes can't tell which is which. While the language Hitchcock uses to describe the physicality of sex is consistently baffled and disgusting
column4: he relegates a particularly insidious and gross image (tiny insects hatching out under his chin) to the ""Kingdom of Love"". Is the hippy-dippy ""Positive Vibrations"" tongue-in-cheek? The answer is not a simple ""yes"" or ""no."" On Underwater Moonlight
column5: you can hear Hitchcock discovering the truth that informs his best work: Blank-faced inscrutability is only as interesting as what might lurk beneath it.

column1: The bonus tracks on these reissues run the gamut from rough sketches to album-ready studio cuts. Some songs
column2: such as a live version of ""Insanely Jealous"" with almost entirely different lyrics
column3: are interesting primarily as procedural artifacts. The more polished songs
column4: some culled from the posthumous almost-album Two Halves for the Price of One (and most included on Matador's reissue)
column5: stand up well on their own
column6: but lack the nuance and depth of Underwater Moonlight.

column1: Case in point: Underwater Moonlight's album-closing title track tells the story of a couple who
column2: after 50 years together
column3: journey to the sea-- only to drown. ""Underwater Moonlight"" is narrative songwriting at its best
column4: resonating in a million different directions without falling back on lyrical cliché. The song shimmers
column5: charges
column6: retreats
column7: and-- improbably-- boogies. That this album flopped upon its initial release is largely a function of bad timing; hot on the heels of punk
column8: there was little interest in a group of four unapologetically middle-class Brits making music that incorporated the indelible harmonies of the Byrds and the surrealism of Syd Barrett. But then again
column9: Underwater Moonlight is best considered with the benefit of hindsight
column10: and for all the famous music it inspired
column11:
there is still nothing quite like Underwater Moonlight.

British Sea Power have always possessed a flair for broad
column3: sweeping anthems. But 2008's third full-length
column4: Do You Like Rock Music?
column5: took those impulses one step-- make that one thousand steps-- further. That record found the Brighton band attempting to ascend to the life-affirming
column6: million-dollar chorus ranks of stadium-ready rock merchants like U2. It was a gamble
column7: and in retrospect
column8: it paid off thanks to their flair for structure and ear-pleasing melody. Even the most ardent fan

column1: Zeus

column3: Valhalla Dancehall
column4: answers that question. Unfortunately
column5: that's probably the most positive thing you could say about the release. Zeus is bloated in the most indulgent sense

column7: with three tunes careening well past the seven-minute mark). Unlike their previous rock-oriented releases
column8: there's no unifying theme running throughout the record. Multiple stylistic shifts take place from song to song or
column9: in the case of the overstuffed opening track ""Zeus""
column10: within a single tune. This grab-bag conceit makes it hard to pinpoint what
column11: exactly
column12: went wrong here: is it the Auto-Tuned(!) glam rock of ""kW-h""
column13: or the skronky faux-motorik of ""Mongk"" that directly precedes it? Did the aptly named closer ""Retreat"" need to be nine minutes long? Does the ultra-filtered shouty goof ""Can We Do It?"" need to exist at all? There's very little here in the way of the meaty hooks and melodies that were once the band's trademark.

column1: Zeus feels more of a house-cleaning release than anything else

column7: (see: last year's film soundtrack Man of Aran)

column9:
you need to get people singing along.

If you're the sort of person for whom the phrase ""featuring the bassist from Black Kids"" seems a label as poisonous as a skull and crossbones on a cartoon bottle-- and really
column3: given that band's stinker of a debut full-length
column4: who could blame you-- prepare to be surprised. Gospel Music
column5: the near-impossible-to-Google new project by Jacksonville's Owen Holmes (the bass player in question)
column6: is an attempt to erase the memory of the overblown
column7: glossy production and mannered songwriting of Black Kids' Partie Traumatic by making music that is its polar opposite: immediate
column8: slightly sloppy
column9: and charmingly casual. And Duettes
column10: the band's maddeningly spelled debut EP
column11: succeeds as a brief-but-likable collection of purposefully lo-fi pop songs that are long on infectious melodies but short on arty pretension.

column1: In fact
column2: if no one told you Duettes had a thing to do with Black Kids
column3: you would never guess. Holmes naturally has the low
column4: gravelly voice and occasional monotone of Calvin Johnson or Adam Green
column5: and he has smartly crafted raw
column6: minimalist songs in the vein of Beat Happening or the Moldy Peaches to fit those vocals. Instead of his other band's synth-driven sound
column7: the keyboard instruments that Holmes plays on this album (like toy piano or vintage organ) are used sparingly as decoration
column8: and the melodies are instead steered by acoustic guitars or rootsy banjos. And the lyrics
column9: which eschew complicated metaphors or grand ideas
column10: are clever and conversational
column11: like something a friend or the drunk on the next barstool has said to you before.

column1: Considering their simple arrangements
column2: these songs are driven forward by Holmes' finely detailed stories. On ""Gamophobia""
column3: Holmes lists all the actions he's willing to take for his beloved if she'll just ""stop asking for a wedding ring."" It's an ""I'd Do Anything For Love (But I Won't Do That)"" for committed singles. And ""Reinheitsgebot""
column4: which takes its name from a German beer-brewing law
column5: elegantly captures the painful
column6: I'm-doing-fine posturing that follows a breakup. Every verse announces a new
column7: exciting hobby the narrator has taken up
column8: from home-brewing to marathon-running
column9: or a vice that he's quit
column10: like smoking
column11: but the real message of the song lies in its chorus: ""You didn't get the best of me. The best of me came after you. Now it's being wasted on someone new
column12: yet listeners can sadly tell that the man doth protest too much.

column1: Holmes smartly sought out a winning team of vocal collaborators for Duettes' five tracks-- hence the album's title. Though he does duet with one man-- Hefner's Darren Hayman on ""Reinheitsgebot""-- his songs sound best when his baritone speak-singing is bolstered by a sweet
column2: girlish voice
column3: allowing listeners to revel in the sound of their opposition. On the bouncy
column4: call-and-response ""Automobile""
column5: that voice comes from Camera Obscura's Tracyanne Campbell; on the Silver Jews-ish ""I Miss the Shit Out of You"" his partner is French singer Soko; and playing up Gospel Music's resemblance to the Magnetic Fields at their most skeletal
column6: that band's Shirley Simms plays the role of the marriage-hungry lover on ""Gamophobia"".

column1: The EP's closing track
column2: ""Are Your Parents Still Together?""
column3: plays like a brief
column4: minute-and-a-half conversation between Holmes and Vivian Girls' Cassie Ramone. Backed by Ramone's gooey ""ooh wah ooh""s
column5: the two singers trade barbs about stereotypically perfect families (""Is your father a professor? Is mom a fiction writer? Do they pledge to public radio
column6: and make their own pasta dough?"") while sussing out whether they will make good partners for each other
column7: vowing at the end of the song to ""do it better"" than their parents did. It is
column8: perhaps
column9: the most nakedly sentimental moment of the album
column10: but it doesn't feel corny
column11: thanks to the song's offhand tone and unfussy production.

column1: The album is brief
column2: and given its messy
column3: tossed-off vibe
column4: it may feel too slapdash or inessential to some listeners. But fans of lo-fi pop would be hard-pressed not to be won over by his lyrical specificity
column5: melodic infectiousness
column6: and vocal collaborators. Considering that we have been waiting for a redemptive follow-up for Partie Traumatic for almost three years
column7: perhaps Holmes' other band should take a cue from their bass player: Don't overthink it. When it comes to pop music
column8:

Soft Circle's first album
column3: 2007's Full Bloom
column4: made for an odd
column5: entrancing hybrid. It had moments as relaxing and soothing as a new age record
column6: yet Soft Circle mainman Hisham Bharoocha's work in neo-no-wave acts Lightning Bolt and Black Dice meant Full Bloom occasionally strayed into darker
column7: uglier
column8: and more abrasive terrain.

column1: Like many of his 21st-century contemporaries
column2: Bharoocha suggested that pretty
column3: meditative noise was only a few knob cranks away from becoming fearsome
column4: plug-your-ears noise. That philosophy still drives Shore Obsessed. Take a cursory listen
column5: though
column6: and you might not even think it's the work of the same man who produced Full Bloom. Unlike that long
column7: meandering album
column8: Shore Obsessed is built out of short
column9: tight dance songs. You can actually shake your stuff to these 10 synth-pop and disco tunes-- while singing along
column10: no less-- which certainly isn't something you could have said about any of Bharoocha's other projects.

column1: Bharoocha first came to my attention as the frighteningly intense drummer behind Black Dice's early singles-- and then as the tribal virtuoso who helped the band stretch out into the glorious Boredoms-esque peaks of Beaches and Canyons-- but often on Full Bloom his drumming was reduced to a pitter-pat running through the background. On Shore Obsessed he shows off the big
column2: bold funk chops that were often hidden in his previous work. For a guy who fractured rhythms into a zillion jagged pieces on Black Dice's Number 3
column3: it's thrilling to hear Bharoocha revel in the bubblegum joy of a Eurodisco pulse on ""Treading Water"". Reading that
column4: of course
column5: you might be groaning: ""Another dance-rock guy content to peddle well-worn disco beats?"" But Bharoocha's clearly done his homework. Shore Obsessed reveals a producer and songwriter who's listened deeply to a wide variety of dance styles
column6: figuring out the rhythmic and melodic ideas that make them tick before trying to put his own stamp on them.

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>

You can also tell he still enjoys his left-field status-- he's unconstrained by ideas about what a genre ""should"" sound like. His background as a texture-obsessed noise artist allows him to bring in oddly perfect new sounds: Balearic beat that goes beyond late-80s synth presets (""First Time""); a raw take on ""world music""-inflected deep house (""Light Bright""); the blocky riffs of early rave and elements of Depeche Mode (""Nerve of People""); mutant kin to the current wave of 8-bit dub steppers (""Bonzer""). Bharoocha's hit the kind of sweet spot that only truly inventive outsiders manage to reach.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15921/homepage_large.1ecd7353.jpg|Body Talk|3666.0|Robyn|['Pop/R&B'
column2: 'Electronic']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Interscope'
column3: 'Konichiwa'
column5: too."" When we first heard Robyn sing those words
column6: on a single promoting what would become a three-volume set of mini-LPs all bearing the name Body Talk
column7: it was easy to focus on the Swedish pop singer's quirky sense of humor. But on this new full-length edition
column8: ""Fembot"" also reveals itself as a compelling statement of purpose. Playing off contemporary pop's age-old diva-as-robot trope and cautioning that fellow droids who ""burn out"" are ""ready for demolition
column9: Robyn is a pop star who first and foremost projects a need for emotional connection.

column1: If that's Robyn's artistic credo
column2: then Body Talk is living
column3: breathing
column4: cybernetic proof. Melding dancehall with bubblegum pop
column5: heartbroken  love songs with hilariously catty weirdness
column6: and euphorically catchy  melodies with propulsive rhythms
column7: Body Talk-- which combines the five-song Body Talk Pt. 3 with
column8: outside of Pt. 1's uncommonly wise ""Cry When You Get Older""
column9: the highlights from the first two mini-albums-- is a deeply affecting pop  record. Robyn may not have released three full albums this  year as first implied
column10: but her first true full-length in five years is one of the year's best.

column1: What sets Robyn apart from her contemporaries is the three-dimensional complexity of her character
column2: and all sides are on display here. There's plenty of don't-fuck-with-me attitude in the icy electro-throb of ""Don't Fucking Tell Me What to Do""
column3: which introduces a shit-talking heroine who may be flawed but won't be anyone's pawn. And with production by Diplo
column4: the mock-outrageous Jamaica homage ""Dancehall Queen"" proves she's not kidding. But she's also sensitive enough that
column5: during one of Body Talk's most inspired moments-- the soaringly tuneful electro-pop ballad ""Call Your Girlfriend""-- she tells her boyfriend exactly how to break it off with the other woman to inflict the least emotional damage.

column1: However
column2: the highlight from this Year of Robyn remains the gorgeous ""Dancing on My Own"". What's especially remarkable is that there was any room for improvement: The track appears here as an amped-up ""radio remix"" with bonus synths giving the lovelorn chorus an extra wallop. But then again
column3: Robyn is a master of re-invention: ""Indestructible"" and ""Hang With Me"" were first released as emotive acoustic ballads
column4: and later given revved-up Eurodisco overhauls that ramped up the intensity without sacrificing an ounce of their bittersweet charm. Those are the versions included here
column5: and both lend further ammunition to Body Talk's already military-grade stockpile.

column1: Robyn's willingness to experiment with album conventions may feel like an ingenious gimmick
column2: but there's no artifice to the desire for human connection that underlies her vocal quiver and party-starting kickdrums. She communicates heartbreak so convincingly that some of her most devoted fans actually wonder online about her presumed loneliness. She also attacks the charts from the fringes. She explores the fringes from the charts. She should be universal. So why isn't she? With Body Talk
column3: Robyn ups the ante for pop stars across the radio dial and raises her own chances of appearing on yours. And for all her three-album talk
column4:
she never forgets that cardinal rule of showmanship: Always leave them wanting more.

column2: a place where crossing genre lines is as natural a day-to-day fact as crossing the Mississippi. Slug quotes Lifter Puller and Kool G Rap with equal conviction
column3: Fog's Andrew Broder turns turntablism into a vital component of avant rock
column4: and P.O.S fronts a hardcore band
column5: Building Better Bombs
column6: that shares a good-sized fanbase overlap with his b-boy followers. So it shouldn't be a huge surprise that one of Minnesota's most prominent young hip-hop producers has a simultaneous footing in the indie rock world. Aaron Mader was a guitarist/vocalist/songwriter with the smartly Fugazi-indebted Plastic Constellations until their indefinite 2008 hiatus
column7: but as Lazerbeak he's also produced much of the Doomtree crew's best material
column8: including some of the hookiest
column9: hardest-hitting tracks on P.O.S' Never Better.

column1: If you think there's some sort of potential contradiction in that career path
column2: his solo debut
column3: Legend Recognize Legend
column4: might confuse you before it converts you. That's because Lazerbeak's first full-length draws out a third facet to his style: its pop-song structure and its sample-based construction build an odd-angled
column5: raspy-voiced take on indie pop that doesn't shred or bang as much as it kind of twinkles. It's a bit twee without being all that cloying about it: A synthesis of harps
column6: flutes
column7: acoustic guitars
column8: and chimes flutter over brisk basslines and drums that still have some suppleness in their spines
column9: and all these elements are combined in a way that actually has some groove to it. Where some artists try to approach R&B from a grounding in indie pop
column10: Lazerbeak appears to be taking the opposite route
column11: and even the lightest
column12: most subdued moments here (""Let It Go""; ""Pearly Gates"") have some real rhythmic snap behind them.

column1: Fortunately
column2: dude's too savvy to go Owl City on us-- for one thing
column3: he can actually write lyrics that don't hemorrhage treacle when you pull them apart. Lazerbeak infuses Legend Recognize Legend with a fair amount of North Woods conceptualism that
column4: in its most Minnesotan trait
column5: depicts nature-- and the things it represents
column6: human behavior included-- as something that can turn on you without remorse. There are mentions of the urge to break the claustrophobia of stifling winters (""Cannon Falls"")
column7: the difficulty of escaping undertows alone (""Salt and Sea"")
column8: and the feeling of being knocked around by forces out of your control (""Tempest""). And this is all delivered in a voice that sounds raw
column9: ragged
column10: frostbitten
column11: and battered
column12: a love-it-or-hate-it rasp that drags its flatness across simple melodies through what sounds like kicking-and-screaming force.

column1: The voice and the tunes don't always match-- the sparser the production
column2: the more intrusive that rasp feels-- but sometimes that dissonance between the rough-edged singing and the fine-hewn production provides a compelling pop thrill
column3: like the resilient
column4: dramatic swells of ""Salt and Sea"" or the mournful intensity in ""Bound"". Disappointed hip-hop fiends might want to find more accommodating solace elsewhere-- for them
column5: I suggest Doomtree cohort Paper Tiger's fine Made Like Us-- but if you're interested in finding out just what a scene without borders is capable of coming up with
column6:
Legend Recognize Legend is worth the initial disorientation.

Reissue releases usually oversell the now-clichéd story of a misunderstood musical genius. Farad
column2: Stones Throw's retrospective of electronic music eccentric Bruce Haack
column3: does peddle that tale to a certain degree
column4: much like the 2004 documentary Haack: The King of Techno. But the real pleasure of the disc
column5: covering music released during the later part of his career from 1970-82
column6: is that it doesn't try too hard to define Haack's compositions and philosophy or spend extensive time wondering
column7: ""What if?"" It instead exposes the raw components of his odd career
column8: an improbable
column9: colorful circuit board resembling the wiring to some Rube Goldberg device.

column1: A musical prodigy from a Canadian mining town
column2: Haack was all-encompassing in his approach. He had composed far-out children's music and pop songs
column3: experimented with classical/synthesizer hybrids
column4: and hand-crafted a studio's worth of electronic instruments (including a proto-vocoder
column5: Farad
column6: named after inventor Michael Faraday) by the end of the 60s. Few can claim to have demoed electronic instruments for Fred Rogers and written a song covered by Beck (""Funky Little Song""
column7: not included on this album). But his scattered biography goes a long way toward explaining the playful weirdness and the philosophical underpinnings that made Haack so refreshing. Even on his psychedelic excursions or the stone cold electro funk of ""Stand Up Lazarus""
column8: there's a sense of wonder and play
column9: and he doesn't stay perpetually plugged-in
column10: letting folk and country twang find its way into his music.

column1: The tone of his tracks veered from suspended
column2: bubbly escapes (""Rain of Earth"") and silly sing-alongs (""Maybe This Song"") to a Kraftwerk-worthy electro jam with a pre-Def Jam Russell Simmons (1982's ""Party Machine"") or the Byrds-like tinge of ""National Anthem to the Moon""
column3: one of a handful of tracks on the comp taken from his 1970 album The Electric Lucifer. Haack took to the vocoder like Jim Henson took to felt
column4: imitating a guttural monster on ""Noon Day Sun"" and bending his voice into that of a cheesy lovelorn cyborg on ""Rita"". On the jaunty
column5: ""Electric to Me Turn""
column6: Haack gets philosophical over steam organ synths
column7: declaring
column8: ""Electric to me turn this night/ Reflecting universal light/ All I knew that should be true/ Is reality in you."" Hindsight may render some of these tracks a bit silly or indulgent
column9:
but this patchwork of music showcases a true believer and a talent that deserves recognition among his early synthesizer peers.

column4: Pascal Emmanuel Sinamoyi Tabou suffered a stroke that forced his retirement from public life at age 68. His most recent position had been a Vice-Governorship of the city of Kinshasa
column5: the capital of his homeland
column6: the Democratic Republic of Congo. Before that he served in the country's transitional parliament and the cabinet of President Laurent Kabila. His public life had begun decades earlier
column7: though
column8: in the 1950s
column9: when he made his singing debut with Rock-A-Mambo
column10: one of the great early Congolese rumba bands. At the time
column11: Congo was still the Belgian Congo
column12: and the rumba music that would become one of its greatest cultural gifts to the world was still coming into its own. Tabou
column13: better known by his school nickname Rochereau
column14: joined the band of Joseph Kabasele
column15: and it was in this band that he cultivated the star power that allowed him to strike out on his own in the mid-60s.

column1: This period was well documented on Sterns' excellent 2xCD The Voice of Lightness 1961-1977 compilation three years ago. That set brought the story up to 1977 and cataloged Rochereau's many shifts in direction as he honed his band
column2: Orchestre Afrisa International
column3: and consolidated his position as one of the masters of Congolese music. By 1977
column4: his only real competitor for the title was the great guitarist and leader of OK Jazz
column5: Franco. Vol. 2 of The Voice of Lightness picks up where the last one left off
column6: right after Rochereau's triumphant appearance as the leader of an all-star Congolese band at the World Black and African Festival of Arts & Culture in Lagos
column7: Nigeria. The band he led at FESTAC '77 appears on the first track here
column8: sounding confident and laid back and maybe even a little old-fashioned playing an airy brand of rumba that was at the time being eclipsed by the faster soukous of Zaiko Langa Langa and other relatively young bands.

column3: enters to stay on the second track

column6: they demonstrate a clear mastery of the new

column10: as he does on ""Ponce Pilate""
column11: where he dryly chastises his defecting band members
column12: singing in Lingal

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
a
column2: ""We're shocked when we see someone injure someone else/ But we laugh when someone injures himself."" Later
column3: on ""Sarah""
column4: he addresses turnover in his personal life
column5: lashing out at his second wife after she divorced him while he was on tour in North America: ""How does a man come to despise the woman he once loved?"" It should be noted that Rochereau wasn't exactly treading on stable ground here-- he was never a one-woman man
column6: and when I say second wife
column7: I mean she was his second wife at the time. Rochereau was a practicing polygamist.

column1: Even when he sang his most bile-filled lines
column2: though
column3: Rochereau's voice remained a light
column4: supple instrument. He had a way of floating through an arrangement without getting a bit of the dust kicked up by the rolling guitars and insistently pulsing percussion on himself. When he's joined by his chorus
column5: which on many of these tracks includes his lover/protege Mbilia Bel
column6: their voices blend sweetly
column7: contrasting sharply with the blasting horn section
column8: led by Rochereau's longtime right-hand man Modero Mekanisi. This period found Rochereau's songs stretching out to accommodate long instrumental passages for dancing
column9: and the tracks on this compilation average somewhere around nine or 10 minutes
column10: giving the various guitarists Rochereau works with plenty of time to stretch their legs and solo.

column1: Two of the greatest Congolese guitarists ever make appearances here. Rochereau had a falling out with Docteur Nico in the late 60s
column2: when the two split from each other to form competing bands
column3: but ""Ohambe"" finds them working brilliantly together once again-- when Rochereau cries out ""Nico
column4: speak!"" Nico obliges with a shimmering
column5: gorgeous solo. The occasion of Joseph Kabasele's death in 1983 brought Rochereau together with his greatest rival
column6: Franco
column7: for ""Kabasele in Memoriam""
column8: which is a highlight in the careers of both men. Rochereau sings beautifully
column9: sometimes in harmony with his old rival
column10: and Franco offers a showcase on both acoustic and electric guitar. Franco was taken by the AIDS epidemic in 1989
column11: and it would have been a shame had the two never recorded together.

column1: As the second disc wears on
column2: a few things become clear: The music was changing around Rochereau
column3: and he had to change with it. This set avoids his Paris studio work with drum machines and synthesizers attempting to stand in for horns
column4: but it still hints at that work in the synths that occasionally drop in for a squiggly solo. More importantly
column5: though
column6: Rochereau spent much of the time covered on the disc living essentially in exile
column7: first in Europe and then in the United States. To his great credit
column8: the singer managed throughout his career to keep more distance between himself and dictator Mobutu Sese Seko than many of his peers
column9: and when living in exile in Paris
column10: he recorded some of his most openly critical songs. The punning title of ""Exil-Ley"" belies a much more serious message-- the song is Rochereau plainly lamenting his nation's descent into graft and economic collapse. ""Le Glas a Sonne""
column11: also recorded in 1993
column12: directly indicts Mobutu's increasingly ruinous regime
column13: listing off the great men of Congo and leaving Mobutu out
column14: in effect likening him to the white colonial rulers the country had thrown out decades before.

column1: Rocehreau's musical career largely petered out during the 90s when he lived in the U.S. As his attentions were drawn more and more to the politics and needs of his homeland. When Mobutu fell in 1997
column2: he went back home to serve in the new government. Even so
column3: his cultural legacy seems likely to loom high over his political legacy when the historical record settles. This compilation and its previous volume are the absolute best place for Westerners to begin exploring that legacy. They're by no means a definitive catalog-- this is
column4: after all

column8:
this is the intro the great artist deserves.

Right from the start of album opener ""Days of Our Lives""
column3: it's clear Restless People aren't glass-half-empty types. The song's mantra about being real is effervescent
column4: an instigation to dance amplified by a combination of airy synths

column7: pure-positive-thinking lyrics aren't as important as the sheer motivational energy captured in the songs. Vocalist Michael Bell-Smith apparently won't settle for any crossed arms or polite head-nods.

column1: The aptly titled Restless People leans heavily on that same amped-up positivity for the duration of its short

column5: synth-heavy blend of world beat sounds

column7: which aren't the outliers they may appear to be-- check out the shout-along section of ""Victimless Crime""-- and put the album's attitude and rapid-fire bursts of energy into perspective. Such a charging-ahead vibe needs plenty of cathartic moments.

column11: and more like a pair of old pros who've learned enough to figure out what they can get away with forgetting.

column1: Fifteen swings from a punkish thwack to a garage-rock strut
column2: but it's got the feel of a scuzzy alt-rock record
column3: with loose-fitting hooks and craggy guitars. McKee and Franz have a kind of multiplying effect when they start smearing their voices atop each other. The diffuse buzz of the music combined with their push-and-pull on the mic can at times feel so familiar
column4: it's almost familial: Super Wild Horses can and do play like a spinier
column5: far less stoney version of the last couple of Breeders LPs. There's an uncanny beauty that comes when they lock their voices in sync that brings to mind the Deal sisters. And like the Breeders in the last decade
column6: they keep the hooks back
column7: and melodies arrive at intersections rather than announcing themselves out front. Vocal similarities aside
column8: both bands take offhandedness to new heights.

column1: Fifteen's first half is its hookiest. ""Lock & Key"" knocks in the door
column2: but the title track swings roughly
column3: ""Mess Around"" threatens convincingly
column4: and ""Adrian"" pleads with palpable longing. The exuberant vocal back-and-forth has kind of a schoolyard charm to it
column5: but lyrically
column6: they cut some standard teenage themes-- unrequited crushes
column7: small-town escapism-- with a refreshingly flip attitude. And for all their pining
column8: they're not afraid to get weird or abstract or downright blasphemous when the mood strikes. For every diaristic ""is he really going out with her?"" bit
column9: there are a couple more slices of this goofy indignation that suggests a couple of very funny
column10: subversive minds at work. The album reads more like the margins of a notebook-- stray thoughts
column11: decent jokes
column12: the kind of stuff you half-hope somebody sneaks a glance at.

column1: Just short of the halfway mark
column2: Fifteen's punchier
column3: more garage-indebted side gives way to an alt-rock haze. The garagey stuff's more fun
column4: but these are impressive songs-- impressionistic and a bit lopsided
column5: they manage to make two voices
column6: one drumkit
column7: one guitar
column8: a touch of keyboard
column9: and a stompbox sound like a lot more people doing a lot more work. Things seem to crash into each other just so
column10: leaving shards of melody everywhere. One simply doesn't arrive at such a sound by accident. In 26 short minutes
column11: Fifteen gets a lot done
column12: and has a hell of a time doing it. They may not have been at it for long
column13:
but they're already leaving peers in the dust.

The musical recipe that UK producer Matthew Barnes uses in his one-man project Forest Swords is simple enough-- pick some sparse rhythms and sounds
column2: loop them at a pace both languid and insistent
column3: and fold in texture and volume as each piece slowly gathers momentum. But judging by the Dagger Paths EP
column4: released by Olde English Spelling Bee earlier this year
column5: the results are richer than you might expect. Through dense
column6: mesmerizing atmospheres
column7: which conjure faded memories and dream states
column8: Barnes manages to evoke techno
column9: dub
column10: drone
column11: and even hip-hop and R&B.

column1: In fact
column2: when I wrote about the EP back in June
column3: I had a little trouble seeing Barnes' work outside of the fog of buzzy micro-genres like chillwave and witch house. His music's ghostly aura connects to those and other leftfield trends
column4: but really
column5: Barnes has pretty much transcended them all. The more I've listened
column6: the more I've found his hypnotic concoctions to be in a category of their own. Now that UK label No Pain in Pop has re-released Dagger Paths
column7: adding two tracks from a recent 7"" and a CD-R with an impressive array of bonus material
column8: the singularity is so clear it's almost blinding.

column1: Most of that bright light comes from the surprisingly integral role of guitar. At first
column2: these songs sound like a slow
column3: sleepy weave of disparate elements-- dubby bass
column4: sparse percussion
column5: distant voices
column6: blurry samples. But eventually
column7: a bold guitar figure crafts a melody that sticks in your head rather than drifting away with all the echo and atmosphere. Barnes' music can rightly be called murky and dream-like
column8: but it's deceptively so. Dagger Paths is much more active and sharp than such descriptions might imply.

column1: The result is that
column2: the further you delve these songs
column3: the catchier each becomes. A few are immediately engaging
column4: like the swinging ""Miarches"" and hip-hop-in-slo-mo ""The Light""

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
. But other tracks prove just as memorable once they have some time to burrow into your brain. On ""Glory Gongs""
column2: winding guitar chimes return whenever the track threatens to fall apart. And even the reverb-heavy
column3: negative-space cover of Aaliyah's ""If Your Girl Only Knew"" retains the hook of the original. That trend persists as Barnes shifts his sound on two newer tracks-- the sparse
column4: reggae-inflected ""Rattling Cage""
column5: and ""Hjurt""
column6: which wraps guitar in bombed-out drums and distant cries.

column1: No Pain in Pop's bonus CD-R starts with six early Forest Swords tracks
column2: all of which show Barnes' methods to have been pretty well intact from the start (a few are so heavy on fuzzed-out guitar explorations that Forest Swords could be mistaken for an improv rock combo). Also added are remixes of Dagger Paths cuts by other artists
column3: and a 20-minute mix in which Barnes inventively reworks These New Puritans
column4: Burial/Four Tet
column5: and Wild Beasts. Clearly the guy has wide ideas about sound and what it can do
column6:
but what impresses most about Dagger Paths is its focus. All the elements and styles that Barnes collects like a magnet quickly align toward one unmistakable musical vision.
