Barbara Morgenstern's music is part of a minor revolution that not only fused indie pop with techno
column3: but helped synths convey indie pop's oblique romanticism as well as a clumsily played acoustic guitar could. When she first started releasing tapes in the late 1990s
column4: she was part of a Berlin scene named Wohnzimmer music
column5: meaning ""living room
column6: because the living room is where they played shows. And though she's worked with Thomas Fehlmann and Pole
column7: whose ties to pop forms are theoretical at best
column8: Morgenstern never capitulated to real techno-- even when her songs run long
column9: they're still songs. But her music was also never as friendly as her peers'
column10: most of whom are basically turning into footnotes in the Postal Service's bio-- by comparison
column11: Morgenstern sounds reluctant
column12: evasive
column13: never cute enough to cuddle. That she never got the attention she deserved makes sense-- it feels like she never really asked for it.

column1: So while other artists might take a greatest-hits occasion to pile on the makeup and make a case for canonization
column2: Fan No. 2-- which serves as both an early-works compilation and a greatest hits-- is as understated as any of Morgenstern's albums. Despite having six full-lengths and a few EPs to draw on
column3: the greatest-hits portion of this 2CD set has three new tracks
column4: including a cover of the Beatles' ""Blackbird"" (which
column5: in a gesture that proves Morgenstern is more interested in art than idol worship
column6: turns Paul McCartney's folksy schmaltz into club-pop). ""The Operator""
column7: her poppiest track-- the best evidence she could've been better-known if she decided that's what she wanted-- is featured as a ""piano"" version
column8: without the blippy little drum machine that made the original usable on the dancefloor. ""Der Augenblick"" shows up as a previously unreleased remix. ""Das Wort"" was taken from an obscure EP. These are the kinds of choices that'd feel frustrating or self-deprecating in the context of other artists
column9: but with Morgenstern they're expected-- the same kinds of choices that have made her career consistently interesting.

column1: The second disc here collects two early EPs
column2: 1997s Enter the Partyzone and Plastikreport
column3: previously released only on cassette. Lo-fi
column4: minor-key
column5: and lead mostly with cheap-sounding keyboards
column6: they're like a less severe and more tousled version of Young Marble Giants-- the kind of music whose smallness lends it a paradoxical strength and resilience. They're not nearly as sophisticated as the sly
column7: spacious sound she arrived at on 2003's Nichts Muss (my favorite album by her)
column8: but they're pretty great examples of her unusual instinct for harmony and melody-- on songs that are mostly between two and three minutes long
column9: it's hard to figure out how she takes all the turns she does without making a mess. Compositionally
column10: she lives at some imagined intersection of 60s spy-movie soundtracks
column11: lounge
column12: and cabaret
column13: the plaintive
column14: mashed-potato familiarity of Anglo indie-rock
column15: and the computerized Euro-folk of Kraftwerk. Like all of her songs
column16: up through ""The Operator"" and the new ones included on the greatest-hits disc
column17: they feel like they're partially obscured or have their back turned-- they're all curve balls.

column1: It's not that Morgenstern's music is alienating or that a listener would have to be that patient to hear what she has to offer
column2: it's that what she has to offer is licorice or a lemon square-- a lot of people just aren't going to like it. Still
column3: the difference between her and other electro-pop artists that nobody namechecks anymore is that she's the only artist who can offer what she offers. At this point
column4: the synthification of indie rock is so familiar to listeners that it's invisible-- it's worth bringing up only if we're talking about historical trajectory. Albums that might've sounded groundbreaking in 2001 or 2002 sound quaint now
column5: or like the building blocks of something better. Barbara Morgenstern never really broke a lot of new ground-- ironically
column6:
it's a big part of what makes Fan No. 2 sound interesting today.

It might be exaggerating slightly to call A-Trak a visionary
column3: but he deserves recognition as a man who rose up to become the right DJ at the right time. His status
column4: his profile
column5: and his output all coincided with a late-aughts surge in this new universal club music concept
column6: fusing the commonalities of Southern bounce
column7: classic house
column8: nu-electro
column9: old-school pre-sampling hip-hop
column10: and West Coast g-funk into an all-encompassing new urban dance music. And his patronage of that scene defined it flatteringly-- if you want to remember the late 00s fondly for some reason yet to be understood
column11: A-Trak's first Dirty South Dance and his mix Infinity +1 should be enough to make you believe the end of the decade was actually great.

column1: So why does Fool's Gold
column2: Vol. 1
column3: a state-of-the-label comp showcasing the imprint he started with like-minded DJ Nick Catchdubs
column4: feel like a debilitating hangover? As solid as the label's been in its three-plus years of releases
column5: too much of this collection of recent material feels weirdly retrograde and a bit crass
column6: a mushy assemblage of the obvious that feels a lot more backward-looking than the best the label has to offer. It might be too early to go ahead and say that electro-rap is on its way out
column7: but if it is
column8: the synth-pop affectations of Trackademicks' ""The Best Stroke"" and Kid Sister's warmed-over jerk slog ""Don't Stop Movin'"" are hollow epitaphs. There's also a Lil B track
column9: ""Freeze""
column10: that exhibits zero of whatever makes Lil B exciting; I've never heard casual gimme-head misogyny sound so bored. And if you thought CyHi da Prynce's verse on ""So Appalled"" was a work of sabotage
column11: check out A-Trak's ""Ray Ban Vision""
column12: an otherwise-choice piece of engagingly woozy bounce that the rapper ruins by yammering about how he fucks women with his sunglasses on.

column1: Things sharpen up a bit when you get closer to standard house turf-- though you have to wade through a few throwbacks to get there. Some are cringeworthy: the synth-drums from Tears for Fears' ""Mad World""
column2: a Stepford version of Teena Marie
column3: and a vocoder? Try harder
column4: Treasure Fingers featuring Haley Small. And some are crowd-pleasing: Tensnake's always good for some earnestly joyous beardo disco
column5: and even though his remix of Vega's ""No Reasons"" feels like preservationist house à la 1995
column6: that piano riff is a hell of a reason to consider that a good year to visit. A few tracks are a bit more forward-looking-- Flosstradamus' ""Cape Town Get Down"" and Riton's remix of Congorock's ""Babylon"" incorporate shreds of contemporary South African house and electro into their structures-- but you'll probably be more satisfied if you come in expecting slightly postmodern tweaks on familiar vintage sounds from Detroit (Jokers of the Scene's ""Power Slave"") or Chicago (LA Riots' ""Control Your Tuba"").

column1: Fool's Gold has put out some quality stuff lately-- just this year
column2: we got style-hybridizing advancements like Kingdom's blistering garage/electro crossover ""Mind Reader""
column3: the superior original mix of Congorock's ""Babylon"" firing a 21-laser salute at UK funky
column4: and the manic
column5: equatorial house of Greenmoney's Gold Ru$h EP. That's more than enough to give you a sense of what this label's really capable of
column6: and it feels like a more tenable direction than the nostalgic
column7: somewhat ossified vision of dance music laid out in Vol. 1. File this under When Bad Comps Happen to Good Labels
column8:
and keep your fingers crossed.

The ""piano trio
column2: which usually consists of cello
column3: violin
column4: and piano
column5: has been a staple of chamber music for hundreds of years. The clarinet-violin-piano trio is relatively rare and modern by comparison
column6: probably because of its potential to sound unbalanced without the low-end anchor of the cello. Bartók
column7: Stravinsky
column8: and Ives all tried their hands at it
column9: and it's really picked up steam over the last few decades

column13: double bass
column14: light IDM-inspired electronics
column15: and the striking compositional voice of pianist Missy Mazzoli. In one fell swoop
column16: the ensemble bypasses the low-end dilemma and breaks with the existing repertoire
column17: in search of music that gives voice to a thoroughly post-classical age.

column1: This isn't to say that Victoire jettison tradition entirely. Their debut LP
column2: Cathedral City (which expands upon material from their 2009 eMusic ""Selects"" series EP)
column3: compares favorably to a number of eminent touchstones. Philip Glass looms large over its balance of lean
column4: taut pulses and pensive
column5: circling melodies
column6: which conjure feelings of hesitancy and doubt. More contemporaneously
column7: you might hear traces of Julianna Barwick in the digitally ruffled choral vocals that crop up
column8: though Victoire's are much crisper and drier
column9: of a piece with their music's almost fussy personality. There's also an affinity with Nico Muhly's Mothertongue: Low
column10: burly keyboards slide tectonically under nimble yet austere tunes
column11: and quotidian vocal elements (especially the spoken numbers on ""India Whiskey"") sift around like interference. Like Muhly
column12: Victoire evoke a vast interiority-- the composer's multi-tasked mind
column13: rustling and preoccupied. But Mothertongue felt like a mind brashly spilling out
column14: while Cathedral City is more introverted and intimate: an album of private fixations.

column1: Victoire worry at their motifs like difficult knots but ground them in relentless cadences. Within these strict parameters
column2: they pack in an admirable variety of technique and emotional shading
column3: from dawning unease to distressed inspiration. ""A Song for Mick Kelly"" feels at once fretful and poised
column4: with a violin sawing desperately against immovable electric guitar chords courtesy of the National's Bryce Dessner. ""A Door Into the Dark"" is furtive but forceful
column5: its layered motifs pausing
column6: lunging boldly forward
column7: scattering. On ""I Am Coming for My Things""
column8: violin tremolos dart around deep
column9: even figures in the clarinet and crackling radio transmissions. The music settles down when the voices subside
column10: implying a direct link between freedom from encroaching signals and serenity of mind. That's a timely preoccupation if ever one was-- privacy
column11: after all
column12: is also a relatively modern invention; one that is currently under duress. Decisively erratic and turbulently lyrical
column13:
Victoire condense moments of focused beauty and quiet conviction from the pandemic distractions of modern life.

Hailing from the Lower Peninsula of Michigan
column2: Breathe Owl Breathe decamped to the wilds of the Upper Peninsula to record their latest album. They spent a few months playing around with instruments and arrangements in a cabin they nicknamed Magic Central
column3: and by naming the album after that structure
column4: they have bestowed on it a certain imaginative power
column5: much like the Black Lodge or Gorilla Manor. The result is
column6: aptly
column7: a collection of decidedly eccentric folk-pop songs with dark emotional subcurrents
column8: one that toggles between light and dark
column9: precocious observations and dark mortal doubts. Yet
column10: for all the sequestered familiarity of that creation narrative (which is reminiscent of Bon Iver’s career-making deep-woods sojourn) and for all its bleak intimations
column11: Breathe Owl Breathe never sound isolated
column12: introverted
column13: or closed off. In fact
column14: Magic Central sounds gregarious and expansive in its idiosyncrasies
column15: which can range from charming to pushy.

column1: As our guide through the peninsular wilderness and as the narrator of so many quirky story-songs
column2: frontman Micah Middaugh possesses a rich tenor that suggests Bill Callahan singing stoned lullabies

column8: they create a wintry
column9: overcast mood that permeates every moment on Magic Central
column10: as if the songs were houses insufficiently insulated from the cold.

column1: Even so
column2: those miniature movies can be aggressive about their whimsy. Middaugh writes about hearts made of papier-mâché and monsters with good penmanship
column3: even tagging ""Dragon"" with a spoken-word intro delivered in a cutesy stoner cadence. That's the low point in the album
column4: the moment when you just wish he'd address you like an adult. But Breathe Owl Breathe do manage to wring some grim uncertainties from his folksy fairytales: Opener ""Own Stunts"" exaggerates his heartbreak with comic imagery that would make Shel Silverstein grin approvingly. And on ""Dragon""
column5: Middaugh asks repeatedly
column6: even doggedly: ""How do you stop loving someone?"" That's not a rhetorical question; he really needs to know. In trying to balance whimsy and gravity
column7: Breathe Owl Breathe come across as both confident and uncertain
column8: full of personality and slightly overbearing
column9: which makes Magic Central an intriguing
column10:
often grating album.

column3: we get something resembling a mission statement from the sleepy-eyed young New Orleans rapper Curren$y: ""Kill these beats humane fashion
column4: painless."" It's a perfect description of the man's rap style. Curren$y is a great pure rapper
column5: a language addict with a tricky slip-sliding delivery and an ability to keep going for minutes at a time
column6: uninterrupted by choruses. But he's not the type to smash us over the head with his strengths. Instead
column7: his understated punchlines sneakily find ways into your brain and stay there. And after he spent years with hometown powerhouses No Limit and Cash Money
column8: and then on the mixtape circuit
column9: Curren$y finally found his ideal place on the first Pilot Talk album
column10: just a few months old now. Teaming almost exclusively with veteran New York producer Ski Beatz
column11: Curren$y rapped over a luxuriously dazed bed of lava-lamp instrumentals that pulled plenty of sounds from woozy psych-rock. And on the sequel
column12: Curren$y and Ski go even further with that central idea
column13: pushing into sleepy
column14: smooth funk territory that fits Curren$y's rap style perfectly.

column1: My favorite Curren$y track from the past year is ""4 Hours & 20 Minutes (Ride to H-Town)""
column2: a team-up with the blowhard Houston underground fixture Killa Kyleon that hit rap blogs shortly after the release of the first Pilot Talk. That rumbling
column3: bass-heavy track doesn't appear on Pilot Talk II

These aqueous beats come fleshed out with all sorts of beautifully rendered live instrumentation: horns and flutes and pianos and Fender Rhodes and slow-rolling stand-up bass and delicately winding acoustic guitars. I've yet to hear any chillwave quite this chill.

column5: money. Curren$y finds artful
column6: sidelong ways of approaching this stuff-- punchlines that can read awkwardly on paper but sound amazing the way he delivers them.

column2: Mos Def
column3: Devin the Dude. But on the sequel
column4: guys like that don't fit; it's all about Curren$y drawing us into his own universe. Other than a nice Raekwon verse on the album-closing remix

column4: that shows that Curren$y's style could work in a pop context if he wanted it to. The song comes with a gorgeously breathy chorus from R&B singer McKenzie Eddy and makes great use of a prettily still piano line. And even though the track sounds like a breakup song

anything less wouldn't make sense.

By the time Robert Wyatt made 1997's Shleep-- his first album in six years-- he was something of a British institution: a magnificent
column2: one-of-a-kind singer who'd become mostly known for memorable cameos on other people's records. The popular perception of him seemed to be his wheelchair and long white beard
column3: without much between them. Shleep
column4: though
column5: re-established Wyatt as the center of attention
column6: and became the foundation of his career's third act
column7: documented (along with parts of the first two) by the second new batch of re-releases of his discography.

column1: Shleep reintroduced a long-absent sense of playfulness and joy into Wyatt's work. (It also helped that the production was more focused and varied than it had been on anything he'd done since Rock Bottom.) The album starts off with the two wittiest songs in his repertoire: ""Heaps of Sheeps""
column2: a collaboration with his old compatriot Brian Eno
column3: and ""The Duchess""
column4: a mischievous tribute to his wife Alfreda Benge that erases language the way his earlier ""Alifib"" confounds it. Nearly every song on Shleep shines in one way or another: It features a couple of his most elegant melodies in ""Was a Friend"" (co-written by his old Soft Machine bandmate Hugh Hopper) and ""Free Will and Testament""
column5: as well as an extended paraphrase of Bob Dylan's ""Subterranean Homesick Blues"" (""Blues in Bob Minor"") and a little instrumental written by Paul Weller. Its centerpiece is a three-song suite whose lyrics (by Benge) are ostensibly about birds and metaphorically about aliens and refugees: their leftist politics were more effective for being integrated into their art rather than plunked onto it
column6: as they'd been in the Dondestan

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
era.
EPs
column2: a box of five short CDs initially released in 1999
column3: is a grab-bag of some of Wyatt's not-really-album-length work. His miraculous 1974 cover of ""I'm a Believer""-- which got him on ""Top of the Pops"" in his wheelchair-- is here; so is his definitive 1982 recording of Elvis Costello's ""Shipbuilding""
column4: the 1984 Work in Progress EP (with a spine-chilling
column5: minimalist version of Peter Gabriel's ""Biko"")
column6: a tedious 20-minute suite he composed for an animal-rights film

column2: one-of-a-kind singer who'd become mostly known for memorable cameos on other people's records. The popular perception of him seemed to be his wheelchair and long white beard
column3: without much between them. Shleep
column4: though
column5: re-established Wyatt as the center of attention
column6: and became the foundation of his career's third act
column7: documented (along with parts of the first two) by the second new batch of re-releases of his discography.

column1: Shleep reintroduced a long-absent sense of playfulness and joy into Wyatt's work. (It also helped that the production was more focused and varied than it had been on anything he'd done since Rock Bottom.) The album starts off with the two wittiest songs in his repertoire: ""Heaps of Sheeps""
column2: a collaboration with his old compatriot Brian Eno
column3: and ""The Duchess""
column4: a mischievous tribute to his wife Alfreda Benge that erases language the way his earlier ""Alifib"" confounds it. Nearly every song on Shleep shines in one way or another: It features a couple of his most elegant melodies in ""Was a Friend"" (co-written by his old Soft Machine bandmate Hugh Hopper) and ""Free Will and Testament""
column5: as well as an extended paraphrase of Bob Dylan's ""Subterranean Homesick Blues"" (""Blues in Bob Minor"") and a little instrumental written by Paul Weller. Its centerpiece is a three-song suite whose lyrics (by Benge) are ostensibly about birds and metaphorically about aliens and refugees: their leftist politics were more effective for being integrated into their art rather than plunked onto it

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15991/homepage_large.fd4b28e5.jpg|Permanent Vacation: Selected Label Works
column3: the Munich-based Permanent Vacation has amassed one of the most aerobic
column4: head-nodding catalogues in all of electronic music; they are almost definitely the best label to share their moniker with an Aerosmith album.  Excuse the gag
column5: at least a little
column6: because the label shares some of the band's tendencies to offer streamlined
column7: updated versions of classic sounds-- in this case
column8: late-80s and early-90s house.  Its roster loads up on galloping pianos
column9: squelchy synth patches
column10: and hoarse-throated divas chopped into inspired repetition.   More than being just retro retreads
column11: Permanent Vacation's roster has excellently integrated prevailing subgenres-- Balearic
column12: space disco
column13: italo-- into weightless
column14: endlessly re-playable jams.

column1: The mileage you get out of deciding whether a track is really space disco or Balearic disco will... vary
column2: so suffice it to say that Select Label Works 2 features
column3: back to back
column4: Tensnake's ""Coma Cat"" and Azari & III's ""Reckless (With Your Love)""
column5: or two of the most ubiquitous house hits in recent memory.  When they play
column6: concerns about defining exactly what is playing will vanish.   As Permanent Vacation still thrives on vinyl
column7: SLW2 isn't a label primer or showcase; it's a compendium of the label's recent singles (and the iron-hot inclusion of 2010's ""Coma Cat"")
column8: most of which are seeing a CD for the first time.  The label has been ridiculously productive
column9: with Selected Label Works 2 marking the second two-disc comp since 2009 (the label also curated the uneven If This Is House I Want My Money Back). The mix is split pretty evenly between the about-to-explode (Azari & III
column10: John Talabot)
column11: the exploding (Tensnake) and the exploded (Sally Shapiro).

column1: If SLW2 has a defining characteristic it's the ease with which these tracks command a room. Aside from obvious crossovers like Four Tet and Pantha du Prince
column2: much of the year's best electronic music (Shed
column3: Jon McMillion
column4: Scuba) were triumps of nuance that could have been stamped ""not for beginners."" SLW2 is different: The hits feel like buckets of water to the face. The interceding tracks are turned in by solid veterans (Phillip Lauer's note-perfect
column5: piano-driven house anthem ""Delta NRG"") or potent newcomers (Pollyester has two tracks of their swampy boogie remixed; Moonoton cozies up with 1980s R&B).  Label heads  Tom Bioly and Benjamin Fröhlich
column6: who record as Permanent Vacation as well
column7: turn in the cinematic
column8: ominous ""Zucker Hut"". The inessential material-- you probably don't need two mixes of Woolfy vs. Projections' ""Neeve""
column9: for instance-- serves as a reminder that SLW2 is a singles comp
column10: B-side warts and all.

column1: Selected Label Works 2 is fun without being goofy. It is music for your treadmill and your pregaming; it is music to which you dance with strangers until they don't seem like strangers. When I listen to it
column2: I hear music that is unstressed and unconcerned
column3: and whether you hear echoes of Frankie Knuckles or Patrick Cowley or no one you've ever heard at all
column4:
its grooves will seem well-trod in the most welcoming of ways.

"|14900.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14900-permanent-vacation-selected-label-works-vol-2/|8.1|Andrew Gaerig

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15993/homepage_large.b6a4c8b9.jpg|Strumming Music for Piano
column2: Harpsichord and String Ensemble|14319.0|Charlemagne Palestine|['Rock'
column3:
'Experimental']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Sub Rosa']|2010-11-30 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:24.911061|"

In the liner notes for the new 3xCD set Strumming Music for Piano
column4: Harpsichord and String Ensemble
column5: there's a newspaper article from 1974 recounting how Charlemagne Palestine
column6: at a concert in New York
column7: ""broke things off"" a little more halfway through what was to be a four-hour performance. He was playing a piano piece composed with a new technique in mind
column8: but he wasn't happy with the piano he was provided. It was a Steinway
column9: not a Bösendorfer. And so it was that Palestine found himself realizing he simply could not-- should not-- soldier on. What's striking there isn't the fact that a musician had issues with his set-up
column10: or the difference between two exalted kinds of world-class pianos. It's that Palestine was two-and-a-half hours into a single piece when he decided that things just weren't adding up.

column1: The three compositions that make up Strumming are all about the ways that sounds can exhibit spectral effects when pushed beyond their bounds or left alone
column2: or both. Palestine's ""strumming"" technique can be summed up as a method of repeating
column3: repeating
column4: and repeating again. But unlike certain kinds of repetition that lie back and lure a listener into divining effects that may or may not actually exist
column5: Palestine's strumming pieces convey a sense of the composer himself leaning in and muscling such effects into being.

column1: Disc One features ""Strumming for Bösendorfer Piano""
column2: performed by Palestine in 1974. It starts out gently
column3: with a little innocuous tinkling
column4: but over the course of 52 minutes locks into a flurry of reiterated notes and chords that churn out different kinds of overtones. The sounds of those overtones are ethereal
column5: ineffable. But overtones are concrete and real
column6: and Palestine starts to play in reaction to them-- creating still more overtones
column7: until the effect turns into a kind of natural acoustic feedback loop. There's nothing dainty or implicit about it. Palestine is a notably physical presence whose way of playing-- of coaxing by way of banging-- invokes the piano's status as a fundamentally percussive instrument. But there's something innately ghostly about the sounds that surface
column8: like bleary trumpets in a dream or whirring test-tones heard from a distance.

column1: The effects are less striking in the other two pieces. ""Strumming for Harpsichord""
column2: performed by Betsy Freeman in 1977
column3: transpires in a similar fashion
column4: but mostly in an upper register on an instrument less roundly resonant than a piano. On Disc Three
column5: ""Strumming for Strings"" is more of a drone
column6: developing slowly and without a manic sense of rhythm in the foreground. Neither is as magisterial as the one for piano
column7: but both are hypnotic and transporting in their own way. Taken all together
column8: the music of Strumming and its effects sound somehow both discovered and designed. It's like the glints and refractions that figured into early days of spirit photography
column9: when people saw ghosts and metaphysics in what could have just as easily been explained away as a scratch in glass. But what
column10: in the case of music
column11:
is the glass?

"|14902.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14902-strumming-music-for-piano-harpsichord-and-string-ensemble/|7.3|Andy Battaglia

column1: 0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15943/homepage_large.773d754d.jpg|Hearts on Hold|29313.0|Tu Fawning|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['City Slang'
column3: Tu Fawning are not simply the sum of their parts. The brainchild of Joe Haege and Corrina Repp
column4: the band has little in common with either the sprained indie rock of his longtime group 31Knots or the muted folk excursions of her solo output. These two Portlanders have
column5: however
column6: lent their talents to each other's records in the past
column7: and Tu Fawning grew out of Haege backing Repp on a European tour a few years ago before it expanded into a quartet of busy multi-instrumentalists. The most outstanding aspect of their debut full-length
column8: Hearts on Hold
column9: is how different this new act is from anything they've ever done. Guitar is only a walk-on; these songs are built on a foundation of droning horns
column10: ambient sounds
column11: and rumbling drums (mostly courtesy of percussionist Toussaint Perrault). Repp sings more forcefully and brazenly in this setting
column12: drawing out her syllables languidly and paring down the lyrics to their barest syllables.

column1: So
column2: Tu Fawning is a means to indulge all the impulses that don't fit with their day-job acts-- an opportunity to start anew with a different set of rules
column3: influences
column4: and possibilities. Hearts on Hold certainly bears that out; its title is the only mundane thing about it. These songs are crammed with ideas and sounds
column5: inventive and fluid as they bend and change shape. A baleful trumpet loop anchors opener ""Multiply a House""
column6: forming an eerie backdrop whose simplicity reinforces its trip-hop potency. That horn will appear throughout the album
column7: nodding alternately to Haege and Repp's love of early twentieth-century jazz and to cheesy neo-noir soundtracks (remember ""The Salton Sea""?). Such associations are tempered by the percussion
column8: which strictly regiments most of these songs. The simple time-keeping tap of ""Lonely Nights"" suggests the regular thrust of a pickaxe or shovel
column9: which
column10: along with the ominous call-and-response
column11: evokes a field holler or prison work song.

column1: Anchored to prominent drums and gloomy airs
column2: Tu Fawning make a noise that might be best described as organic industrial. Yet
column3: in this context the rigid rhythms of that genre sound stiff
column4: convoluted
column5: and-- perhaps most damningly-- premeditated. The musicians are so intent on creating and sustaining such dark moods that they dampen the songs rather than free them. ""Just Too Much"" struggles to live up to its title
column6: to go off the rail and lead them into danger. Even as they build to a promised payoff
column7: Tu Fawning rein everything in
column8: creating a sense of timidity and truncation. It's a missed opportunity-- and not the only one on Hearts on Hold. The moody atmosphere is an end in itself for the band
column9: but it would make a better starting point.

column1: "|14857.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14857-hearts-on-hold/|6.2|Stephen M. Deusner

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15990/homepage_large.225bb664.jpg|All Day|4832.0|Girl Talk|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Illegal Art']|2010-11-29 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:26.202882|"

The simplest way to a successful and rewarding career: Find something you love doing
column2: then get paid to do it. This is why people talk about Gregg Gillis with a tinge of envy; as Pitchfork's Ryan Dombal has said
column3: Gillis has figured out exactly what he was put on this earth to do--transforming five decades of pop music into seamless
column4: well-paced mixes
column5: and then
column6: live
column7: turning those mixes into a sweaty
column8: tribal celebration of pop music itself. But while 2008's Feed the Animals proved his staying power and solidified his aesthetic
column9: there was a creeping worry that as long as Gillis stuck with this maximalist mashup thing
column10: we'd be stuck having the same arguments for and against him over and over again. So
column11: the question with his fifth album
column12: All Day: In 2010
column13: is a newly minted Girl Talk fan someone who just simply hasn't heard of him before? Or is Gillis capable of converting those still on the fence?

column1: If there are still holdouts
column2: the arguments against Girl Talk are getting slimmer.All Day is a reminder that
column3: despite the number of party DJs and bedroom mashup artists
column4: nobody does it better than Gillis; here he makes the strongest argument yet for himself as a master of his craft. Initially
column5: Gillis comes off like he's baiting his detractors: his ""legitimacy"" as a DJ has been brought into question on account of having the cleanest hands of any cratedigger
column6: but Gillis goes even more mainstream with his source material (we're talking John Lennon
column7: the Rolling Stones
column8: the Jackson 5...). Compared to All Day
column9: Girl Talk's calling-card LPNight Ripper might as well be Endtroducing... And even those who've enjoyed his work will admit that it's a hell of a lot to take for extended periods of time
column10: yet All Day clocks in at a titanic 71 minutes
column11: almost 20 minutes longer than Animals.

column1: Against those odds
column2: Gillis turns these perceived weaknesses into strengths; as his most fussed-over and carefully plotted album
column3: All Day paradoxically sounds like his most effortless. He's still operating within a ""if it's not fun
column4: why do it?"" ethos
column5: but fortunately
column6: it doesn't have the same relentless pacing of his prior work
column7: offering a couple of cooldown moments to collect yourself before spazzing out again (the most notable is the ""Imagine""/ ""One Day"" comedown that closes out All Day). Which is crucial
column8: since All Day is meant to be listened to as a whole. (Gillis admits that the seemingly arbitrary track breakdown is solely for ease of navigation.)

column1: But if I need a five-minute fix
column2: ""Get It Get It"" is the best illustration of how the roomier confines of these songs allow the samples to breathe
column3: evolve
column4: and take on a life of their own without wearing out their welcome. Scoff at the supposed ""wackiness"" of matching ""Pretty Boy Swag"" with ""Windowlicker"" and you'll miss what is arguably Gillis' most inspired musical arrangement. It's not great because of novelty
column5: it's great because it totally makes sense-- it's almost eerie how perfectly Soulja Boy's halting cadences match Aphex Twin's fidgety programming
column6: amplifying the implicit weirdness of the former and the skewed pop instincts of the latter. If M.I.A. realized that agit-pop is greatly enhanced with kickass guitar riffs
column7: she might realize how perfectly tailored Rage Against the Machine's ""Killing in the Name"" is for her protégé Rye Rye. Later in the track
column8: Gillis pairs up the hyper machismo of Pitbull's ""Hotel Room Service"" with Depeche Mode's ""Just Can't Get Enough"" as a musical illustration of Girl Talk's general outlook
column9: a unity borne of the search for hedonistic pleasure.

column1: Befitting the party-starting functionality of All Day
column2: it doesn't ever go into the chin-stroking appeal of obvious precedent Plunderphonics
column3: and the samples aren't given new contexts so much as new purposes. It's pretty much impossible for ""Sunshine of Your Love"" to sound new
column4: but it's a blast to drop the flower-power lyrics and have Biggie's ""Nasty Boy"" bring out the lurid appeal of the riffs (lolz at Eric Clapton's soloing beginning with the line ""then I whipped it out""). And of course
column5: there's the Easter eggs
column6: the knowing winks and the in-jokes-- an instantly recognizable clip from ""One More Time"" sneaks in for a split second
column7: but Daft Punk lay low for a minute or two before resurfacing for ""Digital Love"". Or chopping up Big Boi's ""Shutterbug"" to stress the line ""I'm double-fisting/ If you're empty you can grab a cup."" Personally
column8: I think the funniest moment is intentionally using the commonly misheard chorus of ""1901"" (it's not ""falling
column9: people!) as a punctuation to Ludacris saying ""how low can you go?"" And the instrumental from ""Mr. Big Stuff"" allows the listener to clown Wale's noxious ""Pretty Girls"" hook without saying a word.

column1: Yes
column2: the headslap moments aren't completely eliminated
column3: just far less frequent (""Jane Says""/""Teach Me How to Dougie"" sticks out the most)
column4: but even the perceived ""mistakes"" have a plan-- at first
column5: the indelible drum sound from ""Idioteque"" sounds horribly beatmatched with the Isley Brothers' ""Shout""
column6: but that's just the second-long windup before hurtling into a crazed strip-club banger.  And while some might see the use of the piano coda from ""Layla"" backing B.o.B.'s ""Haterz Everywhere"" as sacrilege
column7: the two achieve a bizarre
column8: complex harmony with each other. As far as what the use of Fugazi's ""Waiting Room"" as the foundation for a ""Rude Boy"" mashup is supposed to ""mean""? I'll allow that Gillis is fucking with us sometimes.

column1: When Girl Talk broke through in 2006 with Night Ripper
column2: the album was often credited for reflecting the new listening habits afforded by the Internet
column3: where long-held grudges were dropped and pop
column4: indie rock
column5: classic AOR
column6: and mainstream rap were on equal playing fields. If only that were true; it's easier than ever to wall yourself off from music you dismiss on principle alone
column7: and if we're living in a time when Arcade Fire fans don't want to have their sincerity questioned when they ride for the cause of Waka Flocka Flame or Birdman (""Wake Up"" bridges the gap here between ""Hard in Da Paint"" and ""Money to Blow"")
column8: I must've missed it.

column1: What All Day and Girl Talk himself are nostalgic for is not a specific sound or even a specific period of time
column2: even though Gillis' sweet spot is alt-rock and pop-rap from the 90s. It's not ""hey
column3: remember 'Thunder Kiss '65'"" or
column4: ""whoa
column5: what happened to Skee-Lo
column6: but rather nostalgia for a time when MTV and radio were the primary methods of conveyance. They weren't perfect
column7: but there was a certain thrill to being something of a captive audience
column8: of letting yourself go and being impressionable for just once
column9: finding out that ""Possum Kingdom"" was pretty rad while waiting for a new Beck single
column10:
that both ""Flava in Ya Ear"" and ""Liquid Swords"" were great in their own way and that your parents liked some cool shit after all once you discovered the classic rock station. It's fitting that Gillis went old-school and ""released"" All Day so that everyone could have it at the same time: He wants nothing more than to recapture the thrill of a true communal pop experience.

It should've been J. Cole's big night: the long-awaited release of the Jay-Z protégé's Friday Night Lights mixtape on November 12. Instead
column2: the spotlight fell to another Jay: Jay Electronica
column3: who joined Cole on Jay-Z's Roc Nation imprint that night
column4: being introduced by Hova himself at a media-heavy Manhattan gathering
column5: in front of a bunch of writers who would've otherwise been home downloading Cole's mixtape. ""This 'posed to be a moment
column6: Cole yells on the tape's intro
column7: as if protesting preemptively.

column1: Beyond their first initial
column2: Cole and Electronica have a lot in common. They're both Southerners who specialize in conscientious
column3: Nas-Style New York rap
column4: and devote their grainy drawls to complex rhyme patterns and even more complex introspection. But Jay Elec is an effortless enigma
column5: a guy who can (and will) rattle off absolute nonsense and make it sound like the deepest thing you ever heard. Cole
column6: in contrast
column7: is the honor student who overthinks everything: Each boast or proposition comes with some sort of tortured justification. It's not enough for him to enjoy the spoils of his success; he has to spell out to us that he's doing it for everyone else who grew up poor in Fayetteville
column8: North Carolina. He's a striver
column9: and he sounds like one.

column1: Friday Night Lights is almost entirely a self-produced affair
column2: and it's to Cole's credit that he knows what makes him sound good
column3: even if he does lean too hard on the tinkly piano sound he loves. On the great summer single ""Who Dat""
column4: Cole came off tense and purposeful
column5: as if he were trying to elbow his way onto radio playlists through sheer force of will. Friday Night Lights finds him in a more expansive mode
column6: getting into the minutiae of his own personal story over exclusively midtempo beats. At its best
column7: the tape has an organic warmth that lends it an immediate approachability. At its worst-- the inevitable dragging moments that come with any hour-plus mix focusing mostly on one voice-- that organic pose fades into an all-surface gleam that doesn't really suit Cole at all. When he raps over the rippling lilt of Erykah Badu's ""Didn't Cha Know""
column8: it's perfect. When he raps over Missy Elliott and Aaliyah's gorgeously still ""Best Friends""
column9: it isn't. But Cole is
column10: in the grand scheme
column11: new to this
column12: and there's a good chance he'll figure this stuff out.

column1: Like the TV show that shares its name
column2: Friday Night Lights is an affecting tale of small-town people trying to figure out their paths in life. Cole
column3: who left Fayetteville for college in New York City
column4: explores bits of his own story that little rap music has found space to address-- like being the one college kid who made it out
column5: then returning home to realize that many of his old friends are in prison or Iraq. Or digging into the fluidity of class
column6: and the weird effects it can have on a kid's psyche: ""Me
column7: I lived it all
column8: from dirt poor in a trailer/ Worried about my mother and never trusting my neighbors/ To middle class with a backyard and my own room/ To being the only black kid in my homeroom."" In one painfully vivid moment
column9: he finds himself jealous of the white kids whose parents sent them to school with Lunchables. In another
column10: he wonders whether college was really the best way out: ""One year cost 'bout the same as a Mercedes/ Four years cost wife
column11: crib
column12: and a baby.""

column1: But those sharp moments don't make up the whole of Friday Night Lights
column2: and Cole wanders into less convincing territory when he rants that people never buy music anymore (though he himself has barely released any music that you can actually buy) or when he talks to the ladies. Loverman songs on mixtapes rarely work
column3: but one exception to the rule is Drake
column4: who shows up here to breeze through ""In the Morning""
column5: absolutely schooling Cole on his own track. Cole tries to get clever with this stuff
column6: and it almost always turns out badly; he actually rhymes ""Rihanna"" with ""vee-gina.""

column1: Cole's restless intelligence works against him almost as much as it helps him; you end up wishing he'd just take some delight in a new car or some nice clothes without reminding us
column2: again and again
column3: that he used to be poor. While it's a major theme in rap-- if not the major theme in rap-- that up-from-nothing rise is implicit for most rappers
column4: something to be touched on
column5:
not to continually fall back on.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15974/homepage_large.1dfb1d7e.jpg|Lina|29197.0|Les Sins|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Carpark']|2010-11-29 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:28.601936|"

Even though the debut LP by Chaz Bundick's Toro Y Moi
column2: Causers of This
column3: maximized the zoned-out vibes
column4: there were traces of dance signifiers worming their way out of the music
column5: itching to be sped up and broadcast as something bigger and bolder. That's exactly what happens on Bundick's solo side project
column6: Les Sins. His first outing under the name
column7: Lina
column8: is a 12"" double-sided single that sounds like Toro Y Moi on club DJ duty
column9: grafting Italo disco
column10: house
column11: and retrofitted roller boogie elements into his already pop-edified palette. The resulting nine minutes of music explore Bundick's dance-friendly impulses in ways both enjoyable and grating.

column1: A-side ""Lina"" is the real keeper. Bundick establishes a steady groove with a female vocal hook
column2: funked-out bass
column3: and string loops. It's propulsive and clean
column4: even when Bundick starts to deconstruct and chop away at all the details. The first minute or so feels rarefied-- fans of Daft Punk and Avalanches will easily find something to latch onto-- it seems a little pointless to just drop everything into the Cuisinart. But since Bundick is able to shape and re-wrap these elements back into the groove so precisely
column5: all the refitting feels ambitious. ""Lina"" shimmers on the surface and pulsates steadily underneath
column6: making it a perfect fit for some cavernous warehouse space that's packed with bodies and hasn't been hit with a noise violation yet.

column1: ""Youth Gone"" is very much the leftfield
column2: exploratory B-side
column3: and despite featuring a similar level of energy
column4: it lacks ""Lina""'s warm
column5: delirious throb. In fact
column6: it's actually a little irritating. A too-short
column7: horn-guided sample leads the first half of the track
column8: imparting a nauseating feeling that awkwardly amplifies some of the skittery leanings of Toro Y Moi proper. Labored and repetitive
column9: ""Youth Gone"" never eases up
column10: even when a more concrete two-step beat is laid down. As a whole
column11: Lina kind of knocks the wind out of you
column12: in ways that feel both pleasurable and disorienting. Still
column13: Les Sins is just the kind of thing you'd want to hear on the side from someone like Bundick-- a brief
column14:
intriguing flight of fancy.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15944/homepage_large.ca0aaaf9.jpg|As U Were|2579.0|Lyrics Born|['Rap'
column3: it has always been about the bounce. Take ""Callin' Out""
column4: the first single from his 2003 solo debut
column5: Later That Day...
column6: which introduced the MC (real name Tom Shimura) to an audience that might not have been up on his work with Lateef the Truthspeaker as half of Latyrx. Despite his dexterous
column7: lyrically agile performance
column8: ""Callin' Out"" stuck in your head as a body-rocker
column9: with its rubbery knock overshadowing just about everything else. Over the course of three albums now
column10: Lyrics Born has been refining that bounce
column11: searching for a hip-hop future that remains deeply rooted in the funk
column12: disco
column13: and soul of the past. His latest
column14: As U Were
column15: brings all of this to a head
column16: adding current pop and R&B elements to form an ebullient
column17: commercially viable hip-hop record. But despite its ambitions
column18: it feels less like a backpacker's idea of pulling a Love Below
column19: and more like the natural next step from a guy who digs Chic as much as Jurassic 5.

column1: Coming from an underground MC who made his name alongside the likes of Blackalicious and DJ Shadow
column2: As U Were's mainstream pop lean is downright shocking. Take ""We Live By the Beat""
column3: which works soul-driven horns and a strobe-lit Euro-house hook (complete with Euro-house chanteuse) into a hometown hyphy track. What looks like a mess on paper meshes convincingly on the floor. And even when these amalgamations falter
column4: you still have to admire the ambition. One near miss is the single ""Lies X 3""
column5: which has less impact than it hopes for
column6: sounding like a Hall & Oates tune all jacked-up on Bob Fosse swagger. And maybe the Timbaland move on ""I Wanna B W/U"" feels a little discount
column7: and the sci-fi prog-rock posturing on ""I'm the Best (Funky Fresh in the Flesh)"" a little soggy. But that still can't cloud Shimura's giddy energy. Though most of As U Were shows little interest in staying true to any one form for too long
column8: it's easy to understand why Shimura doesn't consider ""crowd-pleasing"" to be a dirty phrase. He seems happy to find himself in the company of forward-thinking artists with retro-minded fundamentals
column9: à la Janelle Monáe.

column1: Ironically
column2: if there is one thing holding these songs back
column3: it's Lyrics Born himself. Shimura spits sparingly
column4: often just to shake a little life into the imaginary crowd once the groove settles. Sometimes
column5: you barely notice whether he's rapping or singing or kind of hanging out somewhere in between. But the more lyrically-minded endeavors lack the pop magnetism that As U Were is all about
column6: so even the more focused head-knock stuff like ""Block Bots"" (boasting a nimble ""B.O.B."" vibe with a few goofed-out James Brown breaks thrown in for good measure) pales in comparison. Stir in some troublingly dull subject matter-- from the sluggish temptation cautionary tale ""I've Lost Myself"" to blandly branding pharmaceutical companies as the true pusher men of today-- and As U Were's wheels begin to spin. But then
column7: just often enough
column8: you'll stumble on something that sounds like Prince jamming out in a haunted house (""Pushed Aside/Pulled Apart"")
column9: or Funkadelic working out to some heavy chiptune synths (""Something Better""). And before you know it
column10:
the bounce is back.

The exclamation point that punctuated Michael Benjamin Lerner's self-titled debut album as Telekinesis felt presumptuous. There were some sugary power-pop gems on that record
column2: but they were outnumbered by alt-rock with tempos that ranged from a mid-paced walk to outright foot-dragging. Perhaps that's why it's a little surprising when one is reminded that Lerner's a part of Merge's stable; his songwriting style uncannily resembles that of the bands featured on Death Cab for Cutie's pre-major label home
column3: Barsuk-- for better and for worse.

column1: Maybe Lerner agrees: Telekinesis' new EP
column2: Parallel Seismic Conspiracies
column3: suggests as much. The five-track release-- a sort of teaser-holdover until the project's forthcoming sophomore full-length
column4: 12 Desperate Straight Lines-- embraces a scruffy
column5: home-recorded sound absent from the debut. The jump to lo-fi could be cynically seen as trend-jumping at a point where a great deal of new bands are setting up studios in their parents' basements
column6: but it turns out to be a good look for Lerner
column7: adding a sense of rough-around-the-edges charm that suits his songwriting talents well. Not a single song on the EP-- which itself just pushes a 10-minute running time-- goes over three minutes
column8: which makes the immediacy of new songs ""Dirty Thing"" and ""Non-Toxic"" more potent.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: ""Calling All Doctors""
column3: a somewhat grating piano-led lowlight from Telekinesis!
column4: gets a much-needed facelift
column5: as spiky guitar lines and a driving beat turns the previously sad-sack ballad into an enjoyably neurotic earworm. The sprightly rework highlights a new confidence evident on Parallel Seismic Conspiracies
column6: one that perhaps led to a pair of ill-advised covers: Guided by Voices' ""Game of Pricks"" and pre-Joy Division outfit Warsaw's ""The Drawback"". There's nothing specifically wrong with Lerner's take on the former-- if anything
column7: that's the problem. It's merely competent and feels unnecessary. The latter
column8: on the other hand
column9: showcases Lerner's technically impressive drum skills with faster-than-fast fills
column10: but his at times wide-eyed voice sounds ill-fitting when wrapped around the original's wordy
column11: political lyrics (""I find a promise in confessions of true faith/ And hypocrisy that always lies within"").  Lesson to learn: It's okay to stray from your comfort zone-- just don't go
column12: you know
column13:
too far.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15977/homepage_large.e5df6c0c.jpg|Pretty Hate Machine|3043.0|Nine Inch Nails|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Universal']|2010-11-24 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:30.347798|"

For reasons I won't get into here
column2: my little brother spent the first couple weeks of ninth grade in a Baltimore psych ward. While he was in there
column3: he desperately wanted one of his tapes
column4: and that tape was Pretty Hate Machine
column5: an album already a few years old at that point. Rather than bringing it to him
column6: my dad decided to listen to it
column7: making it about 90 seconds in-- to the first ""Bow down before the one you serve/ You're going to get what you deserve"" bit on ""Head Like a Hole""-- before deciding the album was Satanic and throwing it in the trash. I tried arguing the point with him (""No
column8: dad
column9: he's talking about money! Listen to it!"")
column10: but he didn't budge. For much of the 1990s
column11: Pretty Hate Machine was that type of album: One that could inspire fervent
column12: devotional need and absolute revulsion
column13: largely depending on the age of the person hearing it. And that's even more impressive when you consider that it's basically a synth-pop album.

column1: The greatest trick Trent Reznor ever pulled was convincing the world he was the devil. With his biblical-phallic band name
column2: his reportedly furious early live shows
column3: his fishnets worn as sleeves
column4: Reznor staked out a position for himself on the Alice Cooper shock-rock continuum. Reznor certainly talked a big game about his industrial influences
column5: even taking part in the Wax Trax! collective Pigface
column6: but it wasn't the punishing megaphone-addled arm of industrial that most informed Reznor's debut album; it was the genre's nascent new-wave period. Scene kings Ministry
column7: after all
column8: started out as floppy-haired New Romantics. And so
column9: for that matter
column10: did Reznor himself; Google Exotic Birds sometime.

column1: Reznor would progress further into scraping roar not long later; 1992's ""Wish"" was certainly no Depeche Mode song. But Pretty Hate Machine is haunted
column2: synthetic dance-pop through and through. The beats have muscle
column3: but it's not metal muscle or pigfuck muscle or even post-punk muscle. ""Head Like a Hole""
column4: the big hit
column5: is probably the most rock thing on the whole album
column6: but even that song opens with ""Heart of Glass""-esque percussion ripples before the drum machine thunder and weird hooting noises come in. ""Terrible Lie"" is built on synth-scrapes that
column7: in less distorted form
column8: could've shown up on a New Order single
column9: and ""Sin"" likewise has a whole lot of ""Blue Monday"" in its DNA. Whenever a verse ends during ""Kinda I Want To""
column10: we get a quick little reptilian disco synth-fight. Glacial new-age keyboard tones abound
column11: and big nasty guitars really don't. And Reznor knew how to mine this form for all the emotional catharsis it was worth
column12: which was a lot.

column1: But Reznor still stood out as a rock star
column2: maybe the rock star of the time. Largely
column3: that's a credit to his absolutely magnificent rock-star voice
column4: one of the finest of his generation. On Pretty Hate Machine
column5: Reznor sounds tough but also strained and vulnerable. There's a huge
column6: frustrated mall-kid aspect to his voice
column7: to the way it goes from defeated mutter to impotent yowl in no time flat. It's like he knows how petty he can sound
column8: but he can't help himself. There's plenty of rancor on Pretty Hate Machine
column9: too
column10: much of it directed at some unspecific ""you"" that made his frustration all the more relatable: ""I gave you my purity
column11: and my purity you stole."" On ""Terrible Lie""
column12: he never bothers to specify what the lie in question is; does it matter? ""Why am I seething with this animosity?"" he asks
column13: like even he doesn't know and can't justify it.

column1: Much of Pretty Hate Machine concerns a simple scenario: Being young but feeling that your life is already over
column2: that your best days are already behind you. On ""Down in It"": ""I used to be somebody."" On ""That's What I Get"": ""How can you turn me into this/ After you just taught me how to kiss... you?"" (On that extended pause
column3: Reznor sounds like he's 12
column4: like that ""you"" will never arrive and he's just admitted that he never made out with anyone before.) And on the time-stopping album centerpiece ""Something I Can Never Have"": ""Everywhere I look
column5: you're all I see/ Just a fading fucking reminder of who I used to be."" ""Something I Can Never Have"" is where Reznor's vulnerability really becomes his greatest asset. His scream gone
column6: his voice turns to pure bottomless dejection. He's carefully considered every aspect of his life
column7: and nothing looks good. In the words of decade-later imitators Linkin Park
column8: he sounds like he's about to break. Or like he's already broken.

column1: ""Something I Can Never Have"" also shows an absolute mastery which would blossom soon after into something like genius
column2: and which was already pretty far along in 1989. Starting with nothing but a haunted
column3: minimal piano figure and a few hushed synth tones
column4: the track slowly lets in sputtering static
column5: faraway door-slam drums
column6: and quiet little counter-melodies. Guitar never shows up; it'd break the spell. When NIN would do this track live
column7: you could practically hear the collective intake of breath at those first piano notes. As far as I'm concerned
column8: it's probably the single finest song Reznor ever wrote.

column1: In later years
column2: Reznor would push all the ideas on Pretty Hate Machine even further-- into a sputtering maelstrom
column3: depressive stillness
column4: zoned-out trance-states
column5: and terrible beauty. But the ideas are all there already
column6: contained in a 10-song capsule that ends quickly enough that everything lingers. Most of the songs on Pretty Hate Machine are fairly long
column7: but no time is wasted. This new reissue doesn't much alter that original experience. The remaster job doesn't sound much different from the original article
column8: and the sole bonus track
column9: a sexed-up B-side cover of Queen's ""Get Down Make Love""
column10: sort of misses the point; this was
column11: in a lot of ways
column12: an album about not getting laid. So the real reason to revisit the album is the album itself
column13: nothing else. Now that Reznor has retired the NIN touring institution and become a sort of Internet-friendly cool-uncle figure
column14:
it's pretty striking to go back to that seismic first strike and re-feel all the stuff we first felt hearing this thing.

column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15985/homepage_large.522af323.jpg|Loud|5310.0|Rihanna|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam'
column2:
'Roc Nation']|2010-11-24 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:30.957738|"

Rejoice: Rihanna is having fun again. If she's not spilling milk with Drake in a (impressively spotless) bodega in her ""What's My Name?"" video
column3: she's playfully grabbing Nicki Minaj's ass at the American Music Awards or living out millions of karaoke dreams by singing ""Livin' on a Prayer"" with Bon Jovi during a recent show in Madrid. All the while whipping her neon-stop-sign hair and smiling and throwing up ridiculous devil's horns. All this just a year after Rated R
column4: her spiked-out  reaction to staggering emotional and physical trauma. And while that  cathartic album provided an outlet for her frustrations and allowed her  to claim some artistic bona fides
column5: the actual songs were often plodding and weighed down by overwrought melodrama. Not so on Loud
column6: which has the 22-year-old Barbados-born star picking up where 2007's Good Girl Gone Bad left off
column7: doling out effervescent pop like it was her birthright.

column1: ""Life's too short to be sittin' around miserable
column2: sings Rihanna with a shrug on future 2 a.m. staple ""Cheers (Drink to That)"". ""People are gonna talk whether you're doin' bad or good."" The lines sum up the general sentiment of Loud nicely. There's no grand statement here
column3: no tabloid back story. And while Rihanna had a hand in writing most of the songs on Rated R
column4: she's not credited with writing anything here. But she's more  experienced
column5: and unlike some of her early material
column6: you feel like she's actually connecting with these tunes on more than a purely melodic level. In his review of Good Girl
column7: Pitchfork's Tom Breihan wrote that Rihanna ""comes off sounding like a robot programmed to impersonate Alanis Morissette."" And the acoustic strums and mid-tempo drum beat-- not to mention the vocal sample of Avril Lavigne's ""I'm With You""-- on ""Cheers"" are particularly Alanis-esque. But now Rihanna is capable of adding her own West Indian lilt and charisma to the tipsy track-- you can almost hear her smirk as she brings hashtag rap to pop&B: ""It's gettin' Coyote Ugly up in here/ No Tyra!""

column1: After releasing five albums in as many years
column2: the singer is closer than ever to becoming the  complete pop package Jay-Z envisioned when he signed her the same day  she walked into Def Jam during his tenure as president. Though gifted  with runway-ready looks
column3: Rihanna has improved in other areas through  sheer perseverance. Her voice-- once fragile and shrill-- is now robust  enough to take on songs like the delightfully Eurotrash pounder ""Only  Girl (In the World)"" not only on record but at high profile awards-show  performances. Her semi-scripted dance moves are sultry and spontaneous.  She can be kinda funny (or at least genuinely excitable) in interviews.  She'll never be as boldly talented as Beyoncé or freakishly engaging as  Gaga

column1: If anything
column2: the record sounds too easy at times. ""California King Bed"" is  a ""I Don't Want to Miss a Thing""-type power ballad genetically engineered  to soundtrack a bi-coastal Kate Hudson rom-com. ""Raining Men"" is a  shameless Beyoncé rip-off that would be quickly dismissed if not for the  fact that it's a pretty-damn-good Beyoncé rip off with a  characteristically scene-stealing guest verse from Nicki Minaj.  Meanwhile
column3: ""Fading"" copies Rihanna's own lightweight R&B formula so much it's redundant.

column1: On the flip
column2: ""Man Down"" takes her violent side to its  logical conclusion as it finds her on the run after killing a poor guy  dead
column3: its reggae bounce matching perfectly with Rihanna's mesmerizing  cadence. And ""Skin"" is her sexiest song yet
column4: a haunted
column5: near-dubstep stunner that wouldn't sound totally out of place on Massive Attack's Mezzanine. Her laissez-faire attitude toward hit-making on Loud can result in too-safe moves or semi-experiments that come off surprisingly great
column6: but
column7: at this rate
column8: by the time she runs out of  singles from this record there will be another one ready to go. More  than a stocking stuffer but less than an idol
column9:
Rihanna has grown into one of the most reliable pop stars we've got.

The original Strategies Against Architecture collection
column5: released in 1984

column2: Vol. 4

column5: richer
column6: layered sound. If albums like SAA and 1981's Kollaps sound like shrill field recordings from a particularly gruesome factory mishap

column6: Gough was a hyper-prolific songwriter who could pull charmingly ramshackle soft-rock lullabies out of his toque as easily as getting water from a tap
column7: but little did we realize how literal the NME's definition of ""now"" would prove to be. Rather than rise to the echelons of the songwriters who so clearly inspired him-- John Lennon
column8: Bruce Springsteen
column9: Nick Drake-- Gough spent the rest of the decade weathering the familiar fate of former next-big-things
column10: watching his critical and commercial stock decline over a series of lukewarmly received releases
column11: and switching labels album to album in an effort to reignite his career.

column1: Of course
column2: Badly Drawn Boy is hardly the first artist to peak on his first album
column3: but as Gough's latest release attests
column4: so few are willing to use that lingering sense of disappointment and wasted potential as the conceptual framework for a trilogy of albums. Recorded during a reported surge of inspiration that carried over from last year's Is There Nothing We Could Do?-- a soundtrack companion to the UK telefilm The Fattest Man in Britain-- the hastily conceived and recorded It's What I'm Thinking (to be released over the next year in three parts
column5: Robyn-style) sees Gough reunite with Bewilderbeast co-conspirator Andy Votel and considerably tone down the eager-to-please ostentation that marred 2004's One Plus One Is One and 2006's Born in the U.K. The songs on this first installment
column6: Photographic Snowflakes
column7: are ostensibly about making amends and starting over
column8: but not so much in the context of a stagnant relationship as that of a career at the crossroads: ""I'm ready to be in love again
column9: Gough sings optimistically amid the Spectorized sleigh-bell strut of ""Too Many Miracles""
column10: an address that seems directed less at an old flame than his old fans.

column1: At the outset at least
column2: Photographing Snowflakes carries the promise of rekindled romance: opener ""In Safe Hands"" bears a spare
column3: spectral quality largely unheard in Gough's work since Bewilderbeast
column4: while the album's most captivating track
column5: ""The Order of Things""
column6: sees Gough lay out all his doubts and insecurities over a tick-tock drum-machine track
column7: while triggered snare rolls
column8: synth textures and radio frequencies gently amplify the feeling of hermetic
column9: fever-dream psychosis. (At one point
column10: he even casts blame for his creative inertia to the ""birds in the sky"" who ""steal my melodies."") But for all its surface similarities to Gough's definitive debut-- ""A Pure Accident"" even directly references signature song ""Magic in the Air""-- Photographing Snowflakes is ultimately more an echo of Bewilderbeast than an answer to its challenge
column11: mostly because Gough used to be a far more playful and expressive vocalist
column12: whereas his unaffected
column13: plain-spoken performances here serve only to magnify the repetitious quality of his songwriting. Whether you feel Photographing Snowflakes is a true return to form will depend on your reception of its six-minute title track centerpiece
column14: on which Gough drowsily monotones his way through 10 increasingly whimsical verses with no chorus in sight; you'll either find its slow-motion
column15: pedal-steeled sway charmingly wistful or tediously self-satisfied. Then again
column16: when your time is no longer now
column17:
what's the point of watching the clock?

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15890/homepage_large.8dbd069e.jpg|Come and Get It: The Best of Apple Records|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Apple']|2010-11-23 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:43.458259|"

By the beginning of 1968
column2: the Beatles had made a pile of money they had to either invest in a business or pay in taxes. They chose the business route
column3: launching a suite of enterprises collectively called Apple Corps
column4: most of which were boondoggles. Apple Electronics was a disaster; Apple Studio was a joke; the Apple Boutique lasted seven months before they gave up and announced that they were simply giving away the rest of their stock. Apple Records might have been a similarly dubious idea-- the Beatles weren't short of hangers-on
column5: and the label's roster was heavily populated by longtime pals of the group and curiosities they decided to release on a whim. But if the Beatles knew how to do one thing
column6: it was make records
column7: and almost everything in the Apple discography is somewhere between ""interesting"" and ""superb.""

column1: This one-disc singles compilation
column2: spanning 1968-1972
column3: isn't quite what its title promises: The Beatles' post-""Hey Jude"" records
column4: and their early solo records
column5: aren't on here. (It's being released alongside reissues of most of Apple's not-Beatles-or-Yoko album catalogue.) Still
column6: they're all over it. Paul McCartney wrote the winning oompah instrumental ""Thingumybob"" for the Black Dyke Mills Band and ""Goodbye"" for Mary Hopkin
column7: and he told Badfinger they could have his new song ""Come and Get It"" if they played it note-for-note like his demo. George Harrison wrote ""Try Some
column8: Buy Some"" for ex-Ronette Ronnie Spector and the explosive rocker ""Sour Milk Sea"" for his old Liverpool pal Jackie Lomax. (The backing band on the latter includes George
column9: Paul
column10: Ringo Starr
column11: and Eric Clapton; recorded during the White Album sessions
column12: it would've been one of the best songs on that record if George had kept it for himself.)

column1: The Beatles were canny judges of popular taste
column2: too
column3: and this set includes a handful of hits that have been out of circulation for years
column4: thanks to the Apple catalogue's being in limbo. Mary Hopkin's ""Those Were the Days

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
was No. 2 in the U.S. (and bumped ""Hey Jude"" off the top
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
of the British charts); Billy Preston's ""That's the Way God Planned It"" and ""My Sweet Lord"" (recorded before Harrison's own version)
column2: Chris Hodge's glam-rock boogie ""We're on Our Way""
column3: and Badfinger's ""Come and Get It"" and ""Day After Day"" all made the charts in America.

column1: What makes Come and Get It really fun
column2: though
column3: is the same thing that made the Beatles' own Apple releases particularly entertaining: their willingness to go to bat for totally uncommercial ideas. George managed to get the Radha Krishna Temple on ""Top of the Pops""
column4: released a single by the Cajun band the Sundown Playboys just because he liked it
column5: and made a nifty album with then-forgotten American soul singer Doris Troy (represented here by the single ""Ain't That Cute""). Paul played bass on the debut single by then-unknown folk singer James Taylor. John Lennon (and Yoko Ono) wrote a benefit single for the underground newspaper Oz
column6: ""God Save Us""
column7: released by Bill Elliot and the Elastic Oz Band (aka John
column8: Ringo
column9: and Klaus Voorman).

column1: There are a couple of outright duds here
column2: especially Brute Force's one-joke ""King of Fuh""-- which George had pressed up with an Apple label despite (or maybe because of) the fact that no store would dare to carry it in 1969-- and a cranky reggae cover of ""Give Peace a Chance"" by Hot Chocolate Band (who'd do much better once they dropped the last word from their name). Still
column3: this is a fascinating document of one of the most adventurous labels of its era
column4:
built around a group so creatively fertile that they could pass their own mojo on to almost everyone they worked with.
