column1: 0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15935/homepage_large.831179e9.jpg|My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy|4639.0|Kanye West|['Rap']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['Def Jam'
column3: Runaway
column4: peaks with a parade. Fireworks flash while red hoods march through a field. At the center of the spectacle is a huge
column5: pale
column6: cartoonish rendering of Michael Jackson's head. My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy's gargantuan ""All of the Lights"" soundtracks the procession
column7: with Kanye pleading
column8: ""Something wrong
column9: I hold my head/ MJ gone
column10: our nigga dead."" The tribute marks another chapter in West's ongoing obsession with the King of Pop.

column1: West's discography contains innumerable references and allusions to Jackson. His first hit as a producer
column2: Jay-Z's ""Izzo (H.O.V.A.)""
column3: sampled the Jackson 5's ""I Want You Back"". For many
column4: his first memorable lines as a rapper came during 2003's ""Slow Jamz"": ""She got a light-skinned friend look like Michael Jackson/ Got a dark-skinned friend look like Michael Jackson."" And when West's recent interview with Matt Lauer on the ""Today"" show went awry
column5: he took to Twitter
column6: writing
column7: ""I wish Michael Jackson had twitter!!!!!! Maybe Mike could have explained how the media tried to set him up!!! It's all a fucking set up!!!!"" Like most everything else
column8: Kanye may exaggerate the kinship
column9: but it's real. And it's never more apparent than on Twisted Fantasy
column10: a blast of surreal pop excess that few artists are capable of creating
column11:
or even willing to attempt.

To be clear
column12: Kanye West is not Michael Jackson. As he told MTV last month
column13: ""I do have a goal in this lifetime to be the greatest artist of all time
column14: [but] that's very difficult being that I can't dance or sing."" He ended the thought with a laugh
column15: but you get the impression he's not kidding. Unlike Michael
column16: he's not interested in scrubbing away bits of himself-- his blackness
column17: his candidness-- to appease the masses. And while Jackson's own twisted fantasies of paranoia and betrayal eventually consumed him whole
column18: West is still aware of his illusions
column19: though that mindfulness becomes increasingly unmoored with each newspaper-splashing controversy. The balance is tenuous
column20: but right now it's working to his advantage. On Twisted Fantasy
column21: Kanye is crazy enough to truly believe he's the greatest out there. And
column22: about a decade into his career
column23:
the hardworking perfectionist has gained the talent on the mic and in the control room to make a startlingly strong case for just that.

Kanye's last album
column25: was heavy on the Auto-Tune and stark synths
column26: but relatively light on grandiose ideas. It was a necessary detour that expanded his emotional palette; a bloodletting after a harsh breakup and the passing of his mother that manifests itself in Twisted Fantasy's harshest lows. But musically
column27: the new album largely continues where 2007's Graduation left off in its maximalist hip-hop bent
column28: with flashes of The College Dropout's comfort-food sampling and Late Registration's baroque instrumentation weaved in seamlessly. As a result
column29: the record comes off like a culmination and an instant greatest hits
column30: the ultimate realization of his strongest talents and divisive public persona. And since the nerd-superstar rap archetype he popularized has now become commonplace
column31: he leaves it in the dust
column32: taking his style and drama to previously uncharted locales
column33:
far away from typical civilization.

He's got a lot on his mind
column34: too. After exiling himself for months following last year's infamous Taylor Swift stage bomb
column35: the rapper made some of his first comeback appearances at the headquarters of Facebook and Twitter in late July. Videos of West standing on a table in tailored GQ duds while gesticulating through new rhymes (sans musical accompaniment) quickly made the rounds. The Silicon Valley visits seemed like a stunt
column36: but they were prophetic. Forever an over-sharer
column37: Kanye was looking for an outlet for his latest mirror-born musings. He found that platform with Twitter
column38: and proceeded to dictate his own narrative in 140 character hits. Whether showing off exotic purchases
column42:
instant-gratification platform he'd always wanted.

Juiced on the direct connection
column43: he began releasing weekly songs for free online
column44: the generosity of which would be moot if the songs didn't deliver. But they did
column46: eventually building up the same type of superstar goodwill Radiohead pulled off with their pay-what-you-want In Rainbows release plan and Lil Wayne's free mixtape barrage leading up to 2008's Tha Carter III. So while Kanye can't sing or dance like Michael
column47: he's making meaningful connections in a fresh
column48:
oftentimes (ahem) naked way. ""When I used to finish an album I would be so excited for my mom to hear the final - final!"" he wrote on November 11. ""The final - final is what we used to call the... completed album with all the skits!!! I made songs to please one person... MY MOM!!! I would think... would my my Mom like this song!""

I'm not sure which song he's talking about. Because
column50: West seemingly decided to make My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy less mom-friendly and more of a hedonistic exploration into a rich and famous American id. At Facebook
column51: he rapped the first verse of what would become album closer ""Lost in the World""
column52: at one point changing Michael Jackson's ""Wanna Be Startin' Something"" refrain to
column54: referring to his late mother. The familial allusion was left off the album. Another Facebook tune-- a brutally oedipal account called ""Mama's Boyfriend""-- was also deleted
column55: along with the vintage-Kanye-sounding ""See Me Now"". Such exclusions speak to the album's sharp focus-- to move everything forward while constantly tipping on the brink of frantic instability.

column1: This isn't the same resourceful prodigy who made The College Dropout or even the wounded soul behind 808s and Heartbreak. Instead
column2: Kanye's Twisted Fantasy incarnation cherry-picks little things from his previous work and blows them up into something less than sane. The expansive
column3: all-encompassing nature of the album is borne out in its staggering guest list which includes mentors Jay-Z
column4: RZA
column5: and No ID
column6: along with new charges like Nicki Minaj
column7: Rick Ross
column8: Kid Cudi
column9: and Bon Iver's Justin Vernon. The inclusion of Minaj (who contributes the schizoid verse of her life on ""Monster"")
column10: Ross (a guy known for making up his own reality as he goes)
column11: and Cudi (who's probably even more wildly self-destructive than Kanye) especially adds to the hallucinatory tone. By the time Chris Rock shows up to provide comic relief during one of the album's bleakest moments
column12: it begins to feel as if Kanye is stage-managing his own award show with enough starpower
column13: shock
column14: and dynamism to flatten the Grammys
column15: the VMAs
column16: and the rest all at once.

column1: Over the past few months
column2: Kanye has intermittently tried to flush away his rep as a boorish egoist in interviews and on Twitter
column3: which is
column4: fortunately
column5: impossible. Because without his exploding self-worth-- itself a cyclical reaction to the self-doubt so much of his music explores-- there would be no Twisted Fantasy. ""Every superhero needs his theme music
column6: he says on ""POWER""
column7: and though he's far from the virtuous paragons of comic book lore
column8: he's no less complex. In his public life
column9: he exhibits vulnerability and invincibility in equal measure
column10: but he's just as apt at villainy-- especially here.

column1: With ""Runaway""
column2: he rousingly highlights his own douchebaggery
column3: turning it into a rallying cry for all humanity. Like many of his greatest songs
column4: it's funny
column5: sad
column6: and perversely relatable. And while the royal horns and martial drums of ""All of the Lights"" make it sound like the ideal outlet for the most over-the-top boasts imaginable
column7: West instead inhabits the role of an abusive deadbeat desperate to make good on a million blown promises. ""Hell of a Life"" attempts to bend its central credo-- ""no more drugs for me
column8: pussy and religion is all I need""-- into a noble pursuit. As a woofer-mulching synth line lurks
column9: Kanye justifies his dreams of not sleeping with but marrying a porn star
column10: peaking with the combative taunt
column11: ""How can you say they live they life wrong/ When you never fuck with the lights on."" Inspired by his two-year relationship with salacious model Amber Rose
column12: the song blurs the line between fantasy and reality
column13: sex and romance
column14: love and religion
column15: until no lines exist at all. It's a zonked nirvana with demons underneath; a fragile state that can't help but break apart on the very next song.

column1: The haunted
column2: Aphex Twin-sampling ""Blame Game"" bottoms out with a verse in which Kanye's voice is sped up
column3: slowed down and stretched out. The effect is almost psychotic
column4: suggesting three or four inner monologues fighting over smashed emotions. It's one of many moments on the record where West manipulates his vocals. Whether funneling some of his best-ever rhymes through a tinny
column5: Strokes-like filter on ""Gorgeous"" or making himself wail like a dying cyborg in the final minutes of ""Runaway""
column6: he uses studio wizardry to draw out his multitudes. Tellingly
column7: though
column8: he doesn't get the last word on the album. That distinction goes to the sobering tones of Gil Scott-Heron's 1970 spoken-word piece ""Comment #1""
column9: a stark take on the American fable. ""All I want is a good home and a wife and children and some food to feed them every night
column10: says Scott-Heron
column11: bringing the fantasy to a close.

column1: On ""POWER""
column2: Kanye raps
column3: ""My childlike creativity
column4: purity
column5: and honesty is honestly being crowded by these grown thoughts/ Reality is catching up with me
column6: taking my inner child
column7: I'm fighting for custody."" The lines nail another commonality between the rapper and his hero. Like Michael
column8: Kanye's behavior-- from the poorly planned outbursts to the musical brilliance-- is wide-eyed in a way that most 33 year olds have long left behind. That naivety is routinely battered on Twisted Fantasy
column9: yet it survives
column10: better for the wear. With his music and persona both marked by a flawed honesty
column11: Kanye's man-myth dichotomy is at once modern and truly classic. ""I can't be everybody's hero and villain
column12: savior and sinner
column13: Christian and anti Christ!"" he wrote earlier this month. That may be true
column14:
but he's more willing than anyone else to try.

column2:

Unlike their Bristol contemporaries-- Tricky with a steady stream of new mediocre albums; Portishead with a long
column3: long layoff that led to an unexpected and masterful reinvention-- Massive Attack have spent the past 15 years working in brief
column4: intermittent bursts of productivity. Five years separated Mezzanine from 100th Window
column5: and then another seven elapsed before this year's Heligoland. They filled the gaps with soundtrack work
column6: but when it comes to Massive Attack the pop group
column7: their albums are still infrequent enough to be sold as events
column8: built up by singles featuring remixes by artists that let the band add the flavor of the current moment
column9: whether that's micro-house circa 100th Window or spacey electronic disco circa now.

column1: The problem is that
column2: as events
column3: these albums have fallen flat.  The remixes on the singles are usually more exciting
column4: and certainly fresher
column5: than the music Massive themselves have released in the 21st century. The band seems stuck in a holding pattern-- not quite as glibly self-parodic as Tricky but afraid to fully make themselves over like Portishead-- that's led to albums that sound just enough like Massive's classics not to feel totally burned and not quite different enough to justify listening to them over Protection. The sense of adventure is gone
column6: the feeling that Massive not only could but must take their own music somewhere new. Best leave it to the younger
column7: less resigned-to-their-sound artists to fill that feeling back in
column8: as with the remix EP that added some unexpected angles to Heligoland earlier this year.

column1: The Atlas Air EP doesn't feel quite as essential as that
column2: but then the shtick-like ""Massive-style"" dread of Heligoland was often so bland that any little spark of invention felt like an improvement. Though there's a charity slant to this EP
column3: it still feels like something snuck out near the end of the year to extend the album's life a bit. Even if the intentions were that crass
column4: and I'm not saying they are
column5: these remixes improve on the original ""Atlas Air""
column6: which pulsed along soporifically on a slow-mo disco beat so by-the-numbers it was almost shameful. Tim Goldsworthy's rework turns it into truly cosmic dance music and Jneiro Jarel's makeover drops the tempo into a FlyLo/Brainfeeder trip-hop lurch
column7: both filling in the clichéd ""dark"" negative space of the original with bright waves of almost kraut-ish synth dissonance. They're actually eerie but also lovely
column8: where the original felt like it was trying for both but not very hard.

column1: In all cases
column2: the remixers seem to have a better grasp on giving shape and drama to tracks via electronic texture than their benefactors do these days. That's doubly a shame considering Massive were once masters at the very same thing; even their instrumentals were memorable
column3: thick and richly detailed and gorgeously skirting the line between dreamy and abrasive. None of the remixes on Atlas Air is mind-blowing-- they're passable-to-good by the standards the producers have set-- but they're definite improvements on the bare-bones original. Which probably proves little but how sadly comfortable Massive are now with just getting by
column4:
with letting their followers do the heavy lifting.

Everything you need to know about March to the Sea comes in its first 10 seconds-- and that's not a criticism. Sledgehammer drums
column3: cavernous bass
column4: strangled guitar
column5: and caged-animal cries fire up opener ""Teaching to Suffer""
column6: then spend the next 24 grueling minutes wrestling for sonic space. Three albums in
column7: AIDS Wolf's monastic commitment to brutal prog-punk and strident no wave has hardened their music from a rough lump of coal into a jagged diamond. In fact it's gotten so hard that few surprises can permeate it
column8: but that shouldn't matter much to anyone already on their side.

column1: Such unrelenting devotion gives the Montreal group a lot in common with the also-bludgeoning
column2: also-questionably-named Brooklyn three-piece Child Abuse. Both rely on non-stop effort and sonic demolition that steamrolls over indecision or subtlety. But I'll give a slight edge to AIDS Wolf because they've immersed themselves more completely into the form
column3: like method actors sunk so far into roles that their craft is hard to detect. Prog-punk can often come off like an exercise-- musical weight-lifting that's more about dogmatic execution than listener engagement-- but here it sounds more inspired than clinical
column4: less a stylistic choice than a calling.

column1: Still
column2: with their hammering beats and workman-like repetitions
column3: AIDS Wolf can sound more like lumberjacks hacking at trees than musicians playing songs. What saves March to the Sea from being just a workout-- and distinguishes it from forefathers like Flying Luttenbachers (whose Weasel Walter mastered the album)-- is Chloe Lum's singing. A desperate scream mixed with a lunatic warble
column4: her style could easily sound contrived. But she infuses it with a convincing humanity
column5: much in the way Lydia Lunch fuses snotty put-on with harrowing emotion
column6: or how John Brannon makes atonal howls feel melodic. Which is not to say Lum sounds like either of those singers. Her voice is unique
column7: and at points-- like when she moans over Alex Moskos' neck-running riffs on ""Wet Winds""-- she turns lonely dismay into something oddly universal.

column1: That track
column2: like most of March to the Sea
column3: is a sprint. But the album closes with a marathon-- a 10-minute cover of Throbbing Gristle's ""Very Friendly"". You might expect a change of pace here
column4: but AIDS Wolf turn the original's detached séance into a microcosm of the rest of the album. Apparently anything fed into their sonic blender comes out as the same grisly stew. For lots of groups that would be a shortcoming
column5:
but with AIDS Wolf the words ""monolithic"" and ""powerful"" are two sides of a coin-- one that they're getting better at endlessly flipping.

"|14876.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14876-march-to-the-sea/|6.9|Marc Masters

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15876/homepage_large.4bfb68d4.jpg|I Love Funky|29276.0|Supa D & DJ MA1|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rinse FM']|2010-11-22 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:50.830248|"

The appeal of UK funky resides less in any particular quality or signature sound than in what it requires of a listener's general approach to music. The charms of the genre coalesce once you adjust your frame of reference and recognize the value of its precarious yet carefree balancing act. Skeptics are frustrated by funky because it foils any attempt to define its development: Its aggressively percussive rhythmic experimentation never fully severs its ties with the comforting familiarity of house
column2: and its MCs and divas refuse to entirely get out of the way and let the music do the work. They're also unwilling to replace their enthusiastic amateurism with the studied professionalism of the R&B and rap whose blueprint they deface
column3: leaving funky hesitant to join the ranks of grown-up genres.

column1: But this immaturity is the music's greatest strength
column2: placing it in a frozen moment before a series of ruinously limiting choices it might otherwise be required to make. So it sits between macho aggression and brazen seduction
column3: between the accomplished and the gratifyingly disposable
column4: between the firmly established provinces of the many genres (house
column5: grime
column6: dancehall
column7: soca
column8: broken beat
column9: R&B) it floats amongst and apart from. It's in keeping with this constant state of musical pre-pubescence that funky's appeals are shallowest on a track-by-track basis. Its magic emerges properly only in the context of the club or radio set
column10: where the dueling interplay between one syncopated rhythm and the next
column11: mediated through the MC
column12: acts like two pens tracing a complex double-spirogram around the absent centre of the house groove
column13: in a spontaneous balance of intricacy and symmetry.

column1: To date
column2: official mix compilations have failed fully to capture this vibe
column3: in part due to the absence of MCs
column4: but more generally by lacking the vibrant spontaneity that is so large a part of funky's appeal. Rinse's hedge-betting double-disc scene overview
column5: I Love Funky
column6: mixed by scene stalwarts Supa D and DJ MA1
column7: certainly is no exception. But in its mostly successful rendering of funky's rhythmic adventurousness and stylistic range
column8: it remains 2010's next best thing for curious listeners.

column1: DJ MA1's disc relies heavily on over-compiled tracks from several years ago
column2: and overall gives the impression of funky as little more than a local variant of an international house sound. The inclusion of funky's archetypal ""hard"" grime-influenced tune
column3: Lil Silva's similarly aged ""Seasons""
column4: is something of a too-blunt protest to the contrary. In his productions and radio sets
column5: MA1 often seems disappointed that funky ever shifted away from its original polite adherence to the house template
column6: and this air of future-fear hangs heavily over the mix
column7: notwithstanding the high standard of most of the individual tracks. A shame
column8: but if nothing else it provides a handy overview for the uninitiated.

column1: By contrast
column2: Supa D's strong (albeit predictable) track selection on his disc covers a satisfyingly broad and reasonably contemporary range of sounds and approaches. It moves from hi-tech syncopated pop (Funkystepz's ""For U"") to aggressive steroid-assisted dancehall (Geeneus and Ms. Dynamite's tense ""Get Low"") to stark
column3: disorienting percussive works (DJ Naughty's ""Rhythm Dance""). Much of the fun lies in the journey from one state to the next
column4: especially the regrettably brief periods in which the grooves coincide in messy
column5: multi-tentacle clashes.

column1: Funky's immaturity isn't facile: duo Ill Blu in particular have spent the last two years positioning themselves as perhaps the most expansive
column2: forward-thinking producers currently operating in dance-pop. On their remix of Shystie's ""Pull It""
column3: the bittersweet anthemism of the synth-horn and harpsichord arrangement belies a furious groove that seems to stagger and stumble like a galloping animal overcome by its own velocity. Still
column4: the disc's most vibe-laden moment is also its simplest
column5: with the Devine Collective's Mad One offering a pared down statement of funky's core principles on ""Housegirls Part 1""
column6: barely more than a ratatat snare pattern
column7: a ceaseless bass throb
column8: and a delightful time-stretched ragga vocal ripped straight from jungle. In its gradual
column9: relentless build of sensual friction from the sparest elements
column10: it captures funky's appeal at its most elusive yet hard-hitting
column11: not just an anthem but a frame of reference
column12:
a way of life.

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15967/homepage_large.25b6728f.jpg|Coals to Newcastle|3226.0|Orange Juice|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Domino']|2010-11-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:53.000504|"

By the time Orange Juice released an album-- 1982's You Can't Hide Your Love Forever-- their early 45s were already the stuff of frustrating legend. Their first home
column2: Postcard Records
column3: had come and gone and left the band in the unfortunate position of having a stellar reputation based on material few could now hear. Everything they subsequently did was judged against those initial releases-- four lost singles which defined lovelorn
column4: literate indie pop. Combined with their sputtering commercial fortunes
column5: it gave Orange Juice an air of underachievement. Come the CD age and those first blasts of inspiration were well served-- compiled and recompiled
column6: most recently on 2005's The Glasgow School. For most of the last decade it's been the group's later career that's fallen into shadow.

column1: This is a band long defined by unavailability. But no more: New box set Coals to Newcastle isn't just a lavish retrospective
column2: it's the complete Orange Juice. More complete than complete
column3: in fact: As well as The Glasgow School
column4: a radio sessions CD
column5: and a DVD
column6: each of the group's four albums gets an expanded disc to itself
column7: which means the six-song Texas Fever is saddled with barely different alternate mixes. But most of the wealth of extra material is worth a play-- Orange Juice were never shy of throwing experiments onto B-sides
column8: and tracks like ""Tongues Begin to Wag"" are droll sketches of their working process. The most treasurable rarity here
column9: from a 1981 John Peel session
column10: is ""Blokes On 45""
column11: a medley of those early singles set to a faux-disco backbeat and a vision of proto-indie as an oldies' circuit variety turn.

column1: That was the essence of Orange Juice: They were always self-conscious
column2: and they were usually very funny. The former came with the post-punk territory-- at the end of the box set there's a radio interview where Edwyn Collins talks about being ""into"" something then chastises himself for sounding like a hippie. The latter was more unusual
column3: but wit and self-deprecation are what links the jangle and rush of their first releases with the louche pop-soul precision of their final ones. That and Collins' immediately recognisable voice-- a plummy
column4: permanently amused croon.

column1: Collins was very cautious of pigeonholing-- he'd emerged talking about fusing pop and soul and then ended up sitting on the sidelines while the s-word became the era's most overused. He resisted the idea that Orange Juice's career was a steady progression towards slickness. But that's unavoidably what it sounds like. You Can't Hide and second album Rip It Up are full of spashy
column2: amateurish collisions of pop
column3: funk
column4: indie
column5: and latterly African sounds which somehow resolve into joy. But by the final
column6: self-titled LP there's a muscle and poise on tracks like ""What Presence?!"" and ""Salmon Fishing in New York"" that's completely absent from the band's earlier work.

column1: Collins' persona
column2: and his love of melody and language
column3: is what makes the contrast seem like a complement
column4: not a trade-off. His killer lines are best discovered for yourself
column5: but a common thread is his talent for picking up on the odd little idioms of everyday speech: ""Here's some mud in your pretty eye
column6: ""Poor old soul."" It makes the songs at once more conversational and more articifial: At the end of ""Tenterhook""
column7: his most smouldering song
column8: he sings ""you tell me don't make any bones about it
column9: and in the slow-burning context it sounds deliciously odd and curiously moving.

column1: Coals to Newcastle is studded with such moments-- the real test of the indie soulboy was how they managed at ballads
column2: and like Scritti Politti's Green Gartside
column3: Collins passed it. The slow numbers help to offset the non-stop wryness
column4: but the indended audience for this box wouldn't have a problem with it in the first place. This isn't an introduction: If you're not sure about Orange Juice
column5: pick up a compilation first. If you've acquired the taste
column6: you'll adore this
column7:
and welcome the opportunity to rediscover the group's less influential but often delightful latter days.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15966/homepage_large.93f6da21.jpg|Infected EP|539.0|The Bug|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Ninja Tune']|2010-11-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:54.998400|"

Both as the Bug and King Midas Sound
column2: UK producer Kevin Martin has been heavily invested in dubstep's Jamaican roots. The genre of course takes inspiration from dub and dancehall
column3: but Martin highlights this more than his contemporaries
column4: putting reggae elements up against low-end grime and the echoes of desolate urban soundscapes. His still-thrilling London Zoo from 2008 is the best example of this fusion and one of the defining LPs of dubstep's ascendancy. It's been a while since we've heard Martin in Bug form
column5: though
column6: and the genre has changed drastically since
column7: splintering off into dozens of microgenres and regionally focused styles.

column1: To reintroduce the project
column2: Martin presents Infected
column3: a double 12"" (basically an EP) that features two new cuts and two pretty high-profile remixes. The EP is intended as a bridge between London Zoo and his next full-length
column4: which is being described as a ""dub battle"" between him and producer Adrian Sherwood
column5: who's known for working with Lee ""Scratch"" Perry and early industrial acts like Cabaret Voltaire and Ministry. The two new songs here are both solid. ""Catch a Fire""
column6: which features King Midas contributor Hitomi
column7: is nice and woozy but essentially an extension of the blown-out downtempo shuffle already explored on KMS' Waiting for You.

column1: ""Tune In""
column2: though
column3: a collaboration with ragga-leaning rapper Roots Manuva
column4: is a totally natural fit. The two are clearly kindred spirits
column5: and Manuva's lithe toasting provides just the right contrast to Martin's grinding synth work. For the remixes
column6: Martin makes some intriguing picks. Impressed by their epic 12-hour podcast earlier this year
column7: he brought in out-techno OGs Autechre to redo ""Skeng"". A cool choice
column8: but their brand of techy minimalism kind of saps the power out of the original. Hyperdub-affiliated newcomer Scratcha DVA
column9: who turned heads with his wild ""Natty/Ganja"" 12""
column10: gives ""Poison Dart"" a UK funky overhaul
column11: adding in the quick stabs of hollow bass that are inherent to the genre.

column1: Both of these remixes work more as interesting genre overlaps than dancefloor jams
column2: and as for the latter
column3: the jury's still out on whether funky will ever make a significant impact stateside. (If the Fives' should-be megahit ""It's What You Do"" doesn't do it
column4: it kind of seems like nothing will.) It's also tough to gauge the impact of a release this short-- if anything it serves as a good reminder of the Bug's presence and reason to keep eyes on his next big release. These original tracks and reworks do suggest
column5: though
column6: that Martin is still very deep into his own thing. In dubstep
column7: where the trend cycle produces so much stylistic crossover
column8:
that's a very valuable characteristic.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15954/homepage_large.03dc0a3b.jpg|Da Trak Genious|29322.0|DJ Nate|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Planet Mu']|2010-11-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:55.819713|"

Juke has been bubbling up in the Chicago area for the better part of the past decade
column2: but its roots are deeper in the past. The combination of repetitious pop and hip-hop samples
column3: jackhammering polyrhythmic beats
column4: and faster-than-fast BPMs owes something to Miami bass and ghetto house
column5: which emerged in Chicago and Detroit in the early 1990s. The accompanying dance is derived from jit
column6: which itself owes debts to both traditional African dancing and the jitterbug. The legacy is obscure
column7: but it's there.

column1: Juke is starting to establish roots in the present
column2: too. Salem frequently feature thudding footwork figures in their tracks
column3: as does London's label-of-the-moment Night Slugs
column4: who just released Girl Unit's footwork-indebted single ""Wut"". UK dubstep artist Addison Groove offered a sparser
column5: cleaner take on the sound with his ""Footcrab"" single-- and
column6: hell
column7: even the relentless slam of Kanye West's ""All of the Lights"" carries a trace of footwork's genetics.

column1: The growing fascination with footwork's compositional tics has also brought an equal interest in its raw materials
column2: which is where UK electronic label Planet Mu comes in. In the past few months
column3: they've put out a scene-spanning footwork compilation
column4: Bangs and Works
column5: as well as full-lengths from 20-year-old rising talent DJ Nate and comparative veteran DJ Roc
column6: Da Trak Genious and The Crack Capone
column7: respectively. Despite their difference in age
column8: Nate and Roc's full-lengths share a few similarities: Both excel when working in juke's sonic braggadocio (Nate's ""Footwurk Homicide""
column9: Roc's ""They Can't Fuck Wit Me"") and downtempo mood-setters (Roc's mesmerizing rework of Robin Thicke's ""Lost Without U""). Both records are of a slightly patience-testing length (Da Trak Genious is a psychosis-inducing 70 minutes long). And
column10: in a quality that applies to the scene as a whole
column11: the tracks succeed in proportion to the quality of their samples.

column1: Roc's The Crack Capone is the more enjoyable full-length. Roc favors cohesive musicality above all else
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
an attribute that ties into his background in the more colorful Chicago juke sound. The ""Crack"" in the album title refers not to the drug but to Roc's production style
column2: which favors tightly edited rhythms and snapping track structures. That sense of tightness makes The Crack Capone a frequently invigorating
column3: accessible listen
column4: whether taking on percolating forms of UK bass (album closer ""Break it Down"") or vibrant blasts of melody (the one-two punch of the Willie Hutch-sampling ""Get Buck Jones"" and ""Gun Smoke"").

column1: If Roc is fixated primarily on melody
column2: then Nate's focus is more texture-based. Da Trak Genious is a tough front-to-back listen
column3: and not just because it's so damn long; many of the tracks turn their pop-fixated samples into abstractions
column4: repeating figures endlessly until they become hypnotically broken mantras. The result can be almost psychedelic at times; when he lets the source material breathe a little
column5: as on the Dreamgirls-biting ""You're Gonna Luv Me"" or the Lil Wayne-sampling ""Let Da Beat Build""
column6: the results are more immediate but ultimately less interesting. Still
column7: it's heartening that Nate
column8: Roc
column9: and other artists working in the genre don't seem overly invested in any one template
column10:
and it'll be interesting to see where the scene's talents take their sound next.

"|14868.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14868-da-trak-genious-the-crack-capone/|7.2|Larry Fitzmaurice

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15947/homepage_large.a01be188.jpg|Glass Eights|29314.0|John Roberts|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dial']|2010-11-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:56.371619|"

John Roberts isn't mysterious so much as inconspicuous. The Berlin-based
column2: Ohio-born producer would be the great young hope of any scene that didn't chew through great young hopes like goldfish crackers. So instead
column3: after four 12""'s and on the heels of his first full-length album
column4: he's the kid with the no-name name who's really good at deep house.

column1: ""Good at deep house"" and not ""techno wunderkind"" because
column2: well
column3: Roberts' skills often seem less like those of a musician than those of an athlete-- a disciplined participant playing a varying but finite game. What was notable about Roberts' early 12""'s was not their singularity or adherence to a breaking style
column4: but their studied execution. Roberts wasn't just dropping house music layups like piano chords and dubby textures; he was performing all manner of subtle and difficult moves
column5: like budding noir atmosphere
column6: pitch-shifted vocals-as-percussion
column7: tension-massing tweaks. Roberts' productions are spellbindingly clear
column8: crystal in their intent and focus.

column1: There is something
column2: then
column3: almost inevitable about Glass Eights
column4: Roberts' debut album for his Dial records. It opens with a shattered piano note and a pattering drum; one minute later
column5: when a tiny vocal sample and electric keyboards drop ""Lesser"" into a well-paced groove
column6: Roberts provides that rare moment in which both bobbing your head and shrugging your shoulders are appropriate reactions.  Simultaneously: ""This is excellent
column7: and
column8: ""We knew he could do this."" Roberts chose to emphasize his compositional skills on Glass Eights. Pianos
column9: violins
column10: and lithe beats rule the tracks
column11: which never seem to stir with overeager rhythms or combust into white noise. There are times when the whole can seem less than the sum of its parts. ""Porcelain"" features bright
column12: ordered drum patterns
column13: a funny little modular synth melody
column14: and an out-of-nowhere steel drum interlude; the total is passable techno. Six minutes of it.

column1: Still
column2: there are only a handful of producers capable of Glass Eights. Sometimes Roberts seems like he's trying to stimulate his tracks solely via the overtones of his chords; call it harmonic house. On cuts like ""Pruned"" and ""Ever or Not"" he searches for the midway point between Carl Craig and Philip Glass
column3: the variety provided by listening to determine on which side he errs. Elsewhere he delights in dispensing with one of deep house's go-to signifers-- ""warm""-- and sends his tracks out to shiver until they seem austere (""Interlude [Telephone]"" and ""Navy Blue"").

column1:
Dance music enthusiasts are really good at asking one question (""Can [hot artist X] possibly keep this up?!"") but predictably poor at asking another: ""What will it mean if he does?"" Glass Eights shyly defers by focusing on a slightly more musically nuanced type of electronic music than Roberts' previous work. It is impossible to call a failure and equally difficult to pinpoint its vigor.

0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15956/homepage_large.af4b5140.jpg|The Weight's on the Wheels|3619.0|The Russian Futurists|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Upper Class']|2010-11-19 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:56.921483|"

Over the course of three albums
column2: the Russian Futurists' Matthew Adam Hart established a specific and successful indie pop template. Virtually every song wedded woozy or bouncy maximalist synth lines to bashy
column3: blown-out drumbeats. Within this bargain-store pomp
column4: Hart would paradoxically bury his most painstaking and precise creations
column5: his lyrics
column6: which were filled with enough complex and internal rhymes to make Cole Porter proud.

column1: You'd be forgiven for wishing that Hart would at least slightly broaden his scope
column2: but then again his albums each take up little more than 30 minutes-- long enough to enjoy his distinctive approach without growing sick of its rigidity. Perhaps he also thought a nice long break between Russian Futurists full-lengths would engender goodwill as well
column3: and so after five years without a proper studio effort
column4: Hart returns with The Weight's on the Wheels. And... not a whole lot has changed. It's hard to fault Hart
column5: as Wheels is another thoroughly pleasurable album that proves his skills as a popsmith haven't rusted.

column1: Though it doesn't affect the quality of the songs
column2: there is one major difference between this Russian Futurists record and preceding releases: Hart has deigned to push his vocals much further up in the mix this time around
column3: so you don't need a lyric sheet to make out his cleverly knotty
column4: densely alliterative rhymes. As always
column5: the dominant subject is romantic struggle and dissatisfaction
column6: and Hart maintains his tendency to prize sound over sense in a way that might be irritating if he weren't so damn good at it. ""Let's serve this nervousness on a plate/ Let's curb our words for impervious debates
column7: goes an entirely representative couplet. That's not to say Hart can't be relatably affecting-- ""Golden Years"" finds him musing
column8: ""Drank my way through my twenties... Slept my way through my thirties
column9: while ""To Be Honest""

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
hinges on the slippery
column2: shifting meanings of the refrain
column3: ""I don't even know what it's like/ To be honest.""

column1: Hart does manage to tweak his tried-and-true formula
column2: albeit slightly
column3: to help keep things interesting. ""One Night
column4: One Kiss""
column5: a duet with Heavy Blinkers vocalist Ruth Minnikin
column6: treats sex with a frankness and joy that's always welcome in indie's less-than-lubricious environs. Meanwhile
column7: the back-to-back pair ""Register My Firearms? No Way!"" and ""100 Shopping Days 'Til Christmas"" both subtly inject R&B touches
column8: the former by way of a sample
column9: the latter with a hook reminiscent of the Junior Boys. Wheels starts to lose a bit of steam toward its end
column10: but as with previous Russian Futurists albums
column11:
it's over well before Hart's shtick turns monotonous.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15959/homepage_large.c2603a3f.jpg|Broken Dreams Club EP|1826.0|Girls|['Rock']|1.0|0.0|0.0|['True Panther']|2010-11-18 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:36:58.373428|"

Just three weeks ago
column2: when Girls announced the release of Broken Dreams Club
column3: they also shared a sprawling
column4: handwritten note penned by frontman Christopher Owens. On stationery flipped upside down
column5: Owens scribbled enthusiastically that this EP was their (timely) way of giving thanks to listeners who've showered the San Francisco duo with love and support since Album
column6: their lemons-to-lemonade debut
column7: which arrived last September. While insisting that his band's latest isn't the sound of them ""all grown up
column8: he described the six songs enclosed as a ""LETTER OF INTENT
column9: a ""SNAPSHOT OF THE HORIZON
column10: and a ""step up"" from its stunning predecessor.

column1: Girls have grown a lot in the past year. All that time on the road together has provided them with ample opportunity to develop into a tight
column2: fire-breathing band. That's exactly how they sound here: serious and totally devoted to their craft
column3: despite their image as drug-addled scabs. Album's handmade production values were often overlooked-- bloodshot at just the right moments
column4: polished thoughtfully in others
column5: haunting at every turn. But this time out
column6: bassist/producer Chet ""JR"" White really goes for it
column7: letting every flourish and lick sing without sacrificing any of the strung out
column8: open-armed spirit with which he and Owens take to updating American rock'n'roll standards. Whether it's the whammy bar ripples on its title track
column9: the hot flare of horns in the opener
column10: or even the stereo panning on ""Heartbreaker""
column11: White's work here frames and accentuates the curves of these songs in ways that elevate them all. Those
column12: too
column13: continue to devastate.

column1: We know from interviews and reviews alike that Owens' back story is big enough to swallow just about any young band. But because of the connective strength of his songwriting
column2: it never did. Singles like ""Lust for Life"" and ""Hellhole Ratrace"" transcended and outlasted that initial ruckus: The celebration Owens spun from the sadness in them was something that could be shared
column3: even if his past could put him at an almost alien distance. He has a natural command of his hooks and confessionals
column4: a gift that's only acquired more compelling shades with time. Take the clarity in his promise of ""rock'n'roll
column5: out of control"" on ""Substance"" as just one example
column6: or seconds later
column7: as he coolly announces a guitar solo just before it's set loose. They're simple enough
column8: but both jump right off the recording.  Elsewhere
column9: lines like those of the aforementioned title track still cut straight to marrow. Over lonesome chords and a few distant strips of pedal steel
column10: Owens hangs his head
column11: ""I know you feel like I did
column12: too/ And even though I'm close to you/ I can't be what you need/ Because
column13: you're just as lost as me."" As a frontman
column14: Owens has discovered a swagger that matches the deep reserves of melancholy in his voice.

column1: This is still undeniably sad
column2: unsettling music. On flirty opener ""Thee Oh So Protective One""
column3: Owens serenades the insecurities of a teenage girl. ""He'll never know about the times that you cried in your bedroom
column4: he croons. ""About the times that you cried in your classroom/ About your mother or your father or the way you got your broken heart."" It's one of several hearts breaking here
column5: though ""Heartbreaker"" showcases the improvement in songwriting best
column6: Owens and White continuing to take the love song template they adore and skew it to their liking. Everything just clicks: its simple
column7: elegant construction
column8: its velvety feel
column9: the way its hopelessly lonesome vocal hook washes over Owens' friendly chord progression. Girls may be only a few releases deep
column10: but those chords sound like theirs alone.

column1: And yet
column2: as much as Broken Dreams Club feels like an improvement upon Album both in songwriting and production
column3: this release is clearly about looking forward. The psychedelic haze of ""Carolina"" is the closest they've come to sonically uncapping the pills they've been known to romanticize. It's a wild hybrid of a song that's intent on stretching out
column4: its opening layer of evil
column5: crying guitar taking on heaps of gauze before ultimately vaulting into a rowdy
column6: bar-band outro at about the six-and-a-half minute mark. In that same letter that promised growth and focus
column7: Owens also said something quite striking in thanks. ""All of us have something to say and give and this is what happens when we show a little interest and support in others."" If Broken Dreams Club is indeed an honest glimpse of what's ahead
column8:
it sounds as though Girls have much more to give.

Kanye West has repeatedly called kiD CuDi his ""favorite living artist"" (""and not just cause he's on my label
column3: he assured us on Twitter). CyHi Da Prince excepted
column4: West's taste in musicians is usually sound
column5: and CuDi is talented. His taste for forlorn melody
column6: chilly electronics
column7: and empty space basically brought 808s and Heartbreak into existence
column8: and his fingerprints are visible all over Kanye's upcoming My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy. As a member of Kanye's revolving door of creative inspiration
column9: he has proven himself to be indispensable.

column1: As a solo artist
column2: well... his second full-length
column3: Man on the Moon II: The Legend of Mr. Rager manages to render the jury still out. His 2009 debut
column4: Man on the Moon: The End of the Day
column5: was a modest commercial success but a mortifying creative face-plant
column6: a compilation of the most two-dimensional art-school-kid clichés (I'm sad
column7: I'm stoned
column8: I'm deep) imaginable
column9: over unrelievedly monotonous electro tracks. It was hard to find a more self-satisfied and less likable pop record that year. Man on the Moon II
column10: the sequel
column11: is still a bumpy listen
column12: but it tweaks his formula enough to at least hint at the massive promise Kanye sees in him.

column1: First
column2: and most crucially
column3: he perks up the tempo a little. After Man on the Moon came out
column4: CuDi told MTV.com that his next album was ""gonna be the complete opposite of what Man on the Moon was. Man on the Moon was so serious. This one is gonna be more playful and fun. It's about having a good time."" It's not
column5: really
column6: unless he's referring to all his dead-eyed bragging about how fucked-up he's capable of getting. But the music is brighter: ""Erase Me"" is a chugging guitar-rock song with a big
column7: slick chorus that could have sat comfortably on late-90s alt-rock radio. (It also features a Kanye verse that ends with a ridiculous ""diarrhea"" pun.) On ""REVOFEV""
column8: he dispenses aw-shucks big-brother wisdom like
column9: ""Things might get tough/ No need to stress
column10: over a tumble of piano chords and acid-rock guitar.

column1: Even his trademark sadface stuff
column2: though
column3: is more fully realized. ""Don't Play This Song"" starts with a somber
column4: harmonically rich string quartet and adds a throbbing pulse and a wailing Mary J. Blige; the track's elements shift slowly and subtly
column5: giving the groove a fluid and hypnotic feel that Cudi echoes with his stuttering ""ra-ra-ra-ra-right"" delivery. CuDi's lyrics
column6: though
column7: still carry a wince-inducing ""Bill and Ted"" ring to them. The chorus of ""Don't Play This Song"" goes: ""Wanna know what I sound like when I'm not on drugs?/ Please
column8: please don't play this song
column9: which I would feel comfortable interpreting as pure comedy if he didn't say
column10: ""I love the dark
column11: maybe we can make it darker/ Give me a marker
column12: in dead earnest on ""Maniac""
column13: a song that gathers a St. Vincent sample
column14: CuDi
column15: and emo-rapper Cage in the same room for probably the first and last time.

column1: Thematically
column2: Mr. Rager is most compelling when it leaves behind moping alone in your room for moping while you're out on the town-- being a coked-up asshole. CuDi's blank
column3: artless affect makes a more interesting vehicle for these semi-poisonous sentiments: ""Hide the pain with some pussy and mimosas
column4:
he mutters on ""Wild'N Cuz I'm Young"". The only true biographical detail we get on Mr. Rager hints at his troubled family-- ""I wish I could tell my brother/ Something for motivation to get him out that gutter/ He's leaving behind a family and a mother"" (""Mojo So Dope"")-- and also provides a glimpse of what CuDi's music might sound like if he provided actual emotional content instead of just gesturing repeatedly towards it.

Syl Johnson is-- there's no other way to put it-- an also-ran. A very good singer
column3: a pretty good guitar player
column4: a fine songwriter
column5: a canny reader of the zeitgeist
column6: he was a fixture on the Chicago soul scene on and off for decades. He made the R&B charts 19 times over the years
column7: but never really broke through to a pop audience. His records are mostly out of print
column8: his big numbers all but forgotten-- although he did apparently make a killing from all the hip-hop records that sampled Morris Jennings' breakbeat and Minnie Riperton's giggle from his 1967 single ""Different Strokes"".

column1: So the Numero Group's comprehensive box set of Johnson's 1959-1971 material is a labor of love-- four CDs
column2: packaged with six LPs of the same material and an extensive booklet
column3: drawn from releases on half dozen or so labels and encompassing a bit of unreleased material
column4: too. This isn't even the full career survey its title implies; more than half of his 19 R&B hits happened after the period documented here
column5: the bulk of them on Hi Records
column6: where he was effectively the second-tier Al Green. (His only Top-10 R&B hit was a cover of Green's ""Take Me to the River"".) It's a tribute to a local guy who really made good only long after the fact.

column1: ""Something is holding me back""
column2: Johnson sang on one of his most potent songs. ""Is it because I'm black?"" Well
column3: of course-- and he addressed racism pretty directly on some of his 1969-1970 recordings. But that wasn't what was holding him back within the R&B context
column4: at least not directly. He spent most of the era covered here on tiny Chicago independent labels that didn't have any other big acts
column5: most famously Twilight
column6: aka Twinight
column7: in which he was a shareholder. A lot of his mid-60s material was indifferently recorded at best. He didn't have a consistent band on record the way most hitmakers of his era did
column8: although he did work with some good ones. (He recorded a handful of these songs in Memphis with the first-rate band who'd later back him up at Hi
column9: including the hit ""Dresses Too Short""
column10: whose attitude

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
is very much of its time: ""Just because I whistle at you/ You say that I'm doin' you wrong/ Why do you blame me
column2: baby?/ I didn't tell you to put it on."")

column1: The broader problem
column2: though
column3: was that he was a totally solid talent in an era of greatness
column4: a deft trendspotter in a period of nonstop innovation. He was a hard shouter
column5: but not quite as hard as Wilson Pickett or James Brown; he was funny
column6: but not as funny as Joe Tex
column7: whose ""Skinny Legs and All"" he answered with ""I'll Take Those Skinny Legs"". Despite the liner notes' questionable argument that 1970's Is It Because I'm Black was ""the first black concept album
column8: he wasn't a conceptualist-- he was a hit-chaser.

column1: And sometimes he got there: ""Come on Sock it to Me""
column2: ""Concrete Reservation""
column3: the Donny Hathaway-arranged ""One Way Ticket to Nowhere"". The market actually did lift up his best material. (The only really essential non-hit here is a long
column4: spark-spitting funk workout
column5: ""Right On""
column6: in which he shouts out the Pieces of Peace
column7: the best Chicago band he got to work with.) If you're looking for an introduction to Johnson's pre-Hi era
column8: the single-disc Chicago Twinight Soul is a lot more compact
column9: and hits almost all of the peaks. What's most interesting about Complete Mythology
column10: though
column11: is the distance between the best stuff and everything else-- the context that shows what it took for a hard-working
column12:
deeply independent-minded R&B singer to try to break through at a time when a hit could come from anywhere.

"|14822.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14822-complete-mythology/|6.8|Douglas Wolk

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15961/homepage_large.1acf0d2e.jpg|We Love|29324.0|We Love|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Bpitch Control']|2010-11-18 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:00.054973|"

We Love's debut album peaks early with a song called ""Ice Lips"". The title is very appropriate. The piece sounds frigid and remote
column2: with layers of grim synthesizer tones implying some impossibly dark
column3: endless frozen landscape. When the vocals come in
column4: they're warmly human and overtly sexy. The two members of the group
column5: Giorgia Angiuli and Piero Fragola
column6: alternate their parts-- he's breathy and intense
column7: she's assertive but serene. They never overlap
column8: but they sound as if they could be tangled together
column9: and face to face. The intimacy of their performance is exaggerated by its contrast with the chilly electronic tones of the track. If you can imagine Ladytron mimicking the sexual tension and minimalism of the xx
column10: you're more than halfway there. It's a very evocative and impressive song.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the rest of the album isn't quite so profound. The Italian duo doesn't stray too far from the tone established by ""Ice Lips""
column3: but their songs are hit-or-miss. Their best compositions are sexy and catchy
column4: albeit in rather understated and introverted ways. ""Even If""
column5: one of the album's highlights
column6: sets a simple
column7: repetitive sing-song melody against a moody guitar figure that wouldn't sound out of place on an Interpol record
column8: resulting in a stealthy earworm of a hook. ""Escape Destination"" and ""No Train No Plane"" are similarly subtle
column9: burying reasonably strong melodic motifs in atmosphere and ambience. They fall short when they lean too hard on setting a mood. Much of the album is indistinct and forgettable
column10: drifting by in a haze of plinking beats and bleeping keyboard notes. The mood being evoked is nondescript and typical of a lot of good-not-great 00s electronica-- vaguely melancholy
column11: sorta uptight
column12: overly serious. The tracks that go too far in this direction
column13: like ""Cruise Control"" and ""White March""
column14: are the flip side of ""Ice Lips"". Instead of sounding intimate and specific
column15: they are aloof and abstract.

column1: It should be noted that a significant part of We Love's project involves fashion
column2: and performances in which the two dress up in futuristic costumes. Of course
column3: this aspect of their art is totally lost on record. Without having witnessed one of these performances
column4: it's hard to say whether or not this adds anything to the music. However
column5: just looking at photographs of the costumes
column6: it's obvious that they are doing something sort of interesting. The suits have a familiar style derived from sci-fi movies and comic books
column7: but intriguingly
column8: everything you would expect to appear hard and rigid looks soft and flowing. Patterns appear where you would expect blank space. Cozy
column9: pajama-esque fabric is contrasted with what appears to be pleather or latex. In some ways
column10: their approach to visual presentation is the opposite of their approach to music. Whereas they go against convention in their costumes
column11: their songs tend to be fairly generic electronic music
column12:
pretty much exactly what you would expect from something put out by Bpitch Control. They certainly have the skill to rise above unchallenging aural wallpaper; they do it at least four times on this record. It's just too bad they couldn't have been more consistent on this album.

News stories about Former Ghosts
column3: the group/collective led by Freddy Ruppert
column4: usually make a point of mentioning the involvement of Xiu Xiu and Zola Jesus. While invoking the names of both a long-running
column5: well-respected
column6: uncompromising underground group and an up-and-coming performer is a great way to sell prospective listeners on an unknown project
column7: it's not really accurate as far as what Former Ghosts is. The best way to think of Former Ghosts is as the newest work from the man previously known as This Song Is a Mess But So Am I
column8: a one-man group created by Ruppert as a coping mechanism for the untimely death of his mother. As A Mess
column9: Ruppert offered listeners a Casio-tonic take on Xiu Xiu's caustic and restless aggression
column10: coupled with vocals that either paid slavish homage to Ian Curtis or adopted the fragile quiver found in Conor Oberst's more vulnerable moments. For better or worse
column11: the music made as A Mess often lived up to the name of the project
column12: coming off like a primal scream therapy session set to noise. Clearly Ruppert wasn't interested in creating music listeners could enjoy as innocuous background noise; he aimed to be a provocateur
column13: creating sonics that matched his own inner turmoil.

column1: Former Ghosts started in part as an excuse for Ruppert and Xiu Xiu's Jamie Stewart to hang out and make synth-pop together; Nika Roza Danilova (aka Zola Jesus)
column2: whose work Ruppert admired (and vice versa) entered the fold soon thereafter. There's a definite edge to New Love that feels distinctive; the drum machine hits and synth stabs have a five o'clock shadow showing beneath their New Romantic veneer. The less-than-flattering fidelity helps in that regard as well
column3: presenting the image of new wave as conducted through the Tesla coils and Van de Graaff generators in a mad scientist's laboratory. In the hands of his charismatic guest vocalists-- for New Love
column4: Danilova and Tearist's Yasmine Kittles-- these backing tracks come to life (when Jamie Stewart sings
column5: it's in a back-up role). On her two turns at the mic
column6: Danilova doesn't sing so much as dominate
column7: her forceful vocals laying waste to whatever's in their path. Kittles
column8: a type of singer decidedly different from Danilova
column9: takes another approach on her two tracks: She emits intermittent whispers and hisses like a subjugated trip-hop diva
column10: instead letting the music take precedence.

column1: Given Ruppert's past predilection for dramatic singing
column2: one would think his vocals would be a perfect match for these backing tracks. Unfortunately
column3: he often doesn't rise to the challenge. The duet he performs with Kittles on ""Winter's Year"" bears this out; where she sounds at ease and at home
column4: Ruppert seems to be fighting against himself to get the words out. On aggressive tracks like ""The Days Will Get Long Again""
column5: his Oberst-esque warbling gets subsumed by the hum and spark of the backing track. During more contemplative sections (like the beginning of ""Winter's Year"")
column6: his singing smothers any prettiness in the instrumentals. Unabashed pop tunes like ""And When You Kiss Me"" and ""Right Here"" need a gentler touch than Ruppert's tin-can singing can provide
column7: while dirges (such as the appropriately titled ""Bare Bones"") are actually undercut by his tendency to overemote.

column1: It seems crass to suggest that Ruppert is a better singer when his songs aren't very song-like
column2: or when he's more interested in screaming than singing. But with two albums as Former Ghosts complete
column3: he hasn't yet hit on tracks that mesh well with his vocal style. Given the success he's had when other people take over vocal duties
column4: it'd be interesting to see what would happen if he invited other like-minded (or oppositely-minded) people to sing his songs across an entire album
column5: à la Stephin Merritt's the 6ths. Unfortunately
column6: as things stand
column7:
the errors of omission in most Former Ghosts news stories are appropriate: Freddy Ruppert is the frontman of a group better served when someone else is center stage.

"|14851.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14851-new-love/|5.3|David Raposa

Sometimes reissues add a few demos or outtakes
column3: sometimes they add a bonus disc with a live show or additional music
column4: and sometimes they go so far with the bonus material they become something else entirely. The Promise
column5: a name given to two sets based around unheard music from Bruce Springsteen dating to 1977 and 1978
column6: when he was writing and recording the seminal Darkness on the Edge of Town
column7: doesn't fit easily into typical reissue categories. There's a 2xCD
column8: 3xLP set that contains 22 unreleased songs from the period
column9: and then there's a deluxe box set that augments the unreleased material with a remastered version of Darkness and three DVDs. And the latter is housed in a faux spiral-bound notebook with facsimiles of Springsteen's handwritten studio notes from the time. Taken all together
column10: we're talking 10 hours plus of video and audio
column11: along with the booklet. So calling this a reissue of Darkness on the Edge of Town is not accurate. This is a trove
column12: a vast clearinghouse from a fertile period
column13: the product of which turned out to be one terrific album. And in addition to containing its share of treasure
column14: The Promise ultimately confirms that Springsteen is a brilliant editor of his own material.

column1: That much is clear when listening to the album itself
column2: which is in danger of being overshadowed by everything released around it. Where the Born to Run box from 2005 looked intently at the album proper (there were few outtakes from those sessions anyway) and portrayed what resulted as a landmark
column3: The Promise focuses on a period of time that produced one memorable album but could have produced others. Much of the material was written when Springsteen was embroiled in a lawsuit with his former manager
column4: and a lot has been made of the impact the legal proceedings were said to have on Springsteen's muse. He made a bleak and bombed-out album
column5: the story goes
column6: because he was feeling lost in the world himself
column7: fearful that he was losing control of his career. And since the lawsuit kept him out of the studio when he wanted so badly to record
column8: he kept piling up songs while he waited for the smoke to clear.

column1: Even more than the lawsuit
column2: Darkness seems like Springsteen's instinctive recoil from the Born to Run hype. That's partly why he burned to cut another record-- to ""find out what he's got
column3: to quote a line from ""Badlands"" that particularly appealed to him. The Promise documentary included with the box
column4: which combines black-and-white video footage taken in the studio while the album was recorded with recent interviews
column5: makes clear that he wanted to make an ""honest"" record that people would take seriously. He was embarrassed by the hype that had put him on the cover of Time and Newsweek simultaneously in 1975
column6: and he didn't want to be the ""next big thing.""

column1: Indeed
column2: it's striking just how different Darkness is from its predecessor in tone and theme. Where Born to Run was about drama
column3: with a sense of bombast that pushed past cinematic and wound up somewhere closer to Broadway
column4: Darkness
column5: despite its share of rockers
column6: is about grim acceptance and pressing on in the face of doubt. In ""Racing in the Street""
column7: the bittersweet ballad that ranks with the best songs Springsteen has ever written
column8: the narrator's girlfriend ""Stares off alone into the night/ With the eyes of one who hates for just being born."" But she's not going anywhere. The darkness that envelops the town keeps the characters in and the rest of the world out. Where the characters in Born to Run were racing against death
column9: the characters here are cursed with the burden of survival. So like all Springsteen records in the early part of his career
column10: there are many songs about cars and driving
column11: but these people seem to be going in circles
column12: idly moving from one place to the next. ""You can ride this road 'til dawn
column13: without another human being in sight
column14: goes a line in the richly emotional mid-tempo rocker ""Something in the Night"". With no chance of escape
column15: you have to figure out how to deal with what's in front of you.

column1: The stark reality of the songs is reinforced by the album's production. Darkness is in its own way as sonically consistent and coherent as Born to Run; but where that album drew inspiration from Phil Spector's Wall of Sound
column2: Darkness tries to do as much as possible with a minimum of embellishment. A few tracks break from this dry and barren template. ""Candy's Room"" and ""Something in the Night"" have the tinkling piano and glockenspiel that might have helped them to fit on Born to Run
column3: while ""Racing in the Street"" has a very particular and hugely effective atmosphere
column4: with just the right touches of reverb and backing vocals to make it sound like an elegy. As for the remastering
column5: I'm not hearing a lot of difference here
column6: but Darkness always sounded good. From the opening drum fill of ""Badlands"" to the grim fade of the title track
column7: there's not a weak song on the album and it deservedly ranks with Springsteen's classics. Which means that it ranks with rock's classic albums
column8: full stop.

column1: And it took a long time to get it that way. The music on the 2xCD set The Promise
column2: which was written during the Darkness sessions
column3: shows what Springsteen had to leave behind to get the record that he wanted. That meant no big pop songs. There's ""Because the Night""
column4: given to Patti Smith before being completed
column5: which she then improved and turned into her biggest hit. And then ""Fire""
column6: which Springsteen gave to the Pointer Sisters
column7: and which went to No. 2 on Billboard. It also means no songs about easy times
column8: hope
column9: and escape. So ""Gotta Get That Feeling""
column10: an appealing mid-tempo track with horns and sweet backing vocals and lines like ""We ain't got no money but we don't care"" was shelved. (In Darkness
column11: people have no money but they do care
column12: a lot.) And ""Save My Love""
column13: a catchy piano-led tune
column14: isn't going to make Darkness with lines like ""If we open up our hearts/ Love won't forsake us."" Tell that to the couple in ""Racing in the Street"".

column1: The Promise is also a good demonstration of how Springsteen mines his unused songs for material
column2: and shows how many ways he tried to record things before figuring out how they worked best. The set kicks off with ""Racing in the Street ('78)""
column3: a version that begins as an austere ballad but builds into a rock song. It's nowhere near as effective as what came to be on the record
column4: but it is riveting
column5: showing just how elastic Springsteen's melodic and thematic ideas could be. An early version of ""Candy's Room"" is here
column6: too
column7: and it's called ""Candy's Boy""; instead of the original's dark and explosive sensuality
column8: here it's a clean
column9: shuffling guitar-pop tune
column10: charming but without a lot at stake.

column1: The tracks on The Promise CD aren't left out just because of subject matter or tone-- they also sound different. As with some songs on Tracks
column2: some of these songs had parts added later. ""Where needed
column3: I worked on them to bring them to fruition
column4: Springsteen writes in the notes. ""Many stand as they were recorded all those years ago."" The re-touching is at its most extreme on ""Save My Love""
column5: which was written in the 70s but cut in 2010. In other places
column6: the vocals and music sound fundamentally different from the recordings of the era. Certainly
column7: the arrangements are thicker than what wound up on Darkness
column8: which makes sense since some of the songs left behind were R&B-based bar-band songs and swooning songs of love and lust. Still
column9: despite the lack of consistency
column10: the 22 new songs (there are 21 tracks
column11: but ""The Way"" is a hidden bonus track at the end) are mostly very good and occasionally great. None feel like they should have been on Darkness
column12: but almost all of them hold up to repeat plays and stand on their own as very good Springsteen-- easily on the level of mid-level stuff on The River
column13: say.

column1: On the visual side
column2: one DVD has a bizarre recording of Springsteen and the E Street Band playing Darkness on the Edge of Town straight through in an empty theater in Asbury Park in December 2009. I suspect that this decision was inspired in part by the notion that the album is about loneliness and open spaces
column3: but there's something off about seeing this band
column4: known so well for its deep connection to its audience
column5: playing by themselves in a large room without people.

column1: More interesting on the same disc are the live odds-and-ends from rehearsals at Springsteen's rented Jersey home in the 70s. The band is packed into what looks like a small bedroom
column2: Springsteen is shirtless
column3: with the familiar guitar around his neck
column4: standing before a microphone taped to a stand. And the band is running through a couple new songs in an intimate space with no sense at all of posterity. (They are so casual
column5: Steve Van Zant isn't even wearing a hat!) Also on this disc are songs from a 1978 show in Phoenix
column6: including the famous clip for ""Rosalita"" that got some play in the early days of MTV.  These Phoenix performances are generally superior to the three-hour set from a 1978 show in Houston included on a separate DVD. The video comes from the arena's video feed and
column7: given the quality of video in 1978
column8: quality could be better. But it is a multi-camera shoot with good coverage and Springsteen and the E Street band were in amazing form throughout that year. So no complaints about more live Springsteen.

column1: Which leaves the documentary
column2: which in one sense serves as the centerpiece of the project. As with the film included with the Born to Run box
column3: there are interesting details about the technical aspects of the album. Chuck Plotkin's theory behind his approach to mixing vocals is fascinating
column4: and explains why this album feels so balanced. We see fragments of songs
column5: lots of exhaustion and sitting around
column6: and get a look at how Springsteen works as a bandleader. There's a moment in the first scene where he looks tired and frustrated and a little pissed off and you realize that it would be scary to have him mad at you. He's not always an easy guy to work for. It's refreshing to see such a simple display of humanity when the documentary obviously has very specific points that it wants to hit.

column1: Still
column2: there's something odd about these ""making of"" documentaries about albums coming from the artist themselves. In part because they seem so intent on directing how the music is heard. Sets like this and Neil Young's Archives reflect a desire for artists to take control of their legacy and shape the narrative of their careers. It's easy to understand this impulse
column3: and doubly so when you are talking about people as controlling as Springsteen or Neil Young. And yet it's also futile. As listeners
column4: our stories are what will ultimately matter
column5: and by having the music in our lives
column6: we give it significance and form. Darkness is the kind of record you sink into
column7: an album of power and dignity and loss and just a hint at the possibility of transcendence
column8: which is something Springsteen's fans have known all along
column9: even without hearing a single detail of how it is made. We'll take it all and have loads of fun exploring all the ephemera
column10: but Springsteen carved through all this-- the pile of songs
column11: the legal bullshit
column12: the media image he wasn't comfortable with-- to make that one magical record
column13:
which is the most impressive part of it all.
