column1: That much is clear when listening to the album itself
column2: which is in danger of being overshadowed by everything released around it. Where the Born to Run box from 2005 looked intently at the album proper (there were few outtakes from those sessions anyway) and portrayed what resulted as a landmark
column3: The Promise focuses on a period of time that produced one memorable album but could have produced others. Much of the material was written when Springsteen was embroiled in a lawsuit with his former manager
column4: and a lot has been made of the impact the legal proceedings were said to have on Springsteen's muse. He made a bleak and bombed-out album
column5: the story goes
column6: because he was feeling lost in the world himself
column7: fearful that he was losing control of his career. And since the lawsuit kept him out of the studio when he wanted so badly to record
column8: he kept piling up songs while he waited for the smoke to clear.

column1: Even more than the lawsuit
column2: Darkness seems like Springsteen's instinctive recoil from the Born to Run hype. That's partly why he burned to cut another record-- to ""find out what he's got
column3: to quote a line from ""Badlands"" that particularly appealed to him. The Promise documentary included with the box
column4: which combines black-and-white video footage taken in the studio while the album was recorded with recent interviews
column5: makes clear that he wanted to make an ""honest"" record that people would take seriously. He was embarrassed by the hype that had put him on the cover of Time and Newsweek simultaneously in 1975
column6: and he didn't want to be the ""next big thing.""

column1: Indeed
column2: it's striking just how different Darkness is from its predecessor in tone and theme. Where Born to Run was about drama
column3: with a sense of bombast that pushed past cinematic and wound up somewhere closer to Broadway
column4: Darkness
column5: despite its share of rockers
column6: is about grim acceptance and pressing on in the face of doubt. In ""Racing in the Street""
column7: the bittersweet ballad that ranks with the best songs Springsteen has ever written
column8: the narrator's girlfriend ""Stares off alone into the night/ With the eyes of one who hates for just being born."" But she's not going anywhere. The darkness that envelops the town keeps the characters in and the rest of the world out. Where the characters in Born to Run were racing against death
column9: the characters here are cursed with the burden of survival. So like all Springsteen records in the early part of his career
column10: there are many songs about cars and driving
column11: but these people seem to be going in circles
column12: idly moving from one place to the next. ""You can ride this road 'til dawn
column13: without another human being in sight
column14: goes a line in the richly emotional mid-tempo rocker ""Something in the Night"". With no chance of escape
column15: you have to figure out how to deal with what's in front of you.

column1: The stark reality of the songs is reinforced by the album's production. Darkness is in its own way as sonically consistent and coherent as Born to Run; but where that album drew inspiration from Phil Spector's Wall of Sound
column2: Darkness tries to do as much as possible with a minimum of embellishment. A few tracks break from this dry and barren template. ""Candy's Room"" and ""Something in the Night"" have the tinkling piano and glockenspiel that might have helped them to fit on Born to Run
column3: while ""Racing in the Street"" has a very particular and hugely effective atmosphere
column4: with just the right touches of reverb and backing vocals to make it sound like an elegy. As for the remastering
column5: I'm not hearing a lot of difference here
column6: but Darkness always sounded good. From the opening drum fill of ""Badlands"" to the grim fade of the title track
column7: there's not a weak song on the album and it deservedly ranks with Springsteen's classics. Which means that it ranks with rock's classic albums
column8: full stop.

column1: And it took a long time to get it that way. The music on the 2xCD set The Promise
column2: which was written during the Darkness sessions
column3: shows what Springsteen had to leave behind to get the record that he wanted. That meant no big pop songs. There's ""Because the Night""
column4: given to Patti Smith before being completed
column5: which she then improved and turned into her biggest hit. And then ""Fire""
column6: which Springsteen gave to the Pointer Sisters
column7: and which went to No. 2 on Billboard. It also means no songs about easy times
column8: hope
column9: and escape. So ""Gotta Get That Feeling""
column10: an appealing mid-tempo track with horns and sweet backing vocals and lines like ""We ain't got no money but we don't care"" was shelved. (In Darkness
column11: people have no money but they do care
column12: a lot.) And ""Save My Love""
column13: a catchy piano-led tune
column14: isn't going to make Darkness with lines like ""If we open up our hearts/ Love won't forsake us."" Tell that to the couple in ""Racing in the Street"".

column1: The Promise is also a good demonstration of how Springsteen mines his unused songs for material
column2: and shows how many ways he tried to record things before figuring out how they worked best. The set kicks off with ""Racing in the Street ('78)""
column3: a version that begins as an austere ballad but builds into a rock song. It's nowhere near as effective as what came to be on the record
column4: but it is riveting
column5: showing just how elastic Springsteen's melodic and thematic ideas could be. An early version of ""Candy's Room"" is here
column6: too
column7: and it's called ""Candy's Boy""; instead of the original's dark and explosive sensuality
column8: here it's a clean
column9: shuffling guitar-pop tune
column10: charming but without a lot at stake.

column1: The tracks on The Promise CD aren't left out just because of subject matter or tone-- they also sound different. As with some songs on Tracks
column2: some of these songs had parts added later. ""Where needed
column3: I worked on them to bring them to fruition
column4: Springsteen writes in the notes. ""Many stand as they were recorded all those years ago."" The re-touching is at its most extreme on ""Save My Love""
column5: which was written in the 70s but cut in 2010. In other places
column6: the vocals and music sound fundamentally different from the recordings of the era. Certainly
column7: the arrangements are thicker than what wound up on Darkness
column8: which makes sense since some of the songs left behind were R&B-based bar-band songs and swooning songs of love and lust. Still
column9: despite the lack of consistency
column10: the 22 new songs (there are 21 tracks
column11: but ""The Way"" is a hidden bonus track at the end) are mostly very good and occasionally great. None feel like they should have been on Darkness
column12: but almost all of them hold up to repeat plays and stand on their own as very good Springsteen-- easily on the level of mid-level stuff on The River
column13: say.

column1: On the visual side
column2: one DVD has a bizarre recording of Springsteen and the E Street Band playing Darkness on the Edge of Town straight through in an empty theater in Asbury Park in December 2009. I suspect that this decision was inspired in part by the notion that the album is about loneliness and open spaces
column3: but there's something off about seeing this band
column4: known so well for its deep connection to its audience
column5: playing by themselves in a large room without people.

column1: More interesting on the same disc are the live odds-and-ends from rehearsals at Springsteen's rented Jersey home in the 70s. The band is packed into what looks like a small bedroom
column2: Springsteen is shirtless
column3: with the familiar guitar around his neck
column4: standing before a microphone taped to a stand. And the band is running through a couple new songs in an intimate space with no sense at all of posterity. (They are so casual
column5: Steve Van Zant isn't even wearing a hat!) Also on this disc are songs from a 1978 show in Phoenix
column6: including the famous clip for ""Rosalita"" that got some play in the early days of MTV.  These Phoenix performances are generally superior to the three-hour set from a 1978 show in Houston included on a separate DVD. The video comes from the arena's video feed and
column7: given the quality of video in 1978
column8: quality could be better. But it is a multi-camera shoot with good coverage and Springsteen and the E Street band were in amazing form throughout that year. So no complaints about more live Springsteen.

column1: Which leaves the documentary
column2: which in one sense serves as the centerpiece of the project. As with the film included with the Born to Run box
column3: there are interesting details about the technical aspects of the album. Chuck Plotkin's theory behind his approach to mixing vocals is fascinating
column4: and explains why this album feels so balanced. We see fragments of songs
column5: lots of exhaustion and sitting around
column6: and get a look at how Springsteen works as a bandleader. There's a moment in the first scene where he looks tired and frustrated and a little pissed off and you realize that it would be scary to have him mad at you. He's not always an easy guy to work for. It's refreshing to see such a simple display of humanity when the documentary obviously has very specific points that it wants to hit.

column1: Still
column2: there's something odd about these ""making of"" documentaries about albums coming from the artist themselves. In part because they seem so intent on directing how the music is heard. Sets like this and Neil Young's Archives reflect a desire for artists to take control of their legacy and shape the narrative of their careers. It's easy to understand this impulse
column3: and doubly so when you are talking about people as controlling as Springsteen or Neil Young. And yet it's also futile. As listeners
column4: our stories are what will ultimately matter
column5: and by having the music in our lives
column6: we give it significance and form. Darkness is the kind of record you sink into
column7: an album of power and dignity and loss and just a hint at the possibility of transcendence
column8: which is something Springsteen's fans have known all along
column9: even without hearing a single detail of how it is made. We'll take it all and have loads of fun exploring all the ephemera
column10: but Springsteen carved through all this-- the pile of songs
column11: the legal bullshit
column12: the media image he wasn't comfortable with-- to make that one magical record
column13:
which is the most impressive part of it all.

Some of us have been waiting years for late 1980s/early 90s rave to have its moment of nostalgia-driven resurgence. For one thing
column3: it's just seemed inevitable
column4: as many indie bands would at some point ditch dance-punk for neo-grunge. But also we're just plain greedy to re-own some hard-to-find tunes from the era when sampling and Roland synthesizers changed the sound of radio almost overnight.

column1: And in the last few years
column2: newer acts
column3: from Scandinavian indie pop bands to UK house producers
column4: many of whom were kids at the time have begun to pay homage to early rave in earnest. Impossible Oddities collects the psychedelic pop-dance singles the Orb and their sampladelic friends released on the duo's W.A.U!. Mr Modo label as the UK's late-80s ""Summer of Love"" gave way to the worldwide rave boom of the early 90s. If dubstep has recently picked up on early breakbeat hardcore's manic roughness
column5: this is stuff you can hear referenced in the trippy-but-cuddly rave recreations of the Tough Alliance axis.

column1: Elements of R&B (Johnson Dean's chintzy
column2: cheesy
column3: pretty great ""Somebody Somewhere"") and reggae (Indica All Stars' ""Open Our Eyes"") and prog-rock (the nature-sounds overload heard on an early demo mix of the Orb's ""Little Fluffy Clouds"") crop up throughout. But mostly these producers were working in idioms that were
column4: for a few years anyway
column5: totally new: Chicago acid
column6: the sample-heavy party records of early instrumental hip-hop
column7: Detroit techno. To these import sounds
column8: the W.A.U!. Mr Modo artists brought a very UK neo-hippie vibe. The track titles and producer monikers alone should give you give you an idea of the angle many of these artists (especially the Orb
column9: informing the whole project) were working: ""Ashram House""
column10: ""Tripping on Sunshine""
column11: Sun Electric
column12: Indica All Stars.

column1: Not quite right for one of Orb mainman Dr. Alex Paterson's legendary chill-out nights
column2: but usually too whimsical for a frenzied warehouse rave
column3: these artists operated during a brief time when it was still possible to exist somewhere in the middle. It's stoner music with a funky pulse and none of the bad-trip vibes of the harder
column4: faster music of just a few years (or months) later. Compared to the crassest pop-dance stuff of the time-- think the huge riffs and learn-in-a-minute raps of Technotronic-- they practically have the grownup restraint of deep house. But there's still an appealing rave-minded roughness and lack of pretension to the tracks on Impossible Oddities.

column1: Not all of it's essential; there are a few too many interchangeable break-plus-synth tunes that were probably little more than DJ fodder even at the time. That's to be expected since this is a specific snapshot of one label's output. But if you've been digging the way the neo-Balearic boom has been getting rave-ier recently-- think artists like Azari & III and Tensnake-- here's a nice
column2:
unexpected opportunity to catch the original vibe without resorting to lo-fi YouTube rips.

Amidst the grime-flecked synth lines and low-riding melodies
column2: the music Tobacco makes is
column3: at its core
column4: sensual. Considering the blown-out beatmaker's visual fetish for pornography and disturbing images
column5: that might seem faulty
column6: but this isn't music you reach out and touch-- it practically swarms your senses
column7: and you don't get much of a chance to get out of its way. Tobacco's main outfit
column8: Black Moth Super Rainbow
column9: laid the template for this synth-smothered sound on their breakout full-length
column10: Dandelion Gum. While that record was like a broken dam of warm liquid
column11: Tobacco's latest solo effort
column12: this year's Maniac Meat
column13: was more like a half-functioning spigot of scalding water: Melodies came in sharp
column14: hard-hitting bursts that attempted to burn your brain.

column1: Maniac Meat was more straightforward than anything put out by the BMSR crew-- but listening to it front-to-back still induced a sensory overload at points. Tobacco's companion EP
column2: LA UTI
column3: takes some measures to correct that. The concept-- rappers laying verses over Maniac Meat cuts
column4: as well as a few new jams-- isn't novel in this endlessly reusable age
column5: but the execution is surprisingly effective. A steady presence is exactly what this music needs in terms of an anchor
column6: as the sheer anthemic nature of cuts like ""Lick the Witch"" and ""Sweatmother"" emerges from the mud-soaked ether it was previously lurking behind.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the function of the rapping greatly outstrips the actual quality. While it's enjoyable to hear the recently reunited Anti-Pop Consortium have fun over ""TV All Greasy""
column3: they also struggle to keep up rhythmically
column4: occasionally slipping from their internal rhythms while delivering stale
column5: uninventive lines. Avant-rap mainstay Doseone somehow becomes another functional cog in the twinkling crunch of new track ""The Injury""
column6: and not much more; Chicago MC Serengeti
column7: on the other hand
column8: failingly attempts to match the sleazy drip of ""2 Thick Scoops"" in delivery. It seems like a lot of the guests here are trying to out-weird the material they're delivering over
column9: which is precisely why Rob Sonic's appearance on ""Lick the Witch"" works so well. Sonic rides the track's asthmatic gasps tightly
column10: delivering surrealist details (""A benchwarmer groom for greeting Marine Corps"") with a hardhead's conviction. Instead of getting smothered
column11:
you're basically getting punched in the face; Tobacco could stand to be this violent a little more often.

column3: the Japanese pop music that finds its way to Western audiences is either cartoonishly cute (in the vein of Shonen Knife) or punishingly noisy (à la Boris or Boredoms). Refreshingly
column4: the all-female quartet the Suzan are neither. On their debut
column5: Golden Week for the Poco Poco Beat
column6: the all-girl Suzan mine garage-rock
column7: pop
column8: new wave
column9: surf-rock
column10: riot-grrrl
column11: and even gypsy-folk for inspiration. This makes for a collection that isn't unified in sound but has an omnivorous attitude that permeates throughout. While some may find the lack of stylistic cohesion to be a drawback
column12: Poco Poco Beat doesn't sound scattered. Rather than coming off as an overstuffed collection by a group who couldn't stick to (or make) one singular aesthetic choice
column13: the album feels like it's burning through a history of girl groups from the Shangri-Las to the Raincoats and the Go-Go's.

column1: Despite that fact
column2: there are a few stylistic markers that act as glue for this willfully disjointed collection. One is the charming vocals of frontwoman Saori Suzuki: Eschewing any of the cloying girlish notes of her versatile voice
column3: she sounds self-assured and womanly
column4: whether she's cooing
column5: scat-singing
column6: or snarling. Another is the band's facility with creating ambiance. They're as adept at creating a sense of creeping dread as they are at summoning celebratory cacophonies. On an album this varied
column7: the Suzan have room to show off all their different sides
column8: and the fact that they sound perfectly natural in both pub-punk screamer mode (""London Tonight"") and in a more soulful 60s pop style (""Ha Ha Ha"") is a testament to their musicality. Perhaps their most essential skill is their ability to temper their most sugary
column9: most melodic impulses with enough tough
column10: raw
column11: or sparse ones to keep things from becoming too precious. For example
column12: despite the almost sickly sweet xylophone that kicks off album opener ""Home""
column13: the song smartly builds an ESG-worthy groove with its rhythmically chanted vocals and tom-heavy drive to become the LP's best track.

column1: As you may have already heard
column2: the Suzan were ""discovered"" on MySpace by Björn Yttling (of Peter Bjorn and John)
column3: pulled out of the vast
column4: overwhelming Internet-music morass by a producer with a proven track record. Then they became the first traditional rock band (although the term ""traditional"" here is a slight stretch) signed to A-Trak and Nick Catchdub's Fool's Gold label. It isn't hard to see why these independent music heavies were won over by this developing-but-driven group from half a world away. The Suzan have an infectious energy
column5: and the ambitious scope of their debut is impressive (if
column6: admittedly
column7: exhausting). Would the band have been better served if they'd tightened their musical scope and not made such a genre-hopping collection? Possibly
column8:
but the Suzan's up-for-anything enthusiasm is part of their charm.

It's difficult to discuss New Zealand indie rock without mentioning the Clean. From the time of their debut single
column2: ""Tally Ho!""

column5: Yo La Tengo) to some of today's most exciting underground bands (Times New Viking
column6: Crystal Stilts
column7: the late Jay Reatard). With the Clean's reputation seemingly at an all-time high

column9: Confusion

column1: On parts of the record
column2: it proves to be a struggle. Throughout the band swipes moves from the playbook of their forebears-- a few jangly guitars here

column6: catchy

column11: synthesized horn blast eerily reminiscent of the opening to Bell Biv Devoe's ""Poison"".

column2: it proves to be a mixed bag. The intro of ""No Oil"" finds them restlessly experimenting with ambient loops before locking into a sulking
column3: bass-driven groove and then devolving into meandering aimlessness. On the other hand

column6: blurry guitars and a bubbling
column7: hypnotic bassline while providing many exploratory detours and even a couple of sharp tempo changes throughout the song's 10 minutes. While the template they've set for themselves can prove to be rigid at points
column8: Confusion is a record that proves Surf Friends are capable of expanding upon it and even abandoning it completely. But in order for them to truly set their own path
column9:
they'll have to learn to do such a thing a little more often.

When Stereolab announced plans to take an indefinite hiatus in April of last year
column4: they also mentioned that a parting gift was in the works: Chemical Chords 2
column5: a second record of material from the 2007 sessions that spawned the concise
column6: horn-studded Chemical Chords. At the time
column7: Tim Gane told Pitchfork it would ""make an interesting kind of sibling or companion to [Chemical Chords]
column8: and that they were hoping to get it out quickly ""because it's too similar
column9: it's from the same sort of  sessions."" Laetitia Sadier described it as having ""31 songs
column10: which are split into two halves. One is the day side
column11: and one is the nighttime side.""

column1: Over the past year and a half
column2: Not Music was pared back considerably: The final version features 13 songs
column3: including two extended remixes of Chemical Chords songs by the Emperor Machine and Atlas Sound. This turns out to have been an effective approach. The careful song selection and sequencing of this mix is intended to play like a proper studio album
column4: and mostly
column5: it does
column6: even with the 8-minute-plus remixes acting as centerpieces. And while obviously similar in sound to Chemical Chords
column7: the record is suffused with as much joyous synth experimentation
column8: astral effects and flourishes
column9: and buzzy motorik rhythms as Stereolab's mid-career efforts.

column1: Needless to say
column2: if you're hoping for a career-defining endcap
column3: this is not that record. The new
column4: non-remix tracks on Not Music ignore much of Stereolab's omnivorous career-- there's no space-age bachelor pad music
column5: no bossa nova flourishes
column6: and no sign of the rawer avant-garde leanings that shaped their earliest records. Instead
column7: the set continues in the taut
column8: propulsive pop vein of their more recent releases.

column1: Album opener ""Everybody's Weird Except Me"" is sweet yet dry
column2: using the richness of Laetitia Sadier's nonchalant alto to cut the cuteness of the melody. The track plays off the dichotomies Stereolab have come to love-- old-fashioned pop tropes delivered by whirring
column3: futuristic instruments
column4: with cold detachment rubbing up against whimsical lushness and cerebral orchestrations played with charm. ""Sun Demon"" opens by deconstructing a garage-rock melody (there's a trace of the Castaways' ""Liar
column5: Liar"" organ line in there) with splashes of videogame bleeps
column6: then throws its back into an unrelenting rhythmic chug. And ""Two Finger Symphony"" explicitly answers the last record's ""One Finger Symphony"" with its slightly altered repetitive keyboard vamp.

column1: Stereolab's last effort was among the most concise and tightly focused of the band's career
column2: distilling their baroque
column3: buzzing aesthetic into breathless
column4: three-minute pop songs. Not Music mostly echoes that change
column5: but also sprawls like vintage Stereolab when it needs to
column6: as on the 10-plus-minute centerpiece ""Silver Sands [Emperor Machine Mix]""
column7: which turns the xylophone melody of the Chemical Chords original into a sparse
column8: mechanized krautrock throb.

column1: The Stereolab story for the last five years has been
column2: ""Yep
column3: they still sound like Stereolab."" And if we're disappointed that the band's ever-experimental drive feels stifled by the brevity of this newer material
column4: perhaps this hiatus is well-timed. While we learn to finally miss the quirky
column5: stylish synth-pop that we've begun to take for granted
column6: we'll have to content ourselves with Not Music as the band's final hurrah-- at least for now. I suspect it won't be long before we realize that the leftovers of a band like Stereolab are still better than main dishes offered up by many of their peers. And maybe by then

they'll be back to recording.

column1: Worth the Weight: Bristol Dubstep Classics-- a 2xCD set with 26 tracks-- surveys the sound of the city more than Punch Drunk per se. And more power to it. (A call-out in the liner notes even casts Bristol as ""dubstep's second city

column1: That kind of surprise and subsequent rush of new understanding is what makes dubstep

column5: Appleblim
column6: Headhunter
column7: Joker
column8: Guido
column9: and more. There's much to be gleaned from the difference between Pinch's brutish opening salvo and the second track
column10: Peverelist's ""The Grind""
column11: which floats and glides in all the places where Pinch trips himself up. And then from there to where Gatekeeper
column12: in ""Tense Past""
column13: bears down and simply stomps.

column1: Those first three tracks alone signal Worth the Weight's focus on the more rhythmic
column2: low-end
column3: and sober extremes of dubstep. The style's recent trends toward weird weightless smearing and especially soulful vocal pastiche don't get much play. Instead
column4: for better and worse
column5: Worth the Weight sounds almost fixated on the formidable. It's ""better"" in that none of the tracks is ever less than strong. But it's ""worse"" in the way that one can grow weary of hearing such shows of relentless strength in succession
column6: without at least a little reprieve. Dubstep
column7: in a club context
column8: thrives on strange intra-set swerves and spells of deep breathing. That's not to say there's no variety here between grim
column9: haunting
column10: decimated-planet anthems like Appleblim & Peverelist's ""Circling"" and Joker's playfully wobbly video-game ooze. But everything on Worth the Weight is
column11: in ways that can't be escaped
column12:
very heavy indeed.

column3:
'Bright Antenna']|2010-11-16 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:06.343797|"

History of Modern is being released at the most synth-heavy time for popular music since the days when OMD first blew up. In America they did it via Pretty in Pink with a less art-rock and more palatably pop version of the sound that is popular now-- the sound that made them stars in the UK. You might think it's the perfect time for the band to stage an improbable comeback
column4: to once again take their original synth-disco sound all the way. Hey
column5: if 43-year-old house producer David Guetta can transform himself into a Billboard star
column6: anything's possible
column7: right?

column1: Unfortunately History of Modern won't be conquering anything except maybe the already primed nostalgia circuit. After a long layoff
column2: OMD have made the kind of the just-okay
column3: just-what-you'd expect album that's always snagged by the handful of folks hungry for anything new by their Big 1980s faves. Think of all those middling Tears for Fears and Erasure ""reunion"" albums that feel mostly like announcements that their creators aren't quite dead yet: Someone's got to be buying them
column4: despite the fact that they rarely match (let alone top) the originals. So it goes with History of Modern.

column1: Not that delivering what your aging audience expects is such a bad thing
column2: especially when your attempts to move beyond those expectations can be kind of embarrassing. No one's ""rock"" should try to imitate the cranky
column3: grit-less late Jesus and Mary Chain or Primal Scream's limpest electro-sleaze
column4: though ""New Babies; New Toys"" sounds like OMD thinks both bands were onto something. And while their dance-pop songs
column5: like ""The Future
column6: the Past
column7: and Forever After""
column8: might yet make it onto the playlists of your less-discerning gay clubs
column9: their thin Hi-NRG pastiches would be eaten alive on the radio
column10: where today's meat-wearing bad romancers have made big beats and instant-earworm choruses a requirement. If your kids abuse you with The Fame Monster on the way to school
column11: don't think counter-programming History of Modern is going to help you seem down.

column1: At its best
column2: HOM sticks to the sound that made OMD stars-- lush
column3: romantic 80s-style electronic music
column4: Andy McCluskey still shamelessly manhandling the melodramatic romantic metaphor
column5: perfect for your high school reunion or remembering prom night-- while mostly ignoring the pre-America ""difficult"" stuff that made them interesting. This is definitely not an album aimed at young post-punk fans who just connected with the ambitious
column6: avant-leaning
column7: and recently reissued Dazzle Ships
column8: OMD's last stab at proggy pomp before they became more reliable (and less winningly weird) hit-makers. But when they want to
column9: OMD can still hit that peak of corny slow-dance grandeur
column10: as on the second part of the title track. So if getting ripped on a box of white wine and bringing on VH1 Classic is how you fill up your weeknights
column11:
here's a way to recreate the feeling at your cubicle the next day while still nominally listening to something new.

There's a considerable amount of cheekiness in the name the War on Drugs
column2: given the Philly roots-rock ramblers' preference for reverb
column3: drone
column4: and heady 10-minute jams. But with his new solo effort
column5: WOD bassist Dave Hartley takes a more sincere approach to the name game-- Nightlands is quite literally a bedroom recording experiment
column6: in which Hartley attempts to translate hazy
column7: morning-after remembrances of last night's dreams into songs that try to recapture their feeling
column8: if not their meaning. With its reliance on analog synths
column9: drum machines
column10: angelic harmonies
column11: and shape-shifting structures
column12: the music of Nightlands bears almost no relation to the music of Hartley's better-known day gig
column13: or the open-road reveries of fellow WOD member Kurt Vile-- Forget the Mantra is less War on Drugs than simply brain-on-drugs.

column1: ""Dreamy"" is often used in a rock-crit context as a synonym for serenity and ecstasy
column2: an interpretation that belies the fact that our dreams are often confusing
column3: disturbing experiences comprised of inexplicable imagery and occurrences. It's this ambiguous sensation-- hovering in that netherworld between the foreign and the familiar
column4: the comforting and the haunting-- that Hartley successfully conjures on Forget the Mantra. On the surface
column5: the album sounds less like a document of Hartley's deep-sleep exploration than a gauge of how Brian Wilson's influence on indie-rock has mutated and manifested itself over the past 15 years
column6: recalling at various times the space-age soft-rock of the High Llamas
column7: the choral pastorales of Fleet Foxes
column8: and the phantasmagoric psych-pop of Panda Bear. But Hartley proves himself adept at putting these customary melodic and harmonic devices to devious use
column9: whether setting the hypnotic
column10: repeated refrain of the opening title track to a jarring
column11: jack-hammered drum break
column12: or shattering the bucolic bliss of ""God What Have I"" with an anodyne chorus of voices asking the ominous question
column13: ""oh my
column14: oh my god
column15: what have I done?""

column1: In keeping with the dream concept
column2: Forget the Mantra turns stranger and more inscrutable the deeper you venture into it. The album's back half is given over to more amorphous
column3: lengthier pieces that interlace found spoken-word recordings with wordless harmonies
column4: hypnotic folkie finger-picking
column5: and manipulated string and synth textures. Though never quite degenerating into ""Revolution 9""-style sound-collage splatter-- Hartley carefully layers the myriad elements onto purposeful
column6: dramatic arcs
column7: particularly on the eerily compelling ""Longways Homebound
column8: 2010""-- Forget the Mantra's enigmatic second act tends to blur the line between music that's meant to evoke a dream state and music that lulls you into one. But
column9: ponderous lapses aside
column10: Nightlands' psychic terrain is still a nice place to visit
column11:
even if you wouldn't want to spend the whole night there.

Dubstep in 2010 is in a similar position to drum and bass a decade ago: stylistically full-grown and perhaps exhausted
column2: its experimental wing drifting into other niches while the remaining core wonders whether the music has already peaked. It's the perfect moment in which to launch an assault on the charts: liberated from any drive for formal innovation
column3: and whittled down to a simple and recognizable repetitive groove formula
column4: dubstep can now inhabit a variety of pop guises while avoiding the identity crisis such moves would have provoked five years ago.

column1: Enter Magnetic Man
column2: which appropriately enough is something of a dubstep supergroup comprising Benga and Skream (perhaps the scene's two most broadly popular producers)
column3: together with Artwork
column4: who've been largely silent since their trend-setting 2002 EP Red. Notwithstanding the aggregated pedigree
column5: Magnetic Man feels like a Benga-helmed affair
column6: and most of the group's eponymous album comes on like a fleshed-out
column7: glossy take on Benga's 2008 album
column8: Diary of an Afro Warrior. The good news for dubstep fans is that this self-consciously sleek and glossy makeover doesn't really depart from the template that album established. The bad news is
column9: well
column10: that is the bad news: Benga's honed brand of lurching
column11: constipated grooves represents dubstep at its most enervated and unappealing; the widely held conviction that this template represents dubstep at its most crossover-friendly is simply further evidence that audiences are unhealthily enamored with buzzing ugliness right now (file it all next to David Guetta-produced R&B).

column1: If Magnetic Man remains a substantially better album than Diary of Afro Warrior
column2: it's because there's more going on than just Benga's boring beatwork. Having abandoned any pretense at rhythmic tension or novelty
column3: the group instead focuses on constructing trebly
column4: fleshy synthesizer melodies cribbed from mid-00s electro-house (and
column5: by extension
column6: trance). The results vaguely recall the lush but metallic pop-techno of Ellen Allien & Apparat's Orchestra of Bubbles. This is a sensible direction for populist dubstep
column7: and Magnetic Man concoct appropriately weedy synth arpeggios and moody atmospherics
column8: though the psuedo-classical motifs on ""Flying Into Tokyo"" and ""Karma Crazy"" trip into hamfisted territory. Ultimately
column9: though
column10: these attempts at melodic levity remain constrained by leaden beats and the boom/bust dynamics of the arrangements
column11: whose cyclical predictability results in most of the tunes' exhausting their welcome within minutes.

column1: Things go better on the vocal tracks
column2: where that same predictable structure usefully frames verses and choruses
column3: in the process receiving a revitalized sense of purpose. The excellent ""Crossover"" pits the wearying grind of the bass-driven groove against Katy B's soft
column4: nurturing vocals
column5: capturing musically the suggestion of temporary sanctuary from endless struggle that Katy paints lyrically. This is the sort of songwork that dubstep facilitates best-- unless it's the cocksure swagger of Rihanna's dubstep-influenced ""Wait Your Turn""
column6: here represented by the grim ""Fire"" featuring Ms. Dynamite providing stern ragga chat. Consistent with dubstep's preferred range of emotions
column7: the songs on Magnetic Man are all variations on a military march
column8: choosing dogged determination
column9: smouldering aggression
column10: or vexed frustration over love or lust.

column1: Maybe it's not romance that dubstep has difficulty accommodating so much as release-- the ecstatic affirmation that is dance-pop's raison d'etre. The exception that proves the rule on both counts is the vibrant ""Perfect Stranger""
column2: a heady collision of moody halfstep R&B verses and breakbeat-driven old-skool rave choruses
column3: with Katy B again handling vocal duties with airy grace. ""Perfect Stranger"" may depart from dubstep's formal sonic signposts
column4: but its explosive releases of rhythmic vitality capture perfectly the appeal of uptempo dubstep at its best
column5: while underscoring the frustrating limitations and contradictions of the rest of the album. Magnetic Man's arrangements may proudly flaunt dance-pop's most universal qualities
column6:
but their efforts remain mere gestures so long as their beats continue to stare so resentfully in the opposite direction.

'DFA']|2010-11-15 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:08.133565|"

For a group whose albums often seem like work of one studio-perfectionist mastermind
column4: LCD Soundsystem have turned out to be one of the greatest live bands of the last decade. In fact
column5: they do just about everything a great live band-- especially a great live dance band-- should do. Known to stretch their songs out to ""special disco version"" lengths
column6: they're able to bring audiences from simmering anticipation to hands-up screaming release in the span of a song
column7: and then do it again. And then again. Like Remain in Light-era Talking Heads
column8: the closest comparison to LCD at their current ""locked-in but loose"" onstage peak
column9: they could release a live album that might offer equal thrills to their studio discs.

column1: But London Sessions is not LCD's The Name of This Band is Talking Heads
column2: and at least one reason why not is because live in-studio sessions like this one tend to capture artists in a slightly different mode than during a full-on concert
column3: where a band can feed off the energy of thousands of sweat-soaked fans. The band mentions iconic BBC radio host John Peel's legendary program when talking about the album for a reason: Like those old Peel sessions
column4: this set finds the band offering tighter
column5: cleaner
column6: more focused versions of their live staples
column7: running through all nine songs with an electrifying
column8: stripped-down effortlessness.

column1: Here
column2: James Murphy proves that even without the thick
column3: enveloping sound his production chops lent This Is Happening
column4: he can match his heroes' delivery: His rare ability to snap from mordant humor to affecting pathos comes through loud and clear with back-to-back takes on ""Daft Punk Is Playing at My House"" and ""All My Friends"". But as great of a frontman as he is
column5: LCD's shit-hot rhythm section
column6: anchored by drummer Pat Mahoney and ex-!!! member Tyler Pope
column7: nearly steals the spotlight. Their interplay is as mesmerizing to listen to here (especially those perfectly timed keyboard jolts that spike the intensity of ""Get Innocuous"" just a little higher each time) as it is to watch in person. And for a kinda-sorta disco band
column8: they tear the roof off in a live-and-loud way. The sense of possible frenzy that lurks behind the slightly-too-hot ""metronomic"" groove of ""Us V Them"" builds to an edge-of-control climax that's even more thrilling than if the band had actually spun into a freakout.

column1: Of course
column2: since these tracks aren't exactly radical live reconstructions
column3: there aren't a ton of surprises on London Sessions. But it's still a wonder to hear a band this committed
column4: this on its game
column5: without the studio tweaks. Plus
column6: you've got to consider what a debased format LCD is working with here. The number of actually transcendent live records-- whether recorded at a radio station or in an arena-- is almost laughably small considering how many exist. This one's a gift
column7:
the second LCD's given us this year.

The first installment in !K7's Tapes series
column2: curated by the Rapture
column3: was an eclectic mix of retro and recent club-ready material that shed light on the band's feral beginnings as well as their more carefully pruned popwise output. It established a precedent for the Berlin-based electronic label's series: at their best
column4: these compilations serve as both a living document of the artist's inspirations and the progression of their sound
column5: as well as a testament to their tastemaking abilities.

column1: Milo Cordell
column2: one half of the post-Britpop duo the Big Pink
column3: uses this second entry in the Tapes series as an introduction to the sounds gathered under the loose banner of witch house. Showcasing bands like Salem
column4: GR†LL GR†LL
column5: oOoOO
column6: and Balam Acab
column7: Cordell mostly proves just how hard he's pressed his ear to the ground in 2010. For the most part
column8: he picks some of the juiciest bits of the syrupy
column9: spooked-out electronic movement: From Balam Acab's gorgeous
column10: ethereal ""See Birds (Moon)"" to the monstrous
column11: chillingly drab early Salem cut ""Dirt""
column12: it's clear that Cordell is no casual listener
column13: able to prudently pluck from several sides of the sound's spectrum. When he's at his best
column14: his curatorial skills may even provoke a bit of second-guessing from the genre's naysayers-- the appeal of this music is easy to understand.

column1: The problem is
column2: the music is presented with a blend of other styles; it's too haphazard to define a clear statement. Cordell himself admits that much of this music ""has never been released on a CD
column3: it's just out there on the Internet."" And yet he fails to grasp the irony of combining such diverse elements here: This is not music crafted for a DJ-style mix; its chilly sound is simply better suited to floating in the cold
column4: crystalizing ethers of cyberspace. By haphazardly lumping it in with material that has nothing to do with witch house per se
column5: a lot of its impact is lost.

column1: Cordell includes choice bits of dubstep (Joker's bounce epic ""Snake Eater"")
column2: minimalist electro (Actress' ""Hubble"")
column3: and a few oddball tracks that
column4: even at their most ridiculously lame (Sewn Leather's glue-huffing-comedown jam ""Smoke Ov the Pvnk"")
column5: feel entertaining. But aside from the inclusion of like-minded artists the xx and Gang Gang Dance (their excellent remix of the Big Pink's ""Velvet"" makes an appearance)
column6: it's anyone's guess as to why the the Big Pink moniker is on the front of this thing-- there's no consistency to tie it to a single group's sound. Instead
column7: this installment of Tapes feels like the decent mix of a guy with good taste
column8: a broadband connection
column9:
and a little experience with the crossfade knob.

"|14834.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14834-tapes/|5.8|Zach Kelly

column3: so can you please save it? Thank you."" That's how Kevin Drew
column4: frontman for Toronto indie rock super collective Broken Social Scene
column5: opened what would become K.C. Accidental's very first recording
column6: an answering machine sketch-turned-jam that he and longtime bandmate Charles Spearin slyly called ""Kev's Message For Charlie"". That was back in 1996. Drew began to play a very simple
column7: one-finger keyboard melody
column8: and Spearin added additional instrumentation. A bass figure there
column9: a few liquid guitar chords here
column10: a bit of brushed snare drum
column11: and wham-- a song was born in such an unexpected
column12: accidental way that it prompted Drew and Spearin to continue recording together. The whole thing lasts only two-and-half minutes
column13: but it's magic: You can hear the bedrock of what would become Broken Social Scene as it began to form.

column1: ""Kev's Message For Charlie"" was one part of K.C. Accidental's first album
column2: Captured Anthems For an Empty Bathtub. That six-song
column3: self-released record has been paired with the follow-up LP
column4: Anthems For the Could've Bin Pills
column5: and is being given a deluxe wide release via Drew's Arts & Crafts imprint. Empty Bathtub was recorded by Spearin and Drew in the latter's childhood bedroom over the course of five days. It's by far the moodier and less focused of the two efforts
column6: though again
column7: in the overdriven guitar charge of opener ""Nancy and the Girdle Boy"" or loose
column8: funereal feel of ""Save the Last Breath for Me""
column9: a great deal of early chemistry between Drew and Spearin can be heard on tape. That's not so much the case in the jazz strokes of ""Something For Chicago"" or trance-y ""Anorexic He-Man""
column10: two other experiments that never really take hold or display much synergy.

column1: For Could've Bin Pill
column2: the two upgraded their studio setup and hunkered down in a friend's living room. Rather than play all the instruments themselves (save for the trumpet work of BSS's Jimmy Shaw)
column3: they added further layers from future BSS members Justin Peroff
column4: Emily Haines
column5: and Jason Collett. Haines actually provides vocals in a duet with Drew on ""Them (Pop Song #3333)""
column6: his very first recording as a vocalist. The additions make for a more muscular unit
column7: one whose expanse you can hear stretch and congeal nicely across every cut. As a whole
column8: that approach provides a listenable
column9: clear bridge to You Forgot It in People and onward. ""Instrumental Died in the Bathtub and Took the Daydreams With It"" builds naturally and beautifully
column10: its guitar and violin parts constantly on the climb. And ""Silverfish Eyelashes"" swaps those guitars for washed-out synths
column11: daisy chaining them with sad-eyed string flourishes to elegant
column12: pre-Postal Service effect. Though the improvisational feel is still present here throughout
column13: the focus that galvanizes every second more or less belies the original
column14: ""accidental"" nature from which they took their name. Full-bodied
column15:
completely immersive songs like the gauzy ""Ruined in 84"" don't so much capture an impromptu experiment as they capture a band at work.

Norway's Supersilent is a supremely questing experimental jazz unit. Whether playing live or recording a new entry in their numbered series of albums for Rune Grammofon/ECM
column2: they don't rehearse or make plans. Instead
column3: they convene and explore
column4: following their collective muse into sound-worlds that seldom fail to seem conceptually centered
column5: despite their spontaneous nature. And in general
column6: I'm game to follow them wherever they go. But they lost me for a minute with Supersilent 9
column7: which sounded like someone had fallen asleep on the keys of a Hammond organ. To be fair
column8: the quartet had recently become a trio with the departure of drummer Jarle Vespestad
column9: and perhaps they were adjusting to the new line-up. Happily
column10: they've bounced back strong for 10 and 11. The latter is a mite uneven
column11: collecting leftovers from the sessions for Supersilent 8 in a vinyl-only format. The former is arguably the finest and most coherent piece of music they've ever recorded.

column1: After 12 years together
column2: it seemed as if Supersilent had tried everything under the sun
column3: from the spattering noise of their early issues to the ambient-inclined 5 to the daunting electro-acoustic jazz of 8. But on 10
column4: they reveal a new direction that would be obvious for anyone else but is counterintuitive for them: a more acoustic
column5: lyrical
column6: almost traditional approach. As much as I admire their more ""difficult"" works
column7: 10 is not only their most listenable record
column8: but their bravest
column9: clearing away the usual thickets of disturbance to let the technical skill and emotional acuity of the players shine through. The elegant interplay between Ståle Storløkken's often-chromatic Steinway piano and Arve Henriksen's talkative trumpet
column10: with its inimitably airy yet ragged timbre
column11: is front and center. As if in recognition of something special happening
column12: producer Deathprod keeps a low profile
column13: subtly coloring the music with quietly cosmic keyboards and hushed ambiance. The result is more similar to Henriksen's beautiful album Cartography than anything in the Supersilent catalog
column14: with the same cold
column15: thin air and heart-wrenching
column16: effortlessly modulated motifs. Minimal ambient and noise passages knit together moving set pieces like the eerie ""10.3""
column17: the pliant ""10.6""
column18: and the penetratingly wistful ""10.8"".

column1: But lest anyone think that Supersilent have gone soft
column2: 11 opens with a long and seemingly breakbeat-inspired passage of electronic mayhem. This is one of the aforementioned disturbances they favor
column3: and it seems a right mess when compared to the impeccable poise of 10. But if you persevere through this nerve-jangling start
column4: you'll be treated to a slow and expressive solo from Henriksen that carries into a more satisfying section of power electronics and fractured beats. Shades of postmodern lounge and rock music ensue
column5: and the album manages to achieve an undeniable if broken throughline despite the disparate nature of its parts. If it feels a bit forced
column6: it also represents the sort of challenging music for which many listeners value Supersilent. But it's 10 that represents a new chapter for the group
column7: without longtime collaborator Vespestad
column8: and so it's the ideal moment to ask: What are all these numbers adding up to? So far
column9: the answer is a body of work that can be difficult or forthcoming
column10: beautiful or ugly
column11: but never anything short of fully committed. And the sequence isn't finished yet. Supersilent 12 has already been announced
column12: and after the re-centering maneuvers of 9
column14: and 11
column15:
who knows where they'll end up next.

column18: and the penetratingly wistful ""10.8"".

column1: But lest anyone think that Supersilent have gone soft
column2: 11 opens with a long and seemingly breakbeat-inspired passage of electronic mayhem. This is one of the aforementioned disturbances they favor
column3: and it seems a right mess when compared to the impeccable poise of 10. But if you persevere through this nerve-jangling start
column4: you'll be treated to a slow and expressive solo from Henriksen that carries into a more satisfying section of power electronics and fractured beats. Shades of postmodern lounge and rock music ensue
column5: and the album manages to achieve an undeniable if broken throughline despite the disparate nature of its parts. If it feels a bit forced
column6: it also represents the sort of challenging music for which many listeners value Supersilent. But it's 10 that represents a new chapter for the group
column7: without longtime collaborator Vespestad
column8: and so it's the ideal moment to ask: What are all these numbers adding up to? So far
column9: the answer is a body of work that can be difficult or forthcoming
column10: beautiful or ugly
column11: but never anything short of fully committed. And the sequence isn't finished yet. Supersilent 12 has already been announced
column12: and after the re-centering maneuvers of 9
column14: and 11
column15:
who knows where they'll end up next.

0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15931/homepage_large.bc10972c.jpg|Quarters|5889.0|Truckasauras|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fourthcity']|2010-11-15 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:10.421194|"

Even if you had no clue what terms like ""chiptunes"" or ""circuit bending"" meant back in 2008
column2: the packaging of Truckasauras' <i>Tea Parties
column3: Guns & Valor gave you an accurate picture of their aesthetic: ""The Simpsons""
column4: monster trucks
column5: neon paint
column6: Nintendo
column7: the WWF. So what's with the Bleach­-like cover of Quarters? Is the Seattle quartet trying to cement its place in the city's musical legacy
column8: or
column9: gasp! trying to present themselves as ""serious artists?"" Of course
column10: a closer look at the grayscale image shows the group amidst a gang of empty liquor bottles
column11: skateboards
column12: and assorted video game equipment.

column1: In fact
column2: Quarters might be even more of a straight-up party record than its predecessor
column3: a welcome relief that Truckasauras aren't trying to overcompensate for working within a niche that's almost entirely defined by its novelty. While ""instrumental hip-hop"" often brings to mind Dilla heads or the bugged-out experimentalism of the Brainfeeder scene
column4: Truckasauras have always put themselves forth unironically as ""crunk."" It's not the most accurate description
column5: but they do share a sort of kinship with more slithery but no less hedonistic Atlanta sounds
column6: as tracks like ""Dom P on Your Backneck"" and ""Show These People Who's Springstein (Yes We Can)"" boast enough 808 and B-A-S-S bass to soundtrack a night cruise to Magic City.

column1: Tea Parties turned out to be enduring even after you got past the Contra and Ultimate Warrior jokes
column2: in large part because its sonics explored a fragile
column3: low-grade beauty. That aspect is still on Quarters
column4: though they arrive at it differently
column5: locating more placid drones while maintaining a rhythmic force. If the prickly
column6: pinwheeling beeps at the outset of ""No More Nerds
column7: Comanche Brancho"" were to simply repeat throughout
column8: it would likely drive you batshit
column9: but it becomes something more like a percussive effect under the quacking bass-- it's not far off from Discovery's side B or even Dâm-Funk for its honest appropriation of roller rink chintz.

column1: While Quarters is ultimately a refinement of Truckasauras' sound
column2: it's possible that some might be mildly let down as they focus more on craftsmanship than showmanship-- once again
column3: the overall packaging of this stuff is important
column4: and the inherent humor sometimes only manifests itself in the song titles
column5: instead of in the wow factor of recognizing a sample from Operation Wolf. But if the primary battle that Truckasauras face is avoiding redundancy while still being a genre of one
column6:
credit them for having the upper hand on Quarters.

column2:
'Glacial Pace']|2010-11-12 00:00:00|2002|2016-06-11 17:37:11.041246|"

Isaac Brock and his friends were teenagers when they wrote the songs on Sad Sappy Sucker. Think about the shitty poems you wrote when you were young (I have one that plagiarizes Green Day's ""Longview""!) and then listen to the splintered and elusive songs collected on this Modest Mouse release. Clearly
column3: Brock had a head start on seeing things differently from the rest of us.

column1: That is one of the more profound takeaways from the so-called Great Lost Modest Mouse album
column2: a 24-track collection of occasionally brilliant odds and ends that was spared the fate of being the band's introduction to the world. Delays forced them to move on and record This Is a Long Drive for Someone With Nothing to Think About before Sad Sappy Sucker could be released. From a historical vantage point
column3: they lucked out-- Sucker has its moments
column4: but they would take a quantum leap from here to This Is a Long Drive.

column1: Nonetheless
column2: a few facets of Modest Mouse's unmistakable sound glint through on these songs
column3: recorded with Calvin Johnson for K Records. There are those eerily pinging bent guitar harmonics
column4: for one
column5: a noise that sounded entirely alien at the time
column6: as well as the way the guitar and bass circled warily around each other without locking
column7: two halves of an endlessly spiraling argument. Jeremiah Green was already an astoundingly talented drummer
column8: one who could fill every inch of available space without overwhelming Brock's harmonically simple songs.

column1: And Brock-- well
column2: first of all
column3: he sounds astoundingly young. His lisp
column4: which would grow a little less noticeable over time
column5: is almost painfully pronounced on Sad Sappy Sucker-- ""Mice Eat Cheese""'s title is rendered ""mithe eat cheethe."" His singing is frail and nervous
column6: and the words are often obscured by mumbling. The lyrics that do surface are like little placeholders for all of Brock's future lyrical obsessions-- ""you can see that birds and worms don't get along
column7: in ""Worms Vs. Birds""; ""Looks like accounting's not accountable for anything or anyone at all/ Jonny took the fall
column8: he yelps in ""Race Car Grin You Ain't No Landmark"". The ringing opening guitar figure for ""It Always Rains on a Picnic"" would pop up almost unchanged on Long Drive's ""Talking Shit About a Pretty Sunset""-- in fact
column9: the former song sounds like a dry run for the latter. It's absorbing listening
column10: but hardly consequential.

column1: When Sad Sappy Sucker first saw release in 2001
column2: on the heels of the monumental The Moon & Antarctica
column3: it felt more like a yellowing sketchbook of curiosities bequeathed to diehard fans than a proper album. Nine years later
column4: now on Brock's Glacial Pace label
column5: it still feels that way. It's being reissued at the same time as the 1997 EP The Fruit That Ate Itself
column6: and taken together
column7: you get a pleasantly bracing aerial view of a young band's gradual development. The Fruit That Ate Itself has some of the band's most abrasive moments-- the title track
column8: in particular
column9: is harrowing
column10: just a descending bassline and Brock's screaming his unhinged napkin poetry (""Take a drive in the wrong hand lane/ Got bad breath talking about fresh rain"") until he's hoarse. But it also had the first hints of the band's fascination with sound effects and overdubs-- the skirling backwards guitars that show up repeatedly point to the frozen-tundra ambience of their later works.

column1: Brock and his bandmates didn't alter a thing for these reissues; there are no bonus tracks
column2: no new songs. Neither of them is an essential Modest Mouse release
column3: but if they provide anything new to us in 2010
column4: it's a useful window back into the pre-Internet era of indie rock. The songs on Sad Sappy Sucker dribbled their way out into the world on 7""s and compilations-- 500 or 1
column5: 000 people bought them
column6: and that was exactly the right audience for the music. Modest Mouse then moved on to the next project
column7: honing their voice. In the Internet hothouse
column8: improving your way into a larger audience is a more fitful
column9: lurching affair
column10: one that often happens in combustible bursts. For a young
column11: unsteady group like Modest Mouse
column12: being able to kick around the Pacific Northwest while working on their songwriting feels crucial to their development-- they had a long way to go from Sad Sappy Sucker to The Lonesome Crowded West and The Moon & Antarctica
column13: and it's hard to imagine they would have gotten there the same way today.  Obscurity smarts
column14:
but sometimes it can be a useful cocoon.

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15939/homepage_large.48a29032.jpg|BLACKENEDWHITE|29288.0|MellowHype|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['self-released']|2010-11-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:11.683481|"

As Straight Outta Compton nears its 25th birthday
column2: it's nearly impossible for gangsta rap music to be legitimately shocking. We've heard thousands of drug-dealing tall tales
column3: bloody murder threats
column4: and clinically minded sex propositions
column5: and these days that stuff just breezes past. If anything
column6: the Young Jeezys of the world are less precise and less disquieting than the Spice 1s of old. So when L.A.'s teenage Odd Future crew snarled its way into the public consciousness earlier this year
column7: the effect was truly jarring-- in part because it was so unfamiliar. Here are 19-year-old kids talking about sniffing coke and giggling about rape-- rec-room shit-talk that stings like a slap to the face. Crew leader Tyler
column8: the Creator gargles kidnapping threats in a burned-out rasp way beyond his 19 years. Earl Sweatshirt
column9: the crew's missing-in-action 16-year-old cult hero
column10: tells you all about the chopped-up girl and cop locked up in the trunk of the car he doesn't have a learner's permit to drive. So when the OF duo MellowHype open their new full-length with a story about blowing off a final exam
column11: it's a relief in a full-body sigh sort of way. Compared to their crewmates
column12: these kids are downright cuddly.

column1: Hodgy Beats
column2: the rapping half of MellowHype
column3: is a Wiz Khalifa stoner-rap type who raps in a high
column4: spaced-out mutter that still makes him sound way more alive than the crew's other resident stoner
column5: the somnolent Domo Genesis. He's not soft-- ""ligaments will dissolve"" is a typical threat
column6: and he has no problems rapping over gun sounds on a track called ""Gun Sounds"". On ""Loco""
column7: he namechecks 1960s Black Panthers with authority. But compared to a nutcase like Tyler
column8: he's actually humane. Tyler makes two appearances on BLACKENEDWHITE. On the first
column9: he leaves six cops dead. On the second
column10: he offers up this: ""Fingers in the middle of bitches' bodacious buttcracks/ Enough fuckin' atheist rappers to get a nun slapped."" This is Tyler on his best behavior
column11: but these are still the two gnarliest moments on the full-length. They're also the two most immediately arresting. With his laid-back approach
column12: Hodgy can be a weird fit for Odd Future-- a technically sound rapper who can adapt to a lot of different styles but who never sounds like a paradigm-shifter. He's a strong supporting player but not much of a lead. So it's a good thing Left Brain
column13: the other half of the group
column14: is around.

column1: Left Brain
column2: who doesn't rap
column3: is every bit the lo-fi beat experimentalist that Tyler is. The two-minute album opener ""Primo"" has great little keyboard plinks interrupting smeary synth wooze before everything slows down into a glitched-out
column4: screwed-up crawl. That's a whole lot of movement for a two-minute introductory track
column5: but it's typical of the whole record. Left Brain's tracks always mesmerize
column6: but they never sit still. ""Gun Sounds""
column7: ""Dead Deputy""
column8: and ""Fuck the Police"" all work as muffled
column9: homemade versions of the apocalyptic crunk bangers that Lex Luger makes for Waka Flocka Flame. ""Brain"" and ""Chordaroy"" are damaged
column10: decayed takes on the lush
column11: string-drenched yacht rap that the Neptunes have been making for a few years. ""Loaded"" is frankly jaw-dropping
column12: an evil blaring creep that sounds like what might happen if an ominous synth-drone type like Oneohtrix Point Never tried making rap beats. (Note to Oneohtrix Point Never: Try making rap beats.)

column1: Parts of BLACKENEDWHITE point toward what might happen when the Odd Future kids leave their terrifying self-created universe and engage with the world at large-- something that's almost inevitable now that major labels are knocking down their doors. ""Hell"" has a beat that's made partially out of someone muttering ""what the hell"" on a loop
column2: but it also has an honest-to-god R&B chorus
column3: the first I've heard from these guys. After the crew has killed god knows how many women on tracks
column4: bonus track ""Based"" features C. Renee
column5: the first female rapper I've heard on an Odd Future song. (The R&B chorus doesn't really work; the C. Renee verse absolutely does.)

column1: But even as it nods toward accessibility
column2: BLACKENEDWHITE works as yet another fascinating
column3: bizarre
column4: expectation-defying piece of work from a group of young artists who don't make anything else. And unlike the others
column5: this one features zero rape threats. For neophytes
column6: Tyler's Bastard is still the place to start; he's the group's figurehead and most talented member
column7: and you really have to confront how fucked up these kids are if you have any interest in engaging them. But BLACKENEDWHITE pushes them closer to humanity without sacrificing the weirdness that's so central to their appeal. They're not out of surprises yet
column8:
and they probably won't be for a long time.

column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Hippos in Tanks']|2010-11-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:12.099702|"

When the first Games tracks started surfacing online earlier this year
column3: people doubted whether Daniel Lopatin (aka Oneohtrix Point Never) was actually behind them. As OPN
column4: Lopatin makes pretty serious
column5: open-ended synth drones
column6: and tracks like ""Planet Party"" felt a little too quirky to be his. But as time went on and we found out that Games was in fact a collaboration between Lopatin and longtime buddy Joel Ford of Tigercity
column7: the project started to make more sense. Games are still about evocative synth music
column8: but this time they're focused on nostalgia and recreating forgotten 80s production techniques.

column1: The vibe they're after isn't easy to pinpoint
column2: but you know it when you hear it. It's that 80s sound-- the cheesy mechanical pop that lived in commercials
column3: movie soundtracks
column4: and arcades. It's laser tag music
column5: Revenge of the Nerds music. Games cop that style and make glitchy electro jams from it
column6: and the appealing thing about these guys is how thoroughly they inhabit the sound. Partly it's equipment. They've got an arsenal of analog synths
column7: and are able to make these instruments feel not just vintage but almost aged
column8: like something you'd hear on a record found deep in the used bin.

column1: The individual tracks that comprise That We Can Play are all pretty solid
column2: and if you've followed the band you probably already know some of them. To me
column3: the standout is still ""Planet Party""
column4: just an unapologetic slice of Apple IIe funk. Over a clipped backing beat and chopped vocal samples
column5: Games bend their synths as if using wah-wah pedals
column6: giving the track this great wobbly whine. Newer cut ""Strawberry Skies""
column7: featuring Brooklyn singer/producer Laurel Halo on vocals
column8: is also very good
column9: a super-bouncy new age workout that brings to mind Bananarama's ""Cruel Summer"". Gatekeeper's remix on the backend nicely ups the darkness
column10: slowing the song down and adding ominous horror synths.

column1: A few of the other tracks here
column2: like the mostly instrumental ""Midi Drift"" and ""Shadows in Bloom"" aren't as melodically strong but do fit within the larger scheme. The EP's a little on the short side and Games do have more tracks than are included here; it might've been nice had they rounded it out with ""Everything Is Working"" and ""Heartlands"". That's a minor complaint
column3: though
column4: and ultimately the record is a quirky and technical treat. Back in August
column5: Games told us an inspiration for the project was ""anything that reminds us of our dads working."" Silly
column6:
but it sounds like they had fun making it. That carries over to the listening experience.

"|14840.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14840-that-we-can-play-ep/|7.6|Joe Colly

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15948/homepage_large.db889cf4.jpg|Nothing Fits|6917.0|Tyvek|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['In the Red']|2010-11-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:12.641833|"

Full of half-hearted fuzz riffs and tossed-off two-note vocals
column2: Tyvek's self-titled debut made for great recession-era listening. In a world suddenly crowded with dying malls
column3: half-built condos
column4: and underwater McMansions
column5: the Detroit basement-punks' wobbly songwriting sounded weirdly poignant. And the name-- copped from the ubiquitous polyethylene house-wrap-- didn't hurt either. But unlike the Midwestern punks that came before them-- the Stooges
column6: the Electric Eels
column7: Negative Approach
column8: to name a few-- Tyvek never seemed particularly cheesed-off about their surroundings. The rotating cast of collaborators fronted by guitarist/singer Kevin Boyer was agitated and noisy
column9: but never aggressive. Something must be getting to them
column10: though; on Nothing Fits
column11: Tyvek are pissed-off.

column1: The band's new full-length is tight
column2: snotty
column3: and pogo-worthy. The mellow instrumental snippets that padded the last LP are long gone. Now there's only the clacking of drumsticks to signal the next onslaught of distortion and motor-mouthed shouting. At some point in the past year
column4: Tyvek decided to go hardcore. As a result
column5: they nail the burnt-out 'burbs imagery better than ever. ""Underwater institution/ Silent hallways vacant always endless yards of paper trails/ Medications healthy systems baby doctors cut their tails
column6: shouts Boyer over chunky power chords on ""Underwater 1""
column7: ticking off his list of gripes. In the refrain
column8: he boils it all down to one perfect image of a ""Safeway bag now sticking to my shoe."" ""Frustration Rock""
column9: the band's original aggro anthem
column10: sounds kind of nerdy in comparison.

column1: Tyvek's first full-length was cobbled together from a smorgasbord of the bands favorite tapes-- practice takes and basement jams full of lo-fi gristle. This time around
column2: Tyvek spent some money. Nothing Fits is the band's first release to be recorded in an actual studio
column3: and the result is a shorter
column4: more focused record
column5: but hardly a cleaner one. The vocals are strangled
column6: the guitars awash in amplifier buzz. On the title track-- with its unrelenting snare cracks and blizzard of treble-cranked guitars-- Tyvek come off like the Motor City's answer to Huggy Bear. It's mosh-worthy
column7: but not to an ugly
column8: macho extreme. Deep down
column9: Tyvek will always be a little bit art-school.

column1: But like the best old-time hardcore
column2: there's an element of audience participation built in via shout-along refrains. Those lyrics are clear enough: ""People in the passing lane
column3: just pricks in a car
column4: sings Boyer. ""Fuck off!"" responds an overdubbed chorus. And burried down in the din
column5: there's a tried and true posi-punk message. ""Underwater 2"" delivers the counter-arguement to Pt. 1's bleak
column6: dumpster-diving worldview: ""Want to make it something out of nothing at all/ So we've gotta pull together/ Now we gotta just start small
column7:
sings Boyer. ""It's all right/ just do what you want."" Tyvek are slackers no more.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15929/homepage_large.4d4fef36.jpg|Radioclit Presents: The Sound of Club Secousse|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Crammed Discs']|2010-11-12 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:14.202812|"

Radioclit first popped in my mailbox-- my physical mailbox
column2: back in the days when even semi-illegal DJ mixes were still sent via mail rather than uploaded to SoundCloud-- in 2005. It was the very tail end of the bootleg era
column3: and Careful Clit Clit felt like a seriously tardy but totally pleasurable contribution to the mash-up thing
column4: mixing the brief vogue for snap rap with grime
column5: techno
column6: R&B
column7: Baltimore club
column8: and a little rock. But apparently Radioclit also got bored with the mid-decade eclectic-or-die DJing style. When they truly made their name a few years later
column9: it was with a seemingly new but heartfelt devotion to African music
column10: first with the Very Best project and also by hawking various forms of African dance and pop and traditional music at their club nights.

column1: The Sound of Club Secousse documents this obsession. I've got only some idea of the tracks' local appeal
column2: or how they fit together on the air or in the clubs of their native lands. But as played by Radioclit they're capable of sating modern club audiences in the Americas
column3: Europe
column4: anywhere that post-rave culture took hold. These are thin
column5: jittery
column6: speedy beats that skip
column7: gallop
column8: and clomp around
column9: super-syncopated rhythms that feel closer to Caribbean-inflected post-rap pop
column10: the early 2000s hard-firing soca-era of UK garage in particular. And like an ultra-poppy UK garage mix
column11: everything about the set is fast
column12: fast
column13: fast. Sometimes deliriously so: Even the few melodic elements-- if you can even call these shrill bleep riffs
column14: synth curlicues
column15: and tinny little digi-highlife runs ""melodies""-- are hard to grab onto
column16: more like being pleasantly bombarded with candy-colored sound effects. ""African Air Horn Dance"" by Jusa Dementor takes the kind of chintzy air horn noises that have been blaring through rap
column17: dancehall
column18: and rave mixes for decades and uses them like synth stabs
column19: a continuous manic blare that runs through whole track. The even chintzier ice rink organ on Naty Kid's ""Sereia"" is pitched up to such an absurd degree that it sounds like Ray Manzarek cutting a happy hardcore single.

column1: When the Shangaan Electro: New Wave Dance Music from South Africa compilation came out earlier this year
column2: most pointed out its similarities (often inferred) to modern European dance music
column3: which of course came as much from the music of Africa as it did from a Euro tradition. When it comes to modern club music
column4: the lineage is (awesomely) all jumbled up
column5: and impossible to untangle. Music from Africa can have just as strong an influence from imports shipped down from the European mainland or up from Jamaica
column6: though certain site-specific stylistic touches usually shine through. So the real difference between Club Secousse and your average cheap pop techno record-- and it's a huge
column7: rainbow-tinted difference-- is the voices
column8: several decades worth of African singing styles squeezed onto a single disc. Those voices also create a vibe about as far from the human-free instrumental blandness of much ""serious"" dance music as you can get. Shouting
column9: exhorting
column10: crooning
column11: and joking
column12: these singers are what make Club Secousse a lovable party record
column13: one made by the kind of people who sound less interested in ""innovating"" than actually delivering on dance music's eternal promise of a plain ol' good time. Tempos cranked high
column14: hooks and beats made to catch ears and feet immediately
column15: voices making the whole thing pop (in both sense of the word): If your standard house
column16: techno
column17: and dubstep collections have been feeling a little dry
column18: Radioclit offers more evidence that the brightest
column19: most functionally inventive
column20:
and most plain fun dance music may just be coming out of Africa right now.
