0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15937/homepage_large.166c020f.jpg|The Lady Killer|910.0|Cee-Lo Green|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Elektra']|2010-11-11 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:14.626233|"

Cee-Lo Green and His Perfect Imperfections announced the title of the former Goodie Mob MC's 2002 solo debut. Cee-Lo Green... Is the Soul Machine declared his 2004 follow-up. And if there was still any doubt that Cee-Lo loved high concepts
column2: next came his Danger Mouse collaboration
column3: Gnarls Barkley
column4: and all of its costumed glory. Cee-Lo's third solo album is simply called The Lady Killer
column5: but given his track record it's pretty obvious who that lady killer is meant to be. Admittedly
column6: releasing a kiss-off single called ""Fuck You"" is not the usual MO of your typical ladies man
column7: but then
column8: there's nothing typical about Cee-Lo
column9: a self-styled eccentric at once rooted in the formalism of classic soul but happily subverting the rules when the mood strikes. Motown
column10: Stax
column11: Philadelphia International-- all those familiar templates are on the table
column12: but no one would ever confuse Cee-Lo's updates of revivalism or pastiche.

column1: ""Fuck You"" is such a gleefully profane
column2: giddily catchy song that frankly it didn't need a corresponding album. Still
column3: as conspicuous an anchor as ""Fuck You"" may be
column4: it's not the only thing the album has going for it. With a bevy of soul-digging producers at his beck and call (including Salaam Remi and Brit synthesizers Fraser T. Smith and Paul Epworth; Bruno Mars' crew the Smeezingtons did ""Fuck You"")
column5: Cee-Lo has a blast role-playing the old-school soul man. Never mind the fact that his non-traditional voice isn't always the right fit for the material
column6: the man's got more than enough personality to make his sideways take on mellow R&B soar.

column1: Throughout
column2: Cee-Lo manages to avoid being both too rough or too smooth; that means we get not only the buoyant Motown homage ""It's OK""
column3: but also the quiet storm seduction of ""Bodies"". He goes slinking 80s synth on ""Bright Lights Bigger City""
column4: its stalking bass line consciously echoing ""Billie Jean""
column5: but he's equally at ease transforming Band of Horses' ""No One's Gonna Love You"" into a slow jam. He cedes much of the spotlight to Paradiso Girl Lauren Bennett on ""Love Gun"" and happily shares it with Earth
column6: Wind & Fire's Philip Bailey on ""Fool For You"". The aptly named ""Old Fashioned"" is the most overtly old-school production on the disc
column7: its call-and-response backing vocals and swooning strings relics of another time
column8: but in the context of the disc it's less a flashback than a reverential reference point.

column1: If the de rigueur synthetic frills keep The Lady Killer from the visceral
column2: tactile highs of the current soul revival
column3: they do remind that artifice can often be its own reward. That is
column4: no one will put on The Lady Killer when they want to hear soul music. They'll put it on when they want to hear Cee-Lo's contemporary
column5: confident conception of soul music
column6: which isn't inherently inferior
column7: just different-- and at its best
column8: infectious. If he's not always lethal
column9:
that doesn't make him any less of an expert marksman.

"|14852.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14852-the-lady-killer/|7.3|Joshua Klein

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15936/homepage_large.8bd76a11.jpg|The Best of Suede|3970.0|Suede|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Suede Limited']|2010-11-11 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:15.228495|"

When Britpop first began to cohere as a concept and a potential mission statement
column2: no band defined its vague
column3: abstract ideas better than Suede. By the time Britpop became an actual going concern
column4: Suede were simply grandfathered in; and when the whole thing spittered to its post-Oasis peak
column5: Suede were considered washed up. But in 1993
column6: they were the creators of the fastest-selling debut LP in UK history and had been anointed as saviors of British indie before their debut single
column7: ""The Drowners""
column8: even hit the shops. This made them a natural for the British press to create ideas around
column9: and so when Select argued for a return to wit
column10: artifice
column11: glamor
column12: and British art school traditions
column13: Suede were easy avatars for those hopes.

column1: Wit
column2: artifice
column3: and glamor may have been foreign to bands like Oasis or Cast or Ocean Colour Scene
column4: but for many in 1993 they were welcome respites from a hangover of faceless
column5: egoless electronic producers and gruff
column6: dour American arena rock. On the relative margins of UK music
column7: Tricky and PJ Harvey and the Tindersticks lurked-- and the Aueturs and Saint Etienne were also considered prototypical British hopes-- but Suede could articulate the desires of the outsider while broadcasting over Radio 1. Like Pulp
column8: although perhaps neither band would be into the comparison
column9: Suede were a more acceptable and easy to grasp Big New Thing. And
column10: also like Pulp
column11: they were comfortable creating complex pop songs about human relationships-- fluid with notions of sexuality and openly pursuant of lust and animal drives in an demure indie world that favors flowers and letters. Try to imagine
column12: for example
column13: Jarvis Cocker or Brett Anderson wooing someone by making them a mixtape?

column1: Unusually
column2: however
column3: they were introspective about the whole thing too. While American glam revivalists like the Dandy Warhols wallowed in a cliché of leather jackets and rock'n'roll decadence
column4: Suede inhabited those worlds at night and seemed to be able make some sense of the consequences and their motivations in the light of day. They did epic and visceral but they also did delicate and tortured. These twin poles-- crunchy glam rock and fragile balladeering-- found them at their best. They slipped when they lived between those worlds
column5: aiming for the midtempo and MOR. As a result
column6: there's a lot to admire about Suede
column7: and a lot to ridicule
column8: and they typically go hand in hand. In the end
column9: Suede had no tribal allegiances
column10: and few nationalistic desires; they were essentially fueled by youth
column11: low-rent glamor
column12: available drugs
column13: cheap thrills
column14: and the hangover and harm one gets from their pursuit. If they romanticized anything
column15: it was being young and bored and free. Ordinariness was the enemy.

column1: The group was undoubtedly at its best during its first few years
column2: when guitarist Bernard Butler was still acting as ambitious musical foil to singer Brett Anderson's anguished
column3: romantic lyricist
column4: and this is reflected on the new 2xCD collection The Best of Suede. The first disc of the set is essentially a replay of their singles collection
column5: dropping a few late inessentials; the second is a very well-chosen selection of album tracks and B-sides from throughout their career
column6: but mostly from the era surrounding the band's 1993 self-titled debut and 1994's Dog Man Star
column7: which was finished without Butler after a walkout over creative differences.

column1: On the whole then
column2: this provides a pretty complete
column3: accurate picture of who Suede were
column4: something that would have been incomplete without that second disc. The group's singles tend to fall into the glam-rock half of their work; it's disc two that elevates this set into something special
column5: and into all the Suede that most people will ever need. In hindsight
column6: it's striking how little the band fit into the landscape that coalesced around it. The band's first five singles-- ""The Drowners""
column7: ""Metal Mickey""
column8: ""Animal Nitrate""
column9: ""So Young""
column10: and ""Stay Together""-- and their B-sides (five of which are here) foisted a charismatic
column11: direct group onto the UK's shoegaze- and Madchester-soaked indie scene of the years prior.

column1: In the end
column2: Britpop soon became about a desperate need to fit in; Suede made great pains
column3: for a time
column4: to stand out. The protracted Dog Man Star sessions left the band in a few pieces
column5: but the sheer scale and willingness to work without a net was at odds with most of their peers. The resulting record is full of pomp or pomposity depending on whom you ask
column6: and there are no apologies for it here: The band wisely include the full
column7: widescreen 20-minute run of ""The 2 of Us""
column8: ""The Asphalt World""
column9: and ""Still Life"" on this compilation.

column1: After the departure of Butler
column2: Suede again kicked against fashion: Unlike their pioneering peers
column3: however-- Blur looked west for their self-titled 1997 album; Pulp made a hangover record-- they eased into the second phase of their career by retreating to their past. When guitarist Bernard Butler split to put together one great single with David McAlmont
column4: and little else
column5: Suede hired Richard Oakes
column6: a 17-year-old Bulter acolyte located through their fanclub. Oakes did his best Butler-circa-Suede impersonation on their comeback LP Coming Up
column7: and Anderson shifted into self-parody on a few of his lyrics. The band got by on hooks and gumption
column8: and oddly became a bigger success than ever
column9: enjoying five Top 10 singles in the UK and taking off throughout the rest of Europe.

column1: Retracing their steps was naturally a sloppy affair creatively
column2: however
column3: with second-hand retreads and just plain gaffes. Another weak album later
column4: and a comeback that few remember
column5: filled out the rest of the group's career
column6: and although the cherry-picked songs from those sessions sound better here in retrospect
column7: nobody was going to break sales records or receive early hype based on the strength of something like ""Everything Will Flow"". These few songs are here to make up the numbers and provide a complete picture. And this is a complete picture: This is one of the most warts-and-all bands of our time-- their risk/reward divide was off the charts. In today's more timid climate
column8:
it would be almost unthinkable.

"|14853.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14853-the-best-of-suede/|8.7|Scott Plagenhoef

column1: 0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15916/homepage_large.68625ed2.jpg|Sports|29185.0|Weekend|['Rock'
column3: the words ""lo-fi"" and ""noise"" have been frequently and inaccurately associated with each other. Although there were dollops of feedback to be found in 2008's ""Lo-Fi Boom"" (Vivian Girls
column4: Times New Viking
column5: Eat Skull)
column6: these days the term more often defines the recent (and
column7: seemingly
column8: never-ending) crop of Brooklyn and New Jersey-based bands whose fey
column9: slackened guitar rock sounds distanced from where the listener is at that very moment. This has a good deal to do with the bands' basement recording techniques
column10: as well as the liberal use of reverb and echo whenever possible. The music's prepared to sound dusty and sepia-toned
column11: even if it's fresh off the mastering boards
column12: and it's an approach that's losing its charm fast.

column1: Weekend
column2: then
column3: are arriving at just the right time. Although no one's going to mistake the San Francisco noise-pop trio's Slumberland debut
column4: Sports
column5: for an album produced at Abbey Road
column6: the record is everything that a lot of modern indie rock is frequently failing to be in 2010: loud
column7: immediate
column8: and engaging
column9: with a strong melodic sense of songwriting to tie it all together. That last facet could just as easily be applied to a number of bands in San Francisco
column10: a location that's quickly threatening to eclipse Brooklyn in the ranks of regional talent. There are a few bands that certainly share similar sonic elements (the Fresh & Onlys
column11: Ty Segall
column12: Girls
column13: and a good deal of the Castle Face garage-rock scene)
column14: but many of these bands otherwise possess their own distinctive brand of sound and songcraft.

column1: Weekend's cited influences are relatively straightforward and unsurprising once you're familiar with their sound: Loveless
column2: Unknown Pleasures
column3: Disintegration
column4: Psychocandy. Sometimes
column5: those influences quite literally rear their head on Sports-- the Joy Division-recalling misery of ""Landscape""
column6: the JAMC dirty-needle noise bursts of ""Youth Haunts""-- but mostly
column7: the band's innate compositional skills and excellent melodic ears are a testament to their love for the accessible ""canon"" albums like the ones mentioned within the genre the band's devoted to.

column1: This is a Slumberland release
column2: so there's a good deal of fuzz-pop here
column3: too; however
column4: moments that recall that still in-vogue sound aren't presented as-is-- rather
column5: they're recontextualized to fit Weekend's dense
column6: screeching sonic swirl. In case you haven't gotten it yet
column7: Sports is loud as all hell
column8: as even the sweetest melodies (the doe-eyed blare of ""End Times""
column9: especially) are surrounded with a maelstrom of negative sonic waves
column10: which can be attributed to the band's focus on the lower end of things.

column1: Despite its dark
column2: static-charged sound
column3: Sports carries a sense of longing and sad-eyed struggle as well. This is expressed through Shaun Durkan's droning flail of a voice
column4: which remains unintelligible for a good deal of the record but revs up with clarity at key phrases: ""I awoke from a coma summer
column5: ""Something deep inside of me turned on"" Underneath it all
column6: the melodies sound wistful
column7: and at times
column8: nostalgic. The latter word's earned a negative connotation over the past 18 months or so
column9: as much of indie's fixations have turned to unearned remembrances of past times
column10: like old photographs picked up at a garage sale. Think of Sports
column11: then
column12:
as a freshly taken Polaroid with a lit cigarette stuck straight in the middle of it-- a burning hole bridging the distance between then and right now.

Both pastoral and a bit generic
column2: the name Electric Sunset could have been spit out of a random indie name generator. But while the sun-dappled synths
column3: warm guitar tones
column4: and smeared vocals of Nic Zwart's latest project are familiar building blocks
column5: the sum total of this self-titled debut is more than mere pastiche.

column1: Zwart is best known as the frontman for the recently disbanded Desolation Wilderness
column2: which had an unhurried
column3: Galaxie 500-inspired delivery. Both of that group's main albums
column4: New Universe and White Light Strobing
column5: were tranquil with suggestions of more exuberant
column6: poppy songwriting either outright or under the surface. Zwart takes steps into more energetic and engaging territory on Electric Sunset
column7: dialing up tempos and introducing driving interplay between stripped-down guitar melodies and synths. You can hear his musical progression on ""Morning City""
column8: with passages of echoing  vocals setting up gentle peaks with crosscurrents of guitar. He still knows how to linger on a note
column9: like the organ-like tones and bass hum of the slow burning ""Soda""
column10: but there's more lift and propulsion with his solo project
column11: airy instead of just misty.

column1: It's soft-focus psychedelic pop that can feel suspended as it gets blissed-out
column2: since Zwart's simple and gradual rhythms don't offer many surprises
column3: and his voice
column4: placed a bit back in the mix
column5: could be more engaging. For every track that develops forward momentum-- ""Palace"" recalls the bubbly sheen and exuberance of Atlas Sound's ""Walkabout""
column6: and ""Future Dream"" also achieves a Bradford Cox vibe-- there are parts that feel a bit restrained. Zwart's melodies often settle into a slow-motion beauty
column7: but as a whole they'd benefit from a bit more kick
column8: a few explosions instead of just the big crescendos. The album's nine songs clock in at a concise 32 minutes
column9: but the impression they leave is more general.

column1: Created as Zwart moved from the northwest to San Francisco
column2: Electric Sunset channels that optimistic feeling of the newly arrived
column3: wistful for the past but relishing the blank slate. When he sings
column4: ""Lose myself in the cities/ Alone among many
column5: on ""Prayer""
column6: it doesn't sound like a lament. But as peaceful as he comes across
column7:
it also doesn't sound like he's fully settled into his routine or his new sound.

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15940/homepage_large.9649e46e.jpg|How to Live|27753.0|Seeland|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['LOAF']|2010-11-11 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:17.042965|"

Seeland named themselves after a song by Neu!-- one of the most singular sounding (and ripped-off) bands of all time-- but until now they haven't much sounded like Neu! In many ways
column2: this is a good thing
column3: wonderful as Neu! were.  Bands who name themselves after songs by other bands already often have a tendency to be glorified cover acts. Not so much with Seeland
column4: whose two members (Tim Felton and Mike ""Billy"" Bainbridge) come from long-running bands (Broadcast and Plone) with distinct signatures of their own
column5: and so their combined efforts bring together a number of sounds from roughly the same era as their namesake (early synth adventures
column6: psychedelic rock
column7: experimental electronic film and TV scores)
column8: making records where you can name the influences without necessarily using the word ""homage"" unflatteringly.

column1: Seeland actually trot out Neu!'s motorik beat once
column2: on ""Black Dot
column3: White Spider""
column4: the first song on How to Live
column5: but most of the band's second album is much harder to pin down
column6: its nostalgic sci-fi pop references more cleverly combined
column7: thanks to Felton and Bainbridge's seemingly effortless ability to meld sounds from different musical spheres into catchy little wholes. Is it folk music if beat coffee shops had been bumping to the Forbidden Planet soundtrack? The British Invasion if Joe Meek had been as big an influence as Muddy Waters? The Beta Band with all the wooly psychedelic edges and bad jokes removed
column8: leaving only a sleek but sorta anonymous retro tunefulness? Plone and Broadcast minus the disquieting touches that made their ""childlike"" music hover beguilingly on the edge of creepiness?

column1: Unfortunately
column2: that uniform cuddliness is actually one of the album's two big weaknesses. It's all very pretty
column3: very lush
column4: and exceedingly well executed on its own terms. But Seeland's songs are also so unflaggingly adorable and friendly and tightly constructed that you wind up longing for just a moment of abrasion or eeriness or chaos. They do one mood
column5: gentle wide-eyed wonder set to slightly kitschy ""futuristic"" music
column6: very well. But that one mood also wears you out in far less time than the album's 34 minutes. It also all sounds a hell of a lot like Seeland's first album Tomorrow Today
column7: released just last year
column8: which is wonderful for people completely charmed by this stuff and a bit of a ""so what?"" proposition for those who already got their fix a year ago.

column1: The band's other
column2: related stumbling block is that Tim Felton is pretty monochrome behind the mic
column3: to the point where you wonder if an instrumental album might not have been a better showcase of the duo's skills. (At least How to Live wouldn't sound so much like Tomorrow Today then.) As a singer
column4: Felton delivers great melodies with the same off-the-rack indie wistfulness on each of the album's 10 tracks
column5: the vocal equivalent to the music's constant happy-sad vibe. His voice is acceptably pretty but not much more
column6: and seriously lacking for dynamics
column7: making How to Live feel repetitive despite the sparkling
column8: slippery variety of backing tracks. Seeland's sound
column9: full of bright and perfectly recreated period touches
column10: has plenty of personality on its own. But if they're committed to writing songs
column11:
they still need to find a singer to match.

"|14854.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14854-how-to-live/|5.5|Jess Harvell

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15925/homepage_large.0bc5c880.jpg|Tradi-Mods vs. Rockers: Alternative Takes on Congotronics|0.0|Various Artists|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Crammed Discs']|2010-11-10 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:17.805981|"

In 1987
column2: a French record label called Ocora released a cassette called Zaïre: Musiques Urbaines á Kinshasa. It was a set of four half-hour performances by four different bands
column3: recorded in Kinshasa
column4: Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of the Congo)
column5: in 1978. It was the first time Kinshasa street music ever made it out of Africa
column6: but the timing wasn't quite right; pre-Internet
column7: word of mouth could only spread this music so far. And it was up against a mainstream world music industry that didn't prize rawness or real African soundworlds. It went out of print
column8: but if you can find it
column9: it is very worth hearing.

column1: But that music couldn't stay hidden forever. In 2004
column2: producer Vincent Kenis curated an album by one of those street bands that had been recorded in 1978
column3: Konono Nº1
column4: for Crammed Discs (they also recorded a live LP for Terp that year). Konono in 2004 sounded almost exactly like Konono in 1978-- a bracing mix of headlong rhythm and interesting texture
column5: created by found-object percussion and crudely electrified likembe thumb pianos. This time
column6: the timing (and let's be honest
column7: the marketing) were much more fortuitous. Konono Nº1 crash-landed in the Western indie rock and avant garde worlds and were embraced wholeheartedly
column8: and Crammed embarked on a series of ""Congotronics"" releases aimed at building a broader picture of Kinshasa's vibrant street music scene
column9: which is comprised of bands from ethnic groups around Congo who amplify their traditional music to be heard over the urban din.

column1: Their latest Congotronics project takes a different tack. There's no doubt that Congotronics has had an impact in the West
column2: and Crammed's Marc Hollander (who long ago was Kenis' partner in the band Aksak Maboul) asked 26 artists to contribute their own personal takes on Congotronics
column3: and contributed one himself under his old Aksak Maboul banner. These artists took a variety of approaches: some wrote original music
column4: some covered actual Congotronics songs or used parts of them as raw musical material
column5: some sampled the source material
column6: and others wrote music modeled on a specific piece. Each song is credited to the artist ""vs"" the Congotronics act that inspired the song (usually Konono or Kasai Allstars)
column7: and it's a hugely diverse
column8: double-disc grab-bag by a group of contributors from Europe
column9: the U.S.
column10: and Japan.

column1: Some tracks are related to their inspiration more in spirit than anything else. A good example is Tussle's spectacular funk workout ""Soft Crush""
column2: which has a very loose relationship to Konono Nº1
column3: dropping ethereal thumb piano patterns into its otherwise relentless stomp. Bear Bones and Lay Low's ""Kuletronics"" is like Congotronics via the BBC Radiophonic Workshop
column4: directly quoting Konono Nº1's ""Kule Kule""
column5: but transposing the likembe groove to odd
column6: throbbing bass sounds and sprinkling the mix liberally with pinging sound effects and filtered
column7: echoing noises. It's interesting to hear the inherent similarities between things that seem as disparate as
column8: say
column9: Konono and Andrew Bird. Bird's pizzicato violin loops on ""Ohnono/Kiwembo"" are nothing too out of the ordinary for him
column10: but it's amazing how well the interlocking patterns he creates reflect an affinity with the band's likembe patterns.

column1: There are plenty of other highlights
column2: from Shackleton's 10-minute
column3: spaced-out ""Mukuba Special""
column4: which features vocal interjections sampled from Kasaï Allstars
column5: to Jherek Bischoff's very literal
column6: amazingly heavy orchestral arrangement of ""Kule Kule"". AU's ""Two Labors"" is a crazy pile-up of as many likembe rhythm patterns as possible playing at breakneck speed
column7: while Oneida sucks the music into its own noisy psychedelic world. Juana Molina is one of several who adds vocals and lyrics of her own
column8: bouncing her own melody off the patterns of Kasaï Allstars
column9: whose call and response chants she samples into her own composition.

column1: Hollander has afforded each artist the chance to talk a little bit about his or her contribution
column2: and reading the range of thoughts behind the tracks here makes for an interesting companion activity to listening. There are certainly ways a project like this could have gone wrong-- everybody avoids the biggest one
column3:
which would have been for a Western artist to try and perform the chants in the original music-- but the artists involved were given enough free reign and seem to have enough genuine appreciation for the music that the final result is a very pleasing listen that captures some of the spirit of the music without outright imitating or caricaturing it.

"|14841.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14841-tradi-mods-vs-rockers-alternative-takes-on-congotronics/|8.1|Joe Tangari

Was there ever a less likely addition to the Sub Pop roster than Saint Etienne? In the late 1990s
column4: the grunge and punk-associated Seattle label was emboldened to expand its purview
column5: and if Sub Pop was going to gamble on any band
column6: why not one of the UK's smartest
column7: most sophisticated connoisseurs? At the time
column8: the band (signed to Creation back home) was reportedly frustrated with its thoroughly continental reputation
column9: and in 1998 the results of that restlessness
column10: Good Humor
column11: made good on threats to try something new.

column1: Following its formative first three records
column2: all self-produced
column3: the band instead decamped to Sweden-- well ahead of the Western embrace of Swedish indie pop-- to work with an outsider
column4: Tore Johansson. Furthermore
column5: while known for its synths
column6: samples
column7: and programming
column8: the band this time chose to embrace traditional rock instruments
column9: including a horn section. And it's not a coincidence that the ""humor"" in the title drops the ""u"" from the anglicized version of that word.

column1: At its best Good Humor capably splits the difference between old Etienne and new
column2: embracing the 1960s as fervently as ever on ""Split Screen"" and ""The Bad Photographer"" while adopting that era's studio vernacular-- brass
column3: vibes
column4: electric piano. It also maintains the band's trademark melancholy streak with songs like ""Mr. Donut""
column5: ""Postman""
column6: and ""Lose That Girl"". Perhaps inevitably
column7: given the origins of the album
column8: the band even tips its hat to ABBA on ""Sylvie"". While perhaps not as immediate as the band's earlier output
column9: these songs remain potent
column10: and anyone that caught the group's full-band tour behind the album will attest that they more than held their own against the group's formidable back catalog.

column1: Yet almost immediately after its release
column2: the band began to retreat back to cult act
column3: creating more homespun music and acting more comfortable on the sidelines than in the spotlight. Indeed
column4: Fairfax High
column5: a collection of material used either as B-sides (in the UK) or as a bonus disc included with Good Humor (in the U.S.)
column6: shows Saint Etienne unable to thwart its instinct for collectible ephemera. Granted
column7: the group's innate quality control ensures that even its castoffs are worthwhile
column8: and Fairfax High (included in full in this deluxe edition) features its own share of highlights
column9: including ""Hit the Brakes"" and the pastoral ditty ""Clark Co. Record Fair"". This new edition also tacks on the unreleased ""Do You Love Me""
column10: the wonderfully corny ""Emidisc Theme"" (which celebrated the launch of Stanley's and Wiggs's shortlived EMI subsidiary imprint)
column11: and the spare de-Kid Loco'd original version of ""4.35 in the Morning"".

column1: Over the course of its next few releases
column2: Saint Etienne gradually returned to form
column3: in a literal sense
column4: bringing back the synths and drum machines to bolster its vision of the sad side of the swinging 60s and returning to London as its inspirational wellspring
column5: a shift culminating with 2005's Tales From Turnpike House
column6: the most recent new Saint Etienne album to date. Pairing the Tales reissue with Good Humor is slightly ironic: The latter album finds the band looking beyond its base
column7: but the former is possibly the most ""British"" thing the band has done
column8: a concept album set in an Islington high-rise flat whose fictional residents provide song-fodder that ranges from the kitchen-sink quotidian to the whimsical.

column1: This deluxe edition features the original UK tracklist-- in the words of Nitsuh Abebe's review
column2: ""one smooth
column3: seamless thing"" that remains as strong an entry into Saint Etienne's world as just about anything in its portfolio (and not just because the chart-minded British production team Xenomania had a hand in a couple of its tracks). Unlike the clearinghouse-minded bonus disc of Good Humor
column4: the second disc of Tales From Turnpike House includes several unreleased songs. Sadly
column5: it's missing the album's attendant EP of would-be children's music Up the Wooden Hills as well as some other esoterica. Predictably there are some pleasant surprises
column6: including ""Another Cup of Coffee"" (an honest to goodness Mike & the Mechanics cover)
column7: the clubby ""Must Be More""
column8: and still more forays into jazzy exotica like ""Holiday Song"" and ""Missing Persons Bureau"". The previously released ""You Can Judge a Book By Its Cover""
column9: on the other hand
column10: would sound almost like a lost new wave nugget were it not for Sarah Cracknell's cosmopolitan coo.

column1: It's helpful that these deluxe editions and their dusted off studio discoveries should arrive now
column2: with the band relatively inactive
column3: as there's a whole lot of worthwhile music to be absorbed and reassessed. But taken in total
column4: they truly underscore Saint Etienne's somewhat unsung status on the pop sidelines. Sure
column5: the group's singles are often its strongest suit
column6: but Saint Etienne has always been a big picture band. If anything
column7: these expanded editions stretch the screen even wider
column8: to CinemaScope proportions
column9:
revealing a breadth of Technicolor vision and consistency worthy of such vivid restorations.

If someone played you the first track off of Maserati's 2002 album
column2: The Language of Cities
column3: and followed that with the first track off of their latest album
column4: you'd probably think you just listened to two different bands. While there have been some personnel shifts-- the rhythm section on Pyramid of the Sun isn't the same one the group had eight years ago-- that only scratches the surface in what's changed with the group. It takes more than just plugging in a new guitarist and drummer to go from making serviceable instrumental music in a mathematical vein to talk-boxed space-bound synth-prog. The latter sound is more in line with what instrumental duo Zombi coax from their Moogs
column5: and Zombi's Steve Moore does indeed make a few appearances on Pyramid. And even though Zombi and Maserati did share some wax last year on a split EP
column6: that Maserati would go so far as to emulate Zombi's sounds-- more specifically
column7: the sounds that Zombi themselves emulate-- probably wasn't a move most would have expected.

column1: Pyramid covers a fair amount of ground over the course of its eight tracks
column2: from the Jan Hammer moves on the Moore-abetted ""Oaxaca"" to the more familiar rock-based grooves laid down for ""We Got the System to Fight the System"". The man who makes Maserati most able to cover this wide swath of territory is the late Jerry Fuchs. When Fuchs joined the band on the drums for 2007's Inventions for the New Season
column3: his impact was felt immediately. His playing
column4: powerful and precise while also exhibiting a little looseness
column5: provided a solid foundation that gave the rest of the group the space to explore and expand their horizons. On Pyramid
column6: that solid base takes on a more motorik feel. On something scuzzy like the short and sweet ""Ruins""
column7: it creates an air that harkens back to early Trans Am (specifically The Surveillance). On a shinier tune like ""They'll No More Suffer From Thirst""
column8: Fuchs' machine-like accuracy fits in perfectly with the pastel-colored synths and scratchy guitar. Throughout the album
column9: Fuchs' playing is exemplary
column10: but not in a showy or needlessly florid manner; he simply gets to work and gets the job done
column11: content with being just one part of a greater whole.

column1: Fittingly
column2: Fuchs' finest moment on Pyramid
column3: ""Bye M'Friend
column4: Goodbye""
column5: is also his most workman-like. At first
column6: the track has a hymn-like feel
column7: with wordless sonorous moaning happening in front of an arpeggiating synthesizer and a slowly shaken tambourine. Soon guitars enter the fray
column8: offering polite yet cheerful counterpoint to the track's solemnity. Finally
column9: fading in from the background
column10: is Fuchs; his slowly approaching beat opens up the song
column11: transforming the song's processional gait into a joyous and exuberant sprint. And while his bandmates cavort and canter with glee
column12: there's Fuchs
column13: doing his job
column14: making it all possible. This song is as fine a tribute and send-off as one could hope for
column15:
and is an equally appropriate way to draw the curtain on this phase of Maserati's career.

Many bands in the current San Francisco scene (the Fresh & Onlys
column2: Sonny & the Sunsets
column3: the Sandwitches) seem fixated with the jangly
column4: flower-powered melodies of the 1960s. Bay Area trio Royal Baths have an affinity for that decade
column5: too-- only a different
column6: darker part of it. Their debut full-length
column7: Litanies
column8: draws from the noisier
column9: more freaked-out side of early garage rock. It also takes cues from Neil Young's lightning-struck guitar sermons and the Velvet Underground's creeping paranoia. The band's singers
column10: Jeremy Cox and Jigmae Baer
column11: favor a dual-voiced delivery that sounds like the VU's multi-narrative sonic puzzle ""The Murder Mystery"".

column1: But for all the backward-looking signifiers
column2: there are some strangely coincidental present-day similarities
column3: too: Cox and Baer's pitched voices and cracked delivery recall Woods' Jeremy Earl
column4: whose Woodsist label is issuing Litanies. And the album's psych-damaged sound brings to mind yet another Woodsist band-- the skronk-loving Moon Duo. Unlike that group
column5: however
column6: Royal Baths let their melodies shine through the muck
column7: instead of burying them in swampy riffage. Before it folds into a deadened dirge
column8: ""Nikki Don't"" is sprightly
column9: with lightly delivered ""ba ba ba""s and a touch of bells. Those ""ba ba ba""s emerge again in one of Litanies' highlights
column10: ""I Detest""
column11: and they cut through that song's doomy chords with sharpness. Litanies' melodies don't struggle with the darker moments; instead
column12: they work within and alongside them.

column1: Still much of Litanies sounds blackened both by the distancing effects of the production quality and by the sheer maelstrom of Cox and Baer's guitar fuzz. Their lyrics often contribute to this shadowed atmosphere: ""Sitting in My Room"" starts off as a promise (""In the morning/ The morning will be there/ And we're not there yet/ But we'll get there"") that turns into a plea
column2: ""Here I am/ I am high/ And I'm too high to/ Go to bed."" Even the innocuously titled ""Pleasant Feeling"" seems to be about the inward effects of heroin use
column3:
with the post-injection entreaty to ""Close the doors/ The light's too bright."" The darkness suits these folks better anyway.

Is there a good name for the music of the Appalachias? Bluegrass grows more in the foothills
column2: folk is too broad
column3: string-band too restrictive
column4: and old-timey implies a deep disconnection from the present. In the extensive liner notes to their second album
column5: the Black Twig Pickers wisely avoid any of these terms. The music is simply music
column6: as much a part of the here-and-now as anything else in Virginia and West Virginia. The band
column7: who backed Jack Rose on an album last year
column8: remain academic-minded
column9: proudly apprenticing themselves to older musicians from the region. In those liners
column10: band member Mike Gangloff recounts the provenance of some of the old songs they play as well as the geneses of their two originals
column11: hinting that the past hangs over the band just by virtue of the style of music they play.

column1: Yet
column2: for the Black Twig Pickers steeping themselves in history doesn't dampen the impact of the music-- it magnifies it. Ironto Special is no dry
column3: studious affair: Named after a mountain town in southwest Virginia
column4: the album is raw and boisterous
column5: sometimes showy and sometimes restrained but always spirited in its execution. The trio may not be the most dexterous pickers
column6: but they wisely emphasize energy over exactness
column7: whether they're playing a barnburner like ""Don't Drink Nothing But Corn"" or a slower number like ""Smoker Wedding March"". If you listen carefully
column8: you might hear a flub or two
column9: but that only contributes to the ramshackle vibe of the album.

column1: From the almost spry bounce of ""Pickin' Out the Devil's Eyes"" to the military processional of ""Rockin' in a Weary Land""
column2: the Pickers play a range of settings
column3: showing how diverse the region and its traditions can be. Then they add a few touches of their own: Nathan Bowles plays the bones on ""Dead Man's Piece""
column4: and the simple rhythms offsets the froggy harmonica and spare banjo
column5: as if ticking off the minutes of a life. That
column6: Gangloff writes in the liners
column7: is a funeral song
column8: and it's followed by a wedding march
column9: creating the album's best sequence. While he bows a springtime reel on ""Smoker Wedding March""
column10: Bowles drums on the fiddle strings with chopsticks.

column1: Much of Ironto Special is instrumental
column2: highlighting the close interplay between the guitars
column3: banjos
column4: washboards
column5: and mouth harps. Oddly
column6: the only instrument that doesn't seem to belong is the human voice. The Pickers trade off vocals on just a few songs and whoop and holler on others. Isak Howell fares best on ""Lay Ten Dollars Down""
column7: his phrasing suggestive of a drunken stagger
column8: but in general
column9: they all sound like they're straining toward some tumbledown genre ideal rather than letting it come as naturally as the rest of the music. In general
column10: though
column11:
the Pickers show a firm and confident grasp of the traditions they're participating in and-- more importantly-- of the relevance of this unnamed genre to the present-day.

It's almost inevitable that the frontman of a rock band will eventually want to strike out on his own
column3: often to showcase material that's more tender and introspective than an amp-cranking
column4: four-piece line-up allows. However
column5: it's rare that these solo sojourns wind up eclipsing the work of the mothership act
column6: and even rarer when they reveal the singer-dude's fondness for lipstick and eyeliner
column7: facility with choreographed dance routines
column8: and eagerness to call his sexuality into question. For those who aren't familiar with John O'Regan's workmanlike post-punk outfit the D'Urbervilles-- and
column9: lamentably
column10: few people outside the Toronto-Montreal indie-rock corridor are-- the magnitude of his transformation into lo-fi glitter god Diamond Rings can be quantified as such: imagine Britt Daniel decided one day that he really wanted to be Lady Gaga.

column1: Alas
column2: the Diamond Rings story has decidedly unglamorous origins-- the concept was born in a Toronto hospital bed
column3: where O'Regan spent summer 2008 battling a sudden
column4: severe onset of Crohn's disease
column5: using the recovery time to write new songs on guitar and keyboards. Many people who've endured invasive medical procedures often feel the desire to reclaim control of their bodies by marking them with tattoos or piercings; it's thus instructive to view O'Regan's metamorphosis from indie-rock everyman into the flamboyant Diamond Rings not as some premeditated
column6: shock-value provocation
column7: but as a process of trading in his scarred
column8: sickly body for a more physically pristine one.

column1: The heavily YouTubed 2009 single ""All Yr Songs"" was Diamond Rings' proverbial coming-out party
column2: showcasing O'Regan's newly mascaraed visage and a sweet boombox serenade several degrees warmer and more affectionate than the D'Urbervilles' spiky new wave. But on his long-gestating full-length debut
column3: Special Affections
column4: O'Regan is less interested in blurring gender lines as toying with extreme contrasts of masculinity and femininity
column5: pitting his authoritative baritone
column6: aggressive electric-guitar strums
column7: and bald
column8: cutting sentiments against silken slow-jam arrangements
column9: radiant synth lines
column10: and twinkling tinker-toy beats.

column1: Pretty much every line on Special Affections can be read as O'Regan's coming to terms with his new persona-- whether he's ""covering [his] conscience with a new disguise"" on the austere
column2: piano-laced opener ""Play by Heart""
column3: or declaring his intent to ""write my own story
column4: make it all up as I go"" on the crunk&B crunch of ""You Oughta Know"". But unlike other artists who've crafted album-length narratives around a new guise-- from Bowie to Beyoncé-- Diamond Rings is a vehicle through which O'Regan can more candidly address the sensitive matters in his own personal life
column5: effectively equating the awkward feeling of wearing make-up in public for the first time to other intimately discomfiting scenarios
column6: be it the painful realization that a relationship is over (""Pre-Owned Heart"") or the fear of acting on suppressed lust (""Give It Up""). When O'Regan sings
column7: ""I'm feeling like a bit-part actor"" on the click-tracked fuzz-pop of ""Wait & See""
column8: you can tell he's got matters on his mind far weightier than how his rainbow face-paint looks.

column1: But as fascinating as it is to hear an indie rock artist step outside of his comfort zone
column2: both musically and emotionally
column3: Special Affections' skeletal electro-pop sketches routinely fortify into full-blooded anthemic choruses that make O'Regan's liberation your own. (The fact that O'Regan never lets on whether he's singing to a boy or a girl further emphasizes its universal applications.) In rock music
column4: the traditional litmus test of a song's strength is whether it holds up to an acoustic-guitar reading; with Special Affections
column5: O'Regan-- who claims he's still committed to keeping the D'Urbervilles a going concern-- simply applies the same logic to his GarageBand presets. And on an album full of sturdy sing-alongs
column6: none stands taller than ""Something Else""
column7: a scrappy power-pop triumph that plays like a more natural
column8: better executed version of the synthed-up Strokes experiment that Julian Casablancas attempted on Phrazes for the Young.

column1: Not one to forget who brought him to the dance
column2: O'Regan drops ""All Yr Songs"" into the final-song slot. But after the preceding nine tracks documenting difficult break-ups and tawdry hook-ups
column3: the gesture feels less like a case of saving the hit for last and more of a time-capsule farewell to Diamond Rings' more innocent origins. And since early versions of Special Affections started circulating as far back as last March
column4: O'Regan has pomped up even further with the big-room Euro-house flourishes and Britney-ized bump'n'grind of recent
column5: non-album single ""Show Me Your Stuff"". But even if Diamond Rings' rapidly evolving aesthetic has already moved beyond Special Affections' bedsit R&B
column6:
the album still stands as an exemplary model of how one can live out blinged-out fantasies on a cubic zirconia budget.

In some ways it's very easy to understand why a band would keep its name after their very distinct lead singer has departed. Name recognition will ensure a certain number of people will pay attention to your new music and come out to shows. Hell
column2: some bands
column3: such as Pink Floyd and Genesis
column4: became only more successful after their charismatic original singer left the group. So there's that. Mostly
column5: however
column6: it's a terrible idea. You run the risk of alienating your audience and tarnishing your legacy. Your new music never gets a fair chance
column7: since it's always going to be compared unfavorably to your past glories. It's hard to grasp why the remaining members of the Concretes ever made this foolish gamble.

column1: WYWH is the second Concretes album without singer Victoria Bergsman
column2: who left to follow her own muse with Taken By Trees. Though the Concretes were always a large band
column3: and current singers Lisa Milberg and Maria Eriksson have been in the group all along
column4: there is no getting around the reality that Bergsman's unmistakable voice was the most attractive and interesting thing about their music. On their brilliant self-titled debut
column5: her heavily accented
column6: painfully introverted presence clicked with the band's Velvet Underground-meets-Motown sound in a way that was unique and magical. Without Bergsman as an anchor
column7: the Concretes have no particular identity. Milberg and Eriksson are good vocalists but are lacking in character
column8: and the songwriting has become rather generic
column9: at least in terms of icy Scandinavian indie music. It may be mostly the same musicians
column10: but it's just not the same band that produced gems like ""You Can't Hurry Love"" and ""Diana Ross"". Carrying on as the Concretes is at least somewhat dishonest
column11: like an artistic bait-and-switch.

column1: In an alternate reality in which WYWH was released under a band name other than the Concretes
column2: it would still be a mediocre effort
column3: but it would at least be easier to appreciate it on its own terms. The group's attempts at a more danceable sound on ""Good Evening"" and ""All Day"" are modestly successful and flatter Milberg's understated vocal style. Despite solid musicianship
column4: however
column5: their grooves are often rather limp
column6: and many of their disco moves are only theoretically conducive to actual dancing. The album maintains a pleasing and mellow atmosphere
column7: but the tone isn't very evocative. Whereas their earliest work brought to mind a surreal winter wonderland
column8: this music seems oddly blank. It feels like being nowhere
column9: and not in an interesting sort of way. The problem here isn't to do with craft-- these are reasonably okay compositions performed by a band of talented professionals-- but it could be a matter of passion and commitment. There's no sense of emotional stakes on the album
column10: and there isn't any strong feeling to connect with either way. To some extent
column11: WYWH can get by on vibe
column12: but really
column13: a listener can do much better
column14:
even without going further back into the Concretes catalog.

column7: how he came up
column8: the creation process
column9: what scenes he's echoing off and adding to-- well
column10: it's important
column11: but there's something about Ardour that makes it feel like it has no manmade origin. Think of a building that's been left unattended for 100 years
column12: and all of the foliage that pushes up through it and engulfs its crumbling foundations. For all the artisanal care that went into this album's creation
column13: it sounds like decaying beats being split apart by deceptively fragile yet resilient melodies
column14: post-hip-hop production as a simulation of nature reclaiming concrete.

column1: Here's what I mean: try and focus on a specific instrument when you listen to an individual track
column2: and you'll discover that Teebs' manipulation has rendered it into something unexpected. That's a wobbly harp on ""Double Fifths""
column3: though in the first few seconds of the loop getting spooled up
column4: it sounds like an out-of-tune ukulele
column5: and over the course of the song its off-time loops start to come across as precipitation rather than a set of strings. There's a trilling piano glissando on ""Moments""
column6: tweaked at points-- drenched in reverb
column7: distorted
column8: subsumed under layers of percussion and hiss-- to halfway convince you into thinking it might not actually be a piano at all. Percussive elements are built in a way that puts kicks and snares front and center
column9: but lets just enough supplemental backbeat elements like backspun loops
column10: flowing chimes
column11: and sparking electronic synapses bubble under the surface so that even the most minimalist rhythms sound mystifyingly busy. Such elements make songs like ""My Whole Life"" and ""Wind Loop"" into drum-rich tracks that sinuously trickle instead of straight-up banging.

column1: A lot of ink and pixels have been thrown around trying to make a case for the idea of electronic music's organic possibilities
column2: but Ardour actually captures the sonic equivalent of watching biological life expand in sped-up time-lapse. And no
column3: that's not to say that Ardour is about as interesting as watching grass grow. Its methodology is subtle
column4: but its mood is immediate. Maybe the best way I can think of to describe that tone is one of disorienting joy: It's wispy and gentle and a bit cheerful on the surface
column5: but giving it a deep listen will bring forth some of the more complex and abrasive elements to the forefront. This music can be flat-out beautiful while still giving your head a jostle: The romantic soundtrack strings of ""Humming Birds""
column6: the icy bells of ""Arthur's Birds""
column7: and the digital bird-chirps of ""Autumn Antique"" are undercut by clicking snap-beats and bass throbs that sound like they're coming from a loose
column8: twitching high-voltage power line. That juxtaposition of gentleness and heat makes Ardour a pleasant exercise in loop-chopping naturalism-- but even through all the foliage
column9:
you can still nod your head to it.

If there's anything resembling a line on Excepter
column3: any kind of conventional wisdom to be thrown at one of experimental music's most dependably unconventional acts

column6: the jokes get funnier

column8: unusually solid 2xCD Presidence underscored this; the further they dug in

column1: Opener ""OBOH"" is a nightmare trip of whirrs and howls

column3: caustic
column4: and rife with unease
column5: but there's something almost mechanical about the performance; we seem to be plopped down into the middle of a fairly successful
column6: locked-in improvisation

column1: ""LAL8"" begins and ends with a thin synthetic pulse

column3: and the two seem to find each other around minute three

column6: and its fervid conclusion provides LATE with its peak. This is Excepter at their best

column3: things are a little more complicated than that; any notion of cutting a rug turns quickly to cutting up a body
column4: as the track grows busier and far more unsettling as it goes. The song's stutter-shout eventually subsides
column5: giving way to a swaying drone; it's a premature comedown for a novel groove that would've benefitted from a little more stretching out. Closer ""Cat Piss and Licorice"" starts out eerie and diffuse before arriving at an unusually delicate keyboard plink. The track
column6: it seems
column7: is a sort of anti-homage to conversation-ending Internet meme Keyboard Cat; ""the cat piano was cute at first
column8: someone moans at one point
column9: ""but now it's on my nerves."" Ditto the joyless ""Cat Piss""
column10: which devolves quickly into mumbling.

column1: LATE's textures are alluringly dingy
column2: its sense of dread palpable

They're certainly capable of working well in miniature-- see the wildly successful Sunbomber EP-- but one can't help but escape the feeling that these are good ideas that simply weren't given enough time to hash themselves out. LATE will find fans among the Excepter loyal

it's tough to tell just what that might be.

After close to 30 years and something in the vicinity of 50 albums
column2: this is apparently the final studio record by the uncategorizable trio Sun City Girls
column3: recorded at their last sessions before drummer Charles Gocher's 2007 death. (Multi-instrumentalists Richard and Alan Bishop did one final tour in 2008 as the Brothers Unconnected
column4: playing material from the SCG songbook
column5: then called it quits.) They made a career out of being unpredictable: If you'd heard the miraculous pancultural freakout of Torch of the Mystics (everyone's favorite SCG album
column6: unforgivably long out of print) and then picked up the sluggish comedy record Jacks Creek
column7: or discovered them through the Fugs-ian ranty-shanties of Horse Cock Phepner and followed that with the space-drone of Bright Surroundings Dark Beginnings
column8: you might have wondered if there were a bunch of different bands calling themselves Sun City Girls. (I'd point neophytes toward the albums that displayed multiple sides of the band
column9: like Kaliflower or Carnival Folklore Resurrection Radio
column10: but those are long-gone too.)

column1: So for their final bow
column2: it's fitting that they took another left turn
column3: this time into overt prettiness. In some ways
column4: Funeral Mariachi is a return to a couple of the modes where they seemed most comfortable-- and this was a band that was usually much more interested in discomfort
column5: even their own. One is pastiches of non-Anglophone folk forms
column6: with singing in made-up languages (sort of an extension of Can's ""Ethnological Forgery Series""); ""The Imam"" and ""Black Orchid"" would've fit right in on Torch of the Mystics. The other is film music
column7: specifically in the tradition of Ennio Morricone. ""Come Maddalena"" is a Morricone cover
column8: and ""Blue West"" and ""Mineral Wells"" might as well be.

column1: Sun City Girls recorded a bunch of ""soundtracks"" over the years-- Juggernaut
column2: Dulce
column3: Piasa... Devourer of Men-- although Mister Lonely is the only movie they scored that demonstrably exists any place other than their record sleeves. But Funeral Mariachi doesn't need a framing device to evoke an imaginary Jodorowsky movie. Unidentifiable instruments slither in and out of the mix; rhythms trudge like mules along a dirt road. Anything you think you hear might be a lie or an illusion. ""When I was dead I looked exactly like you/ Now I'm alive where nothing is true
column4: the Bishops purr on ""This Is My Name""
column5: one of only a couple of songs with much in the way of English lyrics.

column1: The Girls boys always had a very weird sense of humor
column2: and there are a few odd little jokes here: ""Bens Radio"" begins and ends with a terrific bit of studio trickery
column3: volleying snippets of voices across the stereo field
column4: as if channel-surfing
column5: and the unutterably lovely ""El Solo"" alternates Morricone-esque vocalese with halting phrases from a loud
column6: old piano. Mostly
column7: though
column8:
the shock of Funeral Mariachi is that it's the friendliest record in their catalogue. It doesn't have the twitching intensity of a lot of their other work-- that's both an asset and a deficit-- but they couldn't have made a sweeter farewell.

Caribou's Dan Snaith is a great remix candidate. The relentless studio tinkerer leaves a lot of process in his music
column3: and his songs have an appealingly imperfect quality. It's not that Caribou tracks feel unfinished; they're more like breathing compositions than polished
column4: flawless objects. This gives remixers a lot of room to maneuver-- they can pick apart individual pieces of songs
column5: expand on one especially interesting element
column6: or even deconstruct the whole thing and start from scratch. And Swim is particularly ripe for reworking because it's easily his clubbiest material to date.

column1: Snaith has never been beholden to one genre and this set honors the exploratory nature of his work. All the artists included are beat-minded in some way
column2: but they vary pretty wildly across the electronic music spectrum. There's indie dance-pop (Walls
column3: Nite Jewel)
column4: dubstep/funky (Ikonika)
column5: minimal techno (DJ Koze)
column6: experimental electronica (James Holden)
column7: and more. This healthy cross-section makes the album feel more relevant than similar remix comps
column8: but also makes it a bit clunky. There are a ton of different ideas to internalize
column9: and at 90 minutes
column10: it's just a lot of music to wade through.

column1: Some of the best material comes from unlikely sources. Tucson unknown Altrice made his way onto the record by winning a remix competition
column2: and his ""Only What You Gave Me"" mix of ""Sun"" is easily one of the best cuts. He flips the whole vibe of the track
column3: taking it from skyward psych to a dark head-knodder riding over hip-hop breaks and distorted synths. Fuck Buttons
column4: who took a step toward the floor last year with their monster Tarot Sport
column5: continue in that direction by turning ""Kaili"" into pulsing house. Without even a hint of noise
column6: the track doesn't resemble much of their other work.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Junior Boys knock out the best ""Odessa"" mix
column3: and it's great to hear them back in crisp
column4: electro-funk form. Gold Panda does his tech-y
column5: Eastern-tinged thing on ""Jamelia""
column6: and the UK's Patten live up to their noise-dance hype with their ""Sun"" remix. Somewhere along the line
column7: though
column8: the record loses focus. Dudes you expect to deliver
column9: like Holden and Koze
column10: sprawl way too far out
column11: and at least three other songs just feel unnecessary. With so much material
column12: you almost start to forget about Caribou altogether
column13: and the record becomes more valuable as a dance-cut grab bag than a reflection of the source material. That's neither compliment nor criticism
column14:
just what happens when nothing gets edited out.

If you've been patiently waiting for that dude in the Bravery to strike out on his own
column2: your moment of glory might come soon enough. 2010 has seen solo records from the frontmen of the Killers and Bloc Party

column4: synth-spiked sound of modern radio rock that turned ""angular"" into the most overused word in music criticism of 2005. Paul Smith makes it an official trend with Margins; while his band
column5: Maxïmo Park
column6: didn't quite reach the same level of notoriety
column7: A Certain Trigger is certainly amongst the best of last decade's post-punk revival records. But while Flowers and Kele were able to use their albums as a logical continuation of their band's increasingly flamboyant tendencies
column8: Maxïmo Park have been leaking momentum for years; by their third album

column1: But even with lower expectations

column5: not pounded

column8: hands-off production aesthetic of holistic reverb and roomsound.

column3: the domestic voyeurism of ""While You're in the Bath""-- but the melodies ramble along
column4: never finding their footing. And then there are the indulgences-- ""Alone
column5: I Would've Dropped"" is the kind of droning
column6: Middle Eastern experiment most people try once and (rightfully) only once in their career
column7: but ""I Drew You Sleeping"" draws a grand melodic guidance from its silvery Johnny Marr riffs to provide an intriguing glimpse of Smith as a luxuriant mope rather than an acoustic-toting confessor.

column1: Smith himself claimed that making Margins was a result of a ""seven-year itch
column2: and it's certainly warranted that the guy who wrote ""Apply Some Pressure"" would want to ease back: As the dominant personality in a band struggling with its direction and
column3: judging from the hurt in the lyrics
column4: smarting from romantic abandonment
column5: a ""sort your shit out"" album is understandable. But ultimately
column6:
Margins feels like an album of songs that needed to be exorcised more than shared.

Screaming Females paid their dues in the basements and closet-size venues of New Brunswick
column2: New Jersey
column3: which despite its size and suburban dispersion boasts an active punk scene. Dodging bottles and cups thrown by their rowdy audiences
column4: the trio developed considerable chops before signing with local label Don Giovanni: Jarrett Dougherty is a heavy drummer mercifully spare with fills
column5: ""King Mike"" Abbate a bass player graciously liberal with melody
column6: and Marissa Paternoster a guitar player with an enormous musical vocabulary that includes everything from classic rock to hardcore to New Wave to indie to lo-fi. Punk has traditionally prized attitude over abilities
column7: but Screaming Females have both: Rather than muzzle their ferocity

column9: tense dynamic amplifies the fuck-off stridency of their fourth LP

column1: There's only one female in the group

column3: she has a mighty howl that's as regal and haughty as that album title implies. She shreds and wails through these songs

column12: J Mascis
column13: Carrie Brownstein

column1: In that regard
column2: the most interesting aspect of Castle Talk is the way Paternoster fulfills her frontwoman status by turning each song into a dialogue-- or
column3: perhaps
column4: an argument-- between voice and guitar. On ""Boss""
column5: she adopts a shaky tone that gives each note a stressed wobble even as she declares
column6: ""I could be the boss of you any day."" The effect is that of a woman steeling herself for a fight
column7: psyching herself up to defy. On the other hand
column8: her guitar swoops in suddenly to punctuate the chorus of ""I Don't Mind It""
column9: adding emphatic certainty to her declaration that ""it's just never enough."" Her riffs alternately underline and undermine her vocals
column10: but she thrives on the conflict between her dual instruments
column11: as well as between herself and the band
column12: the band and the world. That sense of scene survival energizes and innervates these songs: ""I'm joyfully employed and normal!"" she asserts on ""Normal""

as if we might miss that all three of them are enjoying every note.

In 2010
column2: a laptop or any other computerized setup at a live gig is just another sound-producing tool
column3: usually about as invisible to the audience as a rack of effects pedals or a backdrop of amps. Ever-increasing processing power means laptops have long since replaced DATs and sequencers when it comes to replaying pre-recorded material. They're also able to generate and transform new music as the show unfolds
column4: which has given rise to a large network of folks who might've been making wholly improvised music with saxophones and guitars and bent circuitry two decades ago-- and all of this with a much reduced possibility of the kind of crashing and/or freezing that once killed whole concerts.

column1: Where does this leave the first generation of laptop-based improvisers like Fenn O'Berg
column2: the trio of Christian Fennesz
column3: Peter Rehberg
column4: and Jim O'Rourke? Well
column5: the novelty behind the approach is certainly gone
column6: and the sound of a bunch of raw computer glitches strung together and called a ""piece"" is no longer alien enough to be a draw all by itself. The trio may no longer even utilize laptops
column7: or wholly computerized sound
column8: for key portions of their music. But many of the technical limitations and glitches have disappeared-- the ones that made early laptop music so often a frustrating live experience for musician and listener alike.

column1: On the two new Live in Japan discs
column2: which collect performances from 2009
column3: it seems Fenn O' Berg's response to the upgraded capabilities of their consumer electronics has been to grow more traditionally ""musical"" in constructing their live shows
column4: even if what they're presenting is still far from accessible. Grainy gray washes of digital static
column5: burbles like running water
column6: tiny not-quite-melodic motifs that disperse almost cruelly before another wave of corrupted electronic sound: Situated somewhere between form and formlessness
column7: ever-changing and moments of sublime near-static repetition
column8: not always pleasant but far from alienating
column9: Live in Japan is often indistinguishable in places from the fluffier end of pure noise.

column1: But for those who prefer their noise to be more immersive than hair-raising
column2: Fenn O'Berg let their often formless bits of digital data wash together into longer ebbing and flowing compositions that bear some distant relation to other long-form experiences like minimalism or even jazz. It's a bit odd that these discs had their genesis on stage
column3: because this seems like precisely the kind of thing best enjoyed at home
column4: preferably through headphones. With its random bursts of crackle and hiss surrounded by vast gulfs of digital silence
column5: glitch was perfect for both laptops (which often spat these sounds out by accident anyway) and live performance (since there's a certain tense fascination in not knowing when next snarl or blurt is gonna zap your ears).

column1: There's something altogether calmer about these two LPs providing a progressive exploration rather than moment-to-moment jolts
column2: after 10-plus years of mind-melding and in-depth play. But the sound palette retains glitch's top-end harshness
column3:
a kind of gnarled and beautiful post-industrial ambient music for noise kids and Mego fans.

About four years ago
column2: I sat down with two big rap producers
column3: Just Blaze and the Alchemist
column4: at Baseline Studios
column5: the old Roc-a-Fella stomping grounds
column6: a since-shuttered hive of mainstream rap dominance. At the time
column7: the two producers were lamenting the decline of the cinematic NYC rap they'd both made their names cranking out. But Alchemist talked with a sense of genuine excitement and wonder about a backpack-rap universe that still sounded pretty new to him: ""Not to dis them
column8: but a lot of that shit is kind of weird. But the world that they're repping
column9: that's the world that I want to be a part of."" These days
column10: Alc still has a foot in whatever's left of the mainstream rap world; he produced ""You Ain't Got Nuthin""
column11: probably the hardest track on Lil Wayne's gazillion-selling Tha Carter III
column12: and he DJed a recent run of Eminem stadium shows. But he's also very much a part of that underground world he was talking about. And now he's teamed up with the stalwart Stones Throw rapper/producer Oh No to form the duo Gangrene and crank out a decidedly weird little record.

column1: Alchemist is probably still best-known for crafting gutpunch street-rap anthems for guys like Mobb Deep and Jadakiss
column2: but his early-decade aesthetic is almost entirely gone from Gutter Water. Instead
column3: he's launched himself into the ADD crate-digging style best exemplified by Oh No's older brother Madlib. The tracks on Gutter Water sputter and crackle and warp
column4: rarely settling into a comfortable thump. Horns and strings and harps-- all seemingly drawn from moldy thrift-shop muzak platters-- always circle whatever groove the drums conjure
column5: but the two producers rarely let them fall into the pocket. Tracks rarely come with choruses
column6: and when those choruses are there
column7: they're awkward enough that you wish they weren't. This is a mood piece. There's a lot of texture at work here
column8: and there would be more if the duo didn't end nearly every track by dissolving into a sample-collage of cheesed-out film dialogue and disembodied news-anchor voices.

column1: Even if they're hell on the album's sustained momentum
column2: those collages do pound home the album's theme: disease
column3: squalor
column4: infection. (One news report about people swimming in open sewage makes me want to gag every time.) But this isn't an album about the need for global health reform; the thematic stuff is there to remind you that you're dealing with two people totally uninterested in meeting you halfway. Alchemist even takes the time to remind us that he's not a ""ringtone rapper
column5: a term I haven't heard in a while. (Alc must not have got the memo that skinny-jeans rappers are everyone's favorite threat to hip-hop culture these days.)

column1: As rappers
column2: Alc and Oh are both perfectly decent but never transcendent. Oh has a solidly loping delivery
column3: and Alc has a raspy off-beat thing that's less technically sound but more distinctive. And Alc has a way with perfectly ridiculous
column4: kind of dumb punchlines that nonetheless lodge themselves in your memory: ""Speed on and get peed on
column5: ""Hopping out the trashcan like Oscar the Grouch
column6: ""I stay high like pussy on a giraffe is."" Plenty of guests stop by
column7: but Raekwon notwithstanding
column8: most of them sit firmly in a willfully hardheaded West Coast underground scene: Planet Asia
column9: Evidence
column10: Roc C. Some of them
column11: like Guilty Simpson
column12: work great with the kinds of beats they're given
column13: but nobody dazzles.

column1: But the rapping on Gutter Water is almost beside the point. Oh and Alc are producers first
column2: and Gutter Water would work nearly as well as an instrumental album. And together
column3: they've created a messy
column4: impressive pile-up of half-broken piano loops and dense
column5: clattery drum programming. It's a hazy
column6: stoned piece of work
column7: an expansive extended head-nod
column8:
everything it sets out to be.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15904/homepage_large.866b79c7.jpg|The Bootleg Series
column3: <i>Chronicles

column7: Dylan writes

column9: ""What I had to work at
column10: Mike already had in his genes
column11: in his genetic makeup... The thought occurred to me that maybe I'd have to write my own folk songs.""

column1: The 47 songs collected on The Bootleg Series
column2: Vol. 9: The Witmark Demos: 1962-1964 allow us to witness how Dylan went about doing just that. Representing the fruits of his first two publishing contracts (with Leeds Music and with M. Witmark & Sons)
column3: the set reveals a much subtler and more fascinating journey than the popular shorthand myth of Dylan's shifting cleanly from folk apprentice to political firebrand to poetic rock'n'roller. For starters
column4: a great many of the songs to which Dylan first affixed his name as writer were simply his own original lyrics atop traditional folk melodies. Not all of these words excoriated social injustice either-- far from it. Even from the beginning
column5: there were love songs and outlaw songs
column6: moodily poetic songs and broad jokes. Still
column7: The Witmark Demos does demonstrate an evolution in songwriting genius
column8: and one that took place in a frighteningly short period of a time by a young man who'd yet to turn 24 when the last of these recordings were made. On this set
column9: you can hear Dylan moving past the bedrock melodies of folk and crafting indelible ones of his own (""Don't Think Twice
column10: It's All Right""). You can hear him perfecting the protest song (""Blowin' in the Wind""
column11: ""Masters of War""). And you can hear him falling in love with the music of words and beginning to invent a new vocabulary for pop music (a scratchy
column12: nascent piano-only take of ""Mr. Tambourine Man"").

column1: Only 15 of the set's 47 songs are unheard in any incarnation on a previous Dylan release (more on them later). The other 32 are split fairly evenly between germinal takes on songs from early-60s Dylan albums and alternate rough cuts of tunes that appear in equally embryonic states on the first Bootleg Series issue
column2: 1991's Volumes 1-3. You might think auxiliary efforts would be of interest only to Dylan obsessives-- and in some cases these readings scarcely differ from others in his catalogue. Still
column3: there are revelations: The oft-covered ""Tomorrow Is a Long Time"" has appeared previously only in live form on Dylan's second greatest hits compilation
column4: and the version here is far richer
column5: the guitar playing lovely and sublime. The classic protest song ""Oxford Town"" may be less immaculate here
column6: but it's more bracing and insistent. The readings of ""Mama
column7: You've Been on My Mind"" and ""I'll Keep It with Mine"" are especially pained and plaintive
column8: while the bitingly satirical ""Talkin' John Birch Paranoid Blues"" and ""Rambling
column9: Gambling Willie"" are looser and more ebullient here than anywhere else they've appeared before.

column1: As for the 15 ""new"" songs
column2: a few are mere fragments and a few others are fairly boilerplate
column3: but again there are real treasures. ""Farewell"" haunts with its melody while ""The Death of Emmett Till"" haunts with its words
column4: yet both are outshone by the bitterly ironic tour de force ""Long Ago
column5: Far Away""
column6: where Dylan enumerates social injustices ostensibly relegated to the distant past that were in fact still occuring in his own time
column7: witheringly spitting the refrain
column8: ""Those things don't happen no more nowadays."" ""I'd Hate to Be You on That Dreadful Day"" and ""All Over You"" further display comic sides
column9: and then there's ""Long Time Gone""
column10: which shows us an initial flowering of the unflappably cool mythical icon Dylan would fully become in the mid-60s. The song's refrain offers a perfect summation of how this set reveals the historical depth of Dylan's musical education as well as the lengths to which he would eclipse it. ""I'm a long time a-comin'
column11: Dylan sings
column12:
""and I'll be a long time gone.""

column13: namely

column14: but tonally

column1: A shame

column3: a demographic made up entirely of magical thinkers
column4: Pharrell Williams' all-encompassing belief in himself is remarkable. It's hard to imagine that he's ever had what he considered to be a bad idea. On the one hand
column5: this sublime self-confidence is sort of awe-inspiring
column6: and exactly the sort of attitude we demand from our pop stars. On the other hand
column7: Pharrell has had an awful lot of wretched ideas.

column1: Ever since 2001
column2: his rock-band side project N.E.R.D. has been a reliable repository for all of the worst ones. Back when he and Chad Hugo were still dominating hip-hop radio
column3: N.E.R.D. albums served a useful purpose: they brought the super-producers
column4: endearingly
column5: to earth. For every indestructible ""What Happened to That Boy"" or ""Superthug""
column6: there was an ""Everyone Nose"" or a ""She Wants to Move""-- something goofy and dubiously conceived where their reach wildly exceeded their grasp. N.E.R.D. albums may never have made for essential listening
column7: but they spoke to an important part of the Neptunes storyline
column8: fleshing out Hugo and Williams' image as likable
column9: overly enthusiastic dorks.

column1: So the fact that Nothing
column2: their fourth album
column3: is a parade of deliriously bad ideas-- terrible ones realized with fervent conviction
column4: half-promising ones botched by disastrous execution-- shouldn't even really be held against it. That's sort of a N.E.R.D. album's reason for existing. The reason that listening to Nothing is so profoundly depressing
column5: however
column6: is because the first half of the above equation-- the part where the Neptunes are still cranking out lethal
column7: indelible radio hits-- has more or less evaporated. Without that crucial ballast
column8: both sides of the Neptunes story swing irretrievably into orbit. The worst moments on Nothing-- ""Life as a Fish""
column9: for instance
column10: which recycles the chord changes to In Search of...'s ""Bobby James"" and uses them to soundtrack Pharrell's preposterously dramatic retelling of God creating Earth; or the Jethro Tull smooth-jazz beat switchup of ""I've Seen the Light / (Interlude) Inside of Clouds""-- are the sounds of an artistic compass spinning wildly.

column1: True to form
column2: Pharrell never sounds in the least discouraged steering his way through this wreckage. Whether he's assaying a timid version of Jim Morrison on ""Help Me"" or pillow-talk whispering his way through the mortifyingly stupid
column3: Daft Punk-produced ""Hypnotize U""
column4: he remains utterly convinced of his capabilities as a frontman. The songs that do work-- the double-time clavinet-and-bongos funk workout of ""Party People""
column5: or the tense
column6: minimal thump of the Deluxe Edition's ""Sacred Temple"" and ""Nothing on You""-- hark back to what Neptunes tracks sounded like in 2004
column7: when Pharrell and Chad still had a firm grasp on the rewards of tension and empty space. There isn't a lot left on Nothing
column8: apart from these faint reminders
column9:
to indicate that these two guys were the same pair who once revolutionized the sound of hip-hop.
