After incubating and bubbling as a key strain of London bass culture for much of last decade
column3: dubstep has recently exploded internationally
column4: and done so in largely unique ways. Like most strains of electronic dance music
column5: dubstep was created and cultivated by adventurous DJs and partygoers. Eventually those new electronic sounds tend to become one of two things: a battleground for arguments about purity and definitions
column6: which inevitably stunts growth and inherently creates dead ends; or a once hands-on
column7: dangerous
column8: and visceral sound that intellectualizes itself into something considerably more dull when removed from its utilitarian dancefloor origins.

column1: A funny thing happened to dubstep
column2: however: So far it's avoided each of these traps
column3: proving itself voracious and adaptable
column4: and just as exciting as headphone music as it is room-shaking club music. It's also become an international force
column5: one of the most universally agreed upon leftfield musics of our time
column6: penetrating the fanbases and sounds of everything from hip-hop to house to indie to the avant-garde. In many ways it's a true reflection of globalism
column7: and arguably a product of this century's downcast global mood. Dark
column8: urban
column9: and paranoid
column10: dubstep is an appropriate soundtrack to an era in which the West is dominated by economic fallout
column11: global warming
column12: terrorism
column13: and its encroaching marginalization.

column1: There isn't another city in the world other than London that could have birthed dubstep
column2: but the sound quickly became a global concern. Crafted in the UK by a young group of producers uninterested in jealously guarding their scene
column3: it quickly spread-- not just as club nights
column4: pirate radio
column5: and white labels but through SoundClouds
column6: message boards
column7: and online mixes as well. It's now a central force in underground culture from Moscow to Los Angeles to Buenos Aires
column8: and with the Internet as its key delivery device
column9: all of these scenes and their players are having an ongoing dialogue with one another
column10: making dubstep a versatile jumping-off point for any number of ideas. It's more of a means than an end
column11: and in that sense it has mutated in unexpected and dynamic ways.

column1: As with other global rhythmic sounds
column2: Diplo now attempts to sift through these rapidly changing sands and make sense of it all on his new mix
column3: Blow Your Head Volume 1. It's an almost impossible task
column4: trying to make sense of something that is changing so quickly. Diplo seems to grasp this
column5: and aims to present the breadth and depth of dubstep as filtered through his own sensibilities
column6: with a heavy emphasis on its booming
column7: large dancefloor-friendly permeations and its encroachment into more pop realms. (He illustrated the latter mostly through his own collaborations or those of his friends.)

column1: Where other effective or on-paper promising dubstep compilations-- 5: Five Years of Hyperdub; Peverelist's forthcoming mix of the Bristol purple sound-- have given themselves a clear umbrella under which they work
column2: Diplo
column3: perhaps fittingly for those familiar with his work
column4: goes all-in on eclecticism. The brave gambit means this was always going to be an incomplete picture. And while his instincts are sound
column5: it's difficult to articulate the full spectrum of a rapidly mutating scene. In that sense
column6: the comp is reminiscent of Soul Jazz's Dynamite sets
column7: which laid to waste the notion that ""all reggae music sounds the same"" by expertly placing songs from throughout Jamaica's rich history-- whether ska
column8: rocksteady
column9: reggae
column10: toasting
column11: dub
column12: roots
column13: lovers rock
column14: or dancehell-- side by side. Those eye-opening collections had 40 years of music to pull from
column15: however; Diplo has about 40 months.

column1: And whether it's a case of licensing limitations or just selection
column2: Diplo's mix never really coalesces around an idea other than ""dubstep is an important sound right now."" Part of the problem is that it's self-promotional: The mix is weakest when Diplo's own circle is involved. Rusko is basically the Audio Bullys or Oxide & Neutrino of this shit
column3: and Borgore isn't much better; subtlety isn't in their arsenal
column4: with each treating dubstep like a bludgeon. Diplo himself collaborates here with Lil Jon
column5: so you know there aren't a lot of shades of gray to that track. (Dubstep as the new big beat can work
column6: granted
column7: as DZ's ""Down"" here indicates.)

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Jessica Mauboy and Little Jinder carry tantalizing glimpses of what the sound could do if Rihanna went all in on it
column3: or if UK funky dirtied itself up a bit
column4: but neither track really hits as hard as it should. The highlights here are the artists most people already know-- Benga
column5: Zomby
column6: Joker & Ginz
column7: and James Blake
column8: none of them at their best. The missteps here sound odd
column9: not just in their sequencing but because of the variation in quality; Rusko's fratboy-baiting next to James Blake's exploratory remix of Untold in particular is a big jump. In the end then
column10: for all of Diplo's good intentions and curatorial muscle
column11: the first volume of Blow Your Head struggles not just as a lesson
column12: or a sampler
column13:
but also simply as a collection of songs you want to listen to.

The creative visions of Baltimore neighbors Twig Harper and Daniel Higgs are so cosmically aligned
column3: collaboration was practically inevitable. Higgs' work centers on dramatic speech
column4: a kind of transcendental sermon-poetry that repeats words and phrases until they break free from literal meanings. Harper does the same with sound
column5: both solo and with Nautical Almanac
column6: his longtime duo with Carly Ptak. Mining busted tape loops
column7: non-linear circuitry
column8: and other homemade sonic tools
column9: Harper juggles noises so that they
column10: as he puts it
column11: ""[interact] with your consciousness"" to produce magical effects.

column1: On their first record together
column2: Clairaudience Fellowship
column3: it sounds like Harper and Higgs have interacted for a long time
column4: maybe forever. Higgs' recent sprawling 2xCD Say God had a timeless feeling too. But its sonic background wasn't always rich enough to match his verbal virtuosity. Rather than rising to meet his commanding voice
column5: the music sometimes retreated from it. By contrast
column6: Harper's sounds stand up to Higgs' proclamations
column7: bouncing off of them
column8: wrapping around them
column9: at times boldly battling them.

column1: The closest reference point to Clairaudience Fellowship is David Tudor and John Cage's Indeterminacy. On that 1959 album
column2: Cage told stories while Tudor created abstract noise in a separate room
column3: finding magic in the random intersections between words and sound. Though just as open to sonic serendipity
column4: Harper and Higgs are more locked-in than Tudor and Cage. Clunking half-beats and static squiggles ride the rhythm of three-word phrases. ""You are the life span of time forms and the life form of time spans
column5: yes the time form of life space
column6: Higgs intones as Harper's metallic clangs leapfrog in response. Those familiar with Harper's music might be surprised at the lack of anything harsh or confrontational. But his sounds are so busy that they're impossible to ignore. Even on his sparest tracks
column7: thin wisps of noise eventually coat Higgs' repetitive descriptions.

column1: In fact
column2: you could say that this is more Harper's record than Higgs'-- his sounds are so consistently interesting they can make Higgs' more formal style feel monotone. That argument is bolstered by the album's final track
column3: a 12-minute noise jam that is almost Higgs-less. But listen closely and you can hear Higgs' cadences filling the sound like a ghost animating a bedsheet. That's the strongest impression left by Clairaudience Fellowship-- you may be able to pick out when Higgs is speaking and Harper is blasting
column4:
but it's impossible to separate their individual ideas from the synchronicity of their musical mind-meld.

A Google search for ""Small Craft on a Milk Sea""
column2: the title of Brian Eno's new album
column3: turns up several sites focused on the record's next-level packaging. As phrases like ""signed and numbered
column4: ""copper plate
column5: and ""lithographic"" gave way to descriptors like ""birch paper-covered slipcase
column6: ""crimson stock
column7: and ""foil blocked credit sheet
column8: my first thought was whether the relentless fetishization of the physical product does the content within any favors.

column1: My second thought was
column2: of course it's going to be lavish. This is
column3: after all
column4: Brian Eno and Warp
column5: two institutions of electronic music
column6: braininess
column7: and design
column8: coming together for their first-ever co-release. The union is so forehead-slappingly perfect that one wonders how the two have managed to co-exist independently for so long. But if lavish is the language here
column9: it's for more than celebratory reasons. Constructed partly out of rejects from Eno's soundtrack work for Peter Jackson's The Lovely Bones and partly from original studio sessions held in 2009 and 2010
column10: Small Craft on a Milk Sea is being pitched as a loose homage to the very concept of soundtrack music.

column1: This concept is not a new one
column2: not even for Eno
column3: whose 1978 album Music for Films and its 1983 sequel were borne from identical insight. If not for the sheer amount of time that's passed
column4: or his new collaborators-- electronic music composer Jon Hopkins and guitarist Leo Abrahams-- he might easily have christened this Music for Films 4. And the truth is that
column5: although much has been made of the trio's working process and how it relied equally on improvization and computer editing
column6: Small Craft on a Milk Sea sits surprisingly comfortably alongside the records from Eno's ambient and experimental golden era. Others might argue that fit is a little too comfortable.

column1: With few exceptions
column2: Small Craft on a Milk Sea's 15 songs fall roughly into one of two categories: 'ambient' and 'active.' The

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
former contains some predictably transcendent moments
column2: such as the gently climbing opener ""Emerald and Lime"" and its later-appearing sister ""Emerald and Stone""
column3: both of which conjure up the sort of meandering
column4: piano-led beauty that Angelo Badalamenti specializes in. Elsewhere
column5: another twin set
column6: ""Complex Heaven"" and ""Lesser Heaven""
column7: offer barely moving soundscapes that are respectively foreboding and serene
column8: and ""Calcium Needles"" invokes an ambient frost that's as chilly as Biosphere's most glacial work.

column1: The 'active' category yields mixed results
column2: occasionally sounding overindulged or dated. ""Horse"" is a hyperactive mix of mewling guitars and shuddering snares
column3: while ""Paleosonic"" and ""Dust Shuffle"" go down as aimless proto-industrial electronica. ""2 Forms of Anger"" fares far better
column4: sounding like a fractured triangulation of Skinny Puppy
column5: Joy Division
column6: and Tin Machine (that's a good thing
column7: right?)
column8: while ""Bone Jump""'s dorky arpeggios and haunted house synths mostly just manage to charm.

column1: As Small Craft on a Milk Sea oscillates between these familiar poles of serenity and disarray
column2: it becomes evident that the Warp connection isn't indicative of any drastic modernization of Eno's sound. And yet
column3: in an interview with Pitchfork earlier this week
column4: Eno spoke about how some of these tracks began with conceptual briefs in which he instructed his collaborators to replicate popular music from the near future. If that's the case
column5: perhaps Eno's version of the future isn't forged by sonic innovation but rather by recombinence and fashion's unpredictable finger. Given enough time
column6: the fresh will be re-born as stale
column7: the wonky will become cool
column8: the cliché will become transcendent
column9: and the freak will become a salaryman. When taken as little slivers of a larger poem
column10: Small Craft on a Milk Sea's song titles present the listener with a notion of the past
column11: present
column12: and future existing as one holistic entity. With Brian Eno
column13:
you have a man who sounds uncompromisingly like all three.

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15879/homepage_large.8c582d8d.jpg|Rock Bottom|4629.0|Robert Wyatt|['Rock'
column3: Robert Wyatt's discography comes around again; this new batch of reissues (the first of two) has apparently been prompted by the release of For the Ghosts Within a few weeks ago. Any excuse will do
column4: really. The albums Wyatt has intermittently released over the past 40 years are glacially paced and occasionally maddening
column5: but they're also fascinating
column6: thoughtful
column7: and spectacularly beautiful at times. He's also got one of the great singing voices in Anglophone pop
column8: as high
column9: lonesome
column10: and weathered as the cliffs of Dover
column11: whether he's crooning the politicized lyrics he favors or being a scat-singing ""human horn.""

column1: 1974's Rock Bottom wasn't Wyatt's first solo album-- that was 1970's long-out-of-print The End of an Ear-- but it was the first record of the second act of his career: In 1973
column2: the wildly energetic former drummer of Soft Machine (and leader of Matching Mole) broke his spine in an accident. He spent eight months in the hospital
column3: reinventing himself as a singer/keyboardist and reworking some pieces he'd already composed for what would have been his new band.

column1: The six songs of Rock Bottom were a new kind of music for Wyatt: very slow
column2: exquisitely deliberate. (It's easy to hear echoes of the album in latter-day Radiohead
column3: among others.) The magnificent ""Sea Song"" is the most immediately gripping piece here
column4: but everything has peculiar little joys that take their time emerging. ""Alifib"" is an aphasic love song to his partner Alfreda Benge (they were married the day the album was released); ""Alife"" brings her in to offer an affectionate rebuke. And Wyatt effectively ducks out of his own album a few minutes before it ends: ""Little Red Robin Hood Hit the Road"" concludes with a peculiar three-minute recitative by Ivor Cutler.

column1: That kind of abdication of the spotlight carried over to Rock Bottom's 1975 sequel
column2: Ruth Is Stranger Than Richard
column3: almost entirely music composed by other people (with occasional lyrics by Wyatt)-- it includes pieces by expatriate South African trumpeter Mongezi Feza (""Sonia""
column4: on which Feza himself plays)
column5: Charlie Haden
column6: and Jacques Offenbach. The eight-and-a-half-minute ""Team Spirit"" is sung from the point of view of a soccer ball; ""Soup Song"" is a rewritten version of the jolly stroll ""Slow Walkin' Talk""
column7: from the repertoire of Wyatt's mid-60s band the Wilde Flowers
column8: now featuring very silly lyrics from the point of view of a ham hock.

column1: Wyatt kept a fairly low profile over the next five years or so: He sang on a handful of Michael Mantler's projects and played a little on Brian Eno's Before and After Science and Music for Airports
column2: but that was about it. (""I am a real minimalist
column3: because I don't do very much
column4: he once noted.) So the material that ended up on 1982's Nothing Can Stop Us was a surprise. Most of the album collects a series of four brilliant cover singles Wyatt recorded in quick succession in early 1980. He turns Chic's ""At Last I Am Free"" into a prayerful drone
column5: the Golden Gate Jubilee Quartet's ""Stalin Wasn't Stallin'"" into a woozy a cappella reappraisal of wartime communism
column6: and Ivor Cutler's ""Grass"" into a comment on ideology (played with a Bengali group called Dishari who got the B-side to themselves). There's also a heartfelt version of the socialist standard ""Red Flag""

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15906/homepage_large.5b8334bd.jpg|Adolescent Funk|28083.0|Dâm-Funk|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Stones Throw']|2010-11-04 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:33.637384|"

Dâm-Funk's recent work has a lot going for it
column2: but one of the things that tends to get underplayed is its mystery. And for all the revelatory material on Dâm-Funk's watershed 2009 releases
column3: his idiosyncratic take on vintage electro-funk had to come from somewhere. The Toeachizown series came across not just like a breakthrough
column4: but a long-brewing culmination of a deep but largely backgrounded career. And the dude was old enough to come up in the roller-boogie era his current music pinpoints so distinctly-- can somebody's style really be retro if it's always been a part of him?

column1: Adolescent Funk sheds a bit of light on Dâm-Funk's underheard formative years
column2: focusing on a series of demos and hometapes he made between 1988 and 1992. That period was a heady one for funk and R&B-- Michael Jackson and Prince running top-speed victory laps; Teddy Riley lighting new jack swing's fuse; g-funk reintroducing bounce to the airwaves-- and the songs on this comp reveal an enthusiastic kid with a Casio SK-1 trying to figure out what he could learn from it all. How you hear this music really depends on whether you like late-80s R&B enough to hear a promising amateur's take on it: ""Sexy Lady""
column3: ""Raindrops""
column4: and ""Attitude"" in particular have a certain Class of '89 vibe to them
column5: though the best cut here
column6: the hypnotic ""When I'm With U I Think of Her""
column7: has all the qualities of a long-lost lo-fi house classic.

column1: Not that his curriculum was limited to then-contemporary sounds. The ""Freak of the Week""-paraphrasing melody of ""I Like Your Big Azz (Girl)"" is the album's second-most obvious nod to late-70s Funkadelic (the collection's title being the first). And while it sounds like Sign 'O' the Times made an influential impression on Dâm-Funk
column2: so did Dirty Mind: check the punchy new wave throb of ""It's My Life!"" A lot of the characteristics that manifested more strongly in Toeachizown were already in their prototype phase here
column3: especially Dâm's ambidextrous
column4: two-keyboard rhythmic counterpoints and his tendency to ride out grooves until their tight-knit structure makes it feel like they're sprawling comfortably.

column1: Then there's another side of Dâm-Funk that didn't really manifest on Toeachizown-- his slickly jovial voice that raggedly combines R&B lover-man smoothness with a sort of halfway-squeaky funk archness. And while young Damon Riddick didn't quite have the vocal chops of
column2: say
column3: Al B. Sure!
column4: his personality drives these songs enough to compensate for it. ""It's My Life!""
column5: ""UCanDoItIfUWant2""
column6: and ""I Love Life"" all ride on affirmations of proudly doing your own thing; the latter song even ends on a message against suicide. The love songs are a bit more angst-ridden-- the self-explanatory ""Sexy Lady"" notwithstanding
column7: most of them focus on disillusioned breakups (""Do You Feel Like I Feel?"")
column8: emotional clashes (""Attitude"")
column9: and restless dissatisfaction (""When I'm With U I Think of Her""). And then there's ""The Telephone Call""
column10: where our protagonist is bothered by constant telephone calls (""It must be a bitch"") when he's trying to work on his music. That it comes across as charismatic rather than self-absorbed attests to how much fun Riddick must've been having putting all this together.

column1: Even so
column2: the rawness of Adolescent Funk fits better as a point of origin for all the great stuff Dâm-Funk does now than as an actual complement to it. Stones Throw majordomo Peanut Butter Wolf picked out the tracks for this
column3: and his judgment's trustworthy enough that I'm convinced this was the best stuff he could excavate. But even the choicest early demo tapes still sound like early demo tapes
column4: and if the tape hiss on this doesn't distract you
column5: the occasional tripped-over beats and undercooked lyrics will. (If you ever want to hear how not to overreach on a drum solo
column6:
""The Telephone Call"" is Exhibit A.) There's plenty here for rare-groove enthusiasts with an 80s fixation and Toeachizown converts interested in a bit of backstory. But knowing where he's taken these sounds since then? It just makes you want to hear that funk all grown up.

"|14823.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14823-adolescent-funk/|6.7|Nate Patrin

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15866/homepage_large.af2da380.jpg|Penpals Forever (and Ever)|5161.0|Svarte Greiner|['Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Digitalis']|2010-11-04 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:34.152312|"

Rattling doorknobs
column2: creaking timbers
column3: knocking plumbing
column4: and disembodied wails-- it's either a haunted mansion or another album of saturnine drones from Erik K. Skodvin
column5: a.k.a. Svarte Greiner (Hint: it's drones). Skodvin has an authoritative way of transforming jet-black bass and chattering textures into dark and distinctive atmospheres. All of his usual tricks were in place on his last record
column6: Kappe
column7: but it felt unusually staid and monochromatic. Both deficiencies are rectified on the latest Svarte Greiner release
column8: Penpals Forever (and Ever)
column9: which isn't even a proper new album. The two long opening tracks were first issued as a limited-edition cassette in 2008
column10: and here
column11: they're re-mastered for CD alongside three brand new
column12: shorter tracks.

column1: The Digitalis label boldly asserts that Penpals tells ""the imaginary tale of a long-dead Baroque painter and his telekinetic correspondence with a flightless bird
column2: although there is zero perceptible evidence of this in the music. Silliness of the meta-story aside
column3: the music itself is sumptuously dreary. Throughout
column4: violin bows and analog filters transform electric guitar tones into gruesome pricks and smears. The first two tracks (all of them are untitled) establish the field of play: One
column5: a jittery fugue for brittle guitar swirls and guttural bass
column6: borders on aggressive; the other
column7: an airy two-tone drone with bowed shrieks and lonesome clangs
column8: more readily slips into the background. More than telekinetic communication (wouldn't that be ""telepathic"" anyway?)
column9: the tracks evoke bleakly pleasurable anxiety.

column1: The highly contrasting timbres of the two openers already break up the monotony that bogged down Kappe
column2: and the new compositions further expand the palette while complementing the reissued material perfectly. In one
column3: gong-like tones accumulate resonance until the whole mass lifts off with the grandeur of a Bach organ chord. In another
column4: delicately stretched and twisted metallic tones  gradually inflate with breath. And then a third track is built around a widening cone of  gale-force distortion.  The slow and tortuous crescendos that Skodvin favors are always satisfying when he takes care to differentiate them from one another
column5: as he does here. The eerie tension doesn't break; it multiplies
column6:
as the sonic light goes dim and weird.

"|14789.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14789-penpals-forever-and-ever/|7.4|Brian Howe

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15869/homepage_large.7d3933f2.jpg|Codename: Rondo|5669.0|Ghostland Observatory|['Rock'
column2:
'Electronic']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Trashy Moped']|2010-11-04 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:34.814052|"

It's said that a rising tide lifts all boats
column3: so the opposite would have to be true as well. Ghostland Observatory had been knocking around Austin for a few years prior to Robotique Majestique
column4: but it was their first album to come out after MGMT blew up. Granted
column5: what ensued was a label feeding frenzy only by 2008's standards
column6: but it was a pretty opportune time to be in a duo whose main talking points were squealing synths
column7: hair-metal falsettos
column8: and a wardrobe that included capes. In light of MGMT's rough 2010
column9: you might figure that if Ghostland Observatory hadn't made good on their ""next big thing"" talk already
column10: it sure wasn't gonna happen now. Of course
column11: it doesn't hurt that kind of armchair quarterbacking that Codename: Rondo is pretty much the same terrible album they've made three times already
column12: only with fewer industry rubberneckers to cheer it on.

column1: Ghostland Observatory are sometimes said to be ""simple"" or ""fun"" and thus necessary in the overly stuffy world of indie rock. This overlooks that most of the other acts that Ghostland immediately conjure (Daft Punk
column2: Hot Chip
column3: Scissor Sisters
column4: even George Michael balladry on ""Mama"") have already proven more than capable of mainstream consumption without a first-gen ringtone version of itself existing. The problem isn't that Ghostland Observatory seem like unserious people
column5: it's that the same flippant attitude infects their musicianship. Codename: Rondo sounds like two people doing the least amount of work possible before something can be considered a ""song."" If you're the type who enjoys watching 35 straight minutes of College Humor clips
column6: Codename: Rondo might be up your alley. Everyone else will just hear 10 songs that fail as both pop and humor.

column1: Unlikely to be heard in any hockey arena
column2: a tinny rendering of the ""Rock'N'Roll Part 2"" beat pops up on ""Glitter"" (get it?) and is overtaken by Aaron Behrens' parody roadhouse blues wail filtered through a malfunctioning modem. If you can't get enough Speak & Spell vocal effects
column3: ""That's Right"" and ""Body Shop"" (which is not about cars!) are there for you. If you're awfully generous
column4: you can view ""Give Me the Beat"" as a straight-faced anti-drug/materialism
column5: pro-""the beat"" PSA
column6: but did it have to be delivered in a ""jive-turkey"" cadence? And if you're someone who heard ""Combination Pizza Hut and Taco Bell"" and fucking hated it
column7: then I feel like you did after experiencing this album's title track-- which didn't deserve the multiple listens it took to figure out the joke. That's just the first half. If you make it to the end
column8: you're rewarded with a return to blog house (""Kick Clap Speaker"") where the squatters haven't taken out the trash in a decade.

column1: Look
column2: I understand it's a party even if I don't want to crash it
column3: and if someone gets drunk or laid to Codename: Rondo
column4: Ghostland Observatory's job is done. And if you willfully misread Insane Clown Posse's 2010 close-up
column5: you can assume the lesson is that keeping the faith in the face of critical beatdowns will ultimately be rewarded. But Ghostland Observatory aren't functioning in opposition to anything. In lieu of actual hits
column6: the mere belief in the mock-populism of this stuff has led to mainstream opportunities at big-time festivals and late night TV where they proved way out of their depth. Ghostland Observatory can't leave this crap alone
column7:
and the game doesn't need them.

"|14786.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14786-codename-rondo/|1.5|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15899/homepage_large.a34d6df0.jpg|Pinkerton [Deluxe Edition]|4568.0|Weezer|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Geffen']|2010-11-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:35.407400|"

At one point
column2: there seemed as strong a chance of Weezer's making an album as good as Pinkerton as there was of their reissuing it. To say nothing of playing it live in its entirety. It's hard to think of a more fiercely beloved record a band has gone to great lengths to write out of its history. To recap: Weezer's self-titled Blue Album went multiplatinum on the strength of shiny power-pop and goofy videos anachronistic in the era of post-grunge. For the follow-up
column3: Rivers Cuomo holed up at Harvard and made a disturbingly graphic
column4: harshly recorded concept album that includes his sniffing the fanmail of an 18-year old Japanese girl while imagining her masturbating. Needless to say
column5: it was not played for laughs. Pinkerton was poorly received by critics upon release and considered a flop after peaking at #19. Cuomo probably didn't care about the critics
column6: but he took the public indifference very personally
column7: soon retreating from view. But the cult that adored and passionately identified with Pinkerton became hard to ignore by the turn of the century
column8: with the commercial breakthrough of confessional emo seen as its ultimate vindication. The record that killed Weezer's career ended up saving it.

column1: It's a nice story
column2: and one that's integral and damn near necessary to protect Pinkerton's legend: a popular misconception is that a Rolling Stone readers' poll named it the worst album of 1996 (it was actually third behind Bush and DJ Spooky)
column3: and as Rob Mitchum suggested in his review of Make Believe
column4: it's something that people of a certain age might protect from re-evaluation for what it might say about their youth. In actuality
column5: Pinkerton may initially have been the victim of a generation gap. It was hardly the first album to get this uncomfortably confessional
column6: but it had some unusually bad timing. Self-laceration was in vogue during 1996
column7: but as far as critical favorites went
column8: it was often from a female perspective (Liz Phair
column9: PJ Harvey
column10: Courtney Love) that balanced boldness and raw vulnerability. In comparison
column11: Pinkerton was hardly misunderstood
column12: but instead seen for what it was: written from a juvenile
column13: male
column14: and incredibly needy perspective. It's a really tough album to go to bat for if you're an adult
column15: particularly since enjoying it is so closely associated with relating to it.

column1: And who would want to do that? On the very first song
column2: Cuomo is Portnoy's Complaint on wax
column3: disappointed with his inability to find true love in the midst of meaningless sex. And on the last one
column4: he forsakes a chance at true love for... you guessed it
column5: meaningless sex
column6: giving an explanation that drips with insincerity: ""I did what my body told me to/ I didn't mean to do you harm."" In between
column7: he lashes out at a woman for having the nerve to be a lesbian (""Pink Triangle"") and for not devoting all of her attention to him (""No Other One""). He takes two failed relationships as concrete proof of romantic futility in ""Why Bother?""
column8: and of course
column9: the big reveal in ""Across the Sea"": ""It's all your fault
column10: mama.""

column1: And yet because of all of this emotional baggage
column2: the cathartic power of Pinkerton is second to none. While it's often compared to the Blue Album
column3: Pinkerton bears more similarity to In Utero
column4: a record that also mixed relatively raw alt-rock production
column5: undeniable pop smarts
column6: and a lead singer absolutely freaked the fuck out by fame. But while many sickeningly thought Kurt Cobain's suicide somehow validated his art
column7: Cuomo's self-destruction was more quotidian and relatable
column8: struggling with an unbearable need to be loved but a complete inability to realize the need for it to be reciprocated. It's why Pinkerton isn't misogynistic so much as confused: ""No Other One"" classically mistakes hating yourself for loving someone else
column9: and ""El Scorcho"" reminds that fictional RomCom behavior is actually borderline sociopathic in real life. In fact
column10: the songs most likened to cuddly Blue Album Weezer are the darkest-- ""The Good Life"" is Cuomo at the end of his rope
column11: hysterical at the ridiculousness of his self-loathing
column12: while a single line in ""El Scorcho"" sums up the core of Pinkerton's pain: ""I can't talk about it/ I gotta sing about it and make a record.""

column1: The influence of Pinkerton led to hundreds of mostly regrettable bands
column2: but what ultimately distinguishes Weezer is how they sonically mirror the unhinged and private mental terror of its narrator. Weezer actually sound dangerous here in places
column3: in part due to the recording of Dave Fridmann
column4: who maintains a first-take intimacy even when every instrument competes to be the loudest thing in the mix. Weezer's rhythm section rarely gets much credit
column5: but Matt Sharp and Pat Wilson maintain a savage low-end they'd never repeat-- the coda of ""Tired of Sex"" embodies overwhelming and impotent frustration
column6: while the chorus of ""Getchoo"" isn't a hook
column7: it's a fist repeatedly hitting a wall.

column1: The supposedly juvenile feelings of Pinkerton still pack visceral power years after listeners would've supposedly outgrown them. It's a record that reaches well beyond a diaristic look at Cuomo's perversions
column2: and instead asks something more universal: Do we really grow out of our teenage feelings
column3: or do we need something like Pinkerton to expose them as merely being repressed to the point where they mutate? It's heavy stuff
column4: and in the manner of Violent Femmes
column5: you can argue about the sexual politics
column6: the late-career parody
column7: or the total uncoolness of it in retrospect
column8: but even if Pinkerton is ultimately an album that gets one single shot at you
column9: the mark it leaves is indelible.

column1: Befitting a band for the diehards
column2: Weezer's always had certain B-sides that are every bit as loved as the singles. Though this deluxe version contains 25 extra tracks
column3: 16 are alternate versions of material that appeared on Pinkerton: If you need muddy-sounding live versions of ""Why Bother?"" and ""Pink Triangle""
column4: or if ""Across the Sea Piano Noodles"" triggers an uncontrollable completist impulse
column5: consider it an early Christmas. Me
column6: I'm here for their acoustic performances of ""El Scorcho"" and ""The Good Life"" at Y100
column7: the erstwhile alt-rock station I listened to in high school. Otherwise
column8: most of the unreleased B-sides are demo-level in both sound and quality.

column1: The more intriguing prospect is Death to False Metal
column2: proudly touted as ""Weezer's third release of the fourth quarter."" Not really sticking to any concrete organizational principle
column3: Weezer cull unreleased material dating back to the late 90s from a wide range of sources
column4: including their own fans and Toni Braxton. But as a clearinghouse for an increasingly prolific band
column5: False Metal isn't particularly generous. In fact
column6: judging from its wacky title/cover combo
column7: 10-song tracklist
column8: and overall quality
column9: it dubiously achieves Cuomo's stated goal of creating the logical follow-up to Hurley.

column1: The power pop Weezer work with maintains its devotees in large part because of its adherence to a kind of strict formula
column2: and having mastered it early in his career
column3: Cuomo can churn it out effortlessly
column4: for better or (mostly) worse. Verses are treated with merely custodial concern before the big hooks
column5: there's the guitar solos that are flashy enough to be noticed but easy enough to learn
column6: and the production glosses everything up to radio-ready ubiquity and anonymity. But once again
column7: there's a laziness that's more annoying than any of Cuomo's ""cool dad"" humor. There's the song about turning up the radio
column8: and it's called ""Turning Up the Radio""-- the irony of its being the result of a YouTube contest is actually kinda fascinating. Cuomo's shown an almost frightening ability to tap into a certain generic teenage frustration
column9: and ""Losing My Mind"" is the song to which you can grouse about your allowance.

column1: Upon reviewing Hurley
column2: I said that Weezer's songs feel more like single-packed sitcoms now
column3: but nothing on that album can match ""The Odd Couple""
column4: which boasts the sort of hack-joke opening line (""I got a PC
column5: you got a Mac"") that Fountains of Wayne wouldn't touch. ""Blowin' My Stack"" and ""I'm a Robot"" are the working-for-the-weekend anthems
column6: and that both have blatantly similar lyrics (""I need cash to pay my bills"" / ""I have to earn money to pay my bills"") suggests a general lack of curatorial oversight to False Metal.

column1: At the very least
column2: there's a sense of closure in the simultaneous release of Pinkerton and Death to False Metal: For the past decade
column3: new Weezer albums have been unfavorably judged relative to Pinkerton
column4: and hey
column5: we finally get to do it in real time. But there's always been an underlying unease that
column6: at least in more indie-leaning circles
column7: we're becoming every bit as susceptible to the generation gap that led to the dismissal of Pinkerton in the first place. Even if Weezer were able to come up with something as potent as Pinkerton
column8: would we recognize it?

column1: I suppose that doesn't give the listener enough credit
column2: but we can do away with the idea that Pinkerton is somehow ""realer"" than other Weezer records. Even if they're more Spike Jones than Spike Jonze these days
column3: it exists on the same continuum as Raditude
column4: Hurley
column5: and yes
column6: even Make Believe-- Cuomo's work has always been driven by a need for approval
column7: and once the Green Album was seemingly spawned by popular demand
column8: he's used his band as an embodiment of that. That their ""Memories Tour"" is financially backed by AXE appears terribly ironic
column9: but in reality
column10: Weezer are also a brand that realizes striking a chord with boys obsessed with sex gives you a license to print money. By the same token
column11:
it gives me comfort that Pinkerton will remain timeless-- its fanbase is the ultimate renewable resource.

"|14817.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14817-pinkerton-deluxe-edition-death-to-false-metal/|10.0|Ian Cohen

0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15887/homepage_large.0979a28e.jpg|Sidewalks|5052.0|Matt & Kim|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fader']|2010-11-03 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:36.184339|"

For anyone who has ever seen a Matt & Kim album
column2: the cover of the Brooklyn synth-punk duo's third effort
column3: Sidewalks
column4: won't come as a surprise. Like the band's 2006 self-titled debut and last year's Grand
column5: Sidewalks comes festooned with a grainy
column6: urban image from the pair's home borough with a colorful
column7: graffiti-inspired
column8: screen-printed overlay. It's a look that pledges allegiance to homemade hipster crafting
column9: DIY punk grit
column10: and locavore Brooklyn living-- all of which have contributed to the band's gleefully spazzy sound in the past. But for anyone who has ever heard a Matt & Kim album
column11: the music within this familiar packaging will come as a surprise.

column1: It's not that the twosome has changed their ingredients. Matt Johnson still sings in his nasal-nerd yelp. His synths still mostly eschew gloss in favor of buzz. He still favors remedial
column2: right-hand-only melodies. Kim Schifino's punk drum sound is still big and sloppy. And her rare vocal turns still mostly serve a background-cheerleader role. But it's the way the band's new producer
column3: Ben Allen
column4: combines those typical ingredients that makes for such an unusual taste. Allen
column5: who was once Diddy's in-house engineer at Bad Boy and who recorded Gnarls Barkley's breakthrough debut (as well as indie rock touchstones like Animal Collective's Merriweather Post Pavilion)
column6: adds some hip-hop swagger and studio polish to Matt & Kim's formerly enthusiastically amateurish punk sound. Therefore
column7: songs like album opener ""Block After Block"" and first single ""Camera"" rely not on propulsive synth riffs or buoyant
column8: messy melodies
column9: but on repetitive
column10: rhythmic chords that almost sound like samples and drums that sound mechanical (instead of manic).

A Bureaucratic Desire for Extra-Capsular Extraction gathers all of the music drone metal progenitors Earth recorded in October 1990
column3: during their earliest sessions at Portland's Smegma Studios. Earth

column10: militant percussion

column13: and an oppressive closer-- now showcases the breadth of Dylan Carlson's vision from the start.

column1: Doubtlessly

column8: lacerated vocals
column9: or dark-side imagery

column11: as moving as Carlson's idols in Black Sabbath.

column1: But A Bureaucratic Desire persuasively argues for a reconsideration of what Earth accomplished-- or
column2: more specifically
column3: just how early: It took Justin Broadrick's Godflesh the better

column1: <script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
part of another decade to make industrial metal with a drum machine that's as compelling as ""Geometry of Murder"" and ""German Dental Work"". Though loud and lumbering
column2: both tracks maneuver with finesse and agility
column3: two basses and a guitar sliding through the big beats. Especially at the start
column4: ""Divine and Bright"" displays an undercurrent of prettiness and radiance. Earth would touch upon the idea again with 1995's Phase 3: Thrones and Dominions and finally explore fully a decade later when Carlson reformed the band as an elegant tortoise-like vehicle for slow blues. Even as Kurt Cobain hums and Kelly Canary howls above the mid-tempo riff
column5: there's a certain redemption to the music

column8: grim march that grinds through one riff over and over again
column9: the drum machine beating against the changes like a whip. It's quintessential nihilistic doom metal-- no hope except an end.

column5: and Eyvind Kang. Her mastering job here is warm
column6: loud and careful

column8: thanks to Steve Moore's organ work on Hibernaculum.) ""A Bureaucratic Desire for Revenge
column9: Parts 1 and 2"" clamp down harder

column11: the percussion pushing through the guitars with more gusto

column15:

Harlem newcomer Vado is a good rapper-- maybe a very good rapper
column2: definitely not a great one. He's got a big
column3: blustery voice
column4: an arrogant snarl

column9: he feels like a man from a time when New York still regularly cranked out hard-edged
column10: uncompromising rap songs that work on a dancefloor. New York doesn't do that very often anymore. Nobody really does that very often anymore. And yet here's Vado.

column1: On Slime Flu

column5: and even club-ready tracks like ""Speaking in Tungs"" are pretty rare. And unlike his mentor Cam'ron
column6: Vado's not a word-drunk stylist. Instead
column7: he's a straight-ahead barker

column8: 'Man
column9: that kid glow'/ In the Pepto Bismol-colored Gran Turismo."" He resists the temptation to paint grand Rick Ross-type pictures of his criminal past
column10: sticking instead to truer-to-life stuff about running credit card scams
column11: being a two-bit hustler. On a late-album troika of slow
column12: sinister tracks (""Bullets & Gun Smoke""
column13: ""Crimesquare""
column14: ""Snapped)
column15: he proves that he can do insinuating atmosphere even better than he can do all-out neck-snap bangers. With everything working in his favor

column1: The amazing thing: Many of the best recent Vado tracks

column4: Ames Room

Part II and Sir Lucious Left Foot: the Son of Chico Dusty sit up there at the top of the pile-- but for just about everybody else in this position

column3: dub

column1: A decent remix either stands on its own as a thoughtful piece of music or does something interesting and creative with the source material. A really good remix does both. Ex-A.R.E. Weapons member Thomas Bullock scores a really good one with his deep retooling of ""The Hammer"". The original version
column2: a dreamy ice-pricked groove with passages of molten force
column3: was already one of Strange Weather’s most alluring tracks. Bullock dials down its entrancing minimalism even tighter

column6: with a breezier texture and dubby vocal edits
column7: but its vampy quality is very pronounced when heard next to Bullock's vision and drive: You never forget for a second that you're hearing someone tweaking and filtering !!! stems.

column3: they're pointless cash-grabs; at best
column4: they tend to include a few standout mixes. But like other indie groups who've released surprisingly fertile remix EPs
column5: such as Hot Chip and LCD Soundsystem
column6: !!! uses dance music as a foundation so remixers have tons to work with. This EP actually achieves the feat of casting a revelatory light on some album tracks. In the battle over ""The Most Certain Sure""
column7: Bibio's predictable IDM mix loses out to Liv Spencer's slinky nighttime crawl
column8: but both draw out hidden moods that were latent in the original. And Tim Goldsworthy should get a medal for turning the innocuous indie-funk of ""Steady as the Sidewalk Cracks"" into a wide-eyed art-pop celebration. All in all
column9:
here's the rare remix EP that I'll probably listen to more than the original record.

Like many singers who came of age during glam and made their name as the new romantics were wresting English rock from the punks
column5: David Sylvian has a voice-- unashamedly mannered and theatrical and oozing wounded romanticism-- that's both inimitable and divisive. It's also been the only constant in his music over the last 30 years; the man shreds styles as a rule
column6: often as soon as listeners have adjusted to his latest changeup. So hardcore Sylvian-ophiles are usually in it for That Voice
column7: which has grown warmer and deeper and more restrained with experience while still being recognizable within seconds. It's the reliable pleasure that's carried listeners through Sylvian's less-than-fertile periods
column8: the collaborations that didn't quite spark
column9: the styles that proved an ill fit for the singing
column10: all the downsides to his ultimately admirable brand of creative restlessness.

column1: Sylvian's voice is certainly the only constant on Sleepwalkers
column2: a collection of his 21st century non-album collaborations that's coherently assembled
column3: which means it flows like an album
column4: but artistically all over the map
column5: which means the individual songs range from several undeniable keepers to a small handful of wince-inducing missteps. Naturally
column6: it's the missteps which stand out on first listen. Sylvian's singing
column7: though it's more versatile than his reputation for mannered art-rock melodrama suggests
column8: proves very
column9: very awkward when dropped into a slab of George Michael-esque blue-eyed soul (""Money for All""
column10: complete with Vegas-y backup singers). The oddity of appropriating the style doesn't necessarily make the song fun to listen to
column11: but it certainly dispels the rumors that Sylvian's hardened into a pop-spurning experimentalist over the last decade.

column1: Some old-school Sylvian fans have been turned off by his 21st century albums
column2: which have stretched verse-chorus structure to its limit while recasting both improv-style instrumental abstraction and avant electronics as a songwriter's tools. Personally I think 2003's Blemish and 2009's Manafon are minor masterpieces
column3: but it's easy to understand why folks who fell in love with Japan's lush
column4: tight synth-rock might not be too keen on the way Sylvian's albums now hide the pleasure of his voice inside the forbidding box marked ""free music."" If you're in that camp
column5: Sleepwalkers
column6: despite its wildly varying quality
column7: may come as some relief. Here
column8: in addition to the knotty electro-acoustic/glitch stuff
column9: brilliant Blemish-esque tracks like ""Sleepwalkers"" and ""Transit""
column10: we also get Sylvian goes country (""Ballad of a Deadman"")
column11: Sylvian goes piano bar torch singer (""Playground Martyrs"")
column12: and so on.

column1: Sylvian's genre-takes are always a little skewed
column2: as befitting a guy who's worked with Holger Czukay
column3: Ryuichi Sakamoto
column4: and other great avant/pop synthesists. Sometimes this tweaking adds frisson to what might have otherwise been too stale
column5: too traditional. Sylvian-goes-country twangs for sure
column6: but it also squeals and clonks and squirms with little Matmos-like musique concrète embellishments. But on a few occasions Sylvian's sound-art touches feel like oddball window dressing on flimsy tunes. And when one of those Blemish/Manafon style songs pops up
column7: you're struck by what a singular sound-world Sylvian's solo albums have created in the last 10 years. That's not an achievement to chuck away lightly
column8: so it's good that Sylvian has these one-off collaborations as release valves. Sleepwalkers naturally doesn't draw you into a world as fully realized as one of Sylvian's true albums. But his fearlessness
column9: if not quite his versatility
column10: at tackling new sounds (and even new structures) is still a beacon
column11:
especially at an age when many of his contemporaries have fossilized into post-punk heritage acts.

column3: most recently

column7: airy effect. But they never sounded quite this omnivorous. Aside from opening track ""Kupanda""

column15: fuzzy shoegaze foundation with a hot-blooded

column4: Buffalo Tom

column7: pop melodies buried in guitar grit

column11: not just on that track

column14: babydoll-voiced singers. On this album

The latter adds sweetness and whimsy to his deeper vocal malaise and recalls the It's a Shame About Ray-era duets by Dando and the similarly elfin-voiced Juliana Hatfield.

column1: Overall
column2: the combination of outward-looking and backward-leaning influences on What It Means to Be Left-Handed makes for a pleasing combination of slacker indie rock ennui and joyous
column3: ravenous culture-borrowing. So often

column1: And while The Fool doesn't fully capture their brain-melded performances
column2: it's a worthy simulacrum. The songs on which Kokal  takes lead duties tend to be a bit more sinister (when she sings
column3: ""Don't you call anybody else baby cause I'm your  baby still"" on spare ballad ""Baby""
column4: the 10-mile-stare delivery is spooky)
column5: while Wayman's verses are more vulnerable. Off-kilter highlight ""Shadows"" has Wayman  stumbling through tinted sidewalks: ""I know I'm afraid/ I'm drunk and  I'm tired/ And the city I walk in feels like it swallows."" The song's  unique
column6: snare-based beat and lonely string plucks aptly re-create  her confusion. Elsewhere
column7: flashes of Stevie Nicks (at her most diffuse)  and Jeff Buckley (at his most daydreamy) meander through. And while sonic comparisons to early Cat Power have been abundant
column8: Warpaint's live prowess and band-oriented sound offer distinct differences
column9: too.

column1: In the middle of ""Baby""
column2: a small bit of George Harrison's White Album favorite ""Long
column3: Long
column4: Long"" sneaks in. ""How I love you
column5: sings Kokal
column6: and then the nod is dropped just as quickly. The group pulled a similar  trick on ""Billie Holiday""
column7: from their Exquisite Corpse EP
column8: on which  they worked some of ""My Guy"" into the track's fabric. Like the  effortlessness that surrounds Warpaint
column9: both references feel  totally instinctive; it's as if they just happened upon them
column10: took what  they needed
column11:
and moved on.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15864/homepage_large.c81db672.jpg|"The Effective Disconnect (Music Composed for the Documentary ""Vanishing of the Bees"")"|2976.0|Brian McBride|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Kranky']|2010-10-29 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:47.277126|"

You know Brian McBride as one half of Stars of the Lid
column2: the ambient outfit that for about 15 years has pretty much set the standard for immersive drone. He released a solo album five years ago that stayed mostly in similar territory to his band with a few stabs outside
column3: but he's otherwise been pretty quiet musically while working on his doctorate and a parallel career as a debate coach. Perhaps due to the demands of writing and soundtrack
column4: his second solo effort
column5: The Effective Disconnect
column6: takes small steps to further nudge the boundaries of his style outward.

column1: One of the primary differences between this and McBride's last solo effort
column2: When the Detail Lost Its Freedom
column3: is textural. Detail had a very specific idea at its heart-- there was a sense that you could hear the air moving between you and every sound
column4: and it gave the record a kind of rough
column5: distant aura. The Effective Disconnect keeps some of the distance
column6: but the sounds are much smoother
column7: more distinct and direct. The rhythmic pulses of these pieces of music are also a lot more varied. ""Girl Nap"" features what sounds like horns calling out long
column8: static drones in a rhythm similar to breathing
column9: which is familiar in McBride's work
column10: but the quicker rhythm of the electric piano that underpins the drones is new.

column1: Other tracks build on that. ""Bee Keepers vs. Warfare Chemicals"" is more rapid than anything I've heard McBride do
column2: with twinkling percussion and rapid chord changes in its opening half. It then shifts to a sparser second movement around deeper
column3: oceanic drones that recall classic Stars of the Lid and closes with a melancholy piano figure. It's interesting to hear how much tension there is between McBride's tendency toward stasis and the need for a little movement to match the visual accompaniment. The biggest surprise is undoubtedly the fact that ""Chamber Minuet"" is somewhat described by its title-- rather than producing an extended
column4: shifting drone
column5: McBride uses the strings here to play active melody. It never coalesces into a real minuet or anything close to one
column6: but to hear those strings finally escape the drone to move a little is almost cathartic.

column1: I haven't seen the documentary that this album soundtracks
column2: but it seems appropriately sad for a film about Colony Collapse Disorder
column3: a confounding affliction that's destroying honey-bee populations around the world and poses a huge threat to food production. On its own
column4: it is occasionally a little sugary
column5: but on the whole
column6:
The Effective Disconnect is a satisfying album that should please fans of McBride's other work.

"|14791.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14791-the-effective-disconnect-music-composed-for-the-documentary-vanishing-of-the-bees/|7.1|Joe Tangari

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15872/homepage_large.3ecdd7a4.jpg|Paupers Field|29275.0|Dylan LeBlanc|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rough Trade']|2010-10-29 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:48.066700|"

Dylan LeBlanc was born in 1990-- a lifetime past the peak of FAME studios in Muscle Shoals
column2: Alabama. That's where his dad
column3: country singer James LeBlanc
column4: regularly cut sessions and also where young Dylan got an early musical education. You don't hear much Aretha Franklin
column5: Otis Redding
column6: or Wilson Pickett in LeBlanc's assured debut
column7: Paupers Field
column8: though-- let alone many of the dozens of other country
column9: soul
column10: or rock acts that recorded down there. You do
column11: however
column12: hear a depth of experience somewhat at odds with LeBlanc's age
column13: his sad voice prematurely scarred with regret and haunted by demons (drugs and alcohol reportedly played a role). This palpable darkness helps what could have otherwise been another run-of-the-mill Americana disc rise above anonymity
column14: its evocative textures and atmosphere a welcome respite from too many milquetoast troubadours.

column1: Paupers Field draws its name from the place where the poor were buried
column2: and LeBlanc has likened his songs to headstones commemorating ""things that have died in my life."" Given such a heavy outlook
column3: it's no shock the compelling intimacy of songs such as ""5th Avenue Bar""
column4: ""Emma Hartley""
column5: and ""Death of Outlaw Billy John"" resonates in a way that doesn't exactly foster passive background listening. A great storyteller
column6: LeBlanc draws you deep into the world he's depicting-- you can practically smell the decay - but for those few minutes there's nowhere else you'd like to be.

column1: Unlike so many masters of gloom and doom
column2: though
column3: LeBlanc doesn't lay it on so thick as to be claustrophobic. His daguerreotype songs actually sway and breathe
column4: and while it's easy to dismiss the familiar signifiers-- the weeping lap steel
column5: the ghostly reverb on the vocals
column6: the presence of Emmylou Harris doing a guest turn on backing vocals-- it's harder to dismiss LeBlanc's potential. If this is what the guy's doing just out of his teens
column7: it's anyone guess what life further lived will evince. Whether it turns out to be a crutch or a launch platform
column8:
Paupers Field definitely paves the path forward.

"|14795.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14795-paupers-field/|6.8|Joshua Klein

column1: 0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15828/homepage_large.0baac41b.jpg|Bloody War: Songs 1924-1939|0.0|Various Artists|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Tompkins Square']|2010-10-29 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:48.783765|"
In debating the uses and wastes of war
column2: no image carries more power than that of a mother grieving for her dead son. Two new collections of old war tunes-- one curated by the New York label Tompkins Square
column3: the other covered by a veteran country singer-- deploy that tragic figure repeatedly
column4: generating a gamut of emotions: from despair to anger
column5: from outrage to honor
column6: from schmaltz to utter devastation. But no matter if you're a lamb or a hawk
column7: a letter in the mail can be more horrifying than a bullet or a bomb. Despite expounding very different views on war
column8: both of these releases are timely as they bring ongoing debates about expensive wars in the Middle East into the realm of music and ground them historically and culturally. By digging so deep into the past
column9: they reveal our present fears and concerns to be no different than those of previous generations.

column1: Bloody War: Songs 1924-1939 goes straight to the source
column2: culling long-lost recordings from between the World Wars to showcase peacetime misgivings. This isn't Greatest Generation lionization nor Baby Boomer dissent. Instead
column3: like so many Tompkins Square releases
column4: it's a dizzyingly well-researched collection whose academic enterprise never dulls the impact of the music. These fifteen songs show just how deeply the Civil War
column5: the Spanish-American War
column6: and World War I
column7: among other conflicts
column8: had penetrated the American conscience
column9: motivating and defining certain corners of popular culture the way WWII and Vietnam do today. (Tompkins Square is donating a portion of the proceeds to Iraq & Afghanistan Veterans of America.)

column1: War may be hell
column2: but it provides mighty inspiration. The music on Bloody War is multivaried
column3: lively
column4: and immediate
column5: flexing genres and styles to make larger points about violence and bravery. ""Johnnie
column6: Get Your Gun""
column7: recorded by Earl Johnson & His Clodhoppers in 1927
column8: rambles with determined urgency
column9: pushed along by the string band's precise picking and the complex sarcasm in Johnson's refrain. There is a great deal of humor in these fearful songs
column10: especially on ""The Battleship of Maine"" by Red Patterson's Piedmont Log Rollers. ""Why are you running
column11: are you afraid to die?"" Patterson asks. ""The reason I am running is because I cannot fly."" Just as often
column12: however
column13: these ruminative songs address the pain of loss more directly: The Dixon Brothers' froggy harmonies intensify the desolation of ""The Old Vacant Chair""
column14: a Civil War tune the siblings updated to the 1930s. As one brother ghosts the other's lead vocals
column15: the song proves an eerie
column16: dignified prayer that perfectly illuminates the human costs of violence.

column1: A few of the songs on Charlie Louvin's The Battles Rage On reach back to the period covered by Bloody War
column2: as does the man himself. Born in 1927
column3: he and his brother Ira were playing county fairs and square dances in Alabama years before Pearl Harbor
column4: after which Charlie enlisted in the Air Force and served during World War II and the Korean War. Those experiences motivate this covers album featuring songs by Tom T. Hall
column5: Roy Acuff
column6: the Statler Brothers
column7: Merle Haggard
column8: and even the Louvin Brothers. Some are gently anti-war
column9: others decidedly not. ""Smoke on the Water
column10: which is not a Deep Purple cover but an updated jingo jingle originally by Zeke Clements
column11: proposes riding Hitler out on a rail and replaces Hirohito with bin Laden. It's much more complex and conflicted than some of the mainstream country war-related songs of the early 2000s (there's nothing as brash as Toby Keith's ""Courtesy of the Red
column12: White & Blue (The Angry American)""
column13: thankfully)
column14: but The Battles Rage On occasionally overplays its sentiments. ""More Than a Name on a Wall"" follows a mother as she visits the Vietnam Memorial
column15: and Louvin sings from her perspective with gentle empathy. The production subtly undermines the song
column16: putting a soft-focus gloss on the guitar and mandolin that sounds somehow too blunt.

column1: The second half of the album is packed with such grieving mother songs
column2: some of them popularized by the Louvin Brothers in the 1950s. It should get predictable or manipulative
column3: but even in his 80s
column4: Louvin remains a steadfast interpreter
column5: imbuing these songs with stoic pride. That approach
column6: more than the music or the lyrics
column7: nods to the complexity of the issue and reveals war as both horrible and necessary. That makes the closer all the more affecting: His cover of the traditional gospel ""Down by the Riverside""
column8: with its declarative refrain ""Ain't gonna study war no more
column9: is almost jubilant in its defiance. Together
column10: The Battles Rage On and Bloody War encompass almost the entire musical and military history of the twentieth century
column11: and their startling evocations of loss
column12: fear
column13: grief
column14: bravery
column15: cowardice
column16: and horror are louder than bombs.

0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15846/homepage_large.a78e436a.jpg|Flockaveli|29211.0|Waka Flocka Flame|['Rap'
column2:
'Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Warner Bros.']|2010-10-28 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:49.402318|"

Flockaveli is for people who find M.O.P. too polite
column3: Silkk the Shocker too relaxed
column4: and Blaq Poet too introspective. Waka Flocka Flame is an unrepentant street-rap hardhead-- as much a descendant of New York aggro-thugs like DMX or Screwball as early 2000s southern club rappers. Producer Lex Luger provides most of Flockaveli's thunderous accompaniment
column5: while a parade of no-name/street-fame character-rappers (plus
column6: inexplicably
column7: Wale) give the album the chaotic tone of a street brawl. But at the record's violent core
column8: Waka Flocka Flame stands as a gangsta rap giant whose lack of range is more than made up for by his grizzled bark.

column1: For 17 straight tracks
column2: Flockaveli is a furious torrent of gangsta rap id. There are zero attempts at crossover
column3: no R&B choruses (unless you count Roscoe Dash's rasp over Drumma Boy's ominous marching horn anthem ""No Hands""). Certain songs jump out immediately-- especially rap-anthem-of-the-year contender ""Hard in Da Paint"". ""Grove St. Party"" subverts the record's adrenaline into a cocktail of intoxicated cockiness and tense creepiness-- a dark
column4: twisted party jam. ""For My Dawgs"" turns the record's energy into a survivalist street anthem: ""One lousy-ass bullet can't fuckin' stop me."" Waka's reckless fatalism-- that sense of him teetering on a knife's edge-- is the part of his persona that best fits with the approach of the album's Makaveli namesake.

column1: But it's the sound of the album that sticks out the most at first
column2: a sonic barrage of uncontained hood aggression. The beats are confrontational
column3: shredding up the template of early-2000s Atlanta and turning the remains into an overwhelmingly dense assault of hi-hats and gothic string pads. Along with gunfire effects and Waka's constant ad libs
column4: these elements create a non-stop gut punch of aural adrenaline. Luger's production isn't far removed from the post-Jeezy trap sound of fellow Atlantans Shawty Redd and Drumma Boy-- in fact
column5: he's a little less dexterous than the latter-- but it works perfectly with Waka's sledgehammer-subtle approach. His beats alternate between unrelentling repetition (""Bang"") and unexpected
column6: lurching drop-outs (""Hard in Da Paint"").

column1: But for all the credit given to Luger-- who
column2: in fairness
column3: has upped the bar for rap producers competing with the post-Tunnel nightclub gangster aesthetic-- it's Waka who gives this record its frenetic intensity. In gangsta rap's race to produce the hardest possible tracks
column4: Waka seems intent on topping everyone
column5: stripping street rap to its essential characteristics and distilling the genre into its purest form. But he's no traditionalist
column6: either
column7: avoiding the New York roughneck's reliance on older production styles. There are few attempts to integrate nuance or complexities
column8: gray-scale morality
column9: or introspection. Each track gives a new perspective on the same basic archetype
column10: reducing gangsta rap to its building blocks: hypermasculine children of the drug trade
column11: reckless fatalism
column12: intensity
column13: and physicality.

column1: Anyone coming to this record expecting wordplay
column2: or criticizing it for its lack thereof
column3: is missing the point completely: Flockaveli thrives on Waka's fresh approach to the same generation gap-widening narrative that's driven street rap since before N.W.A. That doesn't mean he can't rap; instead
column4: Waka sells on the way his personality bleeds through his vocals and phrasing
column5: the way his voice rolls
column6: ""I'ma die for this
column7: shawty
column8: I swwweartogod
column9: on ""Hard in Da Paint""
column10: imprinting his vocals in the most memorable possible way: ""Mizz-ayy management
column11: shit
column12: that my motherrr.""

column1: Which leads to the line that explains the entire record: ""When my little brother died
column2: I said
column3: 'Fuck school.'"" This one lyric summarizes the attitude of a record utterly unconcerned with authority and anyone else who gets in the way. It points to the unspoken undercurrent in gangsta rap that's usually mischaracterized as undirected underclass rage: Waka's aggression is the survivalist reaction of the powerless
column4: directed toward the threats of the immediate environment. He knows his strengths and he plays to them
column5:
exactingly.

"|14771.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14771-flockaveli/|8.0|David Drake

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15854/homepage_large.97c2097f.jpg|Nocturne of Exploded Crystal Chandelier|28842.0|Sun Airway|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Dead Oceans']|2010-10-28 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:50.136156|"

From a cursory survey of its beaming major-key melodies
column2: swirling synth tones
column3: and drum machine chatter dipped in dubby reverb
column4: it would be easy to slot Nocturne of Exploded Crystal Chandelier with prevailing indie trends
column5: slap on few a ""RIYL""s
column6: and leave it to the listener to decide whether or not to move on. But should it matter that Philadelphia duo Sun Airway wrote most of these songs long before the release of Merriweather Post Pavilion? In this case
column7: I'd say it does: A lot of current acts working in a similar vein intrigue through potential and seem to have a better grasp on how to adopt still-fresh influences than they do on songwriting. But Sun Airway invert that balance
column8: radiating warmth instead of sounding warped by it. They've created a sturdy album of electronic pop gems that just happens to have great timing.

column1: What's most immediately striking is the tone of Jon Barthmus' vocals. We've become used to a certain kind of boyish
column2: longing yelp accompanying this sort of sound. While Barthmus employs a gleaming falsetto when the time is right
column3: his voice has more in common with the kind of everydude croon linked with turn-of-the-century garage rock. It furthers the idea that the crisp and purposeful melodies of the landlocked road anthem ""American West"" and the endlessly corkscrewing vocal lead of ""Waiting on You"" would be every bit as potent supported by wood and string as they would by electronics. That said
column4: Nocturne benefits from the compositional freedom of samplers. ""Oh
column5: Naoko"" triangulates the swooning sustain of shoegaze
column6: a near-dancehall riddim
column7: and the unabashed gushing of post-Fugazi emo
column8: all leading into a monster chorus.

column1: A little less artful is ""Shared Piano""
column2: which strips the ""Ebony and Ivory"" metaphor of its racial connotations and flips it into a brood on a disintegrating relationship. Catchy as they are
column3: it might be a tough sell if you're not as much into mash-note lyricism
column4: but it's heartening when a ""bedroom pop"" album acknowledges its creation space as a place for romance and not just retreat.

column1: Which is why a line like
column2: ""I wish we could be swallowed by the sky
column3: is a good summation for when Sun Airway slip up-- they benefit more from economy than overload (overproduction also haunted their former band
column4: A-Sides). Particularly during the second half
column5: perfectly legible melodies ascend ever upward into unnecessary cumulus clouds of echo. But those are minor quibbles-- whether you think the mainstreaming of Person Pitch was the worst thing to happen to current indie
column6: or you're hoping the deadbeat summer remains endless
column7: it shouldn't apply to Sun Airway
column8:
who crafted a mature and confident collection of alternate-reality singles far less common than its sound might initially imply.

"|14780.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14780-nocturne-of-exploded-crystal-chandelier/|7.8|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn3.pitchfork.com/albums/15859/homepage_large.c8bb5d5a.jpg|Anda Jaleo|29280.0|Josephine Foster & the Victor Herrero Band|['Folk/Country']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Fire']|2010-10-28 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:37:51.678622|"

Josephine Foster's voice is an especially distinctive instrument
column2: one that can somehow sound less timeless than vintage
column3: as though it might be best heard through the speaker of an old hand-crank Victrola. Over the course of her career
column4: she has applied her quavering soprano to an impressively broad array of styles that has included rustic folk
column5: spiky acid rock
column6: German lieder
column7: and a musical setting of Emily Dickinson poems. On Anda Jaleo
column8: recorded live in the Grenadine Sierra with the Victor Herrero Band
column9: she returns to more traditional material. The album features songs from poet Federico Garcia Lorca's folk collection Las Canciones Populares Espanolas. And for better or worse
column10: Foster and her group have taken a conservative
column11: almost reverential approach to this material
column12: resulting in an album that goes exactly as far as its premise might suggest and no further.

column1: As genre exercises go
column2: however
column3: Anda Jaleo is extremely well-executed. Drawing inspiration from Lorca's own 1931 recordings with the flamenco singer/dancer La Argentinita
column4: these performances are spirited and infectious
column5: with Foster's voice perfectly framed by the sound of acoustic guitars
column6: castanets
column7: handclaps
column8: and dancing feet. The album's humble production suits her well
column9: and on such tracks as the mournful ""Las Morillas de Jaen"" there's little to indicate that these are modern recordings rather than some antique 78-rpm discs.

column1: While Garcia Lorca's work was closely informed by his friendships and collaborations with surrealists Salvador Dali
column2: Luis Bunuel
column3: and other contemporary modernists
column4: his poetry was also heavily steeped in traditional Spanish culture. These traditions are directly reflected in the songs he collected for Las Canciones
column5: whose lyrics are filled with references to Moorish girls
column6: gypsies
column7: bullfighters
column8: and Spanish geography. The songbook was suppressed during Franco's dictatorship
column9: despite the fact that the songs contain few if any overt political references. (Although during the Spanish Civil War the lyrics to songs such as ""Anda Jaleo"" were occasionally altered to reflect anti-Franco sentiment.)

column1: The album's stylish package includes song lyrics in both Spanish and English translation
column2: and though the songs may not be directly political
column3: nearly every song in the collection seems to carry fragments of loss and mystery. Foster and Herrero prove themselves expert at mining the songbook's wealth of emotion
column4: be it in the high-spirited drive of ""Los Cuatro Muleros"" or in the half-sung
column5: half-spoken ""Los Mozos de Monleon""
column6: an enigmatic tale of death in the bullring. The album is at its best during its quietest moments

column1: As lovely as Anda Jaleo can sound

Shugo Tokumaru is a freakishly gifted Japanese bedroom-pop artist with an effortless command of hundreds of instruments. Judging from the gentle
column3: whimsical tone of his music
column4: he is also probably one of the sweetest  people in the world. The joyful music he creates
column5: however
column6: has  extremely limited use-- 15 minutes of his manically giddy pop  should be enough for anybody. His fifth full-length album
column7: Port Entropy
column8: grows wearying at less than 40. Whether they are employing flutes
column9: woodblocks
column10: chimes
column11: xylophones
column12: accordion
column13: upright piano
column14: or
column15: more  likely
column16: all of them at once
column17: every Tokumaru song expresses the same  basic sentiment: in a word
column18: ""YAY!!"" Port Entropy is charming and pretty and brilliantly assembled
column19: but utterly  two-dimensional
column20: and listening to it even one time completely through yields strikingly diminished returns.

column1: Tokumaru's albums usually make room for a sigh or two amid the cartoon clamor. The calmest moments on Port Entropy are the lovely Big Star-reminiscent ballad ""Laminate"" and the plaintive singing saw and piano of ""Linne"". Apart from those
column2: Port Entropy is  unrelentingly chipper. Tokumaru's ability to layer dozens of tiny musical elements-- to pick just a single example
column3: the  flute
column4: chimes
column5: recorder
column6: and bird chattering on ""Lahaha""-- is  still impressive
column7: and
column8: in small doses
column9: infectious. Tokumaru could  probably craft some spectacular indie film scores. Inventive sounds and  textures abound: the clanging pots-and-pans percussion on ""Tracking  Elevator""
column10: the John Fahey-style fingerpicking of ""Straw"". But without  any room to breathe
column11: none of these sounds are allowed to settle in and  gather meaning. When every song gallops in all directions at once
column12: the result is a curious kind of stasis.

column1: One of a long line of sugar-rush bedroom-pop enthusiasts-- spiritual forefather Cornelius and recent Swedish import Loney
column2: Dear come to mind-- the disconcerting note of insistence beneath Tokumaru's boyishness sours the atmosphere.  There is a surely an undergrad psychoanalysis paper waiting to be done  on the types of musicians who retreat to create four-track wonderlands  behind closed doors
column3: and a trenchant conclusion to be drawn about why  their music is so often aggressively winsome. Suffice to say that  prolonged exposure to Tokumaru's flights of fancy grows tiresome at  first and then
column4: eventually
column5:
slightly creepy.
