When I heard that Baltimore quartet Ponytail grew out of an assignment in a college art class
column2: I expected them to sound heavily conceptual and musically primitive-- more interested in ideas than technique. It turned out they did have an abstract side
column3: especially in the word-less vocals of Molly Siegel
column4: but they were also seriously proficient musicians. Drummer Jeremy Hyman whipped up a tornado of rhythms-- he's now a go-to percussionist for the Boredoms-- and intercutting guitarists Ken Seeno and Dustin Wong were fast
column5: complex
column6: and precise. The brilliance of Ponytail was that all these chops served engaging music. You could dig the craft without focusing on it-- often at their shows I'd get so caught up in all the ecstatic momentum that the wizardry didn't hit me until afterwards.

column1: Ponytail went on hiatus in August
column2: and Wong is the first member to release a solo record. Though his guitar prowess is more obvious on Infinite Love
column3: he continues to use it primarily for emotional impact. A 40-minute piece cut into 15 tracks (and then re-done on a 2nd CD-- more on that later)
column4: the album was made with electric guitar
column5: effects pedals
column6: and a few cameos by a drum machine. Many of its passages begin like compulsory exercises
column7: the instrumental equivalent of connecting dots
column8: tracing lines
column9: or winding up a toy and watching it scuttle across the floor. But they become hypnotic melodies quickly. Pin-pricks congeal into chords
column10: loops swing into low-end waves
column11: and strums spawn glistening notes like a sparkler emitting embers.

column1: Not every Ponytail fan will be thrilled with Infinite Love-- even at its most engaging
column2: it feels like an experiment. Wong encourages this a bit in his presentation-- the two CDs here are ""brother"" and ""sister"" versions which open and end the same but vary in their middles
column3: and both include a DVD of accompanying visuals. Clearly this is not an album of songs
column4: and its appeal will be quicker for those inclined to solo guitar explorations
column5: or for whom repetition and layering are a form of verse-chorus-verse. But for formal-sounding guitar art
column6: Infinite Love is sneakily memorable. At various points I hear echoes of Ian Williams' playing in Don Caballero
column7: Steve Reich's phasing repetitions
column8: the softer clouds of Mark McGuire
column9: and hints of metal and prog-rock. Most moving is a passage of lonely balladry that sounds like Wong covering Loren Connors.

column1: As diverse as all those sounds are
column2: it would be fun to hear Wong throw off the conceptual chains and follow this album with looser
column3: more unpredictable sonics-- much the way his other group
column4: Ecstatic Sunshine
column5: often does. Given the history he's forged with them and Ponytail
column6: Wong likely won't sit still for long
column7:
and even the most rigid parts of Infinite Love suggest he's got a lot more ideas to draw on.

Released in fall 2002
column2: when Mount Eerie mastermind Phil Elverum was still calling himself the Microphones
column3: the first Song Islands singles collection has proven a sort of signpost in Elverum's vast sonic journey. Breaking from the dense
column4: craggy
column5: world-beating noise-folk that marked his LPs-- particularly the towering The Glow Pt. 2-- Song Islands was an unusually naked affair that offered new insights into the makings of an Elverum production while
column6: at its best
column7: frequently pulling the focus squarely on the songs rather than their embellishments. The LPs that would follow Song Islands-- the impossibly huge Mount Eerie
column8: the lopsided No Flashlight-- failed to reach the heights of Elverum's earlier work
column9: and he seemed to retreat further into his art
column10: issuing numerous singles and EPs
column11: exploring genres
column12: and releasing lavish coffee-table books with records that often felt secondary. The proliferation of individual pieces-- often with similar names
column13: typically attached to curious-on-paper concepts-- has made it a near impossibility to keep up with Elverum
column14: more creatively restless than ever. We needed an overview.

column1: Instead
column2: we're presented with another volume of Song Islands: Thirty-some tracks
column3: primarily unreleased
column4: covering everything from raw alternate takes of recent works to wormy 1970s AM pop castoffs. It's a lot to take in
column5: as a retrospective of such a monstrous catalog ought to be. But the territory Song Islands Vol. 2 attempts to chart is simply too vast-- nearly a decade's worth of diversions-- to cover in 80 minutes' time. The nature-kid proselytizing
column6: the scabrous drums and stalactite  guitars
column7: the existential anguish-- it's all here. But Elverum's always at his best when the songs feel sewn into their surroundings; the songs from Song Islands 2 seem plucked piecemeal from the archives
column8: divorced  from the bursts of inspiration that birthed them. Elverum's refusal to  sit still these past few years has resulted in some breathktaking music
column9: no doubt
column10: but laid out like this
column11: it also makes for a scattershot listen

column1: We begin with ""Where?""
column2: a scene-setting bit of folk that immediately lays out Elverum's post-Glow 2 identity crisis: ""Mount Eerie is nowhere/ Mount Eerie is playing tonight."" From there
column3: Song Islands slips into the Carpenters homage of ""Calf in Pasture"" (less grim than it sounds)
column4: the percussive drone of ""The Intimacy""
column5: then the more typical Elverum wayfarer ""I Whale"". Each has its charms
column6: but due to their clipped construction-- most songs hover around the two-minute mark-- and the record's pacing-averse genre-hopping
column7: Song Islands never establishes the internal rhythms and deliberate dynamic shifts that mark his best work. There's little apparent order to the tracklist; a chronological sequence might've explained the odd pacing and would've offered up a little more insight into Elverum's evolution over the last several years
column8: but these tunes almost seem picked out of a hat. It's hardly a best-of; the tender
column9: searching ""Wooly Mammoth's Mighty Absence""
column10: certainly on anyone's shortlist for the single best Elverum song in a decade
column11: is conspicuously AWOL
column12: making room for directionless ambient interludes (""Heart Lake at Night"")
column13: sketchbook remnants (""Voices in Headphones [Singers]"") and half-formed
column14: heart-on-sleeve strums (take your pick).  Roughhewn tone pieces sit next to barren folk laments
column15: only occasionally meeting in the middle; his sonic palette
column16: one of the richest in indie rock
column17: often feels pared down to a few basic elements
column18: and while Song Islands 2 covers a great deal of ground
column19: rarely do these songs reach the hushed intimacy or thunderous calamity of Elverum's more elaborate productions.

column1: ""In Moonlight"" gets it right
column2: moving from a meandering solo Phil to a powerful
column3: sweeping crescendo; it's one of the few numbers here that feels more like a proper song than a thumbnail sketch. ""Get Off the Internet"" may be cloying-- whether it's imploring you to take out the garbage or doing it to the tune of ""We Are the World""-- but it's at least memorable. And Elverum's still quick with a well-placed Waldenism that'll cut you to the core; ""when was the last time you touched a leaf?
column4: he asks
column5: and you'll keep wondering about. But
column6: caught up amongst the flotsam of Song Islands 2
column7:
moments like these are far too fleeting.

There was a point at which Olympia was intended to be a new Roxy Music album. It would have been the band's first since 1982's Avalon
column3: and there even seems to be a sly nod to that two-decade gap on album opener ""You Can Dance""
column4: which opens with a brief musical passage that is pretty much a note-for-note reference to Avalon's ""True to Life"". Somewhere in the process
column5: though
column6: this became another Bryan Ferry solo album
column7: featuring original Roxy Music members Andy Mackay
column8: Phil Manzanera
column9: and Brian Eno
column10: and Ferry brought in a raft of collaborators
column11: some old
column12: some new
column13: to round out the record
column14: his first to feature original songs since 2002's Frantic.

column1: The funny thing is
column2: if Roxy Music had released this exact album in 1983 as a follow-up to Avalon
column3: I don't think anyone would have batted an eye. It spills over with the aesthetics and sounds of Ferry's 80s work
column4: which has the strange effect of also making it sound very current. The synths
column5: fluid beats
column6: wiry guitar parts with just a bit of chorus
column7: and electric pianos are all things you can hear on any number of indie rock records today. Ferry puts them together in a very classic rock way
column8: residing at the center as the charismatic front man. The FM-rock approach to the emphasis on vocals is mirrored in the lead guitar contributed by Manzanera and Pink Floyd's David Gilmour-- that kind of playing is one of the few elements of 80s album rock that hasn't made a significant comeback
column9: which may partly be down to the proficiency it requires.

column1: The first half of the album is as solid as anything Ferry has done under his own name. ""You Can Dance"" and ""Alphaville"" have their roots in a late-90s session that ultimately produced about half of Frantic
column2: and they're both very centered on grooves. ""You Can Dance"" grinds along on a creeping bass line and heavy drumming
column3: guitars hovering in the wings as Ferry underplays his signature vocal quaver. ""Alphaville"" is more slippery
column4: cut through with nicely phrased lead guitar by Gilmour
column5: and it's  good pivot to one of the album's standouts
column6: ""Heartache By Numbers"". The song features the Scissor Sisters as backing band
column7: and their studied grasp of disco and New Wave suits Ferry well-- the echoing piano intro is almost cheeky in its easy anthemic fluency
column8: but it's very much of a piece with the singer's classic songs.

column1: Elsewhere
column2: Ferry indulges in a couple of covers; one is a completely disposable take on Traffic's ""No Face
column3: No Name and No Number""
column4: but the other is a pretty stunning transformation of Tim Buckley's epochal ""Song to the Siren"" into a sweeping
column5: synth-soaked pop ballad. Ferry has always been fond of interpreting others' songs on his albums
column6: and like his very best covers in the past
column7: this one reveals a real connection to the song. The album does falter a bit in its second half--""BF Bass"" just has a sort of generic fashion-rock sheen
column8: aiming for something high-class and hitting something more like the oddly sterile cover image of Kate Moss
column9: which basically looks like a perfume ad. Still
column10: it's a good album
column11: and without the pressure of making it under the Roxy Music name
column12: Ferry has made a confident and remarkably fresh-sounding record simply by doing what he's done best for over three decades.

The narratives surrounding the Foreign Exchange's albums often overshadowed the conversation around the music itself. On their debut
column2: Connected
column3: it was that rapper Phonte and producer Nicolay constructed their tracks through back-and-forth Internet correspondence
column4: having never met by the time their album was released. With their follow-up
column5: Leave It All Behind
column6: it was that the group had committed a total about-face
column7: Phonte having traded rapping for singing. In both cases
column8: the results of such improbable experiments were astonishing. But unlike Connected
column9: which seemed to lose steam with time
column10: Leave It All Behind had a different trajectory. That album grew only richer and more impressive as the years passed
column11: revealing itself to be a remarkably complex
column12: mature R&B record.

column1: Now there's a third Foreign Exchange album
column2: Authenticity-- but this time
column3: there's no gimmick. What's more
column4: it is about as far from ""cool"" or ""edgy"" as any music can be: It's an adult contemporary record that is actually musically and emotionally sophisticated in the vein of Van Morrison
column5: Paul Simon
column6: Peter Gabriel

column8: it's adulthood-- not just in the aural placidity but also a lyrical fixation on the politics of relationships. As with Leave It All Behind
column9: this topical concern is very much intact. But musically
column10: this is a much more refined album. Leave It All Behind insinuated a break-up-- if not one that's already happened
column11: then one that's just on the horizon; Authenticity is undoubtedly the aftermath.

column1: Nicolay has successfully synthesized the polished
column2: straightforward constructs of Connected with the labyrinthine soul arrangements of Leave It All Behind. The music on Authenticity may initially sound remedial and elemental
column3: even saccharine
column4: but further listens reveal new intricacies. What kept pulling me back in was the album's final track
column5: the somehow elliptical and conclusive ""This City Ain't the Same Without You"". Over a trickling keyboard pattern and a breezy guitar strum
column6: Phonte and guest YahZarah echo the song's title into the ether with a lingering hook. It urged me to keep revisiting the album
column7: and each time around
column8: another song would stand out
column9: until I soon began to admire all of them. But as with all albums possessing this level of depth and detail
column10: that's how this kind of thing works. At a brisk 40 minutes
column11: Authenticity reaffirms that sense of accomplishment
column12:
cementing the Foreign Exchange as one of the artists at the forefront of contemporary R&B's avant-garde.

The fourth installment in a markedly busy year for !K7's DJ-Kicks series
column2: Apparat's (real name: Sascha Ring) contribution is also the least predictable. Part of that has to do with how difficult it is to describe his music
column3: an ambiguous form of electronic dance where texture varies greatly from one sound to the next. In his world
column4: if a reverbed guitar echoes overhead
column5: then perhaps the hectic clickity-clack of skittering drums will offset it
column6: rapidly stapling it down. And each sound in an Apparat track seems like it was created using different tools
column7: so that guitar strain might reflect the smoothness and shine of silk while each of those percussive instruments sounds like a completely different kind of metal was used to sculpt it. Since Apparat has such a wide array of textures at his disposal
column8: his possibilities for a mix seem vast.

column1: Of the three 2010 DJ-Kicks mixes prior to this one-- Juan MacLean
column2: Kode9
column3: and James Holden-- Apparat's most resembles the latter. Where MacLean blurred distinctions between house music old and new and Kode9 tried to pack as many funky/dubstep records into a small space
column4: Holden went a different route: He took a number of disparate records and tried to make them resemble his own aesthetic. MacLean and Kode9 were selecting and mixing tracks in order to make a banging mix; Holden was selecting and mixing tracks to make a banging album. Likewise
column5: Apparat digs through his collection in an attempt to make an Apparat-sounding album out of other people's music. Though in so doing
column6: he shows his cards a bit
column7: suggesting that his sound could be loosely categorized as one where experimental electronic music edges further into indie territory.

column1: Between Holden's and Apparat's DJ-Kicks
column2: Holden's gets the edge
column3: and it's not even because he selects better tracks. Ultimately
column4: Holden is the better sequencer
column5: with a stronger understanding of the rhythm and pacing of a mix. Apparat finds his groove during a stretch in the middle beginning with Four Tet's remix of Born Ruffians' ""I Need a Life"" and ending at Vincent Markowski's ""The Madness of Moths""
column6: possibly the best patch on any of the four DJ-Kicks this year
column7: but there's a lack of a defined arc over the course of these 24 songs. When Thom Yorke's ""Harrowdown Hill"" appears near the end
column8: its placement feels odd and disjunctive
column9: as if your roommate came in and decided to drag one of his favorite songs into a playlist you spent hours making.

column1: That's a shame
column2: because Apparat does have a knack for conveying his aesthetic through other people's music
column3: especially when he blends two records that shouldn't work together but do. It's most indicative here when the chirrup of small
column4: echoed percussion on Phon.o's ""Intervall"" peppers the muffled sadness of Burial and Four Tet's ""Moth""
column5: enhancing an already smoldering track. And the way Apparat mixes his exclusive DJ-Kicks track
column6: the operatic techno of ""Sayulita""
column7: is similarly representative of this skill. Arriving just after the dryly funky dubstep of Joy Orbison's ""The Shrew Would Have Cushioned the Blow"" and a couple tracks before the expansive ambience of the closing track
column8: Tim Hecker's ""Borderlands""
column9:
Apparat demonstrates how his exacting attention to detail unites him with artists from all over electronic music's terrain.

column1: Norlin returns to the Swedish language on her second Säkert! album

column6: who again produces and now also gets co-writing credit

column8: approachable jangle that puts the focus on Norlin's conversational vocals. So sooner or later you're going to have to try to understand what she's singing about

column13: Lonely Planet

column1: It turns out there's a wedding song

column3: fastän""
column4: where horns
column5: handclaps
column6: and Daniel Berglund's subtle drumming nicely frame Norlin's romantic disillusionment. There's a funeral song
column7: ""När du dör""
column8: where a whispery Norlin imagines a dead lover turning into a tree
column9: so future generations can meet him
column10: or else that tree getting cut down to make paper
column11: in which case she'd write letters with pen again-- she'd write poetry. And best of all
column12: there's an unrequited-love song

column14: where a couple go to a Stockholm bar called Dovas

column17: like the inland simplicity to which it hearkens
column18: is doomed not to last. There was a minor Swedish media frenzy this summer after a magazine  reported that Norlin would be quitting music. She has since dismissed  such rumors
column19: but Facit makes it easy to see why people might want to believe them. Although obviously crafted with great care
column20: the songs  here feel tremendously naked and transparent
column21:
even to someone who doesn't speak the language.

Liars can occasionally be mistaken for an experimental band when you listen to their records. But seen live there's no mistaking that they're a great rock band of a really traditional sort
column4: even when they're performing not-very-traditional rock songs. They bring an instrument-walloping
column5: body-tossing intensity to their gigs

column1: Live at Sheperds Bush Empire is a decent if slightly compromised approximation of the Liars-in-concert experience. The minus side is that there's some energy invariably lost when you can't see frontman Angus Andrew bounding across the stage like a lanky shaman and so on. The plus side is that you can still hear the band attacking their songs with an intensity you get only intermittently on their albums. Liars' always shroud their records in a layer of grotty industrial ambiance
column2: and so it's not surprising that Shepherds Bush doesn't actually sound all that different
column3: fidelity-wise
column4: from your standard Liars studio release. What's different is that

column7: turning murky Krautrock-inspired jams into tribal sing-alongs (""Proud Evolution"") or playing with the joyful fury of a basement-show punk band (""The Overachievers""). ""Fun"" isn't a word that crops up when discussing a band as into eeriness and discomfort as Liars
column8: but this is about as fun (you know
column9: like a rock record) as their records are likely to get
column10: a punchy memento for fans between tours.

column1: Half of the Proud Evolution EP-- the title track

column3: and a live take-- will be a non-issue for anyone who owns Sisterworld
column4: the Sisterworld Reinterpretations remix album
column5: and/or Live at Shepherds Bush. The new half showcases what Liars do best offstage: 21st century post-punk that's all hypnotic rhythm
column6: goosebump-inducing noise
column7: and Andrew's unnerving vocals
column8: which alternate between pained moaning and even more pained keening. It's drifting
column9: droning
column10: dark stuff
column11: much better suited to a 2 a.m. bedroom listening than a cramped club. There's always been a goth side to Liars-- you thought it was an accident there are live covers of the band doing Bauhaus on YouTube?-- but here they crank it to the max. Except this is goth with any campy hysteria stripped away until all that's left is an insistent
column12:
unshakable sense of dread. Plenty of bands make music for your Halloween party. Liars are one of the few you'd want to invite to an actual exorcism.

Liars can occasionally be mistaken for an experimental band when you listen to their records. But seen live there's no mistaking that they're a great rock band of a really traditional sort
column4: even when they're performing not-very-traditional rock songs. They bring an instrument-walloping
column5: body-tossing intensity to their gigs
column6: the kind of abandon that makes it hard to just sit back and check your Twitter feed. Even when the rhythms get delicate and the guitars get dreamy
column7: when the music turns more art-rock than art-punk
column8: there's a certain slightly mocking theatrical grandeur to the band's delivery. They understand that an audience
column9: who could just as easily be listening to this spacey stuff while sacked out on the couch at home
column10: needs to be entertained.

column1: Live at Sheperds Bush Empire is a decent if slightly compromised approximation of the Liars-in-concert experience. The minus side is that there's some energy invariably lost when you can't see frontman Angus Andrew bounding across the stage like a lanky shaman and so on. The plus side is that you can still hear the band attacking their songs with an intensity you get only intermittently on their albums. Liars' always shroud their records in a layer of grotty industrial ambiance
column2: and so it's not surprising that Shepherds Bush doesn't actually sound all that different
column3: fidelity-wise
column4: from your standard Liars studio release. What's different is that
column5: faced with a roomful of bodies
column6: Liars can't (or won't) pull their punches. Here we get Liars the avant-garage band
column7: turning murky Krautrock-inspired jams into tribal sing-alongs (""Proud Evolution"") or playing with the joyful fury of a basement-show punk band (""The Overachievers""). ""Fun"" isn't a word that crops up when discussing a band as into eeriness and discomfort as Liars
column8: but this is about as fun (you know
column9: like a rock record) as their records are likely to get
column10: a punchy memento for fans between tours.

column1: Half of the Proud Evolution EP-- the title track
column2: a Thom Yorke remix
column3: and a live take-- will be a non-issue for anyone who owns Sisterworld
column4: the Sisterworld Reinterpretations remix album
column5: and/or Live at Shepherds Bush. The new half showcases what Liars do best offstage: 21st century post-punk that's all hypnotic rhythm
column6: goosebump-inducing noise
column7: and Andrew's unnerving vocals
column8: which alternate between pained moaning and even more pained keening. It's drifting
column9: droning
column10: dark stuff
column11: much better suited to a 2 a.m. bedroom listening than a cramped club. There's always been a goth side to Liars-- you thought it was an accident there are live covers of the band doing Bauhaus on YouTube?-- but here they crank it to the max. Except this is goth with any campy hysteria stripped away until all that's left is an insistent
column12:
unshakable sense of dread. Plenty of bands make music for your Halloween party. Liars are one of the few you'd want to invite to an actual exorcism.

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15836/homepage_large.52f39a3a.jpg|Orange|2205.0|The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion|['Rock']|0.0|1.0|0.0|['Majordomo']|2010-10-26 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:00.249499|"

1994's Orange finds the Blues Explosion at the exact moment they left behind the pompadour-and-sideburns Crypt Records trash-can garage-rock universe and sidled their way into the Beastie Boys/Beck/Cibo Matto downtown genre-fucking cosmpolitan party. Beck actually shows up on Orange
column2: literally phoning in a guest verse on ""Flavor""
column3: and they toured with the Beasties soon after. It's easy to hear what those guys liked in the band's assault. The Blues Explosion were honest
column4: organic experimenters-- fusing tons of different styles into their musical assault without compromising their ferocity or making any of it sound forced. These influences are fully internalized
column5: rather than self-consciously stapled on. So we get Isaac Hayes disco strings on the drawn-out ""Bellbottoms"" intro
column6: feral James Chance-sounding sax squawks on ""Ditch""
column7: Meters/Booker T organ grease on ""Very Rare""
column8: g-funk keyboard whine on ""Greyhound"". But we also get a scuzzed-up
column9: pigfuck-descended rock band working at the absolute peak of its considerable powers.

column1: On Orange
column2: everything falls into place like it never had before and never would again. The band's gnarled
column3: borderline-cartoonish gutbucket roots are proudly on display
column4: and its delirious self-glorifying goes way further than it had before. (As the liner notes of this new reissue point out
column5: Spencer didn't yell out ""Blues Explosion!"" too often on Blues Explosion songs pre-Orange. Here
column6: he yells it constantly.) But most of the greatest moments on the album aren't the go-for-broke blasts of adrenaline; they're the points where the band pulls back and sticks to the pocket. It's a bit of a surprise to learn
column7: via the newly fleshed-out liner notes
column8: that the band was in a pretty dysfunctional and drugged-out state at the time they recorded it. Guitarist Judah Bauer floats the theory that he might've played behind the beat throughout the album because he was ""junk sick."" Instead
column9: on Orange
column10: these three guys sound able to anticipate each other's moves way ahead of time. The tracks groove hard
column11: and every change feels totally intuitive.

column1: Only a couple of songs on Orange have what could even loosely be considered choruses. Spencer is the unquestioned frontman here
column2: but his vocals are more hypeman exhortation than actual song. A few instrumentals turn up
column3: and all the songs could really work without Spencer's vocals
column4: fun as it is to hear him whoop out the names of different cities or scream about how much his wife likes to fuck. Even with all the smart
column5: well-placed studio embellishments here
column6: this feels like an excerpted version of a long
column7: on-fire jam session. Spencer and Bauer pile on layer after layer of stomp-riff
column8: while Russell Simins' drumming is a natural wonder: an absurdly funky push-pull with some of the thundercrack heaviness of John Bonham. Next to the spidery
column9: introverted indie rock of its day
column10: Orange sounded like a revelation-- an absurd burst of swagger and libido
column11: as rendered by three total expert musicians. Even Beck sounds a bit taken aback when Spencer starts wailing
column12: ""You got the flavor!"" at him after he gets done laying his verse. The thing sold 100
column13: 000 copies
column14: and yet it didn't really go on to influence anyone
column15: possibly because nobody else could do it like this.

column1: This new blown-out reissue of Orange comes with a ton of extra material
column2: none of which rivals the original album's power. In fact
column3: the various outtakes and extra tracks really reinforce how well-sequenced and pared-down the final album actually was. These guys knew when they'd done something special
column4: and they knew when something didn't quite measure up. So a lot of this extra stuff is fun
column5: but none of it is actually necessary. And some of it is straight-up dogshit; I challenge anyone to make it through the 15-minute found-sound collage ""Tour Dairy"" even once before skipping past. But the reissue is still worthy of your attention
column6: since it includes the 1995 EP Experimental Remixes
column7: which cashed in on the band's newfound cachet by getting guys like Mike D and Beck to amp up the dusty breakbeak-funk elements of these tracks. Moby's take on ""Greyhound"" is a sleek
column8: streamlined synth-rock thing
column9: an early attempt at the glacial pop majesty he'd find with a song like ""Southside"" a few years later
column10: while GZA turns the same song into grimy paranoia and offers the world the rare opportunity to hear someone say
column11: ""Killah Priest was born in a pillar of yeast
column12: lost in the miscarriage
column13: on a goddam Blues Explosion song.

column1: Orange is the smoking hole at the center of the Blues Explosion discography. Every album that came after
column2: in one way or another
column3: felt like a reaction to it. Now I Got Worry was the dark hangover after the all-night party
column4: Acme the attempt to push the LP's experimental side even further
column5: Plastic Fang the retrenchment into pre-Orange garage-rock squall. Orange was a one-producer affair
column6: whereas Acme ropes in an unlikely coalition that includes Steve Albini
column7: Calvin Johnson
column8: and Automator. And even though it succeeds in giving extra dimension to the band's hip-hop side
column9: it feels like a big step back from the tersely funky force of the two preceding records. It's a bit of a slapdash mess-- a fiery band getting lost in the margins and
column10: to some extent
column11: losing their way.

column1: On nearly half the album
column2: they sound as great as ever. ""Magical Colors"" is a slow
column3: soul-inflected swell
column4: and it indicates that the band might've kept its hot streak going a lot longer if they'd dialed the adrenaline way back on this one and gone for slinky instead. ""Do You Wanna Get Heavy?"" is a loose
column5: sidelong drunken ramble with an insanely catchy chorus that suddenly turns the song into doo-wop. ""I Wanna Make It All Right"" is as righteously funky as the band ever got. But the songs don't build and retract the way they did on Orange and Now I Got Worry. Instead
column6: they smush into each other with no sense of reason or progression. The choice of Automator as a collaborator is pretty interesting
column7: but it's also a fairly entry-level rap choice for a rock band working at the time. If they'd instead linked up with
column8: say
column9: Pete Rock or Organized Noize
column10: we could be looking at an absolute classic here. Meanwhile
column11: much of the Calvin Johnson material was recorded for the stopgap side-project record Dub Narcotic Sound System Meets the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion in a Dancehall Style!
column12: and much of it should've stayed there. And sometimes
column13: we get that distracting barrage of new directions within the songs themselves. The album-closing ""Attack""
column14: for instance
column15: finds the band at the three-way intersection of Albini
column16: Automator
column17: and Atari Teeage Riot's Alec Empire
column18: and it's exactly the flaming car wreck you'd expect.

column1: Since Acme is so scattered and unfocused
column2: the expanded 2xCD reissue doesn't dip in quality once the original album ends
column3: as the Orange set does. So here we get two CDs' worth of a great band in decent but frustratingly scattershot form-- not bad
column4: then
column5:
but no place to start.

"|14763.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14763-orange-acme/|8.6|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15849/homepage_large.9385c234.jpg|New Chain|28111.0|Small Black|['Rock']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Jagjaguwar']|2010-10-26 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:00.856513|"

Remember that scene in the first Wayne's World movie
column2: when Wayne and Garth are able to travel the world with a little help from the magic of green screen? ""Imagine being able to be magically whisked away to... Delaware... I'm in Delaware."" Well it's that same locale that hypnogogic Brooklyn indie poppers Small Black traveled to get started on their debut LP
column3: New Chain. It's actually less of a headscratcher than you think. Recorded in suburban seclusion in the First State
column4: Small Black selected the location in hopes to try and tap back into the kind of motifs that their self-titled debut EP established-- nostalgia and dream-drunk melancholy chiefly among them. Unlike that ultra-personal
column5: demo-quality introduction
column6: New Chain marks the unveiling of a cleaner
column7: more direct sound
column8: thanks to the now-cemented four-piece lineup and improved production.

column1: This isn't to say that that the band has shed the woozy
column2: new wave vibe that got them lumped in with chillwave in the first place. New Chain doesn't make much of an attempt to skirt those signifiers
column3: focusing more on electronics and rhythm. Most of the songs-- several of which could be classified as straight-up ballads-- are very simply constructed
column4: relying on details to elicit feeling through a myriad of synth textures and vocal layers. There's a pretty simple equation that can be applied: The more compelling the details are
column5: the more compelling the song is. The syrupy funk lurch of ""Goons""
column6: those lava lamp bell tones on ""Photojournalist""
column7: the bouncy drum programming on ""Crisp 100s""-- all are elements that elevate these very patient pop songs and make them memorable.

column1: Sometimes it's synthesized almost seamlessly. ""New Chain"" is both drowsy and insular
column2: but a subtle
column3: muted boogie and Josh Kolenik's vocal melody help lodge it into your head in ways that a flat track like the tryingly plain ""Light Curse"" can't. Small Black are often at their best when they can either make you move or get you to feel or remember something-- it's no wonder why ""Despicable Dogs""
column4: a single from that first EP that managed to do both
column5: is their most beloved. ""New Chain""
column6: with it's gorgeous smattering of vivid synth patterns
column7: is ""Despicable Dogs"" reupholstered: It still feels like a sunrise bike ride with a head full of weed
column8:
but this time in full-blown technicolor.

column1:
0|http://cdn4.pitchfork.com/albums/15868/homepage_large.1604e248.jpg|The Naked Soul of Sweet Jones|9055.0|Pimp C|['Rap']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Rap-A-Lot']|2010-10-26 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:01.419598|"

""Talkin' bout my first solo album
column2: bitch
column3: says Pimp C at the outset of The Naked Soul of Sweet Jones. ""I ain't never had one before."" He's sort of right. Sweet James Jones Stories
column4: his official debut
column5: was a cobbled-together collection released while Pimp served out a prison sentence. Pimpalation
column6: the follow-up
column7: actually came out while Pimp was alive and free
column8: but
column9: obviously enough
column10: the man conceived it as a compilation-- a way for Pimp to showcase himself among all the artists and producers in his expanded circle
column11: rather than a stand-alone statement. And sadly enough
column12: it's impossible to tell how much of The Naked Soul is the real solo debut that Pimp wanted to release.

column1: Pimp's been dead for nearly three years
column2: a casualty of some combination of unprescribed prescription cough syrup and sleep apnea. Plenty of the material on the album sounds like it dates back to the era just before Pimp died
column3: as his duo UGK roared back to life with the triumphant double album Underground Kingz. Other tracks could've been finished only later-- after Pimp's death. One of the album's guests
column4: the onetime Pimp protégé Lil Boosie
column5: has been in prison
column6: facing murder charges
column7: for about a year now. Another
column8: Drake
column9: has really had a career only in the years following Pimp's death; even though Drake calls himself ""an honorary resident of UGK-town
column10: I'm not even sure the two ever met. (And given Pimp's outspoken views on sensitive R&B types like Ne-Yo
column11: it's easy to imagine Pimp mercilessly mocking Drake in public if their careers had had a chance to overlap.) Parts of the record
column12: like the regrettable Jazze Pha collab ""Fly Lady""
column13: feel like chintzy time-capsule artifacts from a forgotten 2007. Others have the sad air of a posthumous Tupac album-- left-behind sketches of freestyle verses
column14: given new music and preserved only because the man isn't still around to improve on them. Like every other Pimp C solo album
column15: this isn't really an album; it's just a bunch of tracks thrown together.

column1: That's a lost opportunity because Pimp C knew how to put albums together. As half of UGK
column2: he produced some truly dazzling Southern rap full-lengths-- giving plenty of room to his blues and soul and swamp-funk influences without ever letting them overwhelm his thunderous low-end thump
column3: helping to establish the blueprint for 90s Southern rap in the process. As a vocalist
column4: he was also the duo's emotional core
column5: singing choruses in a strutting
column6: pinched falsetto and sneering his verses in a thick
column7: arrogant twang while partner Bun B played the wise and precise elder to his unreformed knucklehead character. Pimp himself didn't produce a single track on The Naked Soul
column8: so we only get to hear a part of what made him great. But that overwhelming swagger remains very much on display here.

column1: Pimp's rapping here covers a pretty narrow spectrum; he spends most of his time talking about either sex or jewelry. And if you're not into the idea of a song in which Pimp and Too $hort explain to you
column2: at some length
column3: why you have a vagina
column4: you should probably stay away. But Pimp played up his player archetype perfectly
column5: and it's still fun to hear him lay out juicy
column6: borderline-disgusting come-ons in that elongated leer of his. More than any rapper this side of Ol' Dirty Bastard
column7: Pimp took absurd delight in the squelchy
column8: squeaky details of sex
column9: and he was absolutely unafraid to sound gross. So: ""We got to the beach
column10: the ground was so sandy/ Bitches on my dick like ants on candy."" Or: ""Suck ya toes
column11: I'm gonna shrimp tonight/ My dick make you weak like kryptonite."" Objectionable as it may be
column12: this stuff is always fun to hear.

column1: But fun or no
column2: the album mostly just makes me sad. There can be only so many unreleased Pimp tracks
column3: so many chances to hear that voice on a new song. And only a few tracks here belong anywhere near Pimp's pantheon. ""Since the 90s"" features cheap
column4: twinkling horror-movie keyboards; Pimp didn't rap on tracks like that too often
column5: but he always sounded great on them
column6: and an on-fire E-40 guest verse only seals the deal. ""Hit the Parking Lot"" is a rumbling slick-talk session with little buddies Webbie and Lil Boosie both operating at peak capacity and Pimp schooling them both. And ""Massacre"" is just a dinky instrumental
column7: no chorus
column8: Pimp issuing guttural threats for five minutes. Really
column9:
that was all he ever needed to do. An hour of that would work a lot better than the patched-together succession of guest-verses and lost verses we get here.

"|14787.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14787-the-naked-soul-of-sweet-jones/|6.4|Tom Breihan

column1:
0|http://cdn.pitchfork.com/albums/15867/homepage_large.8fa7d1a3.jpg|Innundir Skinni|28950.0|Ólöf Arnalds|['Pop/R&B']|0.0|0.0|0.0|['One Little Indian']|2010-10-26 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:02.010561|"

The Icelandic singer/songwriter Ólöf Arnalds isn't well-known in America
column2: but the few who warmed themselves to the glow of her quietly spellbinding 2007 album Við Og Við or witnessed one of her charmingly quirky live shows passed her around like a secret. Her snowflake-delicate folk songs are composed of one or two acoustic instruments
column3: her high
column4: trilling voice
column5: and nothing else. She sings almost entirely in Icelandic
column6: which casts its own peculiar spell-- there are no turns of phrase to puzzle over
column7: nothing to separate from the serene whole. Her new album
column8: Innundir Skinni
column9: is fuller-sounding than Við Og Við
column10: but its pleasures are just as elusive and profound. Like Joanna Newsom's Have One on Me
column11: it is a rich and musically complex experience that evaporates into the ether if you let it. It is impossible not be charmed by Arnalds' music
column12: but loving it takes focus.

column1: Við Og Við was structured almost entirely around Arnald's finger-picked acoustic guitar
column2: but Innundir Skinni includes a bustling menagerie of folk instruments
column3: from the South American charango to the stroh violin
column4: a thin
column5: whiny horn-violin hybrid. None of them share the stage all at once
column6: however; they creep in quietly
column7: one by one
column8: from the side
column9: making little pinpricks in the songs' texture before gliding away. Arnalds seems to be freely borrowing what she loves about other cultures (Chinese music on ""Vinkonur""
column10: fado on ""Madrid""
column11: Celtic reels on ""Jonathan"") to create something indigenous only to herself. There are lots of lovely surprises as a result-- the little ""too rah loo rah lay"" chant on ""Jonathan""
column12: the spaghetti-western horns that intrude on the group singalong ""Vinur Minn""-- even if you have to lean in close to register them.

column1: Innundir Skinni also includes Arnalds' first-ever English-language songs. ""Crazy Car"" is a disarming plea to a musician friend not to seek her fortunes in America-- ""Don't go in the crazy car
column2: Arnalds sings lightly
column3: over and over again
column4: to a melody that twirls like a child's mobile. ""Surrender"" is the dark inverse-- a hypnotic song that features Björk on moaning background vocals. The lyrics are incantatory and difficult to make out
column5: but the floating phrases that surface (""I carry you/ I nurture you/ Give birth to you"") and the circular melody worm their way under your skin nonetheless. Incidentally
column6: this is what the title Innundir Skinni translates to loosely in English-- ""under the skin""-- an apt description for Arnalds' gentle
column7:
peculiar and powerful music itself.

Animal Collective's Dave Portner told us in a recent interview that Down There
column2: his first solo album as Avey Tare
column3: grew out of a negative emotional atmosphere: ""[The record] primarily comes from being bummed out-- which
column4: I felt like in the past two years
column5: I've had a darker time"". And indeed
column6: in terms of both general mood and sound
column7: Down There is among the darkest pieces of music to emerge from a member of Animal Collective. The images of the crocodile on the album's cover and in promotional photos hint at the swampy vibe
column8: but the animal association could be extended further: You can almost see Portner's head barely above water
column9: not exactly drowning but having a hard time holding on regardless.

column1: Produced by fellow A.C. member Josh Dibb
column2: the marshland sonics of Down There feel related to the smeared
column3: strung-out electric confusion of Animal Collective's 2005 album
column4: Feels. But to think too much about the past would be to ignore the album's distinct rhythmic tics. While Animal Collective's 2009 breakthrough LP
column5: Merriweather Post Pavilion
column6: was notable for its big
column7: buzzy beats
column8: here the pulse is more introverted and irregular. So we get the clicking dub of ""Ghost of Books"" and the Warp-like IDM textures of ""Heads Hammock"". The clatter of ""Lucky 1"" is panicked and freaked-out
column9: while the straightforward pulse of ""Oliver Twist"" smacks distantly like the remnants of a pounding headache. The rhythms are prominent
column10: but they don't exactly seem designed for dancing.

column1: Down There is less accessible than latter-day Animal Collective and harder to wrap your head around
column2: but it isn't a callback to the more difficult sound that marked the band early on. If anything
column3: it sounds like Portner is taking a lateral step away from Animal Collective in order to work out some pressing personal issues on his own. This sense of retreat
column4: coupled with the internally focused
column5: claustrophobic atmosphere
column6: brings to mind the thematic concerns (if certainly not the sound) of Neil Young's 1974 bummed-out classic On the Beach. But unlike Neil
column7: Portner doesn't seem angry at the outside world. He's asking questions of himself
column8: and it seems he's doing so without expecting any easy answers. ""Shouldn't I be content with what I got?"" he muses in ""Oliver Twist""
column9: later wondering if ""I'm just a thief.""

column1: Down There opener ""Laughing Hieroglyphic"" finds Portner touching on notions of protection and kinship
column2: ideas common to the work of his bandmate Panda Bear's solo work. But here
column3: there's less hope and more personal questioning: ""When I get fucked up/ I do the best/ To make myself not fucked up again/ My heart and my lungs do/ Why can't I do the same for everyone I love too?"" Malaise overcomes Portner in ""Heads Hammock""
column4: as the phrase ""I don't want to"" goes unfinished
column5: swallowed up by echoed gurgles. ""Heather in the Hospital""
column6: which addresses his sister's bout with cancer
column7: ditches internal narrative almost entirely
column8: using emergency room imagery (""The people bandaged up/ The doctor's making rounds"") as emotional armor from that beatific
column9: bluesy shout that runs through the song. The music and lyrics here are cut from the same downcast cloth.

column1: Portner has said that he has no plans to perform this material live
column2: hinting that the feeling of the music isn't something that he wants to revisit every night on tour. And it's true that Down There embodies a mindset that most people are trying to get away from. But there's a fantastical bent to the album that opens up with repeated listening
column3: the dripping
column4: moist ""weird hell"" vibe that Portner's mentioned in several interviews since. The album's theme of the underworld reveals itself in the beginning of the stately instrumental ""Glass Bottom Boat""
column5: where one warped voice asks another
column6: ""Hey
column7: do you know how to get to that cemetery?"" and receives the reply
column8: ""Sure
column9: I can get you there. Just step into my boat here."" The exchange brings to mind Charon
column10: the Greek mythological figure that ferried souls across the rivers Styx and Acheron and into the deeper recesses of Hades. Portner's on that same boat later on during Down There's standout ""Cemeteries""
column11: his voice reverberating off the reflecting pool of the hushed production: ""Looking back on/ Old days"". Throughout the record
column12: the vogue for nostalgia that permeates so much modern indie gets inverted. Sometimes
column13: this record says
column14:
the past is better left behind.

"|14764.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14764-down-there/|7.9|Larry Fitzmaurice

column2:
Atzmon & Stephen|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Domino']|2010-10-25 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:03.202226|"

When The Guardian asked Robert Wyatt how he felt about the neologism ""Wyatting""-- playing a weird song on a jukebox to freak out other patrons-- he noted that he doesn't try to disconcert people with his music; he tries to be normal. What constitutes ""normal"" for Wyatt is this: He was a titan of the Canterbury prog-rock scene in the 1960s before turning to jazz and experimental idioms
column3: though he also had a big single in the 70s with a cover of the Monkees' ""I'm a Believer"". He's equally hard to pigeonhole via his diverse collaborators
column4: including Brian Eno
column5: Ryuichi Sakamoto
column6: David Gilmour
column7: Max Richter
column8: Björk
column9: and Hot Chip. Wyatt freaks us out because he seems too chimerical and free for this age
column10: with its mania for classification. He's a traditionalist who hears with weird ears.

column1: His latest album
column2: a collaboration with the saxophonist Gilad Atzmon and the violinist Ros Stephen
column3: is again evasive
column4: seeming at once defiantly old-fashioned and defiantly quirky. The trio
column5: backed by Stephen's Sigamos String Quartet
column6: brushes the mothballs off a variety of jazz standards
column7: from David Raskin and Johnny Mercer's weepy ""Laura"" to the Louis Armstrong chestnut ""What a Wonderful World""
column8: and checks in at ""Lush Life""
column9: ""In a Sentimental Mood""
column10: and ""Round Midnight"" along the way. But the record also features Palestinian rapping
column11: screwy remakes of old Wyatt songs
column12: and Wyatt's second stab at Chic's ""At Last I Am Free"". The mood is elegiac yet playful
column13: with Wyatt's advancing age and bulletproof stature creating an impression of ease
column14: not to mention a welcome indifference to popular trends.

column1: The fine musicianship does justice to the standards. The coarse wool of Wyatt's voice plays well against the strings
column2: and Atzmon's alto sax injects some glossier colors. His style here blends bebop virtuosity and Middle Eastern sinuosity. In most cases
column3: there is something pleasingly ""off"" or new about the standards. ""Laura"" has seldom sounded so understated and ghostly
column4: and it plays wonderfully beside the original ""Lullaby for Irena""
column5: an incorporeal love song. On ""Round Midnight""
column6: the piano melody is transcribed to strings
column7: and a lonesome whistle stands in for the vocal melody
column8: drawing its wistfulness into surprising clarity. Shades of radio crackle drift through the patient
column9: noodling ""In a Sentimental Mood"". Only the tranquil and straight-faced take on ""What a Wonderful World"" that closes the album seems untouched by a light
column10: impish subversion.

column1: But for all of its nostalgic comforts
column2: For the Ghosts Within is also a protest record. Atzmon
column3: an Israeli-born British citizen
column4: is a notable anti-Zionist writer and activist. On the title track
column5: his sax yodels like a muezzin calling the faithful to prayer
column6: and the lyrics by Wyatt's wife Alfreda Benge are unmistakable in their sympathies: ""We're still here
column7: under the olive trees/ When will you see it's where we belong?"" The theme of Palestinian displacement and rage is sounded again on the album's strangest song
column8: ""Where Are They Now?"" A palimpsest of Charleston-dancing horns slams abruptly into furious Arabic raps by a pair of British-Palestinian MCs. The way Atzmon weaves exotic foreign figures into fusty Western standards is more than progressive fusion
column9:
seeming to angrily parody the besieged mindset of xenophobes and cultural purists everywhere. Leave it to Wyatt to craft a record that simultaneously celebrates and criticizes the limits of the traditional.

"|14761.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14761-for-the-ghosts-within/|7.7|Brian Howe

Last fall
column2: Cleveland native Dylan Baldi began recording songs in his parents' basement
column3: on a computer
column4: under the name Cloud Nothings. By December
column5: Baldi was playing his first show
column6: opening for lo-fi kingpins Woods and Real Estate in Brooklyn. There was one snag: Baldi
column7: 18 at the time
column8: was in the middle of his first college finals. He opted to drop out
column9: play the show
column10: and spend his time touring and recording like wild.

column1: Turning On is a compilation that lassos together nearly everything from those first several months
column2: including one split cassette
column4: and the cassette-turned-CD-R-turned-vinyl LP from which it takes its name. All of the songs have been floating around online for a while
column5: but the comp is as much a primer for a forthcoming full-length as it is an early portrait of a young songwriter with an immediate ear for what works and why. Though Baldi figured out pretty quickly how to deliver his hooks in a variety of styles (see: the post-punk squall of ""I Am Rooftop"" or the AM-radio twinkle of ""Strummin'"") his strength lies in always giving straight-ahead pop mechanics license to spazz out. Verses boast sharp fangs
column6: choruses beg repeating
column7: and everything is presented with throaty conviction.

column1: But what becomes clear most quickly is how much these songs would benefit from a studio and band. (Baldi recorded every instrument himself.) Beneath his chorus and backup vocal on ""Waddya Wanna Know""
column2: you can barely make out a handsome guitar line that
column3: if heard more clearly
column4: would only tease out more melody. Three quarters of the way through ""Water Turns Back""
column5: the disc's highlight
column6: Baldi solos loosely but very faintly
column7: the sound of his Fender almost completely buried in an already heady mix. Moments like that are scattered throughout this compilation
column8: though to really hear a difference
column9: you need to hear something new.

column1: Released alongside Turning On
column2: the four-song Leave You Forever single
column3: recorded this summer
column4: finds Baldi giving his songs a bath. The guitars are clean and sharp
column5: there's a drummer with verve behind the kit
column6: and as a result
column7: every hook is more vibrant. From the slingshot pace of the title track to the La's-like ribbons of ""Talk to Me"" to the harmony-enriched coda of ""You Were Scared""
column8: there's a lot at which to marvel. Here
column9: Baldi sounds not just like a guy getting over a girl
column10:
but someone whose melodic understanding continues to evolve as his confidence grows.

"|14765.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14765-turning-on-leave-you-forever/|7.9|David Bevan

With their debut
column2: last year's Until the Earth Begins to Part
column3: sweeping Scottish sextet Broken Records announced themselves as outsized emoters who never met a baroque chamber arrangement they didn't covet. They then pitched themselves to an audience of Caledonophiles who worship the crashing songcraft of Frightened Rabbit
column4: the Twilight Sad
column5: and We Were Promised Jetpacks. Compared to their fellow countrymen
column6: however
column7: Broken Records sounded overcooked: too intense for their glossy production
column8: too self-serious to be relatable
column9: and
column10: overall
column11: too reliant on over-the-top dynamics.

column1: Though Broken Records have made no major changes to the aggressively earnest sound on their second album
column2: Let Me Come Home
column3: they have made some adjustments for the better. The overall mood is a little darker and the production rawer. They locate moments of relative quiet or expansiveness
column4: instead of pitching a constant aural assault. And frontman Jamie Sutherland
column5: whose guttural Boss-with-a-brogue bellowing grates
column6: finally allows himself to sound simple at times. When he gives over to his stirring baritone (as on the restrained
column7: sparse piano ballad ""Dia Dos Namarados"" or the beginning of ""A Leaving Song"") he sounds haunted and vulnerable rather than like a drunk having a tantrum. Yes
column8: there are still moments when he relies too heavily on his raving caterwaul or an equally irritating Coldplay-like falsetto keening
column9: but they are blessedly fewer and farther between on this album.

column1: Broken Records have been called the Scottish Arcade Fire
column2: but that is true only in theory
column3: because both are huge bands with huge sounds that are obsessed with huge ideas. In practice
column4: Broken Records are actually more like the Killers with accents (or
column5: more accurately
column6: without fake accents). Home's best track
column7: ""A Darkness Rises Up""
column8: recalls the Killers' own Sam's Town-era Springsteen affliction and plays like a sequel to ""When You Were Young"" with its insistent piano pounding
column9: dramatically hushed bridge
column10: and unrelenting drive. And like the Killers
column11: Broken Records are strivers that sound so desperate to be liked that they give off a whiff of bloated (and unearned) self-importance.

column1: But that said
column2: the album's overall theme of searching for security resonates-- with the trifecta of ""The Leaving Song""
column3: ""I Used To Dream""
column4: and album closer ""Home"" forming a story arc of a man striking out on his own
column5: looking for his place in the world
column6: and wanting to return home-- and are nicely echoed in homey flourishes of Americana-influenced string arrangements and continual lyrical repetition. The band are smart to end with ""Home""
column7: a track that not only offers the clearest sentiment (the loneliness-tinged
column8: oft-repeated ""let me come home
column9: which is obviously central to the record as it forms its title)
column10: but also closes the collection with a swooning whisper instead of a raucous bleat
column11: which allows even the album's most bombastic moments to recede into your memory. Let Me Come Home is still too overworked
column12: but
column13: as that final song proves
column14:
it represents a welcome shift toward (relative) musical simplicity and lyrical honestly that shows that the band is heading in the right direction.

The psych band NYMPH's self-titled debut has been available only on vinyl until this point
column2: which makes perfect sense considering their fringe aesthetic and free-form impulses. Tinkering with fractured classic rock
column3: drum-circle grooves
column4: thrash
column5: jazz
column6: and just about anything else that happens to wiggle its way into the band's train of thought
column7: NYMPH seem almost out to make music solely because it's fun for them to play. But with quirky style-appropriation and some flat-out ballsy performances
column8: the band's dedication to exercising their pure id usually outweighs any of the numbing pretensions associated with underground rock
column9: making this album both unpredictable and weirdly satisfying.

column1: Sure
column2: there are only three proper songs cozily nestled in between two spastic jams
column3: the latter of which clocks in at 22 minutes. Those long
column4: improvisational bookends are the album highlights: Save for the sax-anchored free-jazz of ""Reeds of Osirion""
column5: opener ""ii-Yo"" and closer ""Namu"" deliver more woolly energy than their condensed counterparts. Instead of getting by solely on its obtuseness
column6: NYMPH feels like the work of a proper rock band: Guitarist Matty McDermott's damaged blues and Jason Robira's spastic drum work on ""ii-Yo"" work together so well even the noisy contrasting moments seem purposefully arranged. All throughout
column7: players collide into one another
column8: providing a little release
column9: a little confusion
column10: and frequently a lot of style
column11: helping richly characterize these two huge tracks.

column1: Not that NYMPH are incapable of handling a little concision once and a while. Though the childish whimsy of ""Bird Song"" is ultimately more trying than anything else
column2: ""Reeds of Osirion"" and ""Snow Song"" both make the most of NYMPH at half a click
column3: teasing out little nuances that stick in your head. ""Snow Song"" plinks about coldly and curiously
column4: featuring a melodic hook that seems to nick Danny Elfman's Edward Scissorhands score-- it's a simple
column5: wonderfully associative detail that provides a somber
column6: chilly backdrop for those frazzled blasts of guitar noise and shallow vocal gasps. For a heady moment on a record that's more inclined to shake its energy out all over the place
column7:
it's a suitably ruminative centerpiece. The rest is actually just a lot of fun.

It's 70 years after John Lennon's birth
column2: and 30 after his death
column3: and his solo career is still a knotty
column4: vexing mess. The current round of reissues and repackages includes the third and fourth posthumous boxed sets of his work
column5: and the fifth-or-so stab at a greatest-hits compilation; they're still not nearly as satisfying as you'd expect from one of the most important figures in the history of rock. That's partly because Lennon spent his solo years painfully aware of how important he was
column6: alternately trying to see how he could use his fame to act in the world and how he could rebel against his fame's trappings.

column1: Lennon had gotten a head start on his solo career: In the final couple of years of the Beatles
column2: he'd started batting out records as reports from the front
column3: whether or not his bandmates were available or interested. In 1968 and 1969
column4: he made three albums with Yoko Ono
column5: in her idiom (conceptual art) but his medium (LPs)
column6: none of them in the current batch of reissues. The two of them also started releasing singles credited to the Plastic Ono Band-- a John song on the A-side
column7: a Yoko song on the B-side. The first Plastic Ono Band single
column8: ""Give Peace a Chance""
column9: was the soundtrack to a clever bit of political branding; ""Cold Turkey"" was written and recorded very shortly after he kicked heroin
column10: in late summer 1969; ""Instant Karma!"" was in record stores 10 days after it was written.

column1: The odd thing about John and Yoko's simultaneously released
column2: identically designed solo albums entitled Plastic Ono Band is that hers is more suited to repeated listening
column3: but his is better as conceptual art. (It's still pretty good as music: He's backed up by Ringo Starr
column4: Billy Preston
column5: and longtime Beatles associate Klaus Voormann.) The concept was the biggest rock star in the world breaking his wand and burning his books; directly expressing his unseemly emotions; doing things he would never
column6: ever have gotten away with in the Beatles. He starts the album by working himself up into a total howling breakdown about his parental abandonment issues-- in 1970
column7: you <i>did not do that in public
column8: ever-- and spends the rest of it essentially stripping himself naked. (He'd already done that
column9: literally
column10: on the cover of his and Yoko's first collaboration
column11: Two Virgins.) ""God"" takes the concept to its destination: it's Lennon declaring
column12: bluntly
column13: that every myth that has ever given his audience comfort
column14: up to and including the Beatles
column15: is no longer of use-- ""the dream is over.""

column1: The Achilles' heel of John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band is that it's functionally very similar to the world's most privileged man having a tantrum; it's hard to hear it now without thinking of National Lampoon's ""Magical Misery Tour""
column2: a dead-on pastiche of the album whose lyrics are entirely drawn from Lennon's legendarily withering 1970 Rolling Stone interview
column3: ending with a repeated howl of ""genius is PAAAAAIN!"" But
column4: yeah
column5: it's a hell of an album
column6: anyway.

column1: Imagine is one last visit to the edgy but likable variety show of White Album-era Beatles (""Jealous Guy"" is actually rewritten from the White Album demo ""Child of Nature""). Lennon still had an axe or five to grind-- ""How Do You Sleep?"" is an open attack on Paul McCartney (and features George Harrison on snarly slide guitar)-- and he was getting into an unfortunate habit of repeating himself: ""Oh Yoko!"" half-recycles a line from ""A Day in the Life"" as its refrain. But there are flashes of brilliance all over the record
column2: from the unstoppable invective of ""Gimme Some Truth"" (""no short-haired yellow-bellied son of Tricky Dicky's gonna Mother Hubbard soft-soap me with just a pocketful of hope"") to the reverse-double-entendre bruiser ""It's So Hard"". If the title track sounds like hippie bullshit now
column3: that's just because it's been played to death.

column1: And then Lennon moved to New York and started hanging out with much bigger potheads than himself
column2: and everything kind of went to hell for a while. Some Time in New York City is a reeking lump of an album
column3: the low point of his catalogue. The first disc is Lennon and Ono trading off songs of sanctimonious
column4: unconvincing agitprop
column5: most of which were guaranteed to alienate the people they were ostensibly meant to convince. (A rock star starting his follow-up to a #1 album with a militant feminist anthem might have been a bracing idea in 1972
column6: except that it's a witless 50s rock'n'roll pastiche called ""Woman Is the Nigger of the World"". Yeah
column7: that'll help.) There's also the matter of Ono's songs: She's a superb artist and a very interesting musician and songwriter
column8: and you should go listen to Fly if you don't believe me
column9: but when she tried to write and sing in Lennon's idiom
column10: she was simply not in the same league. The previous reissue of Some Time excised most of the second disc's shitty live jams; this one reinstates them.

column1: Mind Games
column2: on the other hand
column3: isn't particularly off-putting-- it's just creatively exhausted and timid. The title track has a nice tune; the session dudes who play on the album are entirely competent; ""Aisumasen (I'm Sorry)"" is a sweet sentiment. But there is not a single risky or urgent moment on the entire thing.

column1: After he separated from Ono in 1973
column2: Lennon moved to L.A. and made a pair of slick but emotionally turbulent albums. The linchpin of Walls and Bridges
column3: ""Whatever Gets You Thru the Night""
column4: featuring Elton John on piano
column5: was Lennon's first solo #1 single
column6: and a slightly jarring nod to disco. Its laissez-faire hedonism was pretty far from the persona Lennon had established

It's 70 years after John Lennon's birth
column2: and 30 after his death
column3: and his solo career is still a knotty
column4: vexing mess. The current round of reissues and repackages includes the third and fourth posthumous boxed sets of his work
column5: and the fifth-or-so stab at a greatest-hits compilation; they're still not nearly as satisfying as you'd expect from one of the most important figures in the history of rock. That's partly because Lennon spent his solo years painfully aware of how important he was
column6: alternately trying to see how he could use his fame to act in the world and how he could rebel against his fame's trappings.

column1: Lennon had gotten a head start on his solo career: In the final couple of years of the Beatles
column2: he'd started batting out records as reports from the front
column3: whether or not his bandmates were available or interested. In 1968 and 1969
column4: he made three albums with Yoko Ono
column5: in her idiom (conceptual art) but his medium (LPs)
column6: none of them in the current batch of reissues. The two of them also started releasing singles credited to the Plastic Ono Band-- a John song on the A-side
column7: a Yoko song on the B-side. The first Plastic Ono Band single
column8: ""Give Peace a Chance""
column9: was the soundtrack to a clever bit of political branding; ""Cold Turkey"" was written and recorded very shortly after he kicked heroin
column10: in late summer 1969; ""Instant Karma!"" was in record stores 10 days after it was written.

column1: The odd thing about John and Yoko's simultaneously released
column2: identically designed solo albums entitled Plastic Ono Band is that hers is more suited to repeated listening
column3: but his is better as conceptual art. (It's still pretty good as music: He's backed up by Ringo Starr
column4: Billy Preston
column5: and longtime Beatles associate Klaus Voormann.) The concept was the biggest rock star in the world breaking his wand and burning his books; directly expressing his unseemly emotions; doing things he would never
column6: ever have gotten away with in the Beatles. He starts the album by working himself up into a total howling breakdown about his parental abandonment issues-- in 1970
column7: you <i>did not do that in public
column8: ever-- and spends the rest of it essentially stripping himself naked. (He'd already done that
column9: literally
column10: on the cover of his and Yoko's first collaboration
column11: Two Virgins.) ""God"" takes the concept to its destination: it's Lennon declaring
column12: bluntly
column13: that every myth that has ever given his audience comfort
column14: up to and including the Beatles
column15: is no longer of use-- ""the dream is over.""

column1: The Achilles' heel of John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band is that it's functionally very similar to the world's most privileged man having a tantrum; it's hard to hear it now without thinking of National Lampoon's ""Magical Misery Tour""
column2: a dead-on pastiche of the album whose lyrics are entirely drawn from Lennon's legendarily withering 1970 Rolling Stone interview
column3: ending with a repeated howl of ""genius is PAAAAAIN!"" But
column4: yeah
column5: it's a hell of an album
column6: anyway.

column1: Imagine is one last visit to the edgy but likable variety show of White Album-era Beatles (""Jealous Guy"" is actually rewritten from the White Album demo ""Child of Nature""). Lennon still had an axe or five to grind-- ""How Do You Sleep?"" is an open attack on Paul McCartney (and features George Harrison on snarly slide guitar)-- and he was getting into an unfortunate habit of repeating himself: ""Oh Yoko!"" half-recycles a line from ""A Day in the Life"" as its refrain. But there are flashes of brilliance all over the record
column2: from the unstoppable invective of ""Gimme Some Truth"" (""no short-haired yellow-bellied son of Tricky Dicky's gonna Mother Hubbard soft-soap me with just a pocketful of hope"") to the reverse-double-entendre bruiser ""It's So Hard"". If the title track sounds like hippie bullshit now
column3: that's just because it's been played to death.

column1: And then Lennon moved to New York and started hanging out with much bigger potheads than himself
column2: and everything kind of went to hell for a while. Some Time in New York City is a reeking lump of an album
column3: the low point of his catalogue. The first disc is Lennon and Ono trading off songs of sanctimonious
column4: unconvincing agitprop
column5: most of which were guaranteed to alienate the people they were ostensibly meant to convince. (A rock star starting his follow-up to a #1 album with a militant feminist anthem might have been a bracing idea in 1972
column6: except that it's a witless 50s rock'n'roll pastiche called ""Woman Is the Nigger of the World"". Yeah
column7: that'll help.) There's also the matter of Ono's songs: She's a superb artist and a very interesting musician and songwriter
column8: and you should go listen to Fly if you don't believe me
column9: but when she tried to write and sing in Lennon's idiom
column10: she was simply not in the same league. The previous reissue of Some Time excised most of the second disc's shitty live jams; this one reinstates them.

column1: Mind Games
column2: on the other hand
column3: isn't particularly off-putting-- it's just creatively exhausted and timid. The title track has a nice tune; the session dudes who play on the album are entirely competent; ""Aisumasen (I'm Sorry)"" is a sweet sentiment. But there is not a single risky or urgent moment on the entire thing.

In their half-decade lifespan Dexys Midnight Runners went through at least four distinct versions
column3: each forged then broken on the ferocious
column4: perfectionist willpower of leader Kevin Rowland. When the version of the band that made debut album Searching for the Young Soul Rebels went on the road
column5: they called it the ""Intense Emotions"" tour
column6: and the music they made together bore that out. This 30th anniversary reissue comes with a bonus disc covering the entire career of that first Dexys incarnation
column7: from debut single ""Dance Stance"" to ""Plan B""
column8: the first disc cut by Dexys Mark II. Repeated material from radio sessions means there's a certain amount of fat
column9: especially if you own prior compilations. But if you're new to the band
column10: this is an album that deserves the extended look.

column1: Dexys thrived in a period of fierce
column2: tribal pop loyalties by radiating and inspiring passion unusual even for the time. ""Dance Stance""-- reprised on the album as ""Burn It Down""-- sets out their stall
column3: a brawling kind of soul
column4: the band's thick
column5: brass-driven sound topped by Rowland's combative yelp: ""Shut your mouth till you know the truth."" Indeed on parts of Searching
column6: Rowland is so passionate he's barely comprehensible-- ""Thankfully Not Living in Yorkshire It Doesn't Apply"" is high-register babble; on ""There
column7: There
column8: My Dear"" his determination to prove a point turns the verses into an angry
column9: thrilling tumult of words.

column1: Rowland's artistic breakthrough came in applying the lessons of punk to the ideal of soul: If soul was a feeling
column2: an inner fire
column3: then the technical limitations of the singer were simply irrelevant. If you believed in yourself
column4: your soul and the purity of your self-expression
column5: you were a soul singer no matter how gulping and agonised your actual voice was. But did he believe in himself? Too contrarian to sing much about politics
column6: Dexys were nonetheless an ideal band for a moment in which every aesthetic and lifestyle decision felt intensely political. Songs like ""There
column7: There
column8: My Dear"" lashed out at others for compromise and fakery
column9: but Rowland was his own harshest critic. His ascetic self-doubt and self-scrutiny powered the band's career. This version of Dexys broke up after falling out over the release of ""Keep It Pt. II"" as a single-- four minutes of choked
column10: howling self-flagellation from Rowland whose subtitle
column11: ""Inferiority Pt. I""
column12: says it all.

column1: That single's B-Side
column2: ""One Way Love""
column3: was a vigorous soul cover-- Dexys' early catalogue is studded with them
column4: and much of this set's second disc is taken up with versions of ""Respect""
column5: ""Soul Finger""
column6: and three goes at Johnny Johnson's terrific ""Breaking Down the Walls of Heartache"". While Rowland's psychodramas are more compelling
column7: this scrappy
column8: good-times side of the band helped build their fanbase. In fact the best moments come when Rowland marries his self-awareness to his group's instrumental toughness-- the loping gang-chant ""Geno""
column9: smoldering ""I'm Just Looking""
column10: and joyful stomper ""Tell Me When My Light Turns Green"". Rowland's obsessions would lead his band in ever more fascinating directions
column11:
but ultimately it's this line-up's aspiration to being a working soul band that makes Searching the tightest and most consistent Dexys album.

For a duo best known for pop-dance albums with big choruses and bright hooks
column3: this is one sinister DJ mix that's not much interested in making converts. When the most accessible vocal cut here is Simian Mobile Disco's own remix of DJ Hell's ""U Can Dance""-- wherein Bryan Ferry sounds like he's moonlighting at Satan's supper club-- you know you're not in SMD's usual user-friendly indie-remix territory. Cherry picking across three decades of dark dance (and not-quite-dance) music
column4: SMD use Is Fixed to explore house and techno's creepier impulses
column5: tracks in which insistent basslines suddenly turn uncomfortably
column6: claustrophobically insistent. And when they leave the rave behind
column7: whether it's Conrad Schnitzler's fizzing pre-Detroit proto-electro or Etienne Jaumet's snarling post-Detroit neo-electro
column8: SMD still favor synth riffs that feel more John Carpenter than Derrick May.

column1: Like most modern DJs with point-and-click access to all eras and genres
column2: SMD are freed up both chronologically and stylistically
column3: for better or worse. Sleekly sculpted modern day minimal is joined
column4: sometimes jarringly
column5: to crude old-school house bangers. All of this decade-hopping and style-shuffling can make for some choppy transitions; Is Fixed certainly isn't the smoothest mix you'll hear this year. Like a lot of DJs who chase a mood even when it gets in the way of technical perfection
column6: SMD will choose a jolt to the ears over an easy fade if it gets them where they need to go.  But the rough edges of the mixing actually suit the agitated
column7: about-to-fray quality of certain tracks. This is dance music that wants to knot you up with tension
column8: offering only little hints of ecstatic release. Even the minimal tunes
column9: like Pitchfork contributor Philip Sherburne's ""Salt and Vinegar""
column10: have the kind of tightly wound percussion that once gave old-school house its eerie tribal vibe.

column1: That vintage acid-house atmosphere of delirium informs the whole mix. It's fitting the
<script src=""http://pitchfork.com/media/backend/js/tiny_mce/themes/advanced/langs/en.js"" type=""text/javascript""></script>
n that SMD acknowledge acid's groove outright by including Bam Bam's ""Where's Your Child""
column2: long the gold standard for goosebump-inducing first-generation acid singles
column3: with its throbbing rhythm track punctuated (but not undone) by disorienting samples of shattering glass and screaming infants. More than 20 years later
column4: ""Where's Your Child"" still feels like funk pitched up to the verge of a full-blown freakout
column5: but like Is Fixed
column6:
it never quite tips over the edge.
