Back in the music industry's Roaring 90s
column3: labels indulged in two particular types of spending sprees that were often related: trying to locate the ""next Seattle"" and forking over lucrative record contracts to bands with heaps of alt cachet but almost no commercial prospects. Which explains how San Diego's Three Mile Pilot scored a deal with Geffen that lasted about as long as it will take to read this review. Now
column4: Three Mile Pilot return after more than a decade of silence with The Inevitable Past Is the Future Forgotten. In the time since
column5: 3MP's Pall Jenkins and Armistead Burwell Smith IV have kept busy-- Jenkins helmed the Black Heart Procession's brooding noir-rock over the span of six studio albums
column6: while Smith co-founded Pinback with Rob Crow.

column1: If you became familiar with the BHP and Pinback in the 2000s
column2: it won't be a surprise about what 3MP sound like: Jenkins' voice is central and can expand like an accordion in terms of range and timbre. The instrumental construction is not far removed from recent Pinback
column3: favoring clean
column4: surgical guitars that prod and slice with precision and a production ethic that's as arid and frigid as the desert at night. While listeners more inured to the frillier
column5: more electronic-based current iteration of indie might find 3MP somewhat repetitive (a valid complaint during Side B's slower numbers)
column6: there's a crucial motion that defines their interplay: With minimal accoutrement
column7: every element feels like an interlocking gear pushing things forward. When they work in relatively high BPMs (""Same Mistake""
column8: ""Left in Vain"")
column9: hooks tumble over each other. It's almost Krautrock-like in its mesmeric build.

column1: But in a weird way
column2: what prevents Inevitable from arguing for Three Mile Pilot as one of the lost treasures of 90s indie is that they sound too much like themselves; it's a weird situation when a band who achieved success amongst a small
column3: intensely dedicated fanbase in their infancy could return from a 13-year hiatus without having become increasingly beloved in the interim. Meanwhile
column4: the bands who sound like they've been clearly influenced by what Three Mile Pilot accomplished are ones their own members started. But they've never really been about the big gesture-- themes on this ostensibly ""triumphant return"" mostly seem to revolve around inertia and escape
column5: though one of the telling first lyrics is
column6: ""this is our battle and how it begun."" A fitting sentiment from a small
column7: well-earned triumph for these few
column8: hopefully not the last
column9:
guys who've become specialists in their field.

"|14778.0|http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14778-the-inevitable-past-is-the-future-forgotten/|7.2|Ian Cohen

column1:
0|http://cdn2.pitchfork.com/albums/15759/homepage_large.74fd3e3b.jpg|Riposte|29226.0|Buke and Gass|[]|0.0|0.0|0.0|['Brassland']|2010-10-22 00:00:00|2010|2016-06-11 17:38:08.214665|"

Some of what makes Buke and Gass so unique is borne of need-- a need to sound like a full band despite having only two members; a need for singer Arone Dyer to find a physically comfortable instrument to play that won't aggravate her carpal tunnel syndrome. Yet the Brooklyn duo's approach to music making goes far beyond simply finding solutions to these problems. Dyer plays a modified baritone ukulele (the ""buke"" in the group's name) that
column2: yes
column3: is smaller than a guitar
column4: but her cohort
column5: Aron Sanchez
column6: also plays a bastardized instrument (the ""gass
column7: Sanchez's own Frankenstein melding of guitar and bass) for no other obvious reason than the fact that he can. Percussion is taken care of by drums and bells operated by the pair's feet
column8: yet Buke and Gass purposefully abstain from utilizing prerecorded loops.

column1: As you might imagine
column2: all this ingenuity and rule-breaking engenders a noise that's quirky and bracing
column3: and those are the hallmarks of Buke and Gass' debut album
column4: Riposte. Dyer and Sanchez feed their respective buke and gass through amps and pedals
column5: creating a buzzing
column6: springy sound that brims with kinetic restlessness. Meanwhile
column7: the foot-propelled percussion monolithically thwacks away
column8: lending the duo's music an austerity that belies its post-punk roots (groups like the Ex
column9: Swell Maps
column10: and Theoretical Girls are some of the main spiritual godfathers here). Dyer's voice easily gets swept up in this nervy momentum
column11: her girlish yelps often evoking Karen O. So twitchy and bursting with ideas are Buke and Gass that their songs have a tendency to jump abruptly from one passage to the next without ever finding resolution or an anchor
column12: and it causes a measurable chunk of Riposte's middle to blend together into something indistinguishable and a little wearying.

column1: When Buke and Gass manage to focus their energy
column2: however
column3: the results are positively arresting. Standouts are several
column4: starting with the opening ""Medulla Oblongata""
column5: with its evocative lyrics and Dyer's breathless repetition of the words ""danger doctor"" (the album's strident
column6: clinical lyrics are occasionally clumsy but actually suit the music well). Other highlights include the hypnotic
column7: circular repetitions of ""Sleep Gets Your Ghost""
column8: the fervent
column9: psychosexual ""Bundletuck"" (""These days you wake up in a bundle of orgasm"")
column10: and the winking ""Outt!"" (""Everybody here is out to get you""). Dyer and Sanchez are the sort of artists who will continue to challenge themselves at every turn. As long as they can keep that boundless creativity from going in a million different directions at once
column11:
their listeners will reap plenty of rewards.

The last time John Darnielle and Franklin Bruno released an album as a duo
column2: it was way back in 2002
column3: and they called themselves the Extra Glenns. That album
column4: Martial Arts Weekend
column5: served as a sort of test case for Darnielle's progression beyond his acoustic-guitar-and-boom-box years. Later that year
column6: Darnielle's Mountain Goats released Tallahassee on 4AD
column7: thus beginning their long and gradual transformation into an actual band. Darnielle and fellow veteran singer-songwriter Bruno haven't exactly been strangers since Martial Arts Weekend; I've seen Bruno join Darnielle onstage at at least a couple of shows. They're old friends
column8: and this new record doesn't sound like a test case for anything. It sounds like a great novelist kicking out a book of short stories
column9: just to shake out all the loose ideas he's had bouncing around in his head.

column1: Most recent Mountain Goats albums have central themes or ideas or moods; they're not concept albums
column2: exactly
column3: but the songs seem intertwined in some ephemeral way. If Undercard has a central theme
column4: it's this: people mired in mediocrity who find themselves trapped in desperate circumstances. ""Cruiserweights"" is an expertly rendered depiction of a boxer fighting in some shitty
column5: inconsequential mid-80s Cleveland arena
column6: feeling himself get pounded into liquid even though he realizes nobody's watching and that his fight is of little consequence. ""Only Existing Footage"" is a postcard from a doomed B-movie set. Even the album's lone cover
column7: of Randy Newman's ""In Germany Before the War""
column8: is a pretty mundane image of the killer from Fritz Lang's M.

column1: Maybe the starkest illustration of the beaten-down comes from Bruno and works as a snapshot of one man's feelings in the moments following an adultery-induced car crash. The title of ""How I Left the Ministry"" tells us one little biographical nugget about the narrator that you won't get from the lyrics themselves
column2: and the liner notes shed even more light: He's actually the leader of ""one of those franchised evangelical churches that dot San Bernadino County."" The liner notes of Undercard are generally a whole lot of fun: Darnielle and Bruno offering shards of commentary about every song-- sometimes revealing big
column3: important things
column4: sometimes not. The whole thing underscores the idea that these two are good friends who love writing
column5: and who love writing together.

column1: In its spare
column2: sparkling production and its generally hushed tone
column3: Undercard could musically pass for a new Mountain Goats record easily
column4: especially as Darnielle sings the lead on every song. But there are some unexpected flourishes here
column5: some of which work (the strum-stomp simplicity of ""Dogs of Clinic 17""
column6: which actually reminds me of Against Me!)
column7: and some of which don't (the intrusively jazzy acoustic-guitar stabs on ""Rockin' Rockin' Twilight of the Gods""). Bruno sings harmony from time to time
column8: and it's a kick to hear someone trying to harmonize with Darnielle's knotty yip and actually succeeding. But as with so many Darnielle-related projects
column9: the words are what stick with you here. And even if there's no transcendent statement to be found
column10: we're still left with these guys sketching out their own little Richard Brautigan short stories
column11: rendering entire lives in quick
column12: mysterious
column13: devastating little strokes. If these guys wanted to make another one of these before another eight years elapse
column14:
I wouldn't be mad.

""We tried hard to sound like the Swell Maps/ What a terrible name for a pop group
column2: David Feck sings on Cinema Red and Blue's ""Ballad of a Vision Pure"". This might read like a throwaway line
column3: but it sounds rueful and affectionate on record
column4: a music vet happily and wearily reflecting on his youth.  Feck
column5: the songwriting force behind minor indie pop legends Comet Gain
column6: is the ringleader for this loose
column7: beery one-off ensemble
column8: which could be called an ""indie pop supergroup"" if that weren't an inherently ridiculous idea. Nonetheless
column9: members of Crystal Stilts
column10: the Clean
column11: the Aislers Set
column12: and the Ladybug Transistor all pop by at various points
column13: and the music shimmers and jangles with all the requisite bittersweet colors. But it is Feck's presence-- self-deprecating
column14: gin-wry
column15: tinged with bitterness-- that provides the emotional anchor for Cinema Red and Blue
column16: a knowing and affecting power-pop record about the foibles of loving records too much.

column1: ""Ballad of a Vision Pure"" is the first of three consecutive songs deemed the ""ballad of"" something (a bus stop
column2: an ""all-night worker"") but every song could easily be retitled ""Ballad of an Unreformed Pop Music Obsessive."" Songs about listening to pop songs are not a novel concept; in indie pop in particular
column3: they're a hallowed tradition. But Feck and co. do them so well
column4: with verve and loving attention to details lyrical and musical. These are songs about lonely people yearning to escape into art--  Melanie of ""Melanie Down"" listens to her radio alone in her room
column5: while the ""cinema red and blue"" of the title pops up repeatedly as a metaphorical space for losing yourself in an all-encompassing experience. Feck readily acknowledges the dark side to this yearning; in ""Ghost Confessions""
column6: he sings mournfully about ""listening to records that nobody wants/ Dreaming of moments that nobody's had/ Thinking of people that don't exist."" Anyone who chuckled at the Swell Maps joke might recoil a bit from the sting.

column1: But wallowing in self-recrimination is an indulgence
column2: and a dead end. Feck's outlook on Cinema Red and Blue works so well because it neatly splits the difference between sourness and generosity. The sunny music helps; the jangly guitars are just as evocative next to a puttering drum machine as a boogie-rock organ. The album is rounded out by a handful of covers
column3: (Dead Moon's ""Love in the Altitude""
column4: the Chills' ""Brave Words""
column5: ""Same Mistakes"" by Vic Godard and the Subway Sect); that they sit comfortably next to the originals highlights how well-conceived this one-off project is. The thread uniting the songs is not just a style but a sensibility
column6: one Feck commandeers with the ease of an old Shakespearean actor. For all his ambivalence about the pull of pop-song love
column7: he yields
column8: finally
column9: to affection
column10: and Cinema Red and Blue glows with it. After that crack about trying to sound like the Swell Maps
column11: he admits
column12:
fondly: ""I was only trying to do something good/ I was only trying to waste my youth/ I was only trying to make some sweet noise/ I was only trying to be a boy.""

When Curtis Mayfield recorded his last album in 1996
column3: he did it lying on his back
column4: singing a line at a time. He had no choice-- he'd been paralyzed since a 1990 lighting rig accident. He was near the end of a life and career that saw him become one of the most influential songwriters and performers of his generation. He was a multi-instrumentalist
column5: singer
column6: songwriter
column7: producer and thinker who had his hands in a lot of amazing music
column8: and was among the first black pop artists to inject the ideas and hopes of the Civil Rights movement into his work
column9: doing it subtly at first with the Impressions with ""Amen"" and ""Keep on Pushing"" and then much more directly later on.

column1: Jazz
column2: of course
column3: got to openly supporting Civil Rights and expressing black pride before pop music did. Max Roach's 1960 Freedom Now Suite is a good example. Charles Mingus' 1959 classic ""Fables of Faubus"" was a sly and sarcastic takedown of Arkansas governor Orval Faubus after the Little Rock Nine incident-- the list is pretty long. Part of the reason jazz got there before Mayfield is that Mayfield was working within the constraints of pop radio
column4: which is where all his record labels were aiming. In 1960
column5: he couldn't have done what Max Roach was doing for the simple fact that no one would have given him the chance.

column1: Jazz bassist William Parker was getting his start in the early 70s just as Mayfield went solo with a series of albums that very directly addressed issues of race
column2: equality
column3: and black pride. These themes have run through Parker's work as well for decades
column4: so a tribute to Mayfield seems natural and fitting. Parker isn't simply interpreting or covering Mayfield's songs on I Plan to Stay a Believer
column5: though. He's extending them
column6: treating them as living documents
column7: and adding new content that dovetails with Mayfield's political thoughts. Parker's notes on the recording explain his belief that every song has an ""inside song"" waiting to be reborn
column8: and he implies that these are the songs he heard inside Mayfield's music.

column1: Parker and his collaborators began work on this project nearly 10 years ago
column2: and this final document is a live compilation of sorts
column3: bringing together performances from 2001
column5: 2007 and 2008 into a basically seamless whole that presents a panoramic exploration of both Mayfield's music and modern black identity over two discs. Actually
column6: the recording dates are interesting
column7: because three of these tracks were recorded in Italy just days before the election of Barack Obama
column8: and there is a sort of old-school Civil Rights thrust to the additional poetry contributed by Amiri Baraka-- post-racial this is not
column9: and it's sort of a pre-acknowledgement that having a black president won't automatically erase all of the nation's tormented racial history.

column1: Looking across the two-disc track list is a little intimidating-- eight of the eleven tracks are over ten minutes long
column2: with ""If There's a Hell Below"" topping out at 21:23
column3: so you know up front that this won't be a casual listen. These songs twist and turn
column4: invariably opening with musical motifs from Mayfield's originals-- the creeping bass line of ""Hell Below""
column5: the funky riff of ""Freddie's Dead""
column6: the ebullient horn fanfare of ""Move on Up""
column7: here slowed
column8: rounded off and made significantly darker-- and from there
column9: it's anyone's guess where the energy of the performance will take the band. Gospel
column10: bop
column11: soul
column12: funk
column13: post-bop and free music are all part of this mix
column14: and the band spends a lot of time between them as well. For instance
column15: the 10-minute version of ""This Is My Country (New York)"" on disc two takes on the feel of an out-of-control revival
column16: ultimately flying off the rails into an ecstatic muddle of squealing sax
column17: shouting
column18: and tumbling drums.

column1: It has the feel of the type of project Charles Mingus might have taken on had he lived to see this century
column2: ambitious and quasi-historical
column3: but still swinging and loaded with content that takes many listens to unpack. The band is amazing. Several tracks feature choirs (including a choir of 90 children on two of those tracks)
column4: but they blend right in
column5: adding to the dual vocal attack of Baraka and singer Leena Conquest
column6: a long-time Parker collaborator who dances through these tangled arrangements and the heavy subject matter with tremendous grace. Asim Barnes plays guitar on only three tracks
column7: but I could spend a whole paragraph breaking down why what he does is thrilling
column8: and drummer Hamid Drake is strictly next-level on every song. The way he switches between a slow
column9: swinging beat and a double-time stomp on ""Move on Up"" is breathtaking and helps transform the song into a living
column10: pulsing beast-- Conquest riffs on ""Keep on Pushing"" as the song begins to break down and head off into freer territory
column11: and if you've spent any amount of time digging Mayfield in the past
column12: you will love the way she does it.

column1: I wish I could've seen some of these performances in person
column2: because the amount of energy the band packs into them surely must have flowed right into the crowd. Even here
column3: pressed onto little plastic discs
column4: the band practically explodes toward you. I have no idea what Mayfield would think of these versions of his songs
column5:
but it's hard to imagine him being anything but flattered by the immense thought and planning that clearly went into these arrangements. To pull and stretch these songs so much and still preserve their essential identity is a true feat of art.

London-based bedroom pop artist Banjo or Freakout's Way Slow Volume One marks the first entry in Lefse Records' new Way Slow series
column2: described by the label as an unconventional approach to record-making that encourages ""instrumentals
column3: covers
column4: collaborations
column5: wacky kids' tunes
column6: spoken word [and] tracks that never made it to albums."" Reminiscent of Konkurrent's In the Fish Tank series
column7: Way Slow (which will feature the likes of Ganglians and Sonny and the Sunsets' Sonny Smith in the near future) seems like a smart way to accommodate diehard fans and allow artists to indulge in fringe fantasies. So it's a little disappointing that Lefse kicks things off with a wishy-washy handful of tracks from a still-developing and emerging artist.

column1: Basically
column2: it's hard to get into the embryonic noodlings of an artist that we don't even know all that well yet. After releasing a few leftfield covers by the likes of Radiohead and Burial online
column3: Banjo or Freakout (aka Alessio Natalizia) has one EP and a handful of original tracks to his name
column4: most of which feel rooted to the ghosted dream-pop sketches that appear here. The problem is
column5: as good as a few of them were
column6: even his previous releases sound underdeveloped. Compared to this batch though
column7: they sound downright accomplished. And at a time when there's so much uninformed bedroom music going around
column8: the last thing you should be considering is taking a step backwards.

column1: This incarnation of Banjo or Freakout seems most interested in taking intimate
column2: simple acoustic songs and obstructing them with aquatic atmospheres
column3: spare percussion
column4: and plenty of delay. With some of his more ambitious work (like those oddball covers)
column5: Natalizia was often able to create some compelling
column6: otherworldly music-- something that would've been a perfect fit for a project like Way Slow. But instead of contributing something surprising or irreverent (""Street Runners"" comes close)
column7: most of these auxiliary details just clutter what are otherwise sleepy coffee-house strummers.

column1: There's some wisdom in keeping things simple here. Banjo or Freakout's best song to date
column2: ""Upside Down""
column3: was a restrained
column4: accessible piece that showed us what Natalizia was capable of when a more direct approach was taken (never mind there's a similar sounding but lesser version here in ""75""). But we also know what Natalizia is capable of when he lets his freak flag fly a little
column5: and with so much creative flexibility at his disposal
column6: wouldn't this have been a perfect time to do it? Maybe one day we'll look back at these songs with a different kind of perspective after Banjo or Freakout has taken the time to develop. Until then
column7: Volume One feels not only premature
column8:
but a little presumptuous.

If you're a fan of painstaking songcraft
column2: there's a good chance you've brushed across Darren Hanlon's name before. The avuncular Australian came up in the 1990s as a member of the Simpletons and played on a bunch of recordings by much-loved countrymen the Lucksmiths. In the course of releasing three fine solo albums over the past decade
column3: Hanlon has toured with Billy Bragg
column4: the Magnetic Fields
column5: and Jeffrey Lewis. With enough wry charm and vivid detail to withstand such comparisons
column6: Hanlon's unassuming brand of indie-pop digs up the mundane or eccentric and scrapes off the dirt until he hits on something universal. Until now
column7: however
column8: he's never enjoyed a proper U.S. promotional push.

column1: Each of Hanlon's albums has moments worth revisiting
column2: but I Will Love You at All is his most consistently rewarding effort yet. Not only because
column3: as befits the self-described ""urban folk"" singer's leap from Melbourne's now-defunct Candle Records to North Carolina-based Yep Roc
column4: it's also his most American: Adam Selzer (M. Ward
column5: She & Him
column6: the Decemberists) recorded the album in Portland
column7: so there's a familiarly Pacific Northwestern tint
column8: not least in longtime Selzer collaborator Rachel Blumberg's meticulously understated drumming. What most sets Hanlon's fourth album apart from its predecessors
column9: though
column10: is that he's no longer singing about squash or the noisy punk-rock girl upstairs; when he shows off his tremendous wit
column11: it's now in subtler and more lasting ways than proving he can shoehorn the word ""aubergine"" into a catchy song. This is a record of heartbreak
column12: rendered richly enough that you might not notice it. It's also an immensely funny record
column13: with enough real emotion behind it that you might not notice that
column14: either.

column1: It doesn't hurt that there's a lot more variety between songs than you expect from your typical heart-on-sleeve troubadour-- or
column2: hell
column3: from most bands in this era of tinier and tinier niches. Ukulele
column4: euphonium
column5: and strings enliven ""All These Things""
column6: an affecting call-and-response duet with Shelley Short about the trivia that comes to define us. ""Scenes From a Separation"" depicts beautifully just what its title says
column7: but with keyboards
column8: a waltzing-Matilda rhythm and more backing vocals from both Short and Alia Farah. Opener ""Butterfly Bones""
column9: about someone who injures easily
column10: sets viola
column11: trumpet
column12: and hammered percussion over syncopated acoustic chords; ""Buy Me Presents"" rattles like the Modern Lovers' ""Roadrunner"" amid bongos
column13: saxophone
column14: and sly observations about fear of commitment. Only grandiose piano ballad ""What Can We Say?"" feels like a relative misstep.

column1: As on records by anyone from Loudon Wainwright III to Jens Lekman
column2: it's Hanlon's distinctive narrative vision that holds it all together
column3: rewarding the attention this album requires. Nearly eight-minute centerpiece ""House"" isn't the album's best track-- that's ""Folk Insomnia""
column4: a stripped-down jaunt about broken hearts and growing older-- but it's the best encapsulation of Hanlon's gift for funny
column5: pathos-laden detail. There's a terrible Barenaked Ladies song called ""The Old Apartment""
column6: where they do little more than state the obvious: ""This is where we used to live."" Here
column7: Hanlon does just about the opposite
column8: documenting all his idiosyncratic thoughts as he debates going into an old home
column9: notices the wall's new color-- ""the horror!""-- and finally comes to terms with the changes
column10: in a crescendo of guitar and Blumberg's drums. Memories
column11: Hanlon concludes
column12: are ""best if they're left in a place you can't find them."" If I Will Love You at All is Hanlon's ""mature"" album
column13: then maturing is less about embracing the flux than accepting it
column14: moving on to the next misadventure
column15:
and then sharing stories about it all over beers.

Die Antwoord were always a group of musicians of course
column3: but chances are you didn't first hear about them because of their music. More likely
column4: you first encountered them as a viral video
column5: a meme
column6: a performance art collective
column7: a joke that left you searching for the punchline
column8: or some combination of the above. Hell
column9: when we first profiled the group
column10: it was under the headline ""Who the Hell Are Die Antwoord?""

column1: Our introduction came last winter
column2: when Boing Boing first posted a pair of their videos. Combining documentary elements with a surreal undercurrent
column3: the clips were funny
column4: confounding
column5: and unique
column6: the sort of thing that you forward to your friends and then do online detective work to learn more about what you're watching and sharing. There was a full music video for their second single
column7: ""Enter the Ninja""
column8: but the first thing most of us were entranced by
column9: the element that articulated and contextualized in some small way who DA were
column10: was a promotional piece about the group called ""Zef Side"". There was music in it
column11: but it served only as a soundtrack to the band's off-the-charts personalities-- you got leader and MC Ninja's testicles dancing in Pink Floyd shorts in slow motion
column12: along with the first hints at fellow MC Yo-Landi Vi$$er's strident
column13: low-rent toughness
column14: which was eventually cited by David Fincher as a potential cinematic look for the femme-hero of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo books.

column1: Ninja and Yo-Landi aren't just striking visual curiosities
column2: either; they're underrated MCs and pop personalities-- much more talented on the mic than they're credited for. They're also captivating live
column3: where the visual fakery of what they do isn't lost; the simple challenge and central difficulty of their debut record
column4: $O$-- most of which was released as a free download last year-- is to fully put across who or what Die Antwoord are when all you have to guide you through their world is recorded music.

column1: It does all come together on ""Enter the Ninja""-- still a fantastic single-- in part because it's an origin story. Ninja here works in and around aspirational hip-hop tropes and clichés
column2: giving listeners me vs. the world self-helpsims alongside superhero boasts alongside regular-guy humility. It's catchy
column3: clever
column4: and funny-- full of excellent deadpan jokes (""They said I was a fuckin' psycho... well look at me now!"") and forceful rave-rap. Also touched upon are the notions of racial confusion and an introduction to Zef culture
column5: a sort of South African version of white trash. But while this bait to intellectualize the project might carry more weight in the racial powderkeg of SA
column6: it's confusing at best outside of it
column7: requiring more footnotes than most will have time for. No fault of Die Antwoord of course
column8: but the racial and social implications of various ethnic groups in and around South Africa was always going to lose much of its potential power and cachet away from home. That in itself is a lamentable reality: South African apartheid
column9: a more literal black-and-white issue
column10: became a global civil rights cause in the 1980s; the subtle
column11: complex
column12: and all-too-real racial politics and biases since are more difficult to address
column13: confront
column14: and defeat.

column1: The loss of the Zef and racial aspects of the project also highlight how much the Die Antwoord project suffers the further away from visuals it moves. For all the shit Lady Gaga or Nicki Minaj get about their potential cultural signifiers not showing up in their music
column2: they at least create tracks that work on their own. So too did great conceptual pop stars of the past like the KLF or Adam & the Ants or the Sex Pistols. Die Antwoord try here and often fail
column3: for some of the same reasons that the concepts themselves are confusing-- they're a jumble sale of mixed-up ideas and items. Ironically
column4: Ninja and Yo-Landi's vast array of skills betray them here
column5: and songs too often feel overstuffed or schizophrenic.

column1: Frustratingly
column2: most songs have great ideas in them
column3: sitting alongside creative dead ends. The overall sound of the record-- to be reductionist
column4: rave-rap-- is a welcome trend
column5: and it proves they have their ear to the ground. If this is to be an ongoing project
column6: they're off to a weirdly good start
column7: despite the many reservations here on this record: They've put together a group of people with skills
column8: ideas
column9: and personalities
column10: and they seem more than capable of piecing together an excellent 21st century rap record. But this isn't it. Still serving to introduce the project
column11: despite much of the music being around now for months
column12: the album is mostly a literal retread of the sounds a lot of us heard in February and March. It seems like one piece of the conceptual puzzle rather than something that stands on its own.

column1: Ideally
column2: Die Antwoord can now move forward with the freedom to not simply be ""that Zef side group
column3: but to be a hip-hop group full stop. That's often a death wish for pop stars-- the charismatic performer wanting to take full control of their vision in order to prove their artistry. Thing is
column4: DA have proven gifted at doing both. Creating music and then adding meme-friendly visuals in aid of that
column5: rather than the other way around
column6: could actually find them improving by leaps and bounds
column7:
without losing what's special and unique and head-turning about them in the first place.

If Seattle's Nuearth Kitchen were a restaurant
column2: it would surely belong to the slow-food movement: you can figure that much out from its name and faintly Prairie School logo. A new label
column3: its first release comes from Jon McMillion
column4: a PacNW native who has previously recorded for Orac
column5: another Seattle outfit dedicated to the fuzzy fringes of techno and house. These somewhat peripheral associations matter only insofar as they situate McMillion's debut album in a wider context
column6: and because they might help to explain how and why it differs from the vast majority of similarly paced and structured electronic music. This isn't the kind of sound that can come out of just anywhere. It needs community and roots to nurture its more esoteric or eccentric tendencies
column7: and it helps to have distance from the world's principal club-music centers
column8: where market tastes too often dictate the shape of the music. You can hear how that breathing room has benefited McMillion: This is one of the most confident
column9: expressive
column10: and rewarding albums that house music has seen this year.

column1: The Jon McMillion LP isn't an experimental work
column2: nor even an explicitly groundbreaking one; its 15 tracks explore a familiar depiction of house
column3: one whose mold has been shaped by Moodymann
column4: Matthew Herbert
column5: Pépé Bradock
column6: Isolée
column7: Ricardo Villalobos
column8: and others. However
column9: like them
column10: McMillion has a voice that's immediately recognizable; in a decade or so of producing electronic music
column11: he's clearly become a master of his craft. His approach is neither expressly digital nor analog; it has the warmth of vintage drum machines
column12: Rhodes keyboards
column13: analog synthesizers
column14: and layer upon layer of processed vocals
column15: but it maps a sense of space-- unstable
column16: porous
column17: with shifting dimensions and contours-- that comes with computer-based processing and arrangements. His many interwoven lines suggest a collage aesthetic
column18: of real-time machine jams chopped and soldered
column19: and his slowly contorting funk is unusually organic.

column1: The album comes in two different versions: The CD features nine tracks (including two exclusives)
column2: and the download version 13 (with six exclusives). Somewhat oddly
column3: the sequencing of each is radically different
column4: a detail that suggests the way the music generates its own possibilities. There's no definitive listening order: the CD version presents one potential
column5: ideal form of the album
column6: but the more you mix its sequencing up
column7: the more you'll begin to notice details-- a buried voice
column8: a strange
column9: electronic ripple-- that had previously remained hidden.

column1: If you had to spell out McMillion's influences
column2: you could name classic Midwestern techno and house
column3: European minimal
column4: 90s R&B
column5: a smattering of dub and disco
column6: and occasional sonics borrowed from progressive rock or experimental computer music. Once or twice the Durutti Column and even Derek Bailey rear their heads; it's not a stretch to hear Arthur Russell's influence in McMillion's muted
column7: soulful vocals
column8: and the explosions of tone color even gesture towards Flying Lotus' brand of digital astral jazz.

column1: That's a lot to squeeze in
column2: but McMillion fuses it elegantly and exquisitely: This is supple
column3: seductive stuff
column4: drawing you in closer and veiling the mechanics at its heart. As soon as you fix upon a given sound
column5: you're reminded that everything is in motion around it. There's far too much to grasp at once
column6: from polyrhythmic percussion lines to slowly evolving tone colors
column7: but the record never overwhelms. Quite the opposite: It's difficult to imagine more inviting
column8: easygoing grooves or arrangements
column9:
no matter how complicated they might be beneath the surface.

At his Low End Theory parties in L.A.
column4: the Gaslamp Killer makes a point of playing whatever records he wants
column5: whether it's obscure Turkish music or wobbly dubstep or garage rock. Like DJ Shadow and Madlib before him
column6: the Gaslamp Killer's record collection is
column7: presumably
column8: so large and unwieldy that what we're listening to is the sound of someone being devoured by his own resources. Death Gate continues the trend: In just over 15 minutes
column9: there are enough scraps of sound for another artist to create a whole album. But what's most intriguing about Gaslamp Killer is that
column10: like early Shadow and Madlib
column11: he has an understanding of restraint. With so much music to draw from
column12: there's a tendency to want to throw out your whole arsenal. But if there's anything connecting these five tracks it's a sense of minimalism-- even tastefulness.

column1: As you might guess
column2: marijuana is a key inspiration here. In a recent interview with Resident Advisor
column3: Gaslamp Killer professes that his aspiration is to have a weed hook-up in whatever city he's in; that way
column4: he can get stoned as soon as he gets off the plane. Back when the mighty herb was half as powerful and half the price
column5: you had dub and jazz and stoner-rock to get high to. Nowadays
column6: with hydroponic technology moving as fast as the Internet
column7: you have all of them in one. Which
column8: at its best
column9: is precisely what the Gaslamp Killer does.

column1: ""Shattering Inner Journeys"" could serve as the Gaslamp Killer's manifesto
column2: and it's easily his best track to date. In a strikingly raw six minutes
column3: Raymond Scott-style library synth squeals creep over a drum break ripped out of a mid-1990s Mo' Wax vault
column4: bleeding into an appropriately eerie Piper at the Gates of Dawn homage. And then in the last minute
column5: the song chugs out on an oddly dubby proto-industrial pitter-patter. Snaky
column6: whiny crunk-rap keyboard riffs twirl around a skittering synth-drum beat on opener ""Fun Over 100""
column7: and the remainder rock gut-punch
column8: battered hip-hop beats that sound like old Company Flow bootleg instrumental tapes. Though these tracks can be somewhat compressed
column9: there is a noticeable paucity of instruments
column10: typically relying on little more than drums and a keyboard or guitar lick.

column1: The Gaslamp Killer's profile was raised substantially by his production work on Gonjasufi's A Sufi and a Killer
column2: and ""When I'm in Awe"" is like a lost track from it
column3: almost to a fault. Within that album
column4: the track would have fit into its whacked-out
column5: garage-Rasta drug nightmare. But here it feels more like a bonus track
column6: especially compared to the rest of the EP
column7: which foregoes that album's Beefheart-hop sound for pronounced percussive instrumentals.

column1: The era and sound that the Gaslamp Killer is going for is pretty easy to identify: the b-boy end of sample-heavy mid-90s hip-hop. But the way that he approaches his tracks is distinctive both in what he adds as well as what he leaves out. What will a Gaslamp Killer LP sound like? It's hard to tell
column2: which
column3: in this case
column4:
is an exciting prospect.
